webTitle: 'Scandal' of business giving scheme

fields.headline: 'Scandal' of business giving scheme
fields.trailText: Despite its name, only 60% of the companies listed in Business in the Community's PerCent Club give 1% of their profits to charity. Nicola Hill reports
fields.body:
Business in the Community has proudly presented its PerCent Club 2000 report detailing the community involvement of 158 companies. But only 99 of those listed invested 1% or more of their pre-tax profits in the community last year.

In fact, the minimum investment to join the club is ½% of UK of global pre-tax profits. "This is one of the greatest corporate scandals of the 21st century," said Stephen Lee, fundraising fellow at South Bank University. "It is the only club I know where members don't achieve the criteria suggested by its name."

However, spokesperson Matt Larkin defended the report: "Some of the firms listed are professional companies like solicitors that do not report profits, others invest in other ways. The benchmark of 1% is something to aspire to."

The PerCent Club was launched in 1986 by the Prince of Wales. One of its founder members is the telecommunications company BT. Its website claimed that it donated £15m in 1999, "while other contributions across the company's operations bring the total to around £30m a year, meeting a new 1% target". However, on another part of its website, it reported profits before tax of £4,295m.

BT is also listed on the PerCent club website as achieving below 1%.

Other members of the PerCent club that are on this list for achieving less than 1% include J Sainsbury plc, which contributed £5.5m last year, and Marks and Spencer, which donated £2.9m.

The PerCent Club has set a new millennium standard of 1% and the aim is for businesses in the club to reach this level of investment by January 1 2001. Larkin confirmed that only those companies that achieved this would be allowed to use the PerCent Club logo on their literature.

webTitle: Law on succession to throne may be incompatible with Human Rights Act

fields.headline: Law on succession to throne may be incompatible with Human Rights Act
fields.trailText: The Guardian is to back a legal challenge to the 300-year-old law banning Roman Catholics and other             non-Protestants from succession to the British throne, on the grounds that it clashes with the Human             Rights Act and should be reinterpreted or removed from the statute book.
fields.body:
The Guardian is to back a legal challenge to the 300-year-old law banning Roman Catholics and other non-Protestants from succession to the British throne, on the grounds that it clashes with the Human Rights Act and should be reinterpreted or removed from the statute book.

Leading human rights lawyer Geoffrey Robertson QC believes the Act of Settlement 1701 may be affected by the European convention on human rights, which became part of UK law two months ago when the Human Rights Act came into force.

The challenge to the Act of Settlement coincides with an editorial in the paper which argues for a referendum on the future of the monarchy .

The act, passed at a time of widespread fear of Catholics, lays down that only Protestant heirs of Princess Sophia, granddaughter of James I, may take the British throne. Neither Catholics, nor those who marry a Catholic, nor those born out of wedlock, may remain in the line of succession.

The act remains the crucial cornerstone of the British constitution, exercising an extraordinary hold over the monarchy and imposing limitations designed to tackle the imperatives of a political crisis at the dawn of the 18th century. But it is scarcely relevant to the 21st.

Because of it, dozens of people have been barred from taking their place in the order of succession (the list appears on page 21). Since many of them are German, the Guardian has placed an advertisement in the Suddeutsche Zeitung asking them to join the action to reclaim their birthright.

Sons also take precedence over daughters and the right of succession belongs to the eldest son. The act institutionalises religious discrimination and male primogeniture.

The Human Rights Act gives UK judges power for the first time to reinterpret statutes to make them compatible "so far as possible" with the European convention.

Mr Robertson considers it may be "possible" for the courts to read the Act of Settlement's language in a way which avoids discrimination against women and some religious faiths but the "express virulence" of the act's anti-Catholic language could only be removed by legislation. If judges find it impossible to reword the statute, the Human Rights Act allows them to make a "declaration of incompatibility". This leaves the statute in force but puts pressure on the government to reform it, since the UK has signed up to the convention and pledged that it will comply with convention rights.

The Guardian argues in an editorial today that in the new millennium Britain should be given the choice whether to keep the royal family or to become a republic.

Today and over the next few days the paper is running a number of articles advocating republicanism, despite another outdated statute, the Treason Felony Act 1848, which threatens anyone doing so with deportation "for the term of his or her natural life".

The paper's editor, Alan Rusbridger, wrote last week to the attorney general, Lord Williams of Mostyn, asking for an assurance that he will not be prosecuted, given that he has no intention of advocating overthrow of the monarchy by force. In his letter, he argued that the Treason Felony Act breaches article 10 of the European convention, the right to freedom of expression.

He suggested the attorney general might ask the high court to reinterpret the Treason Felony Act so that only calls to overthrow the monarchy by violence would be an offence. He offered the paper's support in the application.

Lord Williams replied: "I hope you understand that Neither David Calvert-Smith [the director of public prosecutions] nor I can give you an assurance regarding whether or not a prosecution or other action will be taken. You are asking me to take action which sanctions in advance conduct which may be criminal. You should take your own legal advice then decide for yourself whether you will follow it."

Under the Human Rights Act, judges are expected to interpret an existing statute as far as possible so as to be compatible with the human rights convention. Mr Robertson believes the courts may use this power to limit the scope of the Treason Felony Act so it complies with the right to freedom of expression. Only if this is not possible should they make a declaration of incompatibility.

The Guardian believes the Act of Settlement violates article 9 of the convention, the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion. In addition, it breaches article 1 of protocol 1, the right to peaceful enjoyment of possessions - in this case the banned descendants' place in the line of succession - and article 14, banning discrimination in relation to any convention right.

Not only are Catholics banned from succession, but the sovereign must be in communion with the Church of England, must swear to preserve the church, and to uphold the Protestant line of succession. This appears to discriminate against other faiths, including Jews, Muslims and Hindus.

At her coronation in 1953, the Queen pledged to maintain and preserve the church's doctrine, worship and discipline.

In December 1999 the Scottish parliament backed unanimously a motion spearheaded by the Scottish National party to abolish the Act of Settlement. The debate was initiated by Lord Hamilton - Tory whip in the parliament - who wrote to Tony Blair asking him to lift the "anachronistic" act.

Soon after the Scottish vote, the Archbishop of York, David Hope, called for the act to be amended to allow the heir to the throne to marry a Catholic.

Officials said amending the Act of Settlement would be very complex. But the Human Rights Act lays down a fast track method for amending statutes judged incompatible with the European convention. Failure to do so would leave the UK open to condemnation by the European court.

"No one can really defend this act," said Mr Rusbridger. "Since MPs are barred from openly debating the role of the monarch we thought a newspaper might set the ball rolling. We very much hope that the odd Hapsburg or Saxe-Coburg might join in."

webTitle: Majority want to be citizens not subjects

fields.headline: Majority want to be citizens not subjects
fields.trailText: The British public overwhelmingly supports an end to the legal ban on Roman Catholics, adopted             children and those born to unmarried parents succeeding to the throne, according to an exclusive             Guardian /ICM poll on the monarchy published today.
fields.body:
The British public overwhelmingly supports an end to the legal ban on Roman Catholics, adopted children and those born to unmarried parents succeeding to the throne, according to an exclusive Guardian /ICM poll on the monarchy published today.

More than 63% of the public agree it is time to end the discrimination inherent in the Act of Settlement 1701, which guarantees the existence of a hereditary monarchy in Britain.

The poll also shows that 60% of British adult voters prefer to see themselves as citizens and only 32% describe themselves as "royal subjects" despite the fact all adults in Britain share that constitutional status.

The poll confirms that support for an outright republican position, with an elected head of state replacing the monarchy , remains at about one in four voters - as repeatedly found in previous polls. Among 18- to 24-year-olds the figure rises to 36% and among Labour voters it is 37%.

One in three voters also support the idea that they should be given the right to vote on who should succeed the Queen, whether a member of the royal family or someone else, when she dies or abdicates.

Some 60% of those surveyed said they opposed the idea but the level of minority support for the principle of holding a referendum on whether there should be an elected head of state of Britain is surprising given how little national debate there has been so far about the idea.

Labour voters are also evenly divided over whether the hereditary monarchy should lose its remaining political powers, such as dissolving parliament and appointing the prime minister. Some 46% of Labour voters say it is time for such crown prerogative powers to be swept away while 46% said they should remain in place.

As to the question of who should succeed the Queen when she finally leaves the throne, if the country were given a choice between Prince Charles and Prince William the ICM poll shows that public opinion is sharply divided. Some 49% said they would prefer to see Prince Charles on the throne, with support strongest in southern England and among men. Some 41% believe the royal family should skip a generation and give Prince William the crown. A majority of women and people living in Scotland and northern England would prefer to see William next on the throne.

 ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,003 adults aged over 18 by telephone between December 1 and 3. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

webTitle: Drive for equality is failing the disabled

fields.headline: Drive for equality is failing the disabled
fields.standfirst: High legal costs are thwarting the battle to stamp out discrimination against people with disablities
fields.trailText: The Disability Discrimination Act (DDA), which arrived on the statute books five years ago this month, has given unenforceable rights to people with disabilities, claims a new report which calls on government to change the mechanisms for tackling discrimination.
fields.body:
The Disability Discrimination Act (DDA), which arrived on the statute books five years ago this month, has given unenforceable rights to people with disabilities, claims a new report which calls on government to change the mechanisms for tackling discrimination.

The complexity and exorbitant cost of bringing cases in the county court for discrimination in the provision of goods, services, facilities and premises makes it virtually impossible for disabled people to enforce their rights in these areas, concludes The Price of Justice, produced by the Royal National Institute for the Blind (RNIB).

Since the DDA came into force in 1996, more than 5,000 cases claiming discrimination at work have been taken to employment tribunals. In contrast, the RNIB knows of only 25 cases claiming discrimination in the provision of goods, services and facilities.

Since there is no evidence that disabled people face more discrimination at work than in the rest of their lives, the report attributes the disparity to the different ways that parts of the DDA are enforced. Employment cases go to employment tribunals - where it costs nothing to bring a claim and the risks of having costs awarded against an applicant are negligible. In contrast, claims against a shop manager for verbally abusing a disabled person, or a company for failing to produce bills in braille, would have to go through the county courts - an often complicated, costly process said by the RNIB to put most people off at the first hurdle.

In one case - brought against Margaret Hodge, minister for disabled people, for failing to send out in braille a copy of a disability rights task force report - the claimant withdrew because she was worried she might face huge bills.

"Disabled people are deterred from taking claims because the system is so complex and they could face enormous costs if they lose," says the report's author, Catherine Casserley, RNIB legal officer. As very few county court judges have ever dealt with a disability discrimination case or received any awareness training, she argues, the odds are stacked against the claimant.

If disabled people's rights are to mean more than the paper they are written on, says the RNIB, the government should allow employment tribunals to deal with cases involving goods, services, facilities and premises. But the Department for Education and Employment says it is "neither appropriate nor sensible" to extend the remit of employment tribunals. "These cases go beyond the expertise of employment tribunals," it says. "Judges and magistrates are receiving disability training and will become more accustomed to the act."

However, the disability rights commission (DRC), the independent body created alongside the DDA to promote the rights of disabled people, acknowledges there is a problem with the county courts. Next month, the commission will introduce a conciliation service designed to tackle discrimination cases outside the courtroom.

The DRC is also working to challenge prejudice by raising awareness of disabled issues among the general public. Next week, Tony Blair is due to launch a short film, Talk, as the centrepiece of the commission's first major campaign, Action Speaks Louder Than Words.

In Talk, the main character, played by television actor Jonathan Kerrigan, has his negative preconceptions of disability shattered when he goes on a date with a girl who turns out to be in a wheelchair. She takes him to a nightclub full of people with disabilities, where he finds he is the minority in a disability-friendly world.

Bert Massie, chair of the DRC, says: "Using a dramatic film storyline is a deliberate departure from traditional campaigns on disability issues. Public appeals for greater understanding of disability are often well received, but rarely translate into specific action."

webTitle: Charities face increasing pressure for openness

fields.headline: Charities face increasing pressure for openness
fields.standfirst: Updated accounting rules will force voluntary organisations into greater disclosure
fields.trailText: Updated accounting rules will force voluntary organisations into greater disclosure, writes Patrick McCurry
fields.body:
The pressure on charities to become more open and transparent about their activities is taken a step further with the new accounting framework, which comes into force on January 1.

The statement of recommended practice (SORP), which was first published in 1995, guides charity accounting for charitable companies and charities with income over £100,000. It has been updated to cover a wider variety of issues and will force voluntary organisations to disclose more about their fundraising, grant-making policies and financial controls.

The move follows growing public scrutiny of how charities operate, particularly the relationship between money raised from donors and spending on charitable activities. The changes include:

 cost of generating funds - the fundraising costs category has been replaced by a wider category called "costs of generating funds", which now includes costs of generating investment income and shop sales
 investments - charities will have to publish statements of their policies on investments and reserves and give details of their performance
 risk control - trustees will have to state what controls are in place to minimise operational and financial risks
 grants - the rules for disclosure of grants have been set out more fully and those on non-disclosure have been tightened

The general thrust of the new SORP is that more information will be required from trustees on the general strategy and running of a charity and how it is performing in different categories. The Charity Commission hopes the changes will result in more meaningful annual reports and discourage a "check list" approach to reporting activities.

One of the most important changes is on how fundraising activities will be presented. Charities will have to break down the various kinds of fundraising in their annual reports and give details, rather than showing fundraising income lumped together.

"That will mean showing, for example, shops' income and costs, events' income and costs and so on," said Kate Sayer of accountants Sayer Vincent and a member of the committee that drew up the new SORP. She said that, until now, it has been difficult to understand the fundraising activities of some charities. For instance, one organisation could choose to put the costs of generating shops sales through its subsidiary, while another would include it in the main charity accounts.

"There has been a lack of consistency and, in some cases, you wouldn't even know that a charity had shops from looking at its accounts," Sayer added. The changes will also mean it will be easier to see ratios for various kinds of fundraising, in other words what the return on investment was in, say, direct marketing, during the year.

But some in the sector are concerned that this extra information could give a distorted picture of fundraising. Andrew Watt, director of the Institute of Charity Fundraising Managers, said some fundraising campaigns require large initial investment but provide returns over several years.

That means in the first year it could look like a particular fundraising campaign was very expensive. "It will be up to directors of fundraising to get across the message that all this information is only part of the picture," he said.

Another of the important changes is on risk controls and follows moves in the private sector to encourage boards to exercise more control over the finances of the organisation. Charles Cox, head of charities at accountants Pannell Kerr Forster said: "Many charities will be reporting on these matters for the first time and will need to review their arrangements."

 SORP 2000 and the summary booklet CC62 - Charities SORP 2000 can be downloaded from the Charity Commission's website

webTitle: Charities demand funding reform

fields.headline: Charities demand funding reform
fields.standfirst: Policy changes have left many charities with soaring fund values, thanks to stock market growth, but declining income.
fields.trailText: The Charity Commission is under pressure to allow more funding flexibility to charities, who have found their investment values soaring while their income declines. Patrick McCurry reports
fields.body:
The Charity Commission is under pressure to allow more flexibility for charities with permanent endowments.

A consultation in October resulted in 85 responses from charities urging the commission to allow them to spend some of the capital growth of their funds rather than just the income. The commission's final decision is expected in the spring.

The problem has been that income from share dividends has been falling in recent years, due to changes in policy in many large quoted companies and because of the phased abolition of advance corporation tax credit.

This has left many permanently endowed charities with soaring fund values, thanks to stock market growth, but declining income.

The original reasons for not allowing charities to spend the capital on such funds were to ensure that future beneficiaries of endowments did not lose out at the expense of current beneficiaries. But changes in the investment environment mean reform of the system is essential, say many in the sector.

Mike Wilson, treasury controller at the National Trust, said: "Dividend yields have dropped to historically low levels, with the FT-SE All Share Index yielding around 2% today compared with 4.5% to 5% a decade ago."

Many large companies, like Microsoft and Vodafone, have stopped paying or reduced the size of dividends. They argue that investors will benefit more if those funds are invested back in the company and generate higher capital growth in the shares. But this trend has hit permanently endowed charities.

What this means for charities like the National Trust is that, even though the size of the trust's endowment funds have grown, the actual income available to spend has fallen. "Someone looking at our balance sheet would see millions of pounds in the funds and wonder what the problem was," said Mr Wilson.

Nigel Siederer, director of the Association of Charitable Foundations, said: "Our members are very much in favour of more flexibility and the government has agreed in principle to reform primary legislation."

The Charity Commission suggests two alternatives to the existing framework, one would be complete liberalisation and the other a middle way solution known as "total return". If there were complete liberalisation, the commission would agree, on a case by case basis, that a charity should be free to spend any or all of its permanent endowment.

But, in its consultation proposals, the commission argues that such a change would effectively eliminate the duty of even-handedness between present and future beneficiaries.

The total return approach would not mean giving trustees unfettered power to spend the capital but allow them to invest in a way that generates the best total return regardless of whether that is income or capital. Some of that total return would be used to meet the needs of present beneficiaries while the rest would be added to the existing capital to help meet the needs of future beneficiaries.

Some investment experts believe that even though the high capital returns of the late 1990s have faded and average stock returns are likely to be around 6%-8%, there is still latitude for flexibility. Robert Ward, head of charities at Chiswell Associates, said that after taking into account inflation charities would probably be able to slice off some capital gains as income, perhaps 1.5% to 2%.

The National Trust's Mike Wilson says he expects that any liberalisation will be accompanied by careful vetting of charities by the commission: "They'll need to check the financial and investment expertise of the charity and perhaps larger charities will be in a better position than smaller ones to fulfil those requirements."

 The Charity Commission consultation, Endowed charities - a fresh approach to investment returns?, is available at its website

webTitle: From: John Withington (6 Dec)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: John Withington
fields.trailText: I went from India to Nepal nine years ago so I hope you are enjoying it! The hassles of travelling three weeks in northern India were to stand me in good stead for the rest of my trip; if you've done this, everything else is easy.
fields.body:
Sue, hope you enjoy Nepal. Just a short mail due to the fact you are probably receiving hundreds via the Guardian!

I went from India to Nepal nine years ago so I hope you are enjoying it! The hassles of travelling three weeks in northern India were to stand me in good stead for the rest of my trip; if you've done this, everything else is easy. Mumbai is incredible, eh? Mad weaving traffic. Bottomless potholes right in the city centre, fading Raj-style buildings. From here I had an epic 16 hour bus journey to Goa, but you'll probably be heading the other way up to Agra, perhaps?

Nepal will seem relaxing by comparison with what came before, eg if you are hassled by people trying to sell you something, then one 'no' is normally enough. This last bit seems a bit negative, but I do like the place and will be there over this christmas/ new year for the first time since that trip.

I am independently trekking. I will be flying from Kathmandu to Lukla on about 15th Dec and walking in the Kumbu/ Everest region between tea-houses. Returning to Kathmandu by 14th January, if not sooner. Just a month's holiday unfortunately! Beware Lukla airstrip out of action from new year's day onwards for repairs! I've also been told the winter snows usually arrive about Christmas-time; above Namche it would be VERY cold and trails might be impassable due to snow. The tea shops on the Gokyo section might be closed (you would have to find out before leaving Namche). Phortse, Dingboche, Pheriche and Lobuche are now inhabited year-round; Gorak Shep lodges might be closed.

Back in 1991 I was in the Annapurna area which I can recommend. I didn't go to the Annapurna sanctuary, I went on the Annapurna circuit, but if you have good weather, the view in the sanctuary is supposed to be the bee's knees. Try and spend a few days hiking up into the hills from Pokhara or go to the Langtang area or take a bus to Jiri and experience back country Nepal. No account of a trip to Nepal/India would be complete without an illness story! - I caught Giardia last time and it is the worst thing I have had so I will be dropping iodine in every drink in sight while there this time! I found the cheap hotels in the Thamel area to be sufficient and in the heart of things.

Your route later seems spot on. Of south America I've only been to Venezuela. Highlights were walking near the city of Merida in the Andes and wildlife spotting on ranch areas in the 'Los Llanos' area (nearest city is Barinas ) - boas, freshwater dolphins, crocs, capybaru, and hundreds of bird species you will not have seen before!

Look forward to hearing more of your travels via the Guardian site. All the best!

webTitle: MP wants police to live on murder estate

fields.headline: MP wants police to live on murder estate
fields.trailText: The MP for the constituency where 10-year-old Damilola Taylor was murdered yesterday called for police officers to be housed on the deprived inner city estate where he was killed, in a bid to crack down on crime and solve the crisis in police recruitment. By Sarah Hall
fields.body:
The MP for the constituency where 10-year-old Damilola Taylor was murdered yesterday called for police officers to be housed on the deprived inner city estate where he was killed, in a bid to crack down on crime and solve the crisis in police recruitment.

Harriet Harman, a former social security secretary and the MP for Camberwell and Peckham, said police were deserting her borough, forced out by central London property prices.

The only hope of recruiting and retaining them was for the council to offer them new houses, even if it meant forcing out other tenants.

"It is controversial because it means you are reducing the number of homes available, but I think we have to have police living in the community," she said. "We can't recruit police without sorting out the housing issue - but we also need this to regenerate society.

"People feel safer when they have police living on their estate, and they are also pleased because they feel that if police live among them, they are totally in tune with their issues."

Ms Harman's call came after the Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir John Stevens, warned of an inner city policing crisis, with London having a 3,000 shortfall. In Southwark, the borough in which Damilola was fatally stabbed, the quota of 800 officers is 46 down.

In an area where the average cost of a terraced house is £185,000, police, in common with nurses and teachers, can no longer afford to buy or rent in the private sector on salaries which start at £23,000 including a housing allowance of £3,327, Ms Harman said.

The problem has been exacerbated by the previous government's decision, in 1994, to sell off police housing stock and freeze the housing allowance.

"They find they are earning enough to buy in a suburb and then they start to question why they should travel into central London when they can earn the same amount and do easier work policing near their home," she warned.

She added that the home secretary, Jack Straw, should back the move.

But Glen Smyth, chairman of the Metropolitan Police Federation, last night warned it would prove unpopular with police, who felt they needed to live outside areas they patrolled, for their own protection.

Touring the half-demolished north Peckham estate where Damilola bled to death, Ms Harman said its inhabitants were increasingly carrying knives as status symbols in a community where their chances of good jobs were consistently curtailed by discrimination.

"There is clearly a sense that this is an unequal society where you are blocked by the colour of your skin, and there is a feeling that you achieve status not by getting a degree or by qualifications but by having a knife," she said.

The growing problem of knife carrying appeared to have developed since children on Peckham's five neighbouring estates had seen their well-educated immigrant parents unable to put their degrees to good use in London.

"Three quarters of the African cab drivers in Peckham have degrees. So how can their children believe their education is worth striving for?" Ms Harman said.

"It is in this atmosphere that some carry knives and turn to crime."

The solution, she added, might lie, in increased resources for Peckham's schools, which, in the case of the Oliver Goldsmith which Damilola attended, had one of the lowest scores in national league tables, with only one in four of its 11-year-olds gaining the expected standard in English.

In the meantime, parents on the Peckham estate were trying to rectify the problems themselves - either by sending children back home to the West Indies or Africa to be educated, or by dispatching them to a private, Christian Fellowship school on the estate that they could ill afford.

webTitle: Care trusts get green light

fields.headline: Care trusts get green light
fields.trailText: Measures to ease joint working between social services and the NHS through the creation of care trusts were announced in the Queen's speech today, writes Patrick Butler
fields.body:
Measures to ease joint working between social services and the NHS through the creation of care trusts were announced in the Queen's speech today.

A bill to extend the powers of the soon-to-be-appointed Children's Commissioner in Wales was also announced, along with a bill to improve access to education for disabled people.

The health and social care bill will enable the creation of care trusts, local bodies responsible for delivering primary health care, community health services and social care for older people. Ministers believe care trusts will firmly integrate joint working between health and social care. The first trusts - which will evolve from existing primary care trusts - are expected next year.

The powers of the children's commissioner for Wales will be widened to cover not just children in care, but also children in hospitals and schools under a new bill. The children's commissioner was the number one recommendation in the Waterhouse report into child abuse in north Wales, published in June. The children's commissioner post was created in an amendment to the subsequent care standards bill, but for technical reasons the commissioner's powers were restricted to children in care.

Wales first minister Rhodri Morgan said the bill would transform children's rights "in a way never before seen in the UK".

The Wales children's commissioner is expected to be announced soon, with the successful candidate taking up post in the new year.

The special educational needs and disability bill removes an anomaly in which education was exempted from the 1995 disability discrimination act. It will introduce new duties on education providers not to treat disabled pupils and students less favourably than their non-disabled peers unless this can be justified. It will also strengthen the right of children with special educational needs to be educated in mainstream schools.

Schools, colleges and universities will also be required to make physical alterations to buildings to ensure their premises are more accessible to disabled people. The government announced in November that schools will receive £220m over three years to improve access for disabled children.
 Join our online debate on care trusts in Talk

webTitle: Councils give cautious welcome to curfew extension

fields.headline: Councils give cautious welcome to curfew extension
fields.trailText: The Queen's speech represents the latest step in the government's attempts to get councils in England and Wales involved in the process of cracking down on crime.
fields.body:
The Queen's speech represents the latest step in the government's attempts to get councils in England and Wales involved in the process of cracking down on crime.

Ministers announced that they want to control anti-social behaviour by young people through an extension of council powers that will allow authorities to impose curfews on under-16s.
Whether councils will enthusiastically grasp this opportunity is another matter. The curfews were introduced for young people under 10 by the Crime and Disorder Act 1998, but they have never been used.

Councils see the measure as extreme, and have generally explored other options, rather than use a blanket restriction on children across whole areas from dusk until dawn.
Mike Ashley, the Local Government Association community safety head, welcomed the extension as useful but added: "There has clearly been a reluctance among social services departments to take this up."

Law and order professionals have also taken issue with the new curfew powers. Harry Fletcher, assistant general secretary of the National Association of Probation Officers, said: "The child curfews are flawed in principle. They target geographical areas rather than problem individuals and risk being discriminatory. They could end up alienating all youngsters against the police." The danger of this power is that it could simply spread the problem of anti-social behaviour to lightly policed areas, he added.

Some councils see Anti Social Behaviour Orders (ASBOs) as a lighter touch alternative. These can be used to target individuals, preventing them from carrying out acttions specified in the order. They have been used against groups such as prostitutes as well as young people and can result in criminal charges if they are broken.
Mr Ashley said: "Councils believe that their tool box contains a whole range of approaches, and if you take ASBOs they are increasingly being used."

Home Office figures, however, show a lacklustre take-up rate - only 140 ASBOs have been issued since they were introduced in April 1999. This is despite repeated calls from ministers for councils to make more use of the orders.

Birmingham council has already issued around 7 ASBOs. Senior policy development officer Neil Grant said the orders had proven useful, but added that authorities often tried to use other means, including criminal legislation, to deal with anti-social behavior and crime: "Some people would argue that an ASBO is a failure to resolve the problem by other means."

If the Home Secretary is really serious about tackling what ministers persist in terming "yob culture", he may have to junk his preference for tough measures against anti-social behaviour and look instead at the wider range of preventative options councils are using as their first resort.

webTitle: Week 1: Heathrow to New York

fields.headline: Taking a bite out of the Big Apple
fields.standfirst: In the first of his weekly emails, Sam marvels to the sights and sounds of New York, and finds his taste in headgear rubbished
fields.trailText: "I spend the whole time thinking I'm on the set of Cagney and Lacey or Hill Street Blues... There's steam rising up out of grills in the road and everyone's in big coats because it's so cold." From the mundane to the miraculous, Sam relates his first impressions of New York
fields.body:
My second full day in New York and I'm beginning to figure my way around. I spend the whole time thinking I'm on the set of Cagney and Lacey or Hill Street Blues. Most of my preconceptions of the city come from cop shows from the 70s and 80s and I've not been disappointed (appropriately my hostel is opposite a NYPD precinct station). There are yellow cabs and those long American fire trucks with the deep honking horns everywhere.

There's steam rising up out of grills in the road and everyone's in big coats because it's so cold.

The flight here was very exciting as it was my first long-haul trip. There was a TV screen in the back of the seat in front of me showing various films but also what altitude and speed the plane was flying at, and where we were on a little map of the Atlantic - cool!

On arriving at the hostel in downtown Manhattan, I decided to take a room rather than a bed in a dormitory just for the first couple of nights. I was a bit shocked by the cost ($60 a night - that's a major chunk of my weekly budget), and the room gave new meaning to the word 'basic' but it was worth it. I was so tired that all I wanted to do was sleep and have my own space.

Before going to bed I had a walk round and got very excited stumbling upon 5th Avenue with the Empire State Building down one end. And I had a beer in a local bar sitting in a big comfy armchair. On my way back I popped my head into the hostel kitchen area but they were all watching TV, but no-one said anything so I didn't stay.

I woke up to bright sunshine on my first proper day. This was rather clouded when I realised I'd lost my black woollen hat. I was very proud of this hat, and had chosen it specially so I could feel like a local (everyone is wearing hats). I rushed down to see if I had dropped it in the kitchen last night but it wasn't there. Asked at reception to see if someone had handed it in, and while I was waiting there I spotted it in the waste bin! My delight at finding it was a bit tempered by Americans' obvious lack of taste in headgear - well I like it anyway.

My photos show you what I got up to on my first day, so I won't go into a lot of detail here. The views from the top of the World Trade Center and on Brooklyn Bridge were amazing. I travelled on the subway and the Statten Island ferry. I walked round Wall Street (great fun with the stock exchange traders in their colourful jackets and fat, suited men in black overcoats discussing the markets).

Thanks for your emails, particularly Rebecca Leyland who gave me a couple of very helpful suggestions. One was to visit the Woolworth Building - excellent gothic skyscraper built by Mr Woolworth himself. And the other was on tipping, which apparently you have to do everywhere, and my failure to do so explains some of the black looks I've been getting.

I'm here for three more days and then it's on to Washington DC, so if anyone's got any hot tips for that city, let me know.


Sam

I walked round Wall Street (great fun with the stock exchange traders in their colourful jackets and fat, suited men in black overcoats discussing the markets). Thanks for your emails, particularly Rebecca Leyland who gave me a couple of very helpful suggestions. One was to visit the Woolworth Building - excellent gothic skyscraper built by Mr Woolworth himself. And the other was on tipping, which apparently you have to do everywhere, and my failure to do so explains some of the black looks I've been getting. I'm here for three more days and then it's on to Washington DC, so if anyone's got any hot tips for that city, let me know. Sam

webTitle: Pros and cons: council scrutiny of the NHS

fields.headline: Pros and cons: council scrutiny of the NHS
fields.trailText: Legislation announced in the queen's speech will give local government a wider role in scrutinising the health service. Here, Simon Parker and Patrick Butler present the case for and against
fields.body:
Legislation announced in the queen's speech will give local government a wider role in scrutinising the health service. Here, we present the case for and against:

NHS trusts are undemocratic and accountable only upwards. Scrutiny from politicians elected by local people will help bridge the gap between communities and health service boards.
It is true that NHS bodies are accountable ultimately to the (democratically elected) secretary of state. However, many local councillors sit on NHS trust, health authority and primary care group boards, even though they are appointed, rather than directly elected.

Local government scrutiny will help to end spats between councils and the health service over issues such as hospital closures.
Giving local government closer scrutiny powers over the NHS will not end spats over hospital or ward closures - indeed it may generate more and more bitter clashes.

In-depth scrutiny from councillors will help open up the workings of NHS trusts to the general public.
It is true that, historically, the NHS has been fairly secretive about how and why it makes its decisions. However, that is changing. Trusts are required to open board meetings to the public, while the NHS is bound by a code of openess. That said, the NHS has generally been rather blasé and tokenistic about consulting with the public over service changes, and council scrutiny will force trusts and health authorities to properly justify their proposals.

The fact that the council scrutineers are not health professionals improves the chance that they will be able to better inform the public about health policy.
The NHS does have a lot to learn about using plain English rather than institutional jargon, and plain-speaking councillors may have an educative role here. On the other hand, many in the NHS would argue councillors are blithely ignorant of developments in modern healthcare, and are often stubbornly obsessed with retaining potent NHS symbols such as cottage hospitals, regardless of clinical safety issues or cost effectiveness.

Joining up health and other local services is essential to the government's regeneration policies. Giving councils powers of scrutiny can only lead to closer working between the NHS and local government.
Not neccessarily. The two parties might be better informed about what each is doing, but that is unlikely in itself to lead to blissful marriage. Councillors, particularly if they belong to a party in opposition to the governement, may have a vested interest in either wrecking local initiatives, or of pandering to local voter opinion regardless of what is best for the local health economy.

Do you have an opinion?Join the debate in Talk

webTitle: Plans to improve NHS at heart of Queen's speech

fields.headline: Plans to improve NHS at heart of Queen's speech
fields.trailText: Measures to improve the performance of the NHS in England and Wales, improve joint working between health and social services, and increase investment in GP surgeries are at the heart of the Queen's speech.
fields.body:
Measures to improve the performance of the NHS in England and Wales, improve joint working between health and social services, and increase investment in GP surgeries are at the heart of the Queen's speech.

The health and social care modernisation bill will legislate to push forward several NHS plan commitments, including the creation of care trusts to allow the merger of health and social services.

From April next year, it will also support a National Health Performance Fund worth up to £500m a year by 2003-04, which will reward NHS trusts that are performing well.

The bill will confirm that the NHS will pay for nursing care costs in homes for the elderly, while a separate bill will widen the range of health professionals allowed to prescribe drugs.

The government's war on cancer and smoking gets a boost in the form of a separate bill to ban the promotion and advertising of tobacco.

Legislation to improve access to learning for disabled people, and to extend the functions of the Children's Commissioner for Wales, are also flagged up in the speech.

The National Health Performance Fund will provide £5m for each health authority area to be distributed to trusts as a "reward" for progress.

Access to the cash would depend on a "traffic light" system. The best performing "green" organisations would have an automatic right to payments while others judged as "yellow" and "red" would have to agree plans or have their spending supervised.

The modernisation bill will enable care trusts to be created. These will be single bodies responsible for delivering primary health care, community health services and social care for older people.

Ministers believe care trusts will firmly establish joint working between health and social care. They expect to launch the first trusts next year.

A new programme of public-private partnerships - similar to that already used to build hospitals - is planned to finance primary care facilities such as GP surgeries.

Priority will be given to those areas, such as inner cities, where primary care services are most in need of expansion.

An equity stake company called NHS Lift (NHS Local Improvement Finance Trust) will unlock up to £1bn of investment, leading to the refurbishment of up to 3,000 family doctors' premises by 2004.

The speech confirms the NHS will be responsible for paying for nursing care in nursing homes. In future, people assessed as needing nursing care will not have to pay for the services of registered nurses in homes.

The legislation will also extend the scope of the direct payments scheme, whereby local authorities make direct payments to individuals to enable them to buy their own care.

Another change will extend prescribing rights to a wider range of health professionals.

Currently, only doctors, dentists and certain specified health visitors and midwives are able to prescribe drugs.

New legislation will be introduced to implement the main recommendations of a government review which accepted nurses should have more freedom to prescribe medicines.

It also called for other professionals such as chiropodists, physiotherapists and pharmacists to be given the right to prescribe.

Under the proposals, the 1968 Medicines Act will be amended to designate new groups of prescribers and limit or specify the medicines they can prescribe.

An advisory body will be set up to consider whether prescribing rights should be granted to any additional groups of health professionals.

webTitle: Queen's speech offers a slim agenda

fields.headline: Queen's speech offers a slim agenda
fields.standfirst:
 Five bills to fight crime
 Drug barons assets targeted
 £500m for NHS trusts immediately
 Hunting vote in next session
 Tobacco advertising ban
 Labour's slimmest programme since election
fields.trailText: The prime minister, Tony Blair, today put crime and health at the centre of the government's agenda in the run-up to the next election - in the slimmest legislative programme announced since Labour came to power.
fields.body:
The prime minister, Tony Blair, today put crime and health at the centre of the government's agenda in the run-up to the next election - in the slimmest legislative programme announced since Labour came to power.

The Queen's speech, delivered to the House of Lords, contained details of only 15 bills, plus four draft measures. That compares to 22 bills in 1997, 26 in 1998 and 28 in 1999.

Downing Street maintained that today's announcements were "a full programme that shows, unusually, a government gaining momentum in its fourth year, not losing it".

However, there will inevitably bound be speculation that ministers are actually clearing the decks for a spring poll.

Today's speech, delivered amid traditional glittering pomp and ceremony from the golden throne in the Lords also confirmed that there will be a free vote on hunting with dogs.

Five bills concentrate on the fight against crime. They will provide for:  Fixed penalties for offences of disorderly behaviour in public places  Police to be able to shut down rowdy pubs and clubs  A ban on drinking alcohol in the street  Child curfew schemes for those aged nine to 15.

The speech reflected Mr Blair's declared determination to tackle "yob culture" in Britain, although there was no place for his ill-received £100 on-the-spot fines.

However, there will be new powers for police to seize the assets of criminals, with drug barons being especially targeted.

In an attempt to dampen speculation about an early election, the government insisted that the speech provides for a full legislative programme.

On health, the government is to shake up funding, making a fund of £500m available to the best run NHS trusts immediately and to others under strict supervision.

There are also plans for public-private partnerships to improve primary health care - such as GP services - particularly in inner cities. More health professionals will be allowed to prescribe drugs and, on long-term care for the elderly, campaigners will be pleased by a pledge that in future the NHS will be responsible for paying nursing care costs in homes.

There will also be a bill to ban the promotion and advertising of tobacco.

On education, which ministers insist will still be given the highest priority, there will be new moves to improve literacy and numeracy for 11 to 14 year-olds, building on what the government says has been the success of its strategy in primary schools.

There will also be a major drive to improve adult literacy.

The Queen's speech also promised a regulatory reform bill designed to sweep away red tape in more than 20 areas. They include simplifying fire regulations, and allowing pubs and restaurants to open later.

Restaurants would be allowed to remain open without providing live entertainment and, from next year, pubs would be allowed to stay open later on New Year's Eve.

A bill will also be introduced to make home-buying simpler in England and Wales. Ministers say the aim is to make it "more transparent and consumer-friendly".

Sellers would be required to compile a special pack for purchasers, including a survey report and details such as planning consents and title documents usually discovered now through the conveyancing process by the buyer's solicitors.

The long-awaited hunting bill will also be brought forward this session. It will provide for three options:
 An almost total ban on hunting with dogs
 A compulsory regulatory system forcing hunts to obtain licences
 A voluntary system of regulation

There will be a free vote on the issue for MPs.

webTitle: The monarchy

fields.headline: The monarchy
fields.standfirst: The Guardian is backing a challenge to the Act of Settlement 1701 and calling for a referendum on the monarchy. Here's our guide to the best sites on Britain's royalty.
fields.trailText:
NetNotes: The Guardian is backing a challenge to the Act of Settlement 1701 and calling for a referendum on the monarchy. Here's our guide to the best sites on Britain's royalty.
More NetNotes More NetNotes
fields.body:
1. Is the monarchy right for Britain?

2. Some people, not least among the Guardian, believe not. They say it has outlived its usefulness.

3. There are those who disagree: to them, the royal family is a living symbol of the nation.

4. Despite a few hiccups along the way (such as the Norman conquest) our current queen claims descent from the Ango-Saxon Kings of Wessex.

5. The job has changed since then: from the military rulers and wily princes of the European middle ages and renaissance, the monarch - in early modern times - became the absolute ruler of the newly centralised nation state.

6. Most royal houses tried absolutism.. Some monarchs, such as Charles I of England and later Louis XVI of France, were executed as a result.

7. Where monarchy survived, it was in a limited form. The English Bill of Rights (1689) invited William of Orange to become king but on parliament's terms.

8. The last absolutist monarchy in western Europe was in Denmark, which abandoned the practice in 1849 in favour of a constitutional system.

9. The first world war killed off many remaining monarchies in Europe. The royal houses of Austria, Germany, Russia and the Ottoman empire either lost their lives or their titles.

10. So that's monarchy's past. Does it have a future?

webTitle: Councils stay loyal to the telephone

fields.headline: Councils stay loyal to the telephone
fields.standfirst: Call centres ring in the changes of delivering improved public services
fields.trailText: Call centres ring in the changes of delivering improved public services, writes Dermott Calpin
fields.body:
In Knowsley telephones have played an integral part in the development of the council's one-stop-shop service since 1994; in Brent a relaunched call centre is a key ingredient in its aim to offer 24-hour council services and the new Liverpool Direct number expects to receive more than 4m calls a year.

It may be the internet and web technology that grabs all the prominent headlines, but in the end it is likely to be a simple phone call to your local council that will matter most when it comes to connecting the drive for improved public services with the people who use them.

Call centres are already changing the way some local authorities work, and are likely to figure prominently in the way many more respond to pressures to change the way they deliver services to their communities.

Tony Blair and the Cabinet Office may be promoting a target of 2005 for all public services to be available online or electronically. But as a series of recent reports have shown, the closer you are to the day to day problems of actual service delivery, the more real the obstacles are.

Most councils have websites and encourage greater use of email as a means of communication, but as the IT Trends 2000/1 report published by the Society of Information Technology Management (Socitm) acknowledges, there is still only a "patchy or poor understanding" about how best to use the technology.

In contrast to this uncertainty, Socitm found: "There is considerable interest in call centre technology and customer relationship management. Very few authorities have a call centre at present but 63% said they expect to introduce one over the next year or so."

The great advantage of the telephone is its widespread availability and relative ease of use, the lack of major skill barriers and its availability to a greater cross section of people from all ages and social-economic class.

However rapid the growth of the internet, the telephone is already in more than 90% of all homes and what the Henley Centre dubbed "teleculture" is a fact of life for councils. According to the Foundation for Information Technology in Local Government, councils already conduct "75% or more of their existing contact with citizens via the phone".

Public confidence
BT published a study this summer which showed widespread concern that lack of public access to the internet could pose a major barrier to the delivery of e-services and could even exasperate problems of social exclusion.

Concerns about a general lack of information technology skills and low levels of the public's confidence in their ability to use new technology were also identified as major problems.

The plain fact is, the older you are, the less likely you are to use a touchscreen, interactive television or personal computer to access information, but the more likely you are to feel comfortable using a telephone. Even in this high tech age, it seems people still value the opportunity of talking to other people when they want to find something out.

This was also a point made in an "Embracing Technology" study by the online bank Egg and research company Mori, which stressed that even though half the population may soon be using the internet regularly there will still be 29m adults who don't use a PC. A hardcore of 9m vow they never will.

For local government these issues have a special resonance in the era of best value, in which councils are charged with securing year-on-year service improvements. Information technology, put to good effect, can offer a solution to transforming service delivery.

Since taking up the post of chief executive at Liverpool, David Henshaw has systematically set about transforming the council from " seaport to e-port" - from near the bottom in national performance standards to the very top.

A former chief executive of Knowsley, where he helped pioneer the development of one stop shops, Mr Henshaw has forged a £500m partnership deal with BT to establish Liverpool Direct, the biggest consumer contact centre in local government.

Liverpool Direct already takes some 25,000 calls a week from the public and by early next year, as the local network of one stop centres expands, it expects to deal with more than 100,000 calls a week.

Local people will be able to access council services by telephone and through a range of newer technologies from touchscreens, digital and web television, WAP phones and the internet, but the guiding principle is to integrate both technology and services to make the council more open and customer friendly.

"Instead of separate council departments all working independently in self-protective silos of service and information, we are integrating our approach right across the council," says Mr Henshaw who emphasises the longer term aim of making the service "more pro-active, more response and more relevant" for the people who use it.

Working conditions
With some 7,000 call centres employing more than 400,000 people throughout the UK, the sector plays a key role for the private sector, which pioneered much of the early development through the rapid growth of online insurance and financial services.

Despite attracting more than their fair share of criticism for being the "sweatshops" of a new industrial age, call centres have had to respond positively to problems such as high levels of absenteeism, high staff turnover and complaints about stress and poor working conditions.

It is a lesson that has not been lost on local authorities, which have recognised the importance of improved staff training and development. As Anne Marie Stagg from the Call Centre Management Association, explains: "Achieving customer services excellence is very simple. All you do is give your frontline people freedom to do what they feel is in the best interests of their customers and then train them, encourage them and support them in excercising this freedom.

"Delivering dreadful customer services is often a result of managerial interference and a tendency to restrict frontline people from applying common sense. Staff who value themselves and who are valued by their bosses, will value their customers."

webTitle: The republic: The Scottish threat

fields.headline: The republic: The Scottish threat
fields.trailText: Has the return of the Scottish parliament changed the way the monarchy is seen? In one sense, hardly           at all yet in another, it threatens to change everything, and in a relatively foreseeable future.
fields.body:
Has the return of the Scottish parliament changed the way the monarchy is seen? In one sense, hardly at all yet in another, it threatens to change everything, and in a relatively foreseeable future.

Her Majesty of course inaugurated the parliament in 1998, and with a certain grace meant to endear her anew to northern subjects. These included the editor-in-chief of the Scotsman, Mr Andrew Neil, who was seen to go weak at the knees while commenting on the event for BBC Scotland. This once stalwart republican even forecast "a new style of monarchy for the 21st century". But the new style was soon in trouble. Because of the large Catholic vote in Scotland, all Scottish parties have a common interest in combating sectarianism, and the new assembly unanimously decided the Windsors were delinquents in this regard. The campaign was backed by Michael Forsyth, a former Tory secretary of state. The modern crown rests upon the infamous 1701 Act of Settlement, which declared that no individual of the Catholic faith should ever again occupy a British throne. Could any sane multicultural court of the present do anything but condemn such discrimination? Surely it was time for Holyrood and Westminster to join in repealing the anachronism?

With unexampled haste and glibness, Blair declined this honour. No parliamentary time, far too many consultations needed, not within the Scottish remit, and emphatically not the kind of thing middle England wanted to hear about. He had not reprieved the Windsors from Diana-fever, merely to subvert them from another direction. Also, an untarnished Queen would be required to open the Millenium Dome. This fire-hose of platitudes omitted something quite important. The Act of Settlement is one item in the rather meagre written part of the British constitution, alongside the less picturesque Treaty of Union of 1706-7. In fact, it was a necessary condition of the latter. In fact, it was just too damn close to the spinal column of "all we hold dear". There are, after all, extremists around (not all Scots) who believe that a modern written constitution would be better for the United Kingdom (or the United Whatever-it-is), and ought to replace these heirlooms altogether. Some of them even think it was a precondition of devolved government, and that without it devolution is sure to break down.

Such lunatics are at odds (sometimes unknowingly) with the very soul of the United Kingdom. The third way pines for regeneration, not wholesale replacement. It wants a monarch kind to Muslims and Buddhists, not a soulless republic. Having transformed local government into "local government" through devolution, it now has little time for upstarts with ideas exceeding their non-sovereign status. The crown should support a given dispensation of authority, not become a lever of possible alteration.

The Scottish parliament's appeal on the 1701 act was intended reasonably, as a gesture of atonement. In reality, it was an arrow aimed at the very core of Anglo-British custom-observance. Formal renunciation of this part of the symbol-heritage might encourage a more thorough formalism, and a lettered constitutionalism, the antithesis of royal magic. Republicanism thrives on precisely that tendency. Also, the Act of Settlement was a prelude to the Treaty of Union between the old parliaments of Scotland and England, five years later: the very hinge of the United Kingdom, and just as much of an anachronism. It was recently reiterated in the Scotland Act 1998, an element of the New Labour dispensation, therefore, and meant to stabilise it. Decidedly, children should not be allowed to play with matches in this cellar.

But play they will. By 2007, the third centenary of union, the SNP will quite probably control the executive, and be seeking to repeal the old treaty. And there will be a growing number of English republicans who agree with them. Since no new constitutional settlement was allowed to precede devolution, it will have to follow it. The matter of Britain, in which most Scots have an overwhelmingly strong, and often personal, interest, could then be renegotiated on a basis of equality, along with the other countries and populations awarded places on the Belfast Agreement's "Council of the Isles".

Terrifying only to addicts of the great and the exceptional, such a process would seek to keep (and build upon) what matters to the common life of the archipelago. Republican in essence, it would surely dispel such 18th century phantasms one and for all.

webTitle: Internet arms dealers face curbs

fields.headline: Internet arms dealers face curbs
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The government will try to head off the fury of the human rights lobby today by vowing that a draft exports control bill will go further than expected by regulating arms trading on the internet.
fields.body:
The government will try to head off the fury of the human rights lobby today by vowing that a draft exports control bill will go further than expected by regulating arms trading on the internet.

British arms exporters will be required to go on a register before they can receive a licence.

The human rights lobby is angry that no space has been found in the Queens Speech for an immediate arms control bill, pointing out that John Major's government published a green paper on arms controls as long as July 1996 in the wake of the Scott inquiry into arms for Iraq. Labour published a white paper in June 1998.

The speech will centre on an assault on crime and a health bill implementing the national plan for the NHS, which will establish joint care trusts between health and social security authorities to end bed blocking.

Oxfam yesterday rounded on the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, and the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, for failing to deliver on arms trading regulation.

"The government has failed to live up to its promises and, because of its inaction, small arms will continue to fall into the wrong hands and innocent people will die," it said.

Severe criticism over the delay is also expected from parliamentary select committees.

However, the Department of Trade and Industry yesterday hit back, promising a bill next year.

Ministers claim the proposals will go substantially further than the recommendations of the Scott inquiry. Following some hard fought cabinet committee meetings in the past few months, Mr Byers has decided his draft bill will require all British arms exporters to put themselves on a register before they can receive a licence.

A licence will be required for traffickers and brokers, so British citizens using third countries to export arms will still be subject to British controls. Under these proposals, some of the arms exports to Sierra Leone via Bulgaria by British firms would have been unlawful.

Ministers accept there will be problems over enforcement.

The bill, replacing emergency legislation dating back to the 1939, will also require a licence if an exporter is trading by email.

Mr Byers also promises that the bill will give government statutory powers to ban all trading in torture equipment.

The bill will not give the parliamentary select committees powers to scrutinise all arms exports licences before ministers grant a licence, the committees' most recent demand.

 Air Chief Marshal Sir Peter Squire, chief of the air staff, has warned that RAF pilots are increasingly frustrated because inadequate funding has deprived them of equipment for training, writes Richard Norton-Taylor

The RAF is short of about 100 jet pilots, and Sir Peter said the problem was compounded by the poor state of living quarters in Britain.

Sir Peter also says in Officer magazine that shortages of spares for Tornados have led to aircraft being cannibalised to allow others to fly. He says hiving off services to the private sector is not securing the savings and efficiencies hoped for.

webTitle: Warning over hospital ranking system

fields.headline: Warning over hospital ranking system
fields.standfirst: GPs fear performance related rewards for the health service will discriminate against deprived areas
fields.trailText: GPs fear performance related rewards for the health service will discriminate against deprived areas, writes Patrick Butler
fields.body:
GPs have warned the government that its proposals to link financial rewards to hospital performance will discriminate against trusts in deprived areas and hamper their attempts to improve.

The government signalled its intention in today's Queen's speech to press ahead with its so-called "traffic light" system of rating hospital and health authority performance.

The proposals, unveiled in the NHS plan in the summer, will grade high-performing NHS bodies as "green", average-performing trusts as as "yellow", and poorly performing trusts as "red".

Trusts given a "red" classification run the risk of having their management board replaced by special NHS recovery teams, and will have restricted access to a £500m performance fund.

BMA GPs' committee chair John Chisholm said labelling organisations as "red" could be "seriously counterproductive", would damage staff recruitment and retention and make it more difficult for the hospital to recover. He said he feared that the criteria would discriminate against hospitals in socially-disadvanted areas.

The BMA's fears appear to be borne out by an unofficial ranking of health authorities published tomorrow which shows that the majority of poor performing HAs are in deprived inner city areas, noticeably in the north of England.

Compiled by John Appleby and Chris Deeming of the independent Kings Fund health think-tank, the rankings use the Department of Health's own methodology to predict how health authorities will be rated.

The rankings, which are previewed today by HSJ Online, show that a quarter of health authorities are likely to receive a "red light" classification, and that 80% of these are in the north of the country.

According to DoH performance critieria, the top ranking authority is Dorset, while the worst performer is Manchester. In all, 70% of health authorities ranked "green" are in the south of England.

The BMA said it feared too much emphasis was being placed on "micro-management from the centre" and that it had yet to be convinced of the fairness of the criteria used to classify hospitals under the traffic light system.

webTitle: The Queen's speech, summarised

fields.headline: Queen's speech offers a slim agenda
fields.standfirst:
· Five bills to fight crime
· Drug barons assets targeted
· £500m for NHS trusts immediately
· Hunting vote in next session
· Tobacco advertising ban
· Labour's slimmest programme since election

Queen's speech: the text in full
fields.trailText: The prime minister, Tony Blair, today put crime and health at the centre of the government's agenda in the run-up to the next election - in the slimmest legislative programme announced since Labour came to power.
fields.body:
The prime minister, Tony Blair, today put crime and health at the centre of the government's agenda in the run-up to the next election - in the slimmest legislative programme announced since Labour came to power.

The Queen's speech, delivered to the House of Lords, contained details of only 15 bills, plus four draft measures. That compares to 22 bills in 1997, 26 in 1998 and 28 in 1999.

Downing Street maintained that today's announcements were "a full programme that shows, unusually, a government gaining momentum in its fourth year, not losing it".

However, there will inevitably bound be speculation that ministers are actually clearing the decks for a spring poll.

Today's speech, delivered amid traditional glittering pomp and ceremony from the golden throne in the Lords also confirmed that there will be a free vote on hunting with dogs.

Five bills concentrate on the fight against crime. They will provide for: · Fixed penalties for offences of disorderly behaviour in public places · Police to be able to shut down rowdy pubs and clubs · A ban on drinking alcohol in the street · Child curfew schemes for those aged nine to 15.

The speech reflected Mr Blair's declared determination to tackle "yob culture" in Britain, although there was no place for his ill-received £100 on-the-spot fines.

However, there will be new powers for police to seize the assets of criminals, with drug barons being especially targeted.

In an attempt to dampen speculation about an early election, the government insisted that the speech provides for a full legislative programme.

On health, the government is to shake up funding, making a fund of £500m available to the best run NHS trusts immediately and to others under strict supervision.

There are also plans for public-private partnerships to improve primary health care - such as GP services - particularly in inner cities. More health professionals will be allowed to prescribe drugs and, on long-term care for the elderly, campaigners will be pleased by a pledge that in future the NHS will be responsible for paying nursing care costs in homes.

There will also be a bill to ban the promotion and advertising of tobacco.

On education, which ministers insist will still be given the highest priority, there will be new moves to improve literacy and numeracy for 11 to 14 year-olds, building on what the government says has been the success of its strategy in primary schools.

There will also be a major drive to improve adult literacy.

The Queen's speech also promised a regulatory reform bill designed to sweep away red tape in more than 20 areas. They include simplifying fire regulations, and allowing pubs and restaurants to open later.

Restaurants would be allowed to remain open without providing live entertainment and, from next year, pubs would be allowed to stay open later on New Year's Eve.

A bill will also be introduced to make home-buying simpler in England and Wales. Ministers say the aim is to make it "more transparent and consumer-friendly".

Sellers would be required to compile a special pack for purchasers, including a survey report and details such as planning consents and title documents usually discovered now through the conveyancing process by the buyer's solicitors.

The long-awaited hunting bill will also be brought forward this session. It will provide for three options:
· An almost total ban on hunting with dogs
· A compulsory regulatory system forcing hunts to obtain licences
· A voluntary system of regulation

There will be a free vote on the issue for MPs.

webTitle: Dairy Council launches ad campaign

fields.headline: Cartoon Rolf Harris stars in TV milk ads
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Rolf Harris is to get a taste of his own medicine when he appears in a new ad to encourage milk drinking, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The cartoonist Rolf Harris is to get a taste of his own medicine when he appears in a new ad to encourage people to drink more milk.

A cartoon version of the famous Australian will appear on TV next month as part of a £9m campaign for the National Dairy Council.

The campaign, whose slogan is "The white stuff", was launched earlier this year with an ad starring the legendary footballer George Best.

The ad, created by BMP DDB, is being kept under wraps until it goes live on January 12 but features Mr Harris playing his famous didgeridoo.

Andrew Ovens, marketing manager for the National Dairy Council, said: "There's no doubt the multi-talented star is made of the 'right' stuff - his TV work and latest venture into dance music has made him one of the country's most popular and well loved entertainers.

"We're hoping he can do for milk in the UK what he's done for didgeridoos, wobbleboards and stylophones!"

The campaign has already featured animated doubles of Prince Naseem and Chris Eubank as well as Best. The strapline, "The white stuff - are you made of it?" is delivered by Jonathan Ross.

The campaign is funded by Britain's 28,000 dairy farmers, with dairies such as Unigate matching their contribution pound for pound.

webTitle: Di Canio meets the definitive goalkeeper

fields.headline: Di Canio meets the definitive goalkeeper
fields.trailText: Aston Villa goalkeeper David James launched his new comedy career today by firing an "amusing" riposte in the direction of Paulo di Canio. James delivered his tongue-in-cheek rebuke after the controversial Italian labelled him a "cretin" and a "moron" in his autobiography.
fields.body:
Aston Villa goalkeeper David James launched his new comedy career today by firing an "amusing" riposte in the direction of Paulo di Canio. James delivered his tongue-in-cheek rebuke after the controversial Italian labelled him a "cretin" and a "moron" in his autobiography.

Di Canio claimed that James refused to shake his hands after a match at Upton Park in January, with the Villa keeper still fuming over a "dive" the Italian allegedly made to earn a penalty in the Hammers' League Cup defeat to Villa three days earlier.

"This cretin would not shake my hand," Di Canio said in the book. "At the end of the game it is the British way to shake hands, but by turning his back this moron, James, was sticking two fingers up to British sportsmanship. I told him 'You are nothing. You are not a man.'"

But James questioned Di Canio's grasp of the English language in an interview with the the Birmingham Evening Mail today. "Does this man not know the meaning of a cretin or a moron?" he asked.

"He clearly doesn't. A cretin suffers from a thyroid deficiency. It comes from an eighteenth century French word and was initially directed at people living in the valleys of the Alps and the Pyrenees.

"In some cases it is said to lead to dwarfism - and I'm 6ft 5ins for heaven's sake."

James continued: "And a moron is an adult person with a mental age of between eight and 12 years old. I'm no brainbox, but I think I'm more advanced than that."

The former Liverpool man then poured scorn over di Canio's reference to sportsmanship with a clear nod to the Italian's infamous push on referee Paul Alcock.

"Di Canio also brands me unsporting which is all very contradictory coming from him.

"Unfortunately, when I was sitting in my lessons at school, he must have been attending his weekly Referees Appreciation Society meetings!"
