fields.body:
'ENGLAND MANAGER IS USELESS LOSER' SHOCK

Sven-Goran Eriksson is certainly preparing well for next season. By turning his once-successful Lazio side into a bunch of abject no-hopers, he is getting ample opportunity to perfect the 'glancing shiftily from side-to-side' interview technique, an essential skill for any England manager. Having seen his team go down to Leeds, Eriksson insisted he wouldn't be leaving his post in Rome earlier than expected. "I believe I'm going to stay here until the end of the season," he said as his pupils clanked around in their sockets. "I don't think the fans decide whether I go. The club president decides."

According to Piercarlo Presutti, head of sport for Italian news agency Ansa, the fans wouldn't have been a problem anyway. "There are no people demonstrating in front of Eriksson's house or the president's house," he explained. "What you have to remember is that Rome has two big clubs and Roma have always been the main one. The supporters have been used to the club having problems. That is why many of them are not that angry."

But what of feared president Sergio Cragnotti? "Eriksson will not be touched," Cragnotti's son Massimo told the Corriere dello Sport today. "He will stay with us until the end of the season. We have a great squad and we have time to redeem ourselves." Massimo has presumably made this statement to buy his dad some time to prepare a nice speech for Sven-Goran's leaving do. Of course, we suppose he could be telling the truth as well, but come off it.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE FIVER'S INTERACTIVE ADVENT CALENDAR

Dec 6: click here

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

BOOKS, NOT KICKS

Hi there guys! It's Trendy Teacher Fiver here, and I'm all about getting today's young footballers to get down with learning. I always say that a good learn is like an Eagles record: it's laid back, it's cool, but it also teaches you something. If I can be honest, though, not every footballer agrees with me. Now that's groovy, each chicken has their own path and everything, but I just wish that some people would take the walkman of ignorance out of their ears and let knowledge in. Just like my closest bud, Aston Villa goalkeeper and England number three, David James.

You see, David is hip to the game. He knows that there's no point in building your body if you haven't got a muscly brain as well. So when Paolo Di Canio said in his autobiography - writing, I like it - that David was "a moron and a cretin", he didn't get mad, he got out a dictionary. Paolo got angry because David refused to shake his hand after a match last season. "This cretin would not shake my hand," Di Canio wrote. "At the end of the game it is the British way to shake hands, but by turning his back this moron, James, was sticking two fingers up to British sportsmanship."

But that criticism is inaccurate in its words - as David proved today. "Does this man not know the meaning of a cretin or a moron?" James told the Birmingham Evening Mail. "He clearly doesn't. A cretin suffers from a thyroid deficiency. It comes from an eighteenth-century French word and was initially directed at people living in the valleys of the Alps and the Pyrenees. In some cases it is said to lead to dwarfism - and I'm 6ft 5ins for heaven's sake. And as for being a moron, that is an adult person with a mental age of between eight and 12 years old. I'm no brainbox, but I think I'm more advanced than that." You certainly are David. Let's big up the books!!!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We have so much will and determination to win and if we can beat Lazio in Rome then we can beat anybody" - Apart from Leicester. Mark Viduka gets understandably carried away after last night's Big Cup win.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

REMOVABLE TRANSFERS

Not that the Fiver wants to do William Hague any favours (unless he's willing to slip us the odd monkey or two), but if he really wants to give full rein to his virulent, wrong-headed, belligerent Europhobia, he could do worse than have a pop at football's ongoing transfer saga. The last time we left it, the lovely Gordon Taylor had stormed out of talks with the mighty Transfer Taskforce because Fifa weren't paying him the blindest bit of notice. Today it looks as if things have turned on their head, like some sort of breakdancing monkey.

A meeting between the European Commission and the Taskforce has been postponed for a week, so as to allow Fifa to think up some new ideas. This development was revealed this morning, but only after Uefa's general secretary Gerhard Aigner, not to mention Manchester United director Maurice Watkins, had travelled to Brussels to talk turkey. Uefa were understandably pooped by this, especially when they thought it was the EC who had postponed the meeting, and only for a day.

The problem is that of the many parts that make up the Taskforce, the EC only legally recognise Fifa, and Uefa believe that Fifa are responsible for the lack of a resolution as yet. So Uefa weren't exactly impressed by reports that the delay is so as to allow Fifa to kiss and make up with Gord Taylor's Fifpro organisation. "We are dismayed and concerned about the postponement," said Uefa communications director Mike Lee. "But we will continue to work to reach a solution on this issue as soon as possible." Now if this is what happens to the transfer system, imagine what they'd do to the good old British breakfast?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Bids for Bayer Leverkusen defender Jens Nowotny are being rejected left, right and centre. Manchester United have had their £23m offer turned down, while Arsenal's £24.5m cheque has been snubbed by the German club.

Leeds will complete the loan signing of Robbie Keane from Internazionale within the next few days, according to Teamtalk. But Planet Football report that Charlton have claimed first option on Keane, in light of their "special relationship" with the San Siro club.

Fiorentina striker Predrag Mijatovic is the latest striker to be linked with Aston Villa.

Dave Jones could return to management with Stockport. The Daily Mail believes the former County boss is being lined up to replace beleaguered Edgeley Park incumbent Andy Kilner.

Tottenham have joined Sunderland in the chase for Norwegian international striker Thorstein Helstad.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Neil Lennon's representative Mel Stein has denied reports that the Leicester midfielder's proposed move to Celtic is dead. "People can say what they like at the moment, but the truth is that there are still ongoing discussions between the two clubs," said Stein. Meanwhile, Foxes boss Peter Taylor has insisted that Martin O'Neill will have to make an offer in excess of £5.7m for any deal to take place. "Celtic will have to increase their offer now that the original deadline has gone for our previous asking price," he said.

Motherwell manager Billy Davies has been awarded the Bank of Scotland manager of the month award for November.

Paul Gascoigne underwent a hernia operation today, which could rule him out of the Everton side for another six weeks.

Darren Jackson, Fitzroy Simpson and Kevin James have all been told that they can leave Hearts by new manager Craig Levein.

Udinese have taken the son of Brazil star Zico on trial. The 23-year-old midfielder Junior Coimbra will train with his father's former club for two weeks.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7.30pm) Listen to a bloke from Northern Ireland cheering on Sturm Graz.

webTitle: Hague calls Blair 'weak' on crime

fields.headline: Hague calls Blair 'weak' on crime
fields.standfirst:
Labour in power
Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Tory leader, William Hague, today accused the government of putting forward "cosmetic measures" in the Queen's speech  to cut crime.
fields.body:
The Tory leader, William Hague, today accused the government of putting forward "cosmetic measures" in the Queen's speech to cut crime.

In response to the slim, seven-minute, speech Mr Hague complained that there was "so little in it" he was surprised that the Queen had come to Westminster at all.

Ministers were hypocritical to claim that they would cut crime with measures such as fixed penalties for disorderly behaviour, a ban on drinking alcohol in the street and child curfew schemes since, said Mr Hague, crime had risen under Labour.

The new proposals merely "parroted" the contents of the government's first Queen's speech. And in a reversal of one of Tony Blair's own soundbites, Mr Hague said that the prime minister was "weak" on crime.

On measures to improve state education and the NHS, Mr Hague said the government was "all spin and no delivery".

In reply, Mr Blair said it was remarkable that Mr Hague "did not mention the economy".

The prime minister savaged the Tories' record in office, citing cuts in nurses' training, a failure to maintain school buildings and record levels of borrowing.

He said crime had doubled under the Conservatives but fallen under Labour.

The short Queen's speech has led many to speculate it will be the last before a spring general election.

Mr Blair mocked Mr Hague's prospects at the election and quoted a letter misdirected to the Labour chief whip from a senior Tory that said the party should play down its hopes so it could "claim great progress although we lost".

webTitle: Battle against discrimination failing due to high legal costs

fields.headline: Obstacles to equality
fields.standfirst: Battle against discrimination failing due to high legal costs
fields.trailText: Battle against discrimination failing due to high legal costs
fields.body:
The Disability Discrimination Act (DDA), which arrived on the statute books five years ago this month, has given unenforceable rights to people with disabilities, claims a new report which calls on government to change the mechanisms for tackling discrimination.

The complexity and exorbitant cost of bringing cases in the county court for discrimination in the provision of goods, services, facilities and premises makes it virtually impossible for disabled people to enforce their rights in these areas, concludes The Price of Justice, produced by the Royal National Institute for the Blind (RNIB).

Since the DDA came into force in 1996, more than 5,000 cases claiming discrimination at work have been taken to employment tribunals. In contrast, the RNIB knows of only 25 cases claiming discrimination in the provision of goods, services and facilities.

Since there is no evidence that disabled people face more discrimination at work than in the rest of their lives, the report attributes the disparity to the different ways that parts of the DDA are enforced. Employment cases go to employment tribunals - where it costs nothing to bring a claim and the risks of having costs awarded against an applicant are negligible. In contrast, claims against a shop manager for verbally abusing a disabled person, or a company for failing to produce bills in braille, would have to go through the county courts - an often complicated, costly process said by the RNIB to put most people off at the first hurdle.

In one case - brought against Margaret Hodge, minister for disabled people, for failing to send out in braille a copy of a disability rights task force report - the claimant withdrew because she was worried she might face huge bills.

"Disabled people are deterred from taking claims because the system is so complex and they could face enormous costs if they lose," says the report's author, Catherine Casserley, RNIB legal officer. As very few county court judges have ever dealt with a disability discrimination case or received any awareness training, she argues, the odds are stacked against the claimant.

If disabled people's rights are to mean more than the paper they are written on, says the RNIB, the government should allow employment tribunals to deal with cases involving goods, services, facilities and premises. But the Department for Education and Employment says it is "neither appropriate nor sensible" to extend the remit of employment tribunals. "These cases go beyond the expertise of employment tribunals," it says. "Judges and magistrates are receiving disability training and will become more accustomed to the act."

However, the disability rights commission (DRC), the independent body created alongside the DDA to promote the rights of disabled people, acknowledges there is a problem with the county courts. Next month, the commission will introduce a conciliation service designed to tackle discrimination cases outside the courtroom.

The DRC is also working to challenge prejudice by raising awareness of disabled issues among the general public. Next week, Tony Blair is due to launch a short film, Talk, as the centrepiece of the commission's first major campaign, Action Speaks Louder Than Words.

In Talk, the main character, played by television actor Jonathan Kerrigan, has his negative preconceptions of disability shattered when he goes on a date with a girl who turns out to be in a wheelchair. She takes him to a nightclub full of people with disabilities, where he finds he is the minority in a disability-friendly world.

Bert Massie, chair of the DRC, says: "Using a dramatic film storyline is a deliberate departure from traditional campaigns on disability issues. Public appeals for greater understanding of disability are often well received, but rarely translate into specific action."

webTitle: Charity fares better than dot.com namesake

fields.headline: Charity fares better than dot.com namesake
fields.standfirst: A charity which sends accountants to developing countries has been a huge success - but still needs more financial support
fields.trailText: Mango, a charity which sends accountants to developing countries has been a huge success - but now needs extra financial support. Nicola Hill reports
fields.body:
A start up charity that has fared better than its namesake dot.com is now looking for more help.

Mango is a charity that sends accountants to developing countries to support relief programmes - far removed from the fortunes of namesake clickmango.com, a natural health website which folded earlier this year.

The charity was established in 1999 and has grown much faster than originally planned. It now has accountants working around the world, including in Kosovo, the Congo, East Timor and India. The charity's director, Alex Jacobs, said: "There has been a dramatic increase in demand for Mango's financial services from agencies like Christian Aid and Oxfam."

However, like the dot.com world, it is suffering from lack of funds. Mr Jacobs explained: "We received initial start up funding and charge modest fees from the service we provide but we now need to appeal for donations from individuals."

The charity has launched a Christmas appeal and is particularly targeting accountants who don't want to give up time to work in the field but can dip into their pockets.

The charity now has 55 people on its register and placed eight overseas. Accountants are sent out on short-term contracts and paid a UK salary by the host charity. Mango administers the scheme, which has so far had more than 500 applicants.

webTitle: Granada wins court battle to interview Jodie and Mary parents

fields.headline: Granada wins court battle to interview Jodie and Mary parents
fields.trailText: 5pm: Granada TV has won the right to broadcast an interview with the parents of the conjoined twins Jodie and Mary, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
Granada TV today won the right to broadcast an interview with the parents of the conjoined twins Jodie and Mary.

The high court in London partially lifted a strict publicity ban, allowing the couple to be identified. They are Michaelangelo and Rina Attard from the Mediterranean island of Gozo.

Mr and Mrs Attard, who have already recorded parts of a programme for Tonight with Trevor McDonald, agreed to the application, which was heard by Dame Elizabeth Butler-Sloss, president of the family division.

Under the new order, three doctors involved in the care of the pair which culminated in an operation to save Jodie's life at the cost of Mary's, can also be named and interviewed.

But the ban on approaching the hospital where the operation took place remains in force, as does the injunction which protects the identity of Jodie.

The Guardian revealed last month that Granada agreed to pay the twins' parents about £150,000 for the interview. The money will go towards the long-term care of the surviving twin.

The father, 44, and mother, 29, have been interviewed by Martin Bashir and the programme will be broadcast on ITV in the next few weeks.

It is likely that the edition will attract the most attention since Tonight screened an interview with the five youths suspected of murdering the black teenager Stepehn Lawrence.

A spokesman for Granada said: "No final decision has yet been made, but we expect the programme to go out before Christmas."

Three doctors, Adrian Bianchi, Mike Maresh and Alan Dickson, will also appear in the documentary.

The plight of the twins and their parents made headlines around the world after the high court ruled last August that the operation could go ahead. Mary, who depended upon Jodie's heart and lungs for life, died after the operation.

webTitle: Anti-abuse projects making a difference

fields.headline: No child's play
fields.standfirst: Amid growing awareness of sexual abuse between siblings,  Linda Jackson  reports on projects making a difference
fields.trailText: Amid growing awareness of sexual abuse between siblings, Linda Jackson reports on projects making a difference
fields.body:
Sarah was looking forward to seeing her two young children after a hard day's work at the office. But her joy at spending the evening with them turned to dismay when she discovered that her four-year-old daughter, Sally, had been sexually abused. Equally shocking was the revelation that the abuser was her six-year-old son, Nigel. His behaviour emerged only when Sally told her mother she didn't like playing doctors any more. Asked why, she replied: "I don't like it when Nigel examines me and gives me operations."

Sadly, Nigel and his sister's case is far from unique. Recent research shows that sexual abuse and inappropriate sexual behaviour between young siblings is far more common than abuse by other family members such as fathers and stepfathers. What is new is that local authorities and child protection charities are starting to concentrate on this area of abuse after more than a decade when adult men have been cast as the villains.

In Nigel's case, an investigation by social services found that his mother's previous partner had often been violent towards the whole family and had forced Sarah into sexual behaviour in front of the children.

The young boy was assessed and his mother agreed to a pioneering programme of work with Warwickshire's "sexualised inappropriate behaviour service" (Sibs). Work took place over the next six months with the family. This involved counselling and help with parent skills for the mother, and joint play work with the children to help them talk through their experience and develop appropriate behaviour.

That was 18 months ago. Social services support for the family has now been withdrawn. But Warwickshire social services department is still running Sibs - one of the few local authorities specialising in this area - amid growing recognition that sexual abuse of children by children is one of the most common forms of sexual abuse.

Only last month, a report by the NSPCC challenged the widespread belief that fathers are chiefly responsible for sexual abuse of children. A survey of the childhood experiences of 2,869 young people aged 18-24 found that abuse by brothers or stepbrothers was twice as common as that by a father or stepfather.

The findings were splashed across the newspapers, and commentators predicted that the findings would trigger a major change in approach to sexual abuse in the family. But probation officers and social workers say awareness of sibling abuse has been growing for years. Interviews with adult sex offenders have revealed a cycle of abuse, with offenders starting their abuse in their early teens after being the victim of sexual or physical assaults. However, experts admit it is only now that therapeutic work with young abusers is being offered as a specialist service.

Driven by a real desire to break this predatory pattern of abuse, Andrew Durham, a senior social worker, set up the project in Warwickshire. What began as a joint health and social services initiative has developed into a permanent specialistassessment and treatment service that has been hailed by the government's social services inspectorate as an example of good practice.

Figures show the high demand for the service, which works sympathetically with young people to retrain and redirect their sexual behaviour. Between 1998 and 1999, Sibs dealt with 62 cases of sexually inappropriate behaviour and child sexual abuse - ranging from over-sexualised five-year-olds, to sexually abusive 11-year-olds and 14-year-old rapists. Three in four referrals were for children aged 10 and over. Ninety per cent of children referred to the project were boys. Most of the victims were female.

The story of Nigel and Sally, in which Nigel tried to simulate sexual intercourse, is drawn from actual cases worked on by Sibs. Most children referred to the project are older. One typical case involved two families where a young teenage boy from one family was found playing "sexual" games with a younger boy and girl from another. Interviews revealed the teenager had been using his father's collection of pornography and was being bullied at school. He was given a police caution following his family's agreement to work with Sibs - work which took place over 12 months. The children in the other family were also offered help and support from the local social services children's team.

The age of the children referred for help may vary - but most share a vulnerability, according to Mr Durham, who has received an advanced award in social work in recognition of his work on the project. "Young people who abuse often have very difficult problems in their lives, which they are unable to deal with in the ways most people do," he says. "They often have experiences of being powerless, of being put down. They want to feel more powerful. For boys, in a distorted way, it reinforces their feelings of being male."

An analysis of cases seen in 1998 shows that 80% of children had family problems. Of these, 54% had been sexually abused, 45% were in care, 28% were physically abused and 42% were emotionally abused. More than half (52%) had problems at school.

Cases are referred to Sibs through the police, social services or schools. An assessment is made of the child or young person and of their willingness to work with the project. An assessment of the family is also made and the social worker makes every effort to work with the parents, who may be angry or in denial. Part of the Sibs work involves setting up a network of people, including the family, to support the young person. They are given practical guidelines to help prevent opportunities where the young person might abuse again.If the young person agrees to work with Sibs, a sexual history is taken. Boys who may want a macho image are taught to be assertive, rather than aggressive.

A similar approach is taken in Oxfordshire, where the Oxfordshire young abusers' project (Oxyap) has been treating young people for the past four years. It runs alongside the Ark - a separate initiative specialising in treating younger children, run by charity NCH Action For Children. So far this year, Oxyap has had 20 referrals and there is now a waiting list for assessments that can run to several weeks. The project has just been awarded £10,000 government funding which will be used to increase staff and reduce waiting times.

Charities such as ChildLine, which every year receives thousands of calls from victims of child abuse, want to see more local authorities offering these specialist services. "Research shows you can identify children who are abusing sexually and may go on to become an adult abuser, so positive work like this is very helpful," says Hereward Harrison, ChildLine's director of policy. "The younger they are identified the better. This can stop the horror and the devastation that comes from a career of abuse which ultimately ends with the abuser in prison."

For Andrew Durham, the message is simple. "If you can work with a person and change their development, you could be preventing quite a large number of future victims," he says. "Our work has only just begun. There will continue to be thousands more victims until every social services departments includes these preventative measures in their child protection policies."

 Sibs is on 01926-813110; Oxyap is on 01865-221201.

webTitle: Which type of internet bank is best?

fields.headline: Which type of internet bank is best?
fields.trailText: There is a debate as to which type of internet bank, standalone or cyberbranch, provides the best value.
fields.body:
There is a debate as to which type of internet bank, standalone or cyberbranch, provides the best value.

The existing banks, which provide online banking as an additional service, say standalone banks such as smile and egg are operating at loss creating rates.

They say that as more and more customers join these banks to take advantage of higher interest rates, the rates will become increasingly difficult to sustain and the banks will be paying out more than they expected.

Standard advice when buying any financial product is to check the financial history of the providers. Look at the long term performance of the banks before choosing.

Of course, as relatively new start-ups, the standalone banks will not have long term performance figures.

In addition, consumer groups say it is very easy to make a mistake on the internet. For example, when transferring £1,000, you might press the 0 too many times and transfer £10,000.

It will then be your responsibility to contact whoever the £10,000 was transferred to in order to get it back.

webTitle: The disadvantages of internet banking

fields.headline: The disadvantages of internet banking
fields.trailText: Security is by far the biggest concern surrounding internet banks, with consumers worrying that hackers will get into their account and spend their money.
fields.body:
Security is by far the biggest concern surrounding internet banks, with consumers worrying that hackers will get into their account and spend their money.

Banks are adamant that the sites are secure, but while there have been no reports of large-scale theft, there have been plenty about unwitting surfers stumbling across peoples' details.

Consumer groups have asked the bank to provide a guarantee, similar to the Direct Debit guarantee, promising to return any funds straight away and investigate afterwards.

So far the banks have refused, raising suspicions that they don't trust their own security systems. After all, if they did, they would have no qualms about providing the guarantee, the consumer groups say.

The biggest day to day problem with internet banking appears to be access.

You might find it difficult to get on to the internet at certain times of day - weekday evenings are the most popular.

The speed with which you access your account will also depend on the amount of memory your computer has or the speed of your modem.

And if your computer crashes completely you will have to resort to the telephone or branch until it is back up.

In addition, your bank may need to shut down its website for maintenance from time to time.

Here, the existing banks have the advantage over the standalone banks, as telephone support is free and most have branches on the high street.

High street banks also have the advantage of being able to offer face to face support and advice, which some people find useful

If you intend to access your account through a company computer, you may need to ask your system administrator first, especially if your company operates a firewall.

Some of the banks cannot operate on Apple Macintosh computers, so check that yours is compatible.

You will also need to have the relevant operating system, typically Windows 95, 98 or NT, and the right system browser, usually Microsoft Internet Explorer 4 or above or Netscape Navigator 4 or above.

However, banks may update the browser they use from time to time, which means you will have to update as well if you want to access your account. Updating your browser is free, it just requires time and effort.

It is also worth remembering that these systems can use up a lot of memory so the more your computer has the better. You might want to think about buying additional memory.

webTitle: The benefits of internet banking

fields.headline: The benefits of internet banking
fields.trailText: The most obvious benefit of internet banking is convenience. You do your banking when you want to, 24 hours a day, seven days a week, saving time and effort.
fields.body:
The most obvious benefit of internet banking is convenience. You do your banking when you want to, 24 hours a day, seven days a week, saving time and effort.

Internet banking should also help you keep more up to date with your finances because transactions are updated on the screen in real time.

If you pay in a cheque, the money will show on your computer at the same time as it shows on the bank's computer, usually within three to four days.

But internal bank transactions should be recorded instantly.

If you're overdrawn on your current account and the cash machines won't give you any money, you can log into your savings account, transfer the required amount and then go straight back out to get it from the cash point.

With many banks, you can programme your account to pay bills at specified dates in the future. So you can go on holiday and not worry about getting your phone cut off.

Similarly, some of the banks let you download your account information from the internet into a number of financial software packages such as Microsoft Money 99.

webTitle: How does internet banking work?

fields.headline: How does internet banking work?
fields.trailText: Websites differ slightly from bank to bank, but managing your finances online should be as simple as logging on to the bank's website and entering you user ID and password. The site will then guide you through the transactions you want to carry out.
fields.body:
Websites differ slightly from bank to bank, but managing your finances online should be as simple as logging on to the bank's website and entering you user ID and password. The site will then guide you through the transactions you want to carry out.

Some standalone banks, such as Smile and Egg prefer to communicate with you by email. They will, for example, send you an email when your statements are ready. And if you have an enquiry or want to order a statement, you are encouraged to email them.

Telephone support is likely to be expensive as the idea behind these banks is that by doing everything on the internet they dramatically reduce overheads and pass the savings on to you.

Other standalone banks, IF and Cahoot, being the prime examples, offer telephone support free of charge.

webTitle: Full text: the Queen's speech

fields.headline: The Queen's speech
fields.standfirst: Queen's speech offers slim agenda
fields.trailText: My Lords and members of the Commons.
fields.body:
My Lords and members of the Commons.

My government will continue to pursue its central economic objective of high and stable levels of growth and employment. My government will ensure the continued economic stability which has enabled it to increase the resources available for education, health, transport, and police services. My government will reflect these policies in its Finance Bill.

This is my government's fourth legislative programme. My government's main Bills for the coming Session will focus on improving public services and cutting crime.

My government also plans other major Bills and other significant initiatives, particularly in secondary education with the creation of more specialist schools, urban school reform and improved teaching in the early years of secondary education.

My government is determined to combat all aspects of crime to protect all members of our society. My government will introduce legislation to modernise and improve law enforcement by, for example, tackling disorderly conduct. Legislation will be introduced to regulate the private security industry.

A Bill will be introduced to cut vehicle crime, reduce opportunities to dispose of stolen vehicles, and extend the time limit for prosecution for vehicle theft.

A Bill will be published in draft to increase powers against money laundering and make it easier to recover the proceeds of crime.

The Bill to give Courts themselves the power to decide whether certain defendants should be tried by jury or by magistrates, will be re-introduced.

Legislation will also be brought forward to reduce benefit fraud. This will enable more information to be obtained to prevent fraud and will provide power to withdraw or reduce benefits where a person has twice been convicted of benefit fraud.

My government remains committed to the founding principles of the National Health Service. My government's NHS Plan showed how it would take forward further reform of health services to improve standards. Legislation will be introduced to support many of the commitments in the Plan, in particular to improve the performance of the NHS. The legislation will also take forward my government's response to the Royal Commission on Long Term Care for the Elderly.

A Bill will be brought forward to ban the advertising and promotion of tobacco products.

My government continues to attach the highest importance to improving education. It has already secured a number of changes to the law to further this end, including legislation to reform the training of teachers, to secure improved school standards and to create the Learning and Skills Councils. My government will introduce a Bill to improve the framework for meeting special educational needs and access to learning for disabled people. During the new Session, my government will continue to work to improve standards in education.

Legislation will be introduced to extend the functions of the Children's Commissioner for Wales, to provide better protection for children in Wales.

A Bill will be introduced to increase the effectiveness of the power to reduce regulatory burdens by removing inappropriate and over-complex regulation.

Legislation will be brought forward to ease the process of buying and selling homes, and to improve the protection given to homeless people. Progress will also be made on the purchase of freeholds by leaseholders, and on commonhold, a new form of tenure for flatowners.

Members of the House of Commons,

Estimates for the Public Service will be laid before you.

My Lords and member of the House of Commons,

A Bill will be introduced to enable a free vote to take place on the future of hunting with dogs.

My government has appointed Lord Cullen to head an Inquiry into safety on our railways. A Bill will be drafted to provide for safer travel on the railways, in the air, at sea and on the roads, and will take forward proposals for revitalising health and safety at work.

A draft Bill will be published to improve the transparency of export controls and to establish their purpose.

In Northern Ireland, my government will continue to work closely with the political parties and the Irish government to secure the full implementation of the Good Friday Agreement. A Bill will be published in draft on the implementation of the recommendations of the review of the Criminal Justice System in Northern Ireland.

My government is committed to making devolution in Scotland and Wales work and to continuing the process of decentralising government in the interests of all the people in the United Kingdom.

A Bill will be introduced to maintain the legislation relating to the Armed Forces for the next five years.

Other measures will be laid before you.

My Lords and member of the House of Commons,

The Duke of Edinburgh and I look forward to our State Visit to Norway.

My government will continue to work with our partners to shape the future of the European Union. It will work for rapid progress on the enlargement negotiations, and for reform of the institutions of the European Union to prepare them for a wider membership.

My government will continue to ensure that NATO remains the foundation of Britain's defence and security. My government will continue to work to make the United Nations Security Council more effective and representative. It will support efforts to improve the United Nations' capacity to undertake peace keeping operations.

A White Paper will be published outlining how my government will work to shape the forces of globalization to benefit the world's poor.

My government believes that those who commit crimes against humanity should be brought to justice. It will introduce a Bill to enable the UK to ratify the statute of the International Criminal Court.

My Lords and member of the House of Commons,

I pray that the blessing of Almighty God may rest upon your counsels.

fields.bodyText: My Lords and members of the Commons. My government will continue to pursue its central economic objective of high and stable levels of growth and employment. My government will ensure the continued economic stability which has enabled it to increase the resources available for education, health, transport, and police services. My government will reflect these policies in its Finance Bill. This is my government's fourth legislative programme. My government's main Bills for the coming Session will focus on improving public services and cutting crime. My government also plans other major Bills and other significant initiatives, particularly in secondary education with the creation of more specialist schools, urban school reform and improved teaching in the early years of secondary education. My government is determined to combat all aspects of crime to protect all members of our society. My government will introduce legislation to modernise and improve law enforcement by, for example, tackling disorderly conduct. Legislation will be introduced to regulate the private security industry. A Bill will be introduced to cut vehicle crime, reduce opportunities to dispose of stolen vehicles, and extend the time limit for prosecution for vehicle theft. A Bill will be published in draft to increase powers against money laundering and make it easier to recover the proceeds of crime. The Bill to give Courts themselves the power to decide whether certain defendants should be tried by jury or by magistrates, will be re-introduced. Legislation will also be brought forward to reduce benefit fraud. This will enable more information to be obtained to prevent fraud and will provide power to withdraw or reduce benefits where a person has twice been convicted of benefit fraud. My government remains committed to the founding principles of the National Health Service. My government's NHS Plan showed how it would take forward further reform of health services to improve standards. Legislation will be introduced to support many of the commitments in the Plan, in particular to improve the performance of the NHS. The legislation will also take forward my government's response to the Royal Commission on Long Term Care for the Elderly. A Bill will be brought forward to ban the advertising and promotion of tobacco products. My government continues to attach the highest importance to improving education. It has already secured a number of changes to the law to further this end, including legislation to reform the training of teachers, to secure improved school standards and to create the Learning and Skills Councils. My government will introduce a Bill to improve the framework for meeting special educational needs and access to learning for disabled people. During the new Session, my government will continue to work to improve standards in education. Legislation will be introduced to extend the functions of the Children's Commissioner for Wales, to provide better protection for children in Wales. A Bill will be introduced to increase the effectiveness of the power to reduce regulatory burdens by removing inappropriate and over-complex regulation. Legislation will be brought forward to ease the process of buying and selling homes, and to improve the protection given to homeless people. Progress will also be made on the purchase of freeholds by leaseholders, and on commonhold, a new form of tenure for flatowners. Members of the House of Commons, Estimates for the Public Service will be laid before you. My Lords and member of the House of Commons, A Bill will be introduced to enable a free vote to take place on the future of hunting with dogs. My government has appointed Lord Cullen to head an Inquiry into safety on our railways. A Bill will be drafted to provide for safer travel on the railways, in the air, at sea and on the roads, and will take forward proposals for revitalising health and safety at work. A draft Bill will be published to improve the transparency of export controls and to establish their purpose. In Northern Ireland, my government will continue to work closely with the political parties and the Irish government to secure the full implementation of the Good Friday Agreement. A Bill will be published in draft on the implementation of the recommendations of the review of the Criminal Justice System in Northern Ireland. My government is committed to making devolution in Scotland and Wales work and to continuing the process of decentralising government in the interests of all the people in the United Kingdom. A Bill will be introduced to maintain the legislation relating to the Armed Forces for the next five years. Other measures will be laid before you. My Lords and member of the House of Commons, The Duke of Edinburgh and I look forward to our State Visit to Norway. My government will continue to work with our partners to shape the future of the European Union. It will work for rapid progress on the enlargement negotiations, and for reform of the institutions of the European Union to prepare them for a wider membership. My government will continue to ensure that NATO remains the foundation of Britain's defence and security. My government will continue to work to make the United Nations Security Council more effective and representative. It will support efforts to improve the United Nations' capacity to undertake peace keeping operations. A White Paper will be published outlining how my government will work to shape the forces of globalization to benefit the world's poor. My government believes that those who commit crimes against humanity should be brought to justice. It will introduce a Bill to enable the UK to ratify the statute of the International Criminal Court. My Lords and member of the House of Commons, I pray that the blessing of Almighty God may rest upon your counsels. webTitle: Queen's speech: the main points

fields.headline: Queen's speech: the main points
fields.standfirst: Queen's speech: the text in full
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's government today unveiled its agenda in the run-up to the general election. The Queen's speech, delivered to the House of Lords, contains 15 main Bills and four draft pieces of legislation. Here are some of the main points in the programme.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's government today unveiled its agenda in the run-up to the general election. The Queen's speech, delivered to the House of Lords, contains 15 main Bills and four draft pieces of legislation. Here are some of the main points in the programme.

Crime
 Fixed penalties for offences of disorderly behaviour in public places
 Police to be able to shut down rowdy pubs and clubs
 A ban on drinking alcohol in the street
 Child curfew schemes for those aged nine to 15
 New powers for police to seize the assets of criminals, especially targeting drug barons

Health
 A fund of £500m is to be made available to the best-run NHS trusts immediately and to others under strict supervision
 Public-private partnerships are planned in an effort to improve primary health care - such as GP services - particularly in inner cities
 More health professionals will be allowed to prescribe drugs
 The NHS will become responsible for paying nursing care costs in homes
 The promotion and advertising of tobacco will be banned

Education
 New moves to improve literacy and numeracy for 11 to 14 year-olds
 A major drive to improve adult literacy.

Bureaucracy
 Red tape will be swept away in more than 20 areas
 Fire regulations are to be simplified
 Pubs and restaurants will be allowed to open later.
 Restaurants are to be allowed to remain open without providing live entertainment
 From next year pubs will be allowed to stay open later on New Year's Eve.

Buying a home
 Sellers will be required to compile a special pack for purchasers, including a survey report and details such as planning consents and title documents.

Bloodsports
 The long-awaited Hunting Bill will be brought forward this session. MPs will get a free vote, when they can choose between an almost total ban on hunting with dogs; a compulsory regulatory system forcing hunts to obtain licences; or a voluntary system of regulation.

Transport

 A draft Safety Bill will cover rail safety measures recommended by Lord Cullen in his inquiry into the Paddington rail crash
 It will also raise port and maritime safety standards
 Drug and alcohol misuse by staff will also be addressed

Arms control
 Export controls are to be made clearer
 The government will attempt to curb the proliferation of weapons, particularly light weapons and small arms.
 Proposals for controls on trafficking and brokering in weapons
 Existing controls on chemical, biological and nuclear weapons will be tightened

Social security
 A Fraud Bill will give the government the power to withdraw or reduce benefit from anybody convicted twice of a benefit offence within three years.
 The Department of Social Security will have powers to offer a fine of between £1,000 and £5,000 as an alternative to prosecution in less serious cases of employers colluding with their employees to commit benefit fraud.

webTitle: Divided reaction to Queen's speech

fields.headline: Divided reaction to Queen's speech
fields.standfirst: Full text of Queen's speech
fields.trailText: Reaction on today's Queen speech from politicians and authorities on the key issues.
fields.body:
Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, dismissed the crime measures as "pre-election puff" and argued many would fail to see the light of day.

She said: "They continue a long tradition of large announcements followed by zero implementation. Labour introduced child curfew orders and trumpeted them as a great flagship and in the past two years there has been not a single curfew issued. Furthermore it is ludicrous to go on loading police with more initiatives when they have fewer officers."

Peter Gammon, president of the Police Superintendent's Association, said he was delighted that crime was at the forefront of the speech.

He said: "I think that yob culture is endemic and we need strong measures and mechanisms to deal with it. We have to improve the quality of life for people, remove the fear of crime. Part of this is brought about by yobbish behaviour and minor crime but we need to use these measures to rebuild the fabric of our community."

Fred Broughton, chairman of the Police Federation, said his members were encouraged that tackling crime was at the heart of the speech. But he dismissed the speech as a "pre-election attempt" to allay fears about the state of law and order. He said: "We are saddened by the state of policing today."

The Association of Chief Police Officers was also sceptical of the practical implementation of some of the measures. A spokesman said: "We need to make sure that when the Bills come forward they are workable. I refer in particular to the practicality of curfews."

Harry Fletcher, assistant general secretary of the National Association of Probation Officers, said the new legislation was purely reactive, and failed to tackle the causes of the so-called yob culture. He said: "These are reactive measures that don't deal with the causes of criminal activity. The problems will only be transferred somewhere else under these measures. The curb on noisy pubs will just mean the trouble-makers move on to somewhere else; the curfew on street activity will just move people on to other streets which are less heavily policed.

"The child curfews are flawed in principle. They target geographic areas rather than problem individuals and risk being discriminatory. They could end up alienating all youngsters against the police."

Mike Ashley, director of community safety at the Local Government Association, said social services departments had been wary of using curfews against young children.

He said: "There have been concerns about whether they are the right mechanism to use for such young children. But the child curfew order is a valuable tool in the toolbox for local authorities and police. It is an extremely sensitive area and we will need to examine the proposals in detail."

Sue Anderson, spokeswoman for the Council of Mortgage Lenders, said new measures to speed up the buying and selling of homes are not ready to become law.

She said: "The pilot study was in no way a clear enough indicator that the sellers' pack will work. What we are looking for from the government is further work so that when it is introduced it will be workable and of value. The house condition report is the point which is causing us the most concern as it is still unclear who should be employed to carry it out. More work is needed."

However, she said the council welcomed other plans to scrap the current system of leaseholds on many homes in multi-occupier developments.

Dennis Skinner, Labour MP for Bolsover, said: "Tell her to read the Guardian" as MPs were summoned by the Black Rod to hear the Queen's Speech in the Lords, in a reference to today's main feature A challenge to the crown.

Officials at the Rail Maritime and Transport union welcomed plans to improve safety on the railways and tackle alcohol and drug use by transport workers with a Safety Bill. A spokesman said: "The days following the Hatfield derailment showed there were massive gaps in safety responsibility while the drive for profit intervenes. We hope this will be rectified in the Bill."

webTitle: BA to cut 1000 jobs

fields.headline: BA to cut 1000 jobs
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Airline to shut down routes out of Gatwick
fields.body:
British Airways is to cut 1,000 jobs over the next two years and restructuring its operations out of Gatwick airport. The airline said it planned to reduce significantly longhaul flights out of London's second airport, reducing the number of destinations from 43 to around 25.

The shorthaul business will be refocused to concentrate on serving the needs of London and south east England, with less emphasis on providing services that feed into longhaul flights.

"The steps we are announcing today should improve our group profitability and ensure British Airways has a long-term viable future as Gatwick's leading airline," said chief executive Rod Eddington.

He said the restructuring was necessary to make BA's operation profitable at Gatwick.

Union leaders expressed disappointment at the scale of the job losses but said they were relieved that redundancies will be voluntary.

Roger Maskell, national officer of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, said: "We regret any job losses, but it is important to see the wider picture.

"We are working very hard with BA to sustain success and job security."

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB, said: "We are very concerned at the level of job losses and will be monitoring the situation very closely.

"But we are pleased there will be no compulsory redundancies and that jobs are to be created at Heathrow in the near future."

webTitle: Parents: Play on teenage pregnancy

fields.headline: Drama out of a crisis
fields.standfirst: Playwright Gill Adams has written a monologue about the grim realities of teenage pregnancy. And who plays the role? Her own daughter, Lucy
fields.trailText: Playwright Gill Adams has written a monologue about the grim realities of teenage pregnancy. And who plays the role? Her own daughter, Lucy.
fields.body:
A snowy night in Hull. Maria, a 14-year-old schoolgirl, stands on a hill shivering. In her arms she holds Robbie, her newborn baby, wrapped in her school coat and named after Robbie Williams. She didn't realise that babies came out before they were fully grown, but of one thing she is sure: she cannot take Robbie home.

She knows because she has worked it all out. She sees her world for what it is and knows that it is not good enough for her baby. Her mother is the "Queen of Misery" and her father is "King Bastard Kong". She hates the way he has stopped loving her mother and enjoys saying no to her when she asks for something nice.

Maria knows that if she takes her baby home, suddenly everyone will start asking questions and looking for someone to blame. She knows the other kids at school will call her a "slag", and the press will hound her parents and want to know why she kept it a secret.

Maria has had her baby alone. She cut the cord with her dad's penknife. She finds the skip outside the old church that they are turning into a pub and she lays Robbie down to sleep on an old mattress. She tells him who she is and the reason she can't keep him. Then she puts on her favourite lipstick, the one that tastes of toffee apples, and kisses him on his little nose and cheeks. She leaves him her "toffee apple kisses".

When she gets home, she puts on her headphones and listens to Robbie Williams singing about loving angels. She is just loving her Robbie instead.

The newspapers have a field day with the story: Baby Dumped in Skip. Maria's mother tells her it is too sad to bear, that whoever the mother is, she must be missing him something terrible and yet Maria still cannot tell her the truth. Her dad shouts at the telly and says she must be a slag and the poor bastard is better off without her. Maria has to go to the bathroom and put toilet roll in her bra because her milk is coming.

A cold November day in Hull. Lucy, my teenage daughter, is playing the part of Maria. We are standing on top of Park Street Bridge in gale force winds. The rain lashes at Lucy's face as she shouts, spits and shivers out her lines: "I know me mam was thinking about his balls ... I know she wants to burst 'em, squash, stamp and rip 'em apart like he does her heart, 'cos she's sick of his face. She's sick of his body and she's sick of his mind, she's sick of his hate and anger and his big bastard ways ..." As she finishes, a train passes under the bridge and a seagull cries overhead. This is why I love radio: a scene like that comes at you from all directions and is so visual.

My heart felt as though it would burst with pride: we all realised why it would have been really tricky for any young actress to have done this piece. I wrote it in reaction to a series of "schoolgirl mum shock" headlines: the sort of stories that seem to focus on statistics rather than individuals, so remote from all the heartache that must have been involved. I wrote Crush with Lucy in mind because that gave me licence to dig deeper and tell it like it is - from what it felt like when Maria's boyfriend, Darren, shoved his thing in her, to wanting to kill her dad for making her mum go down on him when he was pissed.

You may be thinking that I was asking my daughter to do something other mothers would not allow their daughters to do; maybe you are right. My daughter, Lucy, is 17. We live in Hull, and she studies performing arts at Wyke sixth-form college. Ours is not a perfect relationship. It hasn't always been easy. We have struggled financially for most of her life and that is because I am a writer. She understands that it is more of a calling than a job, but it is not always easy living with a mother who lives in her head. We bicker and annoy each other like most mothers and daughters, but we also laugh and she knows I love her to pieces.

I have always written raw, realistic material; Lucy helps by reading my work out loud so that I can hear it off the page. She has read every kind of part, from a prostitute to a refugee child. She knows the rhythms and the reasons behind my sentences. Living in Hull, we see and hear most things and I have never tried to hide the hard bits from Lucy. Suddenly hearing my daughter easily falling into character made me think, "My God, she really knows this world so well. What else does she know that she's not telling me?"

But for all our honesty with each other, Lucy has told me that every teenage kid at some time does some thing really bad that they can't tell their parents about. Why? Usually because they know it will get them into big trouble or that their parents won't understand: they will overreact and ground them, blame their friends and never trust them again. When Lucy confesses to doing something she shouldn't have, it usually means that it has become too big for her to cope with.

When I ask her why she has left it so long to tell me, she always says the same thing: you're so busy; or I know you've got problems of your own, the bills, the deadlines ... Teenagers are old enough to observe our lives and worry about us as much as we do about them.

Lucy told me once that I was weak because I was depressed. I told her that I was finding life tough. She responded by telling me that a close friend of hers was still having nightmares after having witnessed a woman jump from a high-rise flat and land virtually at his feet; that a 15-year-old boy from her school was thinking about running away from the hostel he had been put in because his mother was a drug addict; that her best friend was at this minute sitting outside a maternity wing because a 16-year-old girl he had had a fling with was having a baby and she thinks he might be the dad; and that her own boyfriend, who is 17, had to leave the army earlier this year because he was bullied.

She sees her world for what it is and knows that it is not good enough for her baby. Her mother is the "Queen of Misery" and her father is "King Bastard Kong". She hates the way he has stopped loving her mother and enjoys saying no to her when she asks for something nice. Maria knows that if she takes her baby home, suddenly everyone will start asking questions and looking for someone to blame. She knows the other kids at school will call her a "slag", and the press will hound her parents and want to know why she kept it a secret. Maria has had her baby alone. webTitle: Parents: Why do children carry knives?

fields.headline: Armed and dangerous
fields.standfirst: An alarming number of children are now carrying knives. Neil McKeganey explains why weapons appeal to young people
fields.trailText: An alarming number of children are now carrying knives. Neil McKeganey explains why weapons appeal to young people.
fields.body:
To many of us, the idea of going to work each day packing a knife along with our sandwiches and office papers would be ridiculous and, probably, alarming. Among young people, however, carrying a weapon is neither absurd nor uncommon.

Recent research by the University of Glasgow found that more than a third of boys and nearly 10% of girls aged 11 to 16 had carried a weapon in the past. The research also showed that knives were the most popular weapon carried by young people.

Carrying a weapon is not, of course, the same thing as using a weapon, but why do young people feel the need to carry a weapon in the first place?

For some young people, carrying a weapon is a way of making them feel safe. Learning a martial art may be a more socially acceptable way of dealing with anxieties about being attacked, but it takes too long to reach a level where it is effective. Picking up a knife takes only seconds and the effect can be that much more dramatic. The trouble with carrying a weapon, though, even if there is no intention to use it, is that it is like nuclear deterrence theory writ small: it inevitably leads to an arms race.

For many, carrying a knife is not about managing their own fear but instilling it in others. It is a way of pushing yourself up the hierarchy of teenage hard cases.

To older children, knives are also a signifier of the adult world. I can remember, as a child, being fascinated by displays of knives in shop windows. School trips abroad always seemed to result in one or other of my peers revealing a flick knife or, more impressively, a stiletto smuggled back into the country. Nobody intended to stab anybody; we were just fascinated by a forbidden but risky toy.

But a knife is now the weapon of choice for many involved in dealing illegal drugs. In the Glasgow research, young people who had carried a weapon were much more likely to have used drugs than their peers, and those who had used more drugs tended to have carried more weapons. The link with drugs is one of the most worrying aspects of the increase in weapon-carrying by young people.

There is clearly a need to educate young people about what can happen when you stick even a short blade into a human body. But this could also create anxiety in other young people about their safety, and so encourage them tto carry weapons.

We need to recognise that the carrying of weapons by young people is largely about our failure to create a safe environment for them. If we leave young people to come up with the solution to their fears, can we be all that surprised if the answer they come up with only serves to make the problem worse?

The idea of carrying a weapon to work seems absurd to adults because we know there are better ways of responding to disputes than by taking direct, violent action ourselves. We put our faith in the institutions of conflict resolution and, even if these fail, we still know that carrying a weapon and threatening others is wrong. Young people, though, are too often left alone to face intimidation.

By failing to protect young people, it is we who are ultimately responsible for the increase in weapons-carrying that we are now seeing in many of our inner-city areas.

 The author is professor of drug misuse research at the University of Glasgow.

webTitle: Arts: Illustrator Quentin Blake

fields.headline: Blake's heaven
fields.standfirst: Illustrator Quentin Blake is still bringing Roald Dahl's characters to life - on stage as well as on the page. Markie Robson-Scott meets him
fields.trailText: Illustrator Quentin Blake is still bringing Roald Dahl's characters to life - on stage as well as on the page. Markie Robson-Scott meets him.
fields.body:
Quentin Blake does not have children. Nor does he possess any pets. Because of his bird drawings, I had thought there might at least be a parrot in his Kensington flat. What he does have is empathy.

"I don't think about how I was when I was five," he explains. "I just feel what it would be like to be a child in that situation, or what it would be like to be that cat carried by that child."

Blake's theory about why children like his illustrations is partly that they are unthreatened by the apparent informality of the drawings and partly that his work contains elements of mime: "A sort of little theatre."

So could it be that performing live at the Royal Court theatre in London, recreating his famous Dahl characters - the BFG, the Twits, the Witches, the Enormous Crocodile - on an overhead projector, while actors such as Richard Wilson read the works aloud, might be second nature to him? "I suspect the way I draw is a bit like acting," he agrees, in the studio where he stands to draw at a lightbox and rests in a swivel armchair between bursts.

"I stare at the wall or look into my imagination and try to imagine what something feels like. The actual drawing is something that happens fast. Then I think about it and I do it again, fast. It's a bit like working out how to get a theatrical effect in rehearsals."

At the Royal Court, of course, the audience will be seeing one-off versions of drawings that might need several rehearsals in real life. "But," says Blake, "the instincts are still the same." All his work smacks of this instinctiveness - the fluid movements, the energy, the expressive faces that often consist of only a dot and three lines. But it's not as easy as it looks. "In a drawing that appears to be very spontaneous," he notes, "if you put the dot in the wrong place, it's no good and you have to start again."

Blake, now 68, is the first children's laureate. Known as Q to his friends from the Royal College of Art (where he was head of illustration for many years), his first drawings were accepted by Punch in 1949, when he was 16. Blake has worked with several authors, including Joan Aiken, Russell Hoban and John Yeoman - and, of course, written and illustrated many books of his own: who could forget Mr Magnolia?

His collaboration with the late Roald Dahl was especially fascinating, because it was so long and successful - from 1978 with The Enormous Crocodile, Dahl's first picture storybook, to Matilda in 1996. (It continues: Blake is working on Even More Revolting Recipes, due next year.) Dahl was delighted that Matilda contained a record 100 illustrations. "He enjoyed having illustrations in his books," says Blake. "Not all authors do."

When Tom Maschler at Jonathan Cape originally put them together, Blake was: "Nervous, because Roald was so famous already. But we seemed to get on rather well. He appreciated that I wanted him to have what he wanted. Sometimes artists take books and run away with them and want them to be something else, but I never did that."

Occasionally, Dahl would change something in the text because of the way the illustrations worked: "At first, he described the BFG as wearing a big leather apron and knee-length boots."

However, the boots turned out to be dull and the apron seemed an encumbrance, so "we rethought the costume".

They couldn't decide what the BFG should wear on his feet. Then, one day, a parcel arrived at Blake's flat containing a large Norwegian sandal: "It was one of Roald's own." Although the giant wasn't directly based on Dahl, says Blake, "I discovered an affinity. This tall man and his rather protective relationship with children, who appeared threatening but was really on your side.

"Sophie, the little girl, is the only person in a Dahl book named after a member of his family - his granddaughter, Sophie Dahl, who is now a model. I drew her with her big spectacles , and then afterwards I met her and she looked like the drawings - a very strange experience. "She looks different now."

 Quentin Blake and Friends, December 7 at the Royal Court theatre, London SW1 (020-7565 5000). The event will benefit the Roald Dahl Foundation and Royal Court.

webTitle: Can parents call their children 'naughty'?

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Nursery staff are being trained not to label children 'naughty' when they misbehave. Should parents abandon the N-word too?
fields.trailText: The Question: Nursery staff are being trained not to label children 'naughty' when they misbehave. Should parents abandon the N-word too?
fields.body:
Theresa May
Conservative MP

Parents should tell their children they are naughty when they misbehave, and staff at nursery school should be able to use that word too, because it's important that children grow up knowing the difference between right and wrong. It's more important to instil the difference between right and wrong into a child than to discuss what it means. If a parent is trying to teach a child the difference between good and bad and that is undermined in school, then the child can end up questioning the parent's authority. Children need a clear framework in which to operate.

Verdict: No

Lee Jasper
Greater London assembly adviser, and father of eight

Not using the word naughty just sounds like more psychobabble. When my kids misbehave, the way I deal with it is to instigate a drama where I walk into the room and tell them off. Parents have to create a moral framework of expectations for their children's behaviour. I express my disappointment mixed with a healthy portion of anger. I don't see the point in not telling them if they've been naughty - as long as it's not the only thing you tell them. The thing about telling children they've been naughty is that you can make things up with them afterwards.

Verdict: No

Dorit Brown
Chief executive, Parentline Plus

Parents need to find a way of tackling the behaviour without labelling the child. Taking a deep breath before saying anything to a child who has misbehaved is always helpful. It is OK to say, "That was a really naughty or silly thing to do," and explain why you don't like it, rather than saying, "You are a bad person". If you lose your temper in the heat of the moment, as a parent, the most important thing is to apologise afterwards. For a professional working with a child, it's more important to maintain a distance and not tell a child he is naughty.

Verdict: Yes

Rosemary Murphy
National Day Nurseries Association

There is nothing particularly wrong with using the word naughty. It's how you do it and the context that are important. If you say it continually to a child, that is how the child will label himself. I don't think the same applies in the home, and we wouldn't want to be directing parents on this. As a mother of four, I would be the last to tell a parent how to discipline children. Children need to know what naughty behaviour is, but just labelling them won't explain it. A little explanation goes a long way and counting to 10 before you open your mouth always helps.

Verdict: Yes

Nick Putz
Performer and children's entertainer

When I am doing workshops or parties with children, some of them do sometimes misbehave. They are always trying to knock me off my stilts. Rather than telling children they are being naughty, I try to create a distraction and encourage them to play with something I do want them to play with rather than something I don't. Because I dress up in very silly clothes, no child would take me seriously as a disciplinarian anyway. If I can make a gag about their behaviour, I find that useful too: distraction and humour are the most useful tools in my armoury.

Verdict: Yes
