webTitle: The Queen's speech

fields.headline: The Queen's speech
fields.trailText: My Lords and members of the Commons.
fields.body:
My Lords and members of the Commons.

My government will continue to pursue its central economic objective of high and stable levels of growth and employment. My government will ensure the continued economic stability which has enabled it to increase the resources available for education, health, transport, and police services. My government will reflect these policies in its Finance Bill.

This is my government's fourth legislative programme. My government's main Bills for the coming Session will focus on improving public services and cutting crime.

My government also plans other major Bills and other significant initiatives, particularly in secondary education with the creation of more specialist schools, urban school reform and improved teaching in the early years of secondary education.

My government is determined to combat all aspects of crime to protect all members of our society. My government will introduce legislation to modernise and improve law enforcement by, for example, tackling disorderly conduct. Legislation will be introduced to regulate the private security industry.

A Bill will be introduced to cut vehicle crime, reduce opportunities to dispose of stolen vehicles, and extend the time limit for prosecution for vehicle theft.

A Bill will be published in draft to increase powers against money laundering and make it easier to recover the proceeds of crime.

The Bill to give Courts themselves the power to decide whether certain defendants should be tried by jury or by magistrates, will be re-introduced.

Legislation will also be brought forward to reduce benefit fraud. This will enable more information to be obtained to prevent fraud and will provide power to withdraw or reduce benefits where a person has twice been convicted of benefit fraud.

My government remains committed to the founding principles of the National Health Service. My government's NHS Plan showed how it would take forward further reform of health services to improve standards. Legislation will be introduced to support many of the commitments in the Plan, in particular to improve the performance of the NHS. The legislation will also take forward my government's response to the Royal Commission on Long Term Care for the Elderly.

A Bill will be brought forward to ban the advertising and promotion of tobacco products.

My government continues to attach the highest importance to improving education. It has already secured a number of changes to the law to further this end, including legislation to reform the training of teachers, to secure improved school standards and to create the Learning and Skills Councils. My government will introduce a Bill to improve the framework for meeting special educational needs and access to learning for disabled people. During the new Session, my government will continue to work to improve standards in education.

Legislation will be introduced to extend the functions of the Children's Commissioner for Wales, to provide better protection for children in Wales.

A Bill will be introduced to increase the effectiveness of the power to reduce regulatory burdens by removing inappropriate and over-complex regulation.

Legislation will be brought forward to ease the process of buying and selling homes, and to improve the protection given to homeless people. Progress will also be made on the purchase of freeholds by leaseholders, and on commonhold, a new form of tenure for flatowners.

Members of the House of Commons,

Estimates for the Public Service will be laid before you.

My Lords and member of the House of Commons,

A Bill will be introduced to enable a free vote to take place on the future of hunting with dogs.

My government has appointed Lord Cullen to head an Inquiry into safety on our railways. A Bill will be drafted to provide for safer travel on the railways, in the air, at sea and on the roads, and will take forward proposals for revitalising health and safety at work.

A draft Bill will be published to improve the transparency of export controls and to establish their purpose.

In Northern Ireland, my government will continue to work closely with the political parties and the Irish government to secure the full implementation of the Good Friday Agreement. A Bill will be published in draft on the implementation of the recommendations of the review of the Criminal Justice System in Northern Ireland.

My government is committed to making devolution in Scotland and Wales work and to continuing the process of decentralising government in the interests of all the people in the United Kingdom.

A Bill will be introduced to maintain the legislation relating to the Armed Forces for the next five years.

Other measures will be laid before you.

My Lords and member of the House of Commons,

The Duke of Edinburgh and I look forward to our State Visit to Norway.

My government will continue to work with our partners to shape the future of the European Union. It will work for rapid progress on the enlargement negotiations, and for reform of the institutions of the European Union to prepare them for a wider membership.

My government will continue to ensure that NATO remains the foundation of Britain's defence and security. My government will continue to work to make the United Nations Security Council more effective and representative. It will support efforts to improve the United Nations' capacity to undertake peace keeping operations.

A White Paper will be published outlining how my government will work to shape the forces of globalization to benefit the world's poor.

My government believes that those who commit crimes against humanity should be brought to justice. It will introduce a Bill to enable the UK to ratify the statute of the International Criminal Court.

My Lords and member of the House of Commons,

I pray that the blessing of Almighty God may rest upon your counsels.

webTitle: Go north ... where the living is a whole lot easier

fields.headline: Go north ... where the living is a whole lot easier
fields.trailText: Partnership between councils in London and Yorkshire seeks to effect migration from crowded bedsits to homes with moorland views. By Peter Hetherington
fields.body:
The glossy brochure, evoking a glorious Pennine landscape, could be straight from a travel agent. But the sales pitch, of unsurpassed countryside and historic canalside towns crammed with listed buildings, is not designed for tourists.

Rather, it marks the first serious campaign to persuade people to leave an overcrowded London with the promise of cheaper housing, more space, and a much lower cost of living up north.

Recognising its growing housing shortage, with 5,000 people vainly waiting for council homes, the London borough of Camden has signed an agreement with Kirklees council - otherwise known as Greater Huddersfield - to take families unable to find accommodation in the capital.

"Camden, like most of London's 32 boroughs, simply cannot meet demand for low cost housing with tens of thousands on the waiting list in the capital.

"This is not a case of persuading people to move into unpleasant, difficult to let homes", said Camden's spokesman, David Petrie. "Huddersfield has a lot of empty houses that would be snapped up if they were in London, and it has a lot more to offer as well."

Emie Townsend would certainly agree. After spending a year with her 13-year-old daughter, Maria, living in one room in a cramped bed and breakfast near King's Cross, she became the first person voluntarily to transfer from Camden to Kirklees this week, lured by cheaper accommodation, moorland air, and a two bedroom house with garden at front and rear.

"Brilliant", she smiled yesterday. "This is far more than I expected - seven minutes by bus from the town centre, a shopping centre which seems bigger than Oxford Street, and much cheaper food and clothing. I can't believe my luck."

Camden's promotion, Kirklees - a Beautiful Place to Live, which is backed up with a video presentation for would-be emigrants, pulls no punches.

"London has a serious housing problem", it warns. "The number of people looking for affordable accommodation far exceeds the available supply ... high demand for housing pushes up prices so that property to buy or rent is extremely expensive ... the situation is unlikely to improve in the near future, which means that many people will remain in temporary accommodation, in expensive and insecure private housing or staying in ... overcrowded conditions.

But in contrast to London, it says, there is a surplus in other towns and cities, "where the local population may have decreased and where property prices are much lower".

The London borough, which last year offered council housing to under 1,400 people from 6,000 applicants, has even arranged a bus trip to take families around Kirklees, immortalised as Last of the Summer Wine country, as the TV series was filmed in the nearby town of Holmfirth.

It has given other families, such as Emie Townsend and her daughter, the train fare to take a closer look.

John Earnshaw, the Kirklees housing officer who has the task of letting 1,000 empty homes, is quietly confident that scores of other Camden residents will be persuaded to follow the Townsends up north. "Their brochure really does Huddersfield proud", he said yesterday.

"It doesn't make sense to have people staying in London in cramped housing, when we can offer them far more up here and help the capital solve its housing crisis. If other boroughs make similar partnerships, then we will really be able to take the strain off London."

Ms Townsend, who moved into the Deighton area of Huddersfield, said her daughter had settled happily into a local high school. She added: "People are really making us feel at home. In King's Cross it was so different - unsafe, dirty and overcrowded."

She heard about the voluntary transfer scheme in a letter from Camden council and then was invited to view the promotional video along with hundreds of others. "When we saw it, we thought it was too good to be true. But so far it has exceeded our expectations."

She heard about the voluntary transfer scheme in a letter from Camden council and then was invited to view the promotional video along with hundreds of others. "When we saw it, we thought it was too good to be true. But so far it has exceeded our expectations."

webTitle: Jonesco latest casualty in Express purge

fields.headline: Jonesco latest casualty in Express purge
fields.trailText: Express Newspapers' managing director Andy Jonesco has been escorted from the building in the latest round of the Express restructure. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Express Newspapers' managing director Andy Jonesco has been escorted from the building in the latest round of purges under the newspaper's new owner, Richard Desmond.

A spokesman for Express Newspapers said the move was "part and parcel of the process of addressing the duplication of management". There are no plans to replace Jonesco, but Stan Myerson and Martin Ellice, will take responsibility for the day-to-day running of the paper.

New Express boss Richard Desmond, owner of soft porn group Northern & Shell, has this week continued to rationalise the Express's commercial operations, cutting twenty jobs in the paper's advertising sales department.

Ad director Richard Bogey has also been made redundant, and heads of display advertising Mark Milner and classified advertising Margaret Nugent will report to Myerson.

Meanwhile, personnel boss Nicky Gray has threatened to resign in protest after the redundancies were imposed in the sales department. The Express has also issued letters to staff in marketing and online departments warning them that there is a consultation going on into duplication and there will be further job losses.

Jonesco was moved to another office in Ludgate House when Desmond's takeover of Express Newspapers was announced.

He became managing director of Express Newspapers in May last year.

webTitle: Kevin Smith fans wanted for his next film

fields.headline: Kevin Smith fans wanted for his next film
fields.trailText: The director of Clerks and Dogma wants his fans to appear in 'Missing' posters in the background of his new road movie
fields.body:
Are you a Kevin Smith fan? Fancy seeing yourself in his latest movie? Well here's your chance. As self-respecting fans of Smith's will know, View Askew Productions, the team behind Dogma, Chasing Amy and Clerks, are working on a road movie, Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back.

A message posted earlier this week on View Askew's website tells you how your image can appear in the movie.

"Submit your picture. . .with a very brief note explaining why your mug needs to be in this flick," it explains, "and we'll choo-choo-choose a winner who'll have the good fortune to see their face on the big screen! How? Well, let a brother break down the deets!

"Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back is a road picture, right? So we spend a lot of time on the road. And on the road, there are street lights and telephone poles that have to be 'dressed' (decorated) so as not to appear as boring as the film itself. Home-made 'Missing' posters will dot the landscape, affording you - the chance to see yourself in the movie.

"We'll be picking the winner(s) by Christmas, so rush those puppies our way."

Full details and a postal adddress can be found on the website.

A final word of warning from the ebullient View Askew team: "Nude photos will be given extra-careful consideration, but head-shots (not the professional kind; just a pic of your head) are preferred."

webTitle: Queen's speech: the main points

fields.headline: Queen's speech: the main points
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's government today unveiled its agenda in the run-up to the general election. The Queen's speech, delivered to the House of Lords, contains 15 main Bills and four draft pieces of legislation. Here are some of the main points in the programme.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's government today unveiled its agenda in the run-up to the general election. The Queen's speech, delivered to the House of Lords, contains 15 main Bills and four draft pieces of legislation. Here are some of the main points in the programme.

Crime
 Fixed penalties for offences of disorderly behaviour in public places
 Police to be able to shut down rowdy pubs and clubs
 A ban on drinking alcohol in the street
 Child curfew schemes for those aged nine to 15
 New powers for police to seize the assets of criminals, especially targeting drug barons

Health
 A fund of £500m is to be made available to the best-run NHS trusts immediately and to others under strict supervision
 Public-private partnerships are planned in an effort to improve primary health care - such as GP services - particularly in inner cities
 More health professionals will be allowed to prescribe drugs
 The NHS will become responsible for paying nursing care costs in homes
 The promotion and advertising of tobacco will be banned

Education
 New moves to improve literacy and numeracy for 11 to 14 year-olds
 A major drive to improve adult literacy.

Bureaucracy
 Red tape will be swept away in more than 20 areas
 Fire regulations are to be simplified
 Pubs and restaurants will be allowed to open later.
 Restaurants are to be allowed to remain open without providing live entertainment
 From next year pubs will be allowed to stay open later on New Year's Eve.

Buying a home
 Sellers will be required to compile a special pack for purchasers, including a survey report and details such as planning consents and title documents.

Bloodsports
 The long-awaited Hunting Bill will be brought forward this session. MPs will get a free vote, when they can choose between an almost total ban on hunting with dogs; a compulsory regulatory system forcing hunts to obtain licences; or a voluntary system of regulation.

Transport

 A draft Safety Bill will cover rail safety measures recommended by Lord Cullen in his inquiry into the Paddington rail crash
 It will also raise port and maritime safety standards
 Drug and alcohol misuse by staff will also be addressed

Arms control
 Export controls are to be made clearer
 The government will attempt to curb the proliferation of weapons, particularly light weapons and small arms.
 Proposals for controls on trafficking and brokering in weapons
 Existing controls on chemical, biological and nuclear weapons will be tightened

Social security
 A Fraud Bill will give the government the power to withdraw or reduce benefit from anybody convicted twice of a benefit offence within three years.
 The Department of Social Security will have powers to offer a fine of between £1,000 and £5,000 as an alternative to prosecution in less serious cases of employers colluding with their employees to commit benefit fraud.

webTitle: The issue explained: the Queen's speech

fields.headline: The issue explained: the Queen's speech
fields.standfirst:
The Queen's speech is an annual parliamentary ritual but what is it and does it really matter? Julian Glover explains
Special report: Labour in power
fields.trailText: The Queen's speech is an annual parliamentary ritual - but what is it and does it really matter? We explain.
fields.body:
What is the Queen's speech?
The Queen's speech is the central part of a wider ceremony known as the state opening of parliament, which marks the start of the parliamentary year. By tradition, the monarch sets out the legislation that he or she would like to see passed, in a short speech. Since the nineteenth century, this has effectively been a statement of the government's aims for the next year. Although the Queen reads it, she has no part in writing it. The speech is put together by a government committee known as futureleg - although in recent years, commentators have suspected that the government's spin doctors have a hand in it, too.

Why does the speech take place?
Because of an ancient parliamentary tradition which means that, each year, parliament begins work with an empty slate. Legislation under consideration cannot be carried over from one year to the next, even between general elections. As a result, the government has to set out its programme anew each year. The timing of the speech is long established - indeed, its origins appear to lie in the date of the medieval harvest. Beyond this, the speech provides a useful platform for the government to state its aims - and, as in this year,s case, its plans for the general election manifesto.

Why is there so much ceremony involved?
Partly because the state opening of parliament is one of the few occasions on which the crown's traditional role in parliament is still on show. And partly because moves to simplify the ceremony have met with complaints. Some commentators even objected to the announcement by the lord chancellor, Derry Irvine, that he would no longer walk backwards from the royal presence after handing the Queen her speech to read. As a result, little has been changed.

What happens after the speech has been delivered?
The work of parliament begins, with a string of debates on the policies proposed in the speech. Before these begin - usually the same afternoon - the Commons debates a short bill, which never reaches the statute book, as a symbol of the House's independence from royal command. Over the rest of the year, the government will introduce the legislation proposed in the speech and attempt to make it law. This year, though, the process is likely to be interrupted by a general election, meaning that few of the bills announced today will become law.

webTitle: International Year of Volunteering kicks off

fields.headline: International Year of Volunteering kicks off
fields.trailText: The International Year of Volunteering has kicked off with events all around the world, from lunch parties in Australia to conferences in Japan and Bangladesh, writes Nicola Hill
fields.body:
The International Year of Volunteering was launched yesterday with events all around the world, from lunch parties in Australia to conferences in Japan and Bangladesh.

In the United Kingdom, the UK Volunteering Forum (UKVF), which comprises the national volunteering agencies in the four countries of the UK, together with the National Association of Volunteer Bureau (NAVB), is taking the lead on IYV 2001.

The idea for the year started in November 1997, when the UN General Assembly proclaimed 2001 as the International Year of Volunteers. The goals of the year are "enhanced recognition, facilitation, promotion and recognition of volunteers and volunteerism".

The IYV website details events taking place throughout the next year around the world, including an international work camp in Palestine on December 20. Volunteers from Europe, USA and Japan will plant trees and clean up "friction lines" between the Israeli army and the Palestinian demonstrators. The work will take place inside the three refugee camps in Bethlehem city; Duheisheh, Azzeh and Aida.

Ethiopia will officially launch IYV on December 9 in conjunction with Sileshi Demissie, a folklore musician, who is "waging a voluntary war against Addis's filth". To celebrate the 114th birthday of Addis Ababa, the volunteers will be undertaking cleaning and renovation work.

Sharon Capeling-Alakija, United Nation volunteers executive coordinator, said: "Research on giving and volunteering has found that individuals are four times as likely to volunteer when asked than when they are not. Organisations that need the help of volunteers sometimes fail to ask for it. So a key message of IYV 2001 is this: reach out. Ask people to get involved, explain the benefits and recruit volunteers like never before."

webTitle: Berlin Festival to honour Kirk Douglas

fields.headline: Berlin Festival to honour Kirk Douglas
fields.trailText: One of the last remaining stars from Hollywood's golden age is to be honoured for a film career spanning half a century
fields.body:
Kirk Douglas - father-in-law of Catherine, and great grandfather to Dylan, not to mention dad to Michael - is helping to ensure that the members of the Douglas dynasty are never far from the media spotlight.

The veteran actor, whose career spans 55 years, is to be honoured at next year's Berlin Film Festival with a Golden Bear for Lifetime Achievement. The 51st annual Berlinale Festival, which runs February 7-18, will also pay homage to the actor by screening 20 of his movies.

Douglas, now 84, is rarely seen these days on the big screen, although last year he appeared opposite Lauren Bacall and Dan Aykroyd in Diamonds (not released in the UK). His illustrious career began in 1946, and he won Oscar nominations for his roles in Champion (1949), The Bad and the Beautiful (1952) and Lust for Life (1956).

He also gave memorable performances in Out of the Past, Ace in the Hole and Paths of Glory, but he is perhaps best known as the rebel slave leader Spartacus in Stanley Kubrick's classic movie of the same name.

Douglas has previously been honoured with a Lifetime Achievement Oscar in 1996 and, in December 1999, the American Film Institute's Lifetime Achievement Award.

Previous recipients of the Berlin Film Festival's Lifetime Achievement Award include James Stewart (1982), Sir Alec Guinness (1988), Sophia Loren (1994), Catherine Deneuve (1998) and Jeanne Moreau (2000).

webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's gossip tears over the gates of Buckingham Palace and does a number two on the throne
fields.trailText: Leeds will complete the loan signing of Robbie Keane from Internazionale within the next few days, according to Teamtalk. The website claims a deal was brokered between the two clubs in Rome last night, following Leeds' Champions League win over Lazio.
fields.body:
Leeds will complete the loan signing of Robbie Keane from Internazionale within the next few days, according to Teamtalk. The website claims a deal was brokered between the two clubs in Rome last night, following Leeds' Champions League win over Lazio.

Dave Jones would like to return to management with Stockport County. The Daily Mail believes the former County boss could replace the beleaguered incumbent Andy Kilner at Edgeley Park.

The Mirror repeats a rumour from a couple of weeks ago and suggests that West Ham have targeted Paris Saint Germain's French international defender Frederic Dehu as a replacement for Rio Ferdinand. They are so faithful to the Sun's original gossip that they even repeat the claim that 28-year-old Dehu is 22.

Planet Football meanwhile suggests that the real object of Harry Redknapp's attentions resides elsewhere in France. They believe he will attempt to sign 26-year-old defender Pascal Cygan from Lille.

The Daily Mail reports that Manchester United have joined Arsenal in attempting to sign Bayer Leverkusen defender Jens Nowotny, but the Premiership leaders have had a bid of £23m for the 26-year-old rejected. Nowotny is expected to leave Leverkusen this summer.

Manchester United are also set to sign 15-year-old attacking midfielder Chris Hogg from York City, according to the Daily Mail.

Robbie Fowler has again been linked with a move away from Anfield, and Gerard Houllier has once again insisted he is not for sale. Fowler has been linked with Leeds, Arsenal and Chelsea, but Houllier said: "He's simply not for sale and I hope that now, finally, everyone will leave Robbie alone to get on with his recovery."

Winston Bogarde has denied that he wants to leave Chelsea. The Dutch international has been tipped for a return to Spain, but the Daily Star quote him as saying: "I am very happy to stay at Chelsea and fight for my place."

webTitle: Drug use inspires moving fiction

fields.headline: Drug use inspires moving fiction
fields.standfirst: The devastating effects drug users can have on family and friends are captured in a new writing competition
fields.trailText: The devastating effects drug users can have on family and friends are captured in a new writing competition
fields.body:
All too rarely is attention paid to the needs of the families and friends of drug users. But charity Adfam National works to help those caught up in their loved ones' addictions.

"Drugs can have a devastating effect on families, partners, children and friends," said Moira Campbell, the charity's fundraiser. "The stress can lead to the breakdown of relationships and health, as well as to financial and legal problems."

The charity has initiated an annual writing competition, encouraging people to express what it is like to live with a drug user. Many of this year's powerful entries were from mothers; others came from siblings. But the winning submission, Addiction Fictions, printed here, was from a wife, charting graphically the decline of her middle-class husband - and the ruin of their relationship .

The competition was judged by a panel comprising Angela Harrison, author and mother of a drug user, Kim Worts, an Adfam trustee, Mike Trace, the government's deputy drugs tsar, and David Brindle, editor of Guardian Society.

The winning entry will be read tomorrow evening at Adfam's fifth annual fundraising carol concert at St Bride's church in Fleet Street, London EC4. Celebrities Michael Parkinson, Nick Hornby and Josie Lawrence will be among readers at the event. Some tickets are still available at £12.

Adfam is on 020-7928 8898. Its helpline is 020-7928 8900.

Addiction Fictions

My husband's not a drug addict. Drug addicts are unemployed, use heroin and live in council flats. Their girlfriends' sex work pays for their drugs. My husband is a social worker. He earns more than me. We live in a nice house in a leafy city street.

My husband uses some drugs. He says drugs are cool. He says they expand his mind and free his creativity. He says I should use more drugs. I've tried. It was quite interesting the first time. The second time was the same as the first time. I thought it was boring after that. He says that's because I'm too conventional.

My husband uses drugs before he goes to work, and when he gets home. Drugs are very important to him. I wonder why. Perhaps it's because he was young in the sixties. Perhaps it's because he had a difficult childhood. Perhaps it's because most of his friends use drugs. I guess the reason isn't important as long as he's happy.

I am proud of my husband. He is fun, he's different, he cares about me. I understand that his drugs are very important to him. I don't have to be the same. I know it can help a marriage when the partners have their own interests.

My husband's not very good with money. Well, nobody's perfect I don't mind paying for him when we go out with friends. Sometimes I invite people round for a meal. I don't mind when he can't join us because he has to go out to buy more drugs. I explain to our friends that he had to go out. I don't tell them why. They might not understand. That doesn't matter; he only needs me to understand.

My husband wants to have a relationship with another woman. A woman who takes drugs. I do mind about this. He says that's because I'm too conventional. He says I should have other relationships too. I don't want to have other relationships. I'm scared he'll meet someone he likes better than me.

I'm angry with my husband. He is being selfish. I tell him if something doesn't change, our marriage will end. I mean that I want him to change, into the person I thought I'd married. Or I want my money back. He doesn't change. I don't change.

My husband has a relationship with the woman who takes drugs. She is much younger than me. She is unemployed. She takes her baby into the city centre to beg, and tells how she lets a man there masturbate on her feet for £50. Easy money, she says. My husband is proud of her. I wonder what she did with the baby.

My husband is a drug addict now. He is unemployed, uses heroin and lives in a council flat. His girlfriend's sex work pays for his drugs. I wonder why he is a drug addict. Perhaps it's because I left him.

webTitle: Nottingham University dons furious over tobacco cash

fields.headline: Dons furious over tobacco cash
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Nottingham University last night faced an internal revolt over the decision to accept £3.8m from British American Tobacco to open a school of business ethics.
fields.body:
Nottingham University last night faced an internal revolt over the decision to accept £3.8m from British American Tobacco to open a school of business ethics.

Staff in the medical school, including academics involved in cancer research, oppose the acceptance of cash from a multinational accused of exploiting smuggling.

John Britton, a consultant chest physician and professor of epidemiology at Nottingham, said: "I think this is an error. If BAT had any social responsibility in their corporate body, they would stop making and selling cigarettes."

Professor Britton, who is also chairman of the Royal College of Physicians' tobacco advisory group, added: "It seems something of a contradiction for what is widely perceived to be a not terribly socially responsible organisation to be funding a centre for corporate social responsibility.

University authorities are understood to have decided the creation of the international centre for corporate social responsibility outweighed what they hope will be a short-term "PR hit".

An academic who declined to be named, however, predicted the relationship with BAT could undermine the university's reputation. "We have sold our good name for £3.8m. The business school gets a new centre, BAT gets a veneer of respectability and we could all end up paying for this."

Nottingham's students were said to be split. Union president Alain de Sales said some thought it would improve the university's prestige while others feared it would undermine the institution's reputation.

Nottingham showed no sign of backing down and talks were continuing with BAT over whether the posts should carry BAT's name to acknowledge the financial support.

webTitle: Call to strengthen parents' and grandparents' rights

fields.headline: Call to strengthen parents' and grandparents' rights
fields.trailText: A family support group is on alert over an announcement expected in the Queen's speech, writes David Brindle
fields.body:
The Family Rights Group (FRG) tonight celebrates 25 years of helping families deal with intervention by social services. But pride in past successes will be tempered by acute awareness of fresh challenges ahead.

The group will be on alert for an announcement, in today's Queen's speech, of adoption law reform. While much of the pressure for reform focuses on the case for easing and speeding adoption, the FRG is concerned to strengthen the rights of birth families.

"We want to see changes to legislation that will redefine adoption to ensure that links between the adopted child and their birth family are respected and maintained as far as is possible," said Robert Tapsfield, the group's chief executive.

The FRG was set up by a group of social workers, lawyers and academics who felt strongly that families facing social services intervention were getting a raw deal. The group's subsequent achievements include lobbying to ensure parents are legally represented in care proceedings; securing a legal right for parents to challenge a local authority decision to end their contact with children in care; and developing the Grandparents' Federation to represent the interests of people who lose grandchildren to adoption or the care system.

Angela Price, who currently chairs the FRG, was herself enabled by its assistance to make and keep contact with her grandson after he was adopted and she faced the loss of any relationship.

Many callers to the group's advice line express a sense of powerlessness when social services steps in to their lives.

Mr Tapsfield said: "Families in contact with social services are often terrified of what social services may do and complain that their views are ignored when services are planned. The government's adoption agenda threatens to put more resources into adoption while ignoring the preventive services that would allow more families to look after their own children."

The group has been instrumental in the implementation of family group conferences, now offered by 61 local authorities, in cases of children deemed to need care and protection. The FRG would like to see all families having a right to such a conference when there is a care or protection issue concerning a child. Among other goals, the group believes that families involved with social services should have a right to independent advice and advocacy, available locally, and be fully informed about child welfare issues.

Dispelling any suggestion that the FRG is "anti" social services, speakers at tonight's 25th anniversary event will include Denise Platt, chief inspector of social services.

 The FRG is on 020-7923 2628 and its free advice line, open Monday to Friday between 1.30pm and 3.30pm, is 0800-731 1696.

webTitle: Bono sets his sights on the movies

fields.headline: Bono sets his sights on the movies
fields.trailText: The Irish frontman of the band U2 is keen to establish himself in films despite earlier failures to gain a foothold in the movie business
fields.body:
Not that he needs to be thinking about giving up the day job yet, but U2 frontman Bono is reported to be looking to Hollywood for his next move in the entertainment world.

It has been reported that Bono lost out to Jim Carrey and Tommy Lee Jones in his attempts to play a baddie in the 1995 film Batman Forever, and his first foray into scriptwriting resulted in the critically panned and commercially ignored The Million Dollar Hotel. Undeterred, the Irish singer has bought himself a home in New York, which friends say he will use as a base from which to mastermind his move into films.

PeopleNews quotes a friend of the singer as saying, "Bono has achieved just about everything in the music industry. He's now ready to turn his attention to the movies in a big way."

An alternative plan of attack for Bono could be through the internet. Short films are a valuable means of gaining experience for aspiring actors and directors, and many successful short films that premiered on the internet have gone on to launch their stars and creative teams to bigger and better things.

Irish music site allireland.com are soon to premiere the seven-minute short, Sightings of Bono. The film, shot on location in the singer's hometown of Dublin, stars Marcella Plunkett as Ellen, a woman who believes she sees Bono everywhere she turns, and finally gets an opportunity to meet him face to face when he visits the shop where she works.

More details here.

webTitle: American Film Institute seeks 'Moments of Significance'

fields.headline: American Film Institute seeks 'Moments of Significance'
fields.trailText: The AFI says that the new awards will honour the most outstanding work of the year in every area of moving image culture
fields.body:
The last thing that the film industry needs is a new awards ceremony. But that's what it is going to get. However, The American Film Institute (AFI) hopes that its awards will, in contrast to so many other gong shows, actually honour great film-making.

"We realised that we ought to start this new century with a new kind of record, an on-going annual history of what has occurred in motion pictures" said Jean Picker Firstenberg, the institute's director.

The AFI jury will select the 10 most outstanding films of 2000, along with up to five AFI 'Moments of Significance' relating to film, television, video, the internet, digital and other forms of moving image culture.

The 'Moments of Significance', explained Firstenberg, could be: "recognition for accomplishments of considerable merit, influences with either a positive or negative impression, trends, either new or re-emerging, anniversaries or memorials of special note, and/or movements in television, new technologies, education, preservation, government or other areas that impact the art of the moving image.''

The films will be chosen by 13 anonymous jury members, who will include a chairman, three film-makers, three film historians, three film critics and three AFI trustees. The public can also nominate their favourite movies on the AFI's site.

When the winning 10 films are announced in January, all the members of the movies' creative teams will be awarded a plaque. "We are honouring the projects as a whole, and, therefore, paying tribute to all the key people who have contributed to the outstanding films of the year,'' said AFI board chairman Tom Pollock.

It remains to be seen whether the AFI can see beyond the huge studio productions that are bound to dominate next year's Oscars. Peter Bart, editor of Variety said, "The real test of this new effort will be what group of pictures they come up with - will they reach beyond the big Oscar contenders to honour some of the smaller but ultimately more important films that the Oscars might overlook?"

This might just be the means by which smaller American productions such as the acclaimed Requiem for a Dream (pictured) or Shadow of the Vampire might earn some recognition.

The AFI 2000 will be announced on January 9, 2001.

webTitle: Wanadoo bids £1.65bn for Freeserve

fields.headline: Wanadoo bids £1.65bn for Freeserve
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: 11 am update: French internet service provider confirms offer following this morning's suspension of Freeserve shares on the London stock exchange.
fields.body:
Wanadoo, France Telecom's internet service provider, has made a £1.65bn takeover bid for British internet firm Freeserve.

Shares in Freeserve were suspended from trading on the London stock exchange earlier today before the announcement of the bid for the British internet service provider.

Last month, Freeserve, which is 80% owned by electrical retailer Dixons, said it was in talks that could lead to a takeover of the business. Wanadoo confirmed at the time that it was in discussions with Freeserve.

New of the talks sent a shockwave through Energis investors who feared their company - part-owned by the National Grid - could lose important telecom contracts if Freeserve were bought.

In June, Freeserve shares plunged by 20% after the collapse of merger talks with German rival T-Online that could have led to a £6bn deal for the acquisition of the British company.

At its last results announcement, in September, Freeserve said it had passed the 2m customer mark but losses for the first quarter of the year had doubled to £17.8m.

If Wanadoo succeeds in buying Freeserve, it would be its biggest acquisition since it floated in May. However, last month it was rumoured that Freeserve was in talks with other interested parties.

webTitle: Freeserve agrees £1.65bn Wanadoo deal

fields.headline: Freeserve agrees £1.65bn Wanadoo deal
fields.standfirst:
9.45am: Freeserve set for takeover
Comment by Amy Vickers
fields.trailText:
11.15am update: Freeserve has agreed a £1.65bn takeover deal with French rival Wanadoo, ending months of speculation, writes Dan Milmo.
9.45am: Freeserve set for takeover
Comment by Amy Vickers
fields.body:
Internet company Freeserve has agreed a £1.65bn takeover deal with French rival Wanadoo, ending months of speculation about the company's future.

The all-share deal values Freeserve's shares at just 157p, far lower than the company's recent trading price. High street retailer Dixons, which owns 80% of Freeserve, will take a 12% stake in the enlarged group.

Nicolas Dufourcq, chief executive of Wanadoo, said: "This agreement with Freeserve is a tremendous step forward in terms of our international growth strategy.

"It makes us the number one ISP provider in two of Europe's top three e-economies."

Wanadoo added that parent company France Telecom, which owns mobile phone operator Orange, will bring added support to the new company.

John Pluthero, chief executive of Freeserve, said: "We are delighted to join forces with Wanadoo. The additional resources of a large international group, combined with our ongoing relationship with Dixons will create new opportunities and accelerate the development of our core business."

The takeover will produce a new group with more than 4m subscribers, which still leaves it behind European competitors such as AOL Europe, T-Online of Germany and Italy's Tiscali.

However, Wanadoo and Freeserve will have a dominant position in the France and UK markets, which rank alongside Germany as the largest in Europe.

webTitle: Marketing round-up

fields.headline: Marketing round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: December 7.
fields.trailText: December 7: Coca-Cola is extending its Fanta brand into a lemon variety with further flavours to follow.
fields.body:
Coca-Cola is extending its Fanta brand into a lemon variety with the possibility of further flavours to follow.

The BBC has defended its decision to drop Leagas Delaney from its roster of ad agencies, saying it is time to look to the future.

The Conservative party has accused the government of rigging new legislation to allow pro-Europe parties more money for referendum advertising than those opposed to the single currency.

Juliet Warkentin, the former Arcadia managing director for marketing and home shopping and editor of Marie Claire, has joined brand consultancy The Fourth Room as a partner.

Lever Brothers is rebranding its cleaning fluid brand Jif as Cif in the UK to bring it in line with the rest of the world.

BSkyB has shortlisted Bates UK, The Leith Agency and WCRS for its £60m account. The three will fight it out against the incumbent, St Luke's, for a place on the final roster.

The ASA has upheld a complaint against a poster for Sega's Dreamcast, headlined "Spank Johnny Foreigner Online", saying it could be seen to condone violence against foreigners.

webTitle: 'I don't want to get no bullet over no bullshit'.

fields.headline: 'I don't want to get no bullet over no bullshit'.
fields.standfirst: An academic at Manchester Metropolitan University went undercover as a nightclub bouncer to research the world of criminals and drug dealers but confesses: "I prioritised my own survival over sociology".
fields.trailText: A 17 stone sociologist skilled in ethnography and kick boxing revealed how he donned a bullet-proof vest, quit the safety of the academic ivory tower and became a bouncer. Dr David Calvey, of the Centre for Employment Research at Manchester Metropolitan University, spent six months under cover on the doors of clubs in central Manchester with his heart in his mouth and a tape recorder up his bomber jacket.
fields.body:
A 17 stone sociologist skilled in ethnography and kick boxing revealed how he donned a bullet-proof vest, quit the safety of the academic ivory tower and became a bouncer. Dr David Calvey, of the Centre for Employment Research at Manchester Metropolitan University, spent six months under cover on the doors of clubs in central Manchester with his heart in his mouth and a tape recorder up his bomber jacket.

During his research, he discovered first-hand evidence of the influence of criminals and drug dealers in a city famed for its clubbing reputation. In a chapter for a new book about dangerous research, Dr Calvey describes an incident in which a bouncer was hurled into a canal in Manchester's gay village and another in which a club manager locked himself and his entire staff in a cellar when two men suspected of carrying guns began hammering on the front door.

Commenting on the second incident, Dr Calvey writes: "I prioritised my own survival over sociology but the tape was kept running throughout. Walking home with my vest on filled me with extreme anxiety about my personal safety and turned the brief journey home into a paranoid nightmare. "Managing threats was a routine job of being a bouncer but at this point I felt very vulnerable...Taking a side was one thing; the threat of being removed from one was another.''

Dr Calvey's research was carried out in 1996 but he has delayed publishing for fear of recriminations. While on the job, he worried frequently about the ethics of his research and also lived in constant fear that his cover would be blown. "Merely stating that I was an academic would offer no or very little protection,'' he adds. He still refuses to be photographed. One perk was that after his bouncing career was over, former colleagues on the doors offered him free entry to clubs and pubs.

He claims that the bouncing business in Manchester still has links with gangsterism and drug crime despite strenuous efforts by Manchester city council and the police to clean up and regulate the business. "It has long been the case that bouncers, affiliated to organised criminal fraternities, have colluded with drug dealers,'' he says.

Dr Carey describes his first night at a new pub in the city's gay village, adding: "The experience was an ethical baptism of fire in which I witnessed two assaults.'' A bouncer punched a customer in the face after refusing him entry. But the customer had a relationship with a gay bouncer who was a senior member of a Manchester gang running the doors in the area. "He took revenge on our member of staff, assisted by eight other bouncers, by breaking his nose and throwing him in the canal...Everyone, including me, had seen and heard nothing. Traditionally, information has never been given by bouncers to the police. One bouncer described the cardinal rule as 'If the police are there, nobody has seen fuck-all'.''

The other incident took place at a club which had closed for two weeks to introduce new security measures in a bid to win back customer confidence after take-over bids by rival gangs. On the second night, a club staffed by ten bouncers in bullet-proof vests was visited by a Salford gang boss. "When he arrived, one of the senior doormen hid behind the main door whilst nervously spying through through the peek hole and firmly pronouncing that he was not going outside,'' writes Dr Calvey.

The head bouncer was summoned to the gangster's car while the other bouncers held an emergency meeting in the club as restless customers queued outside. But the night passed without incident until two men suspected of carrying guns demanded entrance. "The head doorman was asked to go outside and investigate. He summed up the collective anxiety of the team by saying, 'I don't want to get no bullet over no bullshit'." The manager then locked all staff in the cellar and called the police.

At the end of his six months on the doors, Dr Calvey retired to academia to continue his research. "I partly enjoyed the seductive buzz from working on doors from the inside but I was simultaneously relieved eventually to melt back into the anonymous crowd.''

webTitle: Impact of a Wanadoo/Freeserve tie-up

fields.headline: A match made in heaven?
fields.standfirst:
With an announcement imminent over a Wanadoo/Freeserve tie-up, what impact will the deal have on the new media marketplace?
Dec 6: Freeserve shares suspended
fields.trailText:
With an announcement imminent over a Wanadoo/Freeserve tie-up, Amy Vickers looks at its potential impact on the new media marketplace.
Dec 6: Freeserve shares suspended
fields.body:
The Freeserve/Wanadoo tie-up does seem to be one of those marriages made in heaven.

Not only does it give Dixons a foothold in France and effectively open up new opportunities in continental Europe for the UK retailer, but the deal has put smiles back on the faces of NTL, Orange and Emap - the other UK media companies in which Wanadoo owner France Telecom has interests.

The first, most logical thing would be for Wanadoo-owner France Telecom to align Freeserve with NTL, the cable giant that is 22%-owned by France Telecom, on the internet service provider side to bolster NTLWorld subscriptions.

However, this would bring into question the viability of France Telecom offering two separate ISP brands in a single market. Will the more well-known and consumer-friendly Freeserve brand survive, or might Wanadoo look to extend its brand into the UK?

A tie-up with Orange is inevitable given France Telecom's full ownership of the mobile operator. Any such alliance would give impetus to Orange's internet plans and conversely, give Freeserve a ready-made internet mobile platform to work with.

Emap has been smiling ever since it was rumoured that Freeserve was in talks with Wanadoo a few weeks back.

Emap has an £8.5m joint venture in France with Wanadoo to build a number of websites. Its ideal would be to extend that agreement to the UK and work closely with other Wanadoo sister companies.

Strategically, the deal gives the gigantic France Telecom a stranglehold on the internet market in the UK and could lead to it taking a lead in the ADSL wars next year.

However likely a deal between Freeserve and Wanadoo seems at this stage, analysts expect a competitive bidding situation to emerge where disgruntled former Freeserve lover T-Online comes back into the ring to fight for Freeserve.

webTitle: Comment: The people versus the crown

fields.headline: The people versus the crown
fields.standfirst:
Our unwritten constitution is no longer working. Inadequate government is not simply a result of badly thought out policies. Jonathan Freedland explains why more fundamental reform is now urgently needed

Future of the monarchy
Join the debate online
fields.trailText: Our unwritten constitution is no longer working. Inadequate government is not simply a result of badly thought out policies. Jonathan Freedland explains why more fundamental reform is now urgently needed
fields.body:
If it ain't broke, don't fix it. That's been the rallying cry of the defenders of our ancient, unwritten constitution through the ages - if not always in those words. Sure, say the old guard, our patchwork quilt of unspoken custom and tacit tradition may not make logical sense when set out on a clean sheet of paper - that's one good reason why we keep it unwritten. But, insist the keepers of the flame, our non-systematic system has held up just fine for centuries. So long as it still works, there's no need to change it.

The trouble is, that's no longer true. The system is not working: it is broke - and we need to fix it. For the test of any constitution is the quality of governance it produces. In just the last few years we have seen all too clearly how well our system works: from the great pension scandal of the mid-1980s to the BSE calamity of the 1990s, from the outbreak of sleaze to the sell-off of our railways, from the poll tax to the debacle of the Dome - the proof is all around us of a standard of government that is just not good enough. In each case the system did not contain the checks and balances, the basic scrutiny, that might have weeded out bad legislation and prevented disastrous mistakes.

This cannot be the exclusive fault of this administration or that individual politician. It happens too often for that. Rather, as both the Scott inquiry into the arms-for-Iraq affair or the Phillips report on BSE concluded, the flaw lies in the system itself - the way we are governed. And that means our constitution.

The British people woke up to this fact long ago, even if few dare say it. Polling data consistently show a decline in esteem for our institutions and the system which links them together. While 48% expressed "quite a lot of confidence" in the House of Commons in 1985, that figure had halved by 1995. A year later a European Union poll found that Britons had less faith in their parliament than the people of any member country bar Portugal. Local government's standing has never been weaker, with turnout in council elections dropping like a stone. Trust in our institutions is in freefall, with the young especially disenchanted. One Mori survey found 71%of first-time voters convinced their ballot would "make little or no difference to their lives". We are beginning to vote with our feet - by staying away from the polling station. Britain's turnout figures are in decline, with recent by-elections lucky to involve more than 30% of the vote. In one Leeds seat, the turnout fell below one in five of all registered voters. It all adds up to a growing loss of faith in our system of governance.

These trends are not wholly new: reformers have seen the need for a radical overhaul of our constitution for decades. But now there is an extra urgency. For not only is the old system not working well: it is beginning to come apart. Since 1997 Labour has undertaken a raft of constitutional changes so radical they have historians reaching for the 1830s to find a precedent. Whether it's the rolling programme of devolution to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland or the partial reform of the House of Lords, the current government has shattered forever the traditionalist belief that our system is a frail, mystical thing that belongs in a glass case and can never be touched by human hand. The conservative conviction that the constitution has remained unaltered for centuries - and therefore cannot be changed in future - is gone. The patchwork quilt can be repaired and even renewed: after all, it's unravelling already.

Four nations

Specifically, Labour's changes have exposed to the light questions that had long been buried - and which now demand to be answered. Take devolution. Until 1997 Britain had never really come clean about its true nature as a multi-national entity: the four constituent nations each had their own cabinet department, but Britain was essentially a unitary state governed from Westminster and Whitehall. Devolution has blown that apart.

It has forced us to recognise that there are distinct countries within Britain, each with the right and ambition to govern itself - whether through a parliament in Edinburgh or assemblies in Cardiff and Belfast. The days of crypto-federalism seem to be over: thanks to devolution, Britain has acted like a country ready to come out as a federal entity.

But not completely. For Labour's decentralisation may have brought to the surface a clutch of dilemmas about Britain, but it has not resolved them. So, for example, most Britons now accept that Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland deserve home rule - but what about England? Should Westminster serve as a federal legislature, dealing only with UK-wide problems - or should it double as a de facto English parliament? Why does one of the island nations, Scotland, have more autonomy than the others? Who should sit and vote in the Westminster parliament; in the terms of the famed West Lothian question, why should Scottish MPs vote on exclusively English matters when English MPs have no say on exclusively Scottish ones?

What Labour has done is to open a can of worms: the worms were always there, we just couldn't see them before. Now the can is open we cannot look away. Perhaps the best illustration is the House of Lords. Some around Tony Blair might once have thought that expelling all but 92 of the hereditary peers would solve the problems of Britain's second chamber. Instead it's done the opposite, suddenly drawing attention to the absurd democratic deficit in parliament. When the hereditaries were there, the whole body could be written off as some Ruritanian joke. But Blair's reforms have prompted Britons to take a closer look. They now see a supposedly reformed second chamber barely more democratic than the blue-blood body it replaced - in which not a single member is elected. Leaving well alone, as the Tories used to advocate, was one thing. Now, say many Britons, if you're going to tinker with the upper house, you might as well make it democratic.

Shattered mystique

And that's a view which is beginning to apply to our entire constitution: now that Labour has broken the taboo by daring to change it, logic demands that it be changed properly - and democratically. For the current, spatchcocked arrangement of old custom and New Labour modernisation risks being the worst of both worlds, creating a constitution that makes no sense and lacks the old (if spurious) defence of ancient continuity. The mystique has shattered at last; now our very system of government is up for grabs. Even the Conservatives are discussing radical, constitutional change: witness William Hague's flirtation with the notion of an English parliament.

There is one last factor which makes urgent our need for a new constitutional settlement. Britain may be an island, but we are not alone. The changes inside the United Kingdom have coincided with profound shifts outside it, too.

We are days away from a summit in Nice which will debate and decide the future shape of the European Union. Who should govern? A simple majority of member nations or each state by wielding its individual veto? How should the peoples of Europe be bound together? With a common currency and a shared military force - or as a loose, free trade area? How should Europe declare its values? With communiques and treaties or with a basic law? In other words, the European Union is in the midst of constitutional upheaval, too.

Beyond even Europe's boundaries, there is a similarly profound argument. The global anti-capitalist movement unleashed in Seattle and Prague asks who should rule the world - its people or the corporations and the World Trade Organisation? On the streets with the protesters or in the summit rooms of Nice, the debate turns on a single word: sovereignty. Put simply, who should be in charge? That's an issue for the world, as it grapples with the domination of Microsoft or Big Oil and gropes for a new regime of global governance. It's an issue for Europe, as it works out whether sovereignty can be pooled or only diluted. And it's an issue for Britain: who is sovereign in our land?

What it all adds up to - the weaknesses of Britain's old system, the changes made by Labour and the worldwide confusion over sovereignty - is a need: we are crying out for a new constitutional settlement. We urgently require a new dispensation that would work better than the current set-up, improve the quality of our governance and yield better outcomes and better policies that would affect all Britons' lives. A new dispensation would also complete some unfinished business left over from Labour's programme of constitutional reform, turning today's "unsettlement" into a settlement. For those who care about the survival of Britain that has become an urgent task: for if we do not decide a future for the union of our nations, then that union will simply unravel. Britain will break apart.

Our country needs this new settlement within our borders to work out our place in the world beyond them. Many reformers have argued that so long as we remain confused over our own sovereignty, we have little chance of sharing or pooling it with others. When the relationship between Scotland and England is still vexed, is it any wonder we cannot find the right connection between Britain and France?

We need to make a change. We need to replace an unwritten constitution which consists of one abstract idea - the crown-in-parliament - with a settlement that fits the nation we have become and the world that now exists. We cannot wear the old, moth-eaten garb of the past any longer: we have outgrown it. This is a new century and a new millennium: we need a new constitution.

fields.headline: The need to modernise our country
fields.standfirst:
Republican commentators want to rebuild the nation. But conservatives see this as folly

Future of the monarchy

fields.trailText: Republican commentators want to rebuild the nation. But conservatives see this as folly
fields.body:
In some quarters a faintly blank look of surprise greets news of the Guardian's republican stand. Why bother? Aren't there more pressing matters? Are there no poor children, disaster schools, desperate estates, over-crowded prisons?

As the Queen trots down the Mall today in her gilded coach, the speech in her golden reticule will no doubt touch upon all these things. It may be mildly comic when the world's richest woman intones her government's concern over the plight of her less fortunate subjects. But so what? Is it really worth investing in the huge turmoil of trying to remove the monarchy when so much else presses? Yes, it is well worth it. She must be Elizabeth the Last.

The tyranny of the monarchy lies less in its temporal than its spiritual power: it tyrannises the imagination. Its spirit permeates political thinking, poisons the appetite for reform and deep dyes the blood of Britain with fantasies of who and what we are. Unconquered, never, never slaves, we are all subject to Britannia the monarch. As our glorious heritage parades again today through London to open parliament, Household Cavalry glinting in the sun, all this empty pageantry of wigs and ermine, britches and sticks promises a better yesterday. It breathes the glory of Good Queen Bess and Bluff King Hal, the Empress of India still ruling a rosy pink globe, our island story on display. Do the marching bands bring a tear to the eye? This is what we do so well!

These bare ruined choirs signify nothing, I used to think - picturesque, harmless, good for tourism. But the trappings are not trivial. They trap us in an infantile fairyland of imaginary heritage. Bogus history fuels present national delusion. Look no further than here for the reason why this country breeds small-minded bigotry, Eurosceptic xenophobia, union flag-painted brutes rampaging at foreign football matches. Why is this country so profoundly conservative, government pollsters ask? Somewhere the answer lies wrapped in the ermine. It is why this country is a recalcitrant bad neighbour in Europe, why it struts and swaggers brazenly despite an economy, a productivity and a social fabric so profoundly inferior to theirs.

The monarchy explains why this country fell behind the rest of Europe after the war, never modernised, never leapt ahead as Germany rose from the ashes. Instead victory enshrined the bad old ways, without change or introspection. The spirit of unconquered monarchy ossified a pre-war class hatred that stopped modern industrial cooperation for the first 30 post-war years.

Complacent trust in tradition let others get ahead while we declined. Modernisation was not in our bones in those key years. The rest of Europe started again, those minor countries with monarchies beginning modern post-war contracts between people and crown. Here, nothing changed. A one-term 1945 Labour government left landmarks such as the National Health Service, but no fundamental break with the past.

Now Britain's 21st century politics are still held back by empty ideas of tradition. Europe - whatever its future construction and membership - is our only destiny and yet British politicians are unable to play a full part, to engage or even to speak the truth about it to a people besotted with the magic word "sovereignty". Stymied in Europe by nothing but our own bizarre Ruritanian obsessions, things can't go on like this. Year by year it is crippling us. That word sovereignty has to be wrestled to the ground, exposed, redefined and laid to rest with a people that feels it has lost touch with power. It is their sense of powerlessness that makes them misunderstand Europe and panic at "losing" what they have too little of already.

Many regard the monarchy as just the glacé cherry atop the worm-eaten constitution. Labour has been burrowing away at its foundations, removing props and the whole edifice is tottering. No doubt more props can be found for particular glitches - the West Lothian question, the English parliament question, the House of Lords - but no amount of sticking plaster will patch together those fundamental and well justified fears that power is slipping from the people. Globalisation and worse - the failure of global governance to solve global crises in climate change or trade deals - has inflamed this sense of helplessness. Local government is a vacant lot, Westminster is a one-party state punctuated only by raucous prime minister's questions that shame rational debate. The democratic deficit creates a dangerous cynicism about all politics.

Ironically, the more people disengage from politics, the harder it becomes to persuade them that the constitution matters. Even at the height of debate about a Scottish parliament, very few Scots' pulses raced: Mori found barely 10% put it near the top of their list of concerns. Though if threatened now with losing its parliament, the Scots would rebel, Brave Heart rise from his grave. Powerlessness breeds apathy, but real power excites. So a new constitution for Britain may not burn on all lips in the bus queues. It is a "chattering classes" question for now - "Guardian stuff" nature's conservatives will say. But once offered a fairer distribution of power, people will seize it.

For the next manifesto Labour should promise a great national constitutional convention out of which to forge something better than this. Put everything into the melting pot, all sources of power, toss in the monarchy, Europe, the regions and above all proportional representation: public interest will ignite. Commission a fine preamble to the first British constitution and begin again. Already Labour's manifesto will promise a new House of Lords and a referendum on PR. Both these raise basic questions. Both require wide and loud debate, opening everything wide.

The people are there already, if asked. A Rowntree/ICM poll in October found 59% wanting PR for Westminster, even more for local government. First-past-the-post has been well discredited in the US. In Britain at the last election the only views that mattered were 168,000 voters in key marginals - 0.5% of those who voted. The rest might just as well never bother - and many didn't. Many disdain the strictly limited party choice on offer. They dislike having candidates foisted on them. They mistrust the vast power in the hands of a prime minister only a minority has voted for. That dangerous disaffection will erupt more often, as over the fuel protests. People who feel denied a voice will become more febrile when they think a government not altogether legitimate - as no doubt George W Bush will discover. Voting systems need to be aired as part of a whole new constitutional settlement.

This is not an abstract issue. Britain now urgently needs an electorate confident enough in its own power to choose to trade some of it with Europe, to multiply its long-term global power. Ironically, the slipping legitimacy of the British system has given us a prime minister with more absolute power than any since the war, yet unable to deliver on his two great projects - Europe and PR. Our essentially two-party system offers no way to build broad based cross-party consent for difficult fundamental change. Lonely as a medieval monarch surrounded by sycophants, British prime ministers become neurotic, prone to cowardice punctuated by bursts of irrational policy-making: the constitution that brought us the poll tax now brings us privatisation of the London tube.

Fine, but leave the Queen out of it, says the palace. However the monarchy is at the very heart of all this. It is not the ornamental cherry but the rotten core of Britain's decrepit democracy. A good constitution does not guarantee a good country - America's fine words are not matched by good governance. But without a new constitution Britain will be unable to shed the baggage of the ages that hold us back and keep us still the barbarian outpost of Europe.

fields.trailText: Has the return of the Scottish parliament changed the way the monarchy is seen? In one sense, hardly at all; yet in another, it threatens to change everything, and in a relatively foreseeable future.
fields.body:
Has the return of the Scottish parliament changed the way the monarchy is seen? In one sense, hardly at all; yet in another, it threatens to change everything, and in a relatively foreseeable future.

Her Majesty of course inaugurated the parliament in 1998, and with a certain grace meant to endear her anew to northern subjects. These included the editor-in-chief of the Scotsman, Mr Andrew Neil, who was seen to go weak at the knees while commenting on the event for BBC Scotland. This once stalwart republican even forecast "a new style of monarchy for the 21st century".

But the new style was soon in trouble. Because of the large Catholic vote in Scotland, all Scottish parties have a common interest in combating sectarianism, and the new assembly unanimously decided the Windsors were delinquents in this regard. The campaign was backed by Michael Forsyth, a former Tory secretary of state. The modern crown rests upon the infamous 1701 Act of Settlement, which declared that no individual of the Catholic faith should ever again occupy a British throne. Could any sane multicultural court of the present do anything but condemn such discrimination? Surely it was time for Holyrood and Westminster to join in repealing the anachronism?

With unexampled haste and glibness, Blair declined this honour. No parliamentary time, far too many consultations needed, not within the Scottish remit, and emphatically not the kind of thing middle England wanted to hear about. He had not reprieved the Windsors from Diana-fever, merely to subvert them from another direction. Also, an untarnished Queen would be required to open the Millenium Dome.

This fire-hose of platitudes omitted something quite important. The Act of Settlement is one item in the rather meagre written part of the British constitution, alongside the less picturesque Treaty of Union of 1706-7. In fact, it was a necessary condition of the latter. In fact, it was just too damn close to the spinal column of "all we hold dear". There are, after all, extremists around (not all Scots) who believe that a modern written constitution would be better for the United Kingdom (or the United Whatever-it-is), and ought to replace these heirlooms altogether. Some of them even think it was a precondition of devolved government, and that without it devolution is sure to break down.

Such lunatics are at odds (sometimes unknowingly) with the very soul of the United Kingdom. The third way pines for regeneration, not wholesale replacement. It wants a monarch kind to Muslims and Buddhists, not a soulless republic. Having transformed local government into "local government" through devolution, it now has little time for upstarts with ideas exceeding their non-sovereign status. The crown should support a given dispensation of authority, not become a lever of possible alteration.

The Scottish parliament's appeal on the 1701 act was intended reasonably, as a gesture of atonement. In reality, it was an arrow aimed at the very core of Anglo-British custom-observance. Formal renunciation of this part of the symbol-heritage might encourage a more thorough formalism, and a lettered constitutionalism, the antithesis of royal magic. Republicanism thrives on precisely that tendency. Also, the Act of Settlement was a prelude to the Treaty of Union between the old parliaments of Scotland and England, five years later: the very hinge of the United Kingdom, and just as much of an anachronism.

It was recently reiterated in the Scotland Act 1998, an element of the New Labour dispensation, therefore, and meant to stabilise it. Decidedly, children should not be allowed to play with matches in this cellar.

But play they will. By 2007, the third centenary of union, the SNP will quite probably control the executive, and be seeking to repeal the old treaty. And there will be a growing number of English republicans who agree with them. Since no new constitutional settlement was allowed to precede devolution, it will have to follow it. The matter of Britain, in which most Scots have an overwhelmingly strong, and often personal, interest, could then be renegotiated on a basis of equality, along with the other countries and populations awarded places on the Belfast Agreement's "Council of the Isles".

Terrifying only to addicts of the great and the exceptional, such a process would seek to keep (and build upon) what matters to the common life of the archipelago. Republican in essence, it would surely dispel such 18th century phantasms once and for all.

Tom Nairn is research fellow in Irish and Scottish studies at the Unversity of Aberdeen. His latest book, After Britain, is published in paperback by Granta Books on January 16
