fields.trailText: Is the modest modernisation programme at the palace enough to transform our country for the 21st century? No, it's time we were citizens, says Jonathan Freedland
fields.body:
It is the question republicans have learned to fear. "All right then," says the smiling royalist, "let's say you go ahead and abolish the monarchy. What would you put in its place?"

Variations of that question have proved lethal for reformers. In Britain the republican cause has been held back for years by two words: President Thatcher. Or, put another way, President Hattersley. Tune in to any of the now regular phone-ins and TV debates on the monarchy and you'll soon hear a defender of the status quo winning over his audience by conjuring up a dread prospect of the future.

In Australia that trap proved fatal for the republican movement. Polls showed that more than 70% of Australians wanted to elect their own head of state. Yet the 1999 referendum proposing to remove the Queen as Oz's national figurehead failed because voters did not like the replacement on offer, a "politicians' president" chosen by the Canberra parliament.

That result left British reformers with a challenge, forcing them to realise that it was not enough simply to rail against the present order: they would have to explain how any future change would work.

The first move, as made clear both by David McKie and in today's editorial, is to address the crown prerogative. Many lawyers, scholars and activists now agree that "the crown" underpins and explains many if not most of the excesses and distortions of our current governmental set-up. But what would reform of such a nebulous, shadowy concept entail? What would abolition of the crown mean?

At first glance, such a drastic move might seem just too vast - like whipping out the ground from underneath our feet. Everything would have to change - from our land law, which technically makes every freeholder the mere owner of an interest in the land of the monarch, to our courts, which currently present every case as The Crown or Regina vs. Joe Bloggs.

In fact, it would not be that complicated. Legally, the notional entity of the crown could simply be replaced by "the state" or, where it's more honest, "the government" or even, perhaps in criminal court cases, by "the people." Each one of these would be abstract entities, admittedly, but they would at least be less opaque than the legal fiction that is "the crown". As Geoffrey Robertson QC explains it, the crown is merely "an artefact". To replace it with the people and their parliament is a simple manoeuvre.

The more fundamental matter is the crown as a constitutional, rather than legal, entity: what would we do with the prerogative?

This is actually two questions rolled into one. First, there are the residual royal powers, which can be exercised by the monarch herself: to appoint a prime minister and refuse a request for a dissolution of parliament. These look merely theoretical, until one imagines Britain caught in a Florida-style electoral deadlock. In the event of a hung parliament, who under our current system would choose whether to give the nod to Tony Blair or William Hague? Answer: the Queen.

The fate for these two royal prerogatives is fairly straightforward. We could simply keep them in the hands of the newly democratic head of state - however that person was chosen (of which more later). Or we could make at least one of those powers redundant. The right to refuse a dissolution exists only because our parliamentary terms are currently not fixed. With set terms, of four or five years, there would be no question of early elections. Polling day would be known years in advance - with no need to give the power over dissolution to anyone. Such a reform would have the added benefit of bringing fairness to our electoral contests: at present, the prime minister's right to name polling day is tantamount to a running race in which one of the contestants gets to fire the starting gun.

Crown prerogative

More complex is the crown prerogative itself. As David McKie writes on page 19, that notion is used to exercise all kinds of executive power - from making war to dispensing largesse and patronage. What would we do with these powers, currently exercised not by the Queen but by the prime minister?

The answer is abolition. The flaw of the last constitutional settlement - in the 17th century - was that it did not abolish the absolute powers of the monarch, but merely tied them up in purple string and handed them, in effect, to the prime minister. The absolute powers themselves remained; only the person wielding them changed. So the solution now would not be to keep crown prerogative in the hands of the PM, with only a change of name. On the contrary, the reformers' case is that the prerogative itself should be taken apart.

What that would mean in practice is diffusion. Some of today's crown powers would stay in the hands of the executive but others would be spread about. The power to make war and sign treaties might go to the UK parliament in Westminster. The power of patronage, to fill the benches of the second chamber, could move to the electorate, via direct election of new members. The vast battery of powers that makes our executive the mightiest in the western world could all be spread elsewhere: more to the parliaments in Edinburgh, Belfast and Cardiff, more to mayors in London and to any other big city that wants them. The crown prerogative would simply be dismantled - its goodies spread around the country, no longer hoarded at the centre. The result would be a change in the very way Britain is governed. No longer the old monarchical model, in which power flows from the top down - but a more democratic shape, in which power is diffuse and flows from the bottom up.

So much for the royal and crown prerogatives. With those powers either aboliished or transferred, what's left in the space marked head of state? Is there even a job left to fill?

The palace doubt it. They believe that the vague, mysterious association of Crown and Queen is essential to her role as head of state. They insist that no head of state could ever function separate from the ancient edifice of prerogative. In other words, Britain could not conceivably have a head of state other than a monarch.

But look closer. Here is how palace officials privately define the job. To them, a head of state must act as the focus of the nation, leading the nation in mourning or celebration - serving as the public expression of collective emotions. Cattily, some might doubt the royals' track record in this particular field. More seriously, they might wonder if this is a task only those of royal blood could perform.

Second, say the Windsor circle, a head of state should recognise public achievement: visiting hospitals, handing out awards. True but, once again, is this a role that could only be performed by a single, genetically ordained family? Third, a national figurehead should contribute to the collective welfare - leading voluntary work or promoting charity. There's no doubt today's royals do that - but so do elected heads of state the world over.

In fact, it is only the last aspect of the palace's job description that touches on a role perhaps the royals alone can perform: to act as a rock of continuity, an anchor during periods of intense change. It's true that royalty can claim a lineage and a past that others cannot. But even that is a mixed blessing: for the rock symbolises not just stability but paralysis, a society whose hierarchies and aristocracy remain in place for centuries - permanently excluding everyone else from ever reaching the nation's symbolic pinnacle.

The people's choice

So, despite the palace's insistence to the contrary, a head of state does not always have to be chosen by birth. They can be chosen by people. How might Britain do it? Most republicans agree the question will not realistically, and probably ought not, arise until the present Queen dies. She has won wide admiration after a half-century of service and will doubtless close out her reign the same way. But what then? There are countless options. Perhaps the simplest would be to combine the role of head of state with that of head of government, so that when the nation chooses a prime minister at election time it would also pick the person to host foreign dignitaries and state banquets. That would be simple, but perhaps unsatisfactory - for we would lose out on the extra role of constitutional longstop a head of state can play.

We could opt for direct election, just like the Irish. Enter the critics threatening the nightmare of Presidents Hattersley or Thatcher - though if that truly is a nightmare, the electorate is hardly likely to vote for it. Besides, one could easily write the rules to prevent any past politician seeking the job. When one looks at the success of Mary Robinson or Mary McAleese in Dublin, direct election looks quite appealing.

For those who suspect a directly-elected president with a national mandate would be too strong a rival for the rest of our politicians - chiefly the prime minister - to tolerate, then indirect election is the obvious alternative. At present MPs, who we vote for, choose the Speaker - and that person could easily double as head of state, even taking on the weighty task of picking which leader should form a government from a hung parliament. Some would say that would give the Speaker too much power, especially if Britain were to adopt proportional representation. But that power already exists -resting in the hands of a hereditary monarch nobody chooses and nobody can remove.

There are plenty of variations: including activist Anthony Barnett's notion that a "royal family" should be chosen by random lot, like jury service, once every three years. Reformers argue that Britons can do it however they like - just so long as, for the first time ever, they choose their own head of state.

The benefits, they say, will be subtle, but real. For Britons will do more than choose the person who "interprets the nation to itself". By asserting themselves, rather than the crown, as the governing force in British life, they will become the owners of their own country - insisting that it is their land, not the crown's, that it is their government, not Her Majesty's, and that nothing is beyond their reach. Britons will be owners, not tenants, of their country; citizens, not subjects. We will at last be able to declare that there is only one sovereign in our land - and it is ourselves.

20 things only a monarch can do

1Own all unmarked mute swans on open water.

2 Hold up other traffic on the railways while the royal train passes.

3 Get the full and unabridged minutes of all Cabinet minutes - unlike Cabinet ministers who must make do with a summary.

4 Receive reports of all Royal commissions ahead of those who commissioned them, on vellum.

5 Declare holidays: an extra bank holiday in 2002 to mark the golden jubilee four- day celebration weekend.

6 Appoint all magistrates in Liverpool, Manchester and Lancashire. The Queen is known as Duke of Lancashire when in the Duchy of Lancaster.

7 Require the national flag to be flown on 16 royal birthdays anniversaries, from 8am until sunset.

8 Appoint a privy council. All senior politicians become members, undergoing a ceremony in which they kneel on a bible, take the royal hand and walk backwards out of the room. The privy council meets where the monarch happens to be (Balmoral, during the fuel crisis).

9 Get advice from QCs, free of charge.

10 Accept more orders and decorations than anyone else: the present Queen has 85 decorations from 68 countries.

11 Extend patronage: the present Queen is patron of 600 societies, organisations and events (816 over the reign).

12 Command regiments: every regiment of the British army owes its loyalty to a member of the royal family. The present Queen commands 46.

13 Receive a daily report of parliamentary proceedings from the vice chamberlain of the household: the report must reach the palace by dinner and is ready by no one else. The vice chamberlain, an MP, is held hostage during the state opening of parliament to ensure the monarch's safe return.

14 Issue special ivory carriage passes to members of the royal household and chosen ministers, allowing them to take a short cut through St James park.

15 Hold position of lord high admiral of the navy, which the present queen has held since 1964. (The Duke of Edinburgh is also admiral of the fleet in three navies: other admirals of the British navy are the King of Sweden and Don Juan of Borbon and Battenberg, the count of Barcelona).

16 Command oaths of loyalty: sworn by all MPs, lords, three of the four armed services, the judiciary, ordained priests of the Church of England, newly naturalised citizens.

17 Drive without a driving licence, because not covered by the Road Traffic Act.

18 Take as treasure trove all coin, bullion, gold and silver found buried for which no owners can be traced.

19 Award royal warrants to around 800 businesses, including seven champagne houses.

20 Avoid the criminal law: the monarch is not subject to it or to everyday regulations governing things like how long royal staff work.

When one looks at the success of Mary Robinson or Mary McAleese in Dublin, direct election looks quite appealing. For those who suspect a directly-elected president with a national mandate would be too strong a rival for the rest of our politicians - chiefly the prime minister - to tolerate, then indirect election is the obvious alternative. At present MPs, who we vote for, choose the Speaker - and that person could easily double as head of state, even taking on the weighty task of picking which leader should form a government from a hung parliament. Some would say that would give the Speaker too much power, especially if Britain were to adopt proportional representation. But that power already exists -resting in the hands of a hereditary monarch nobody chooses and nobody can remove. There are plenty of variations: including activist Anthony Barnett's notion that a "royal family" should be chosen by random lot, like jury service, once every three years. Reformers argue that Britons can do it however they like - just so long as, for the first time ever, they choose their own head of state. The benefits, they say, will be subtle, but real. For Britons will do more than choose the person who "interprets the nation to itself". By asserting themselves, rather than the crown, as the governing force in British life, they will become the owners of their own country - insisting that it is their land, not the crown's, that it is their government, not Her Majesty's, and that nothing is beyond their reach. Britons will be owners, not tenants, of their country; citizens, not subjects. We will at last be able to declare that there is only one sovereign in our land - and it is ourselves. 20 things only a monarch can do 1Own all unmarked mute swans on open water. 2 Hold up other traffic on the railways while the royal train passes. 3 Get the full and unabridged minutes of all Cabinet minutes - unlike Cabinet ministers who must make do with a summary. 4 Receive reports of all Royal commissions ahead of those who commissioned them, on vellum. 5 Declare holidays: an extra bank holiday in 2002 to mark the golden jubilee four- day celebration weekend. 6 Appoint all magistrates in Liverpool, Manchester and Lancashire. The Queen is known as Duke of Lancashire when in the Duchy of Lancaster. 7 Require the national flag to be flown on 16 royal birthdays anniversaries, from 8am until sunset. 8 Appoint a privy council. All senior politicians become members, undergoing a ceremony in which they kneel on a bible, take the royal hand and walk backwards out of the room. The privy council meets where the monarch happens to be (Balmoral, during the fuel crisis). 9 Get advice from QCs, free of charge. 10 Accept more orders and decorations than anyone else: the present Queen has 85 decorations from 68 countries. 11 Extend patronage: the present Queen is patron of 600 societies, organisations and events (816 over the reign). 12 Command regiments: every regiment of the British army owes its loyalty to a member of the royal family. The present Queen commands 46. 13 Receive a daily report of parliamentary proceedings from the vice chamberlain of the household: the report must reach the palace by dinner and is ready by no one else. The vice chamberlain, an MP, is held hostage during the state opening of parliament to ensure the monarch's safe return. 14 Issue special ivory carriage passes to members of the royal household and chosen ministers, allowing them to take a short cut through St James park. 15 Hold position of lord high admiral of the navy, which the present queen has held since 1964. (The Duke of Edinburgh is also admiral of the fleet in three navies: other admirals of the British navy are the King of Sweden and Don Juan of Borbon and Battenberg, the count of Barcelona). 16 Command oaths of loyalty: sworn by all MPs, lords, three of the four armed services, the judiciary, ordained priests of the Church of England, newly naturalised citizens. 17 Drive without a driving licence, because not covered by the Road Traffic Act. 18 Take as treasure trove all coin, bullion, gold and silver found buried for which no owners can be traced. 19 Award royal warrants to around 800 businesses, including seven champagne houses. 20 Avoid the criminal law: the monarch is not subject to it or to everyday regulations governing things like how long royal staff work. webTitle: Metro to launch in Leeds and Sheffield

fields.headline: Metro to launch in Leeds and Sheffield
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Associated Newspapers is to launch two more editions of its successful Metro newspaper, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Associated Newspapers is to launch two more editions of its successful Metro newspaper.

It will add Leeds and Sheffield in January to its existing network of six city papers.

And the publisher is considering launching two more Metro editions in Liverpool and Bristol next year.

Managing director Mike Anderson said the company may also step up the circulation war with the Guardian-owned Manchester Evening News.

The metropolitan freesheet has already been launched in Manchester, but Associated, which publishes the London Evening Standard, believes it could also have a market in the evening.

Mr Anderson said: "It would be foolish for us not to engage with our Manchester audience in other parts of the day - for example, when they are going home.

"We have clearly got the editorial expertise to talk to this audience and we might want to talk to them again."

webTitle: Comment: The legality of 1701 Act of Settlement

fields.headline: A challenge to the crown: now is the time for change
fields.standfirst:
Law on succession to throne may be incompatible with Human Rights Act

Future of the monarchy

Join the debate online
fields.trailText: Law on succession to throne may be incompatible with Human Rights Act
fields.body:
The Guardian is to back a legal challenge to the 300-year-old law banning Roman Catholics and other non-Protestants from succession to the British throne, on the grounds that it clashes with the Human Rights Act and should be reinterpreted or removed from the statute book.

Leading human rights lawyer Geoffrey Robertson QC believes the Act of Settlement 1701 may be affected by the European convention on human rights, which became part of UK law two months ago when the Human Rights Act came into force.

The challenge to the Act of Settlement coincides with an editorial in the paper which argues for a referendum on the future of the monarchy.

The act, passed at a time of widespread fear of Catholics, lays down that only Protestant heirs of Princess Sophia, granddaughter of James I, may take the British throne. Neither Catholics, nor those who marry a Catholic, nor those born out of wedlock, may remain in the line of succession.

The act remains the crucial cornerstone of the British constitution, exercising an extraordinary hold over the monarchy and imposing limitations designed to tackle the imperatives of a political crisis at the dawn of the 18th century. But it is scarcely relevant to the 21st.

Because of it, dozens of people have been barred from taking their place in the order of succession. Since many of them are German, the Guardian has placed an advertisement in the Süddeutsche Zeitung asking them to join the action to reclaim their birthright.

Sons also take precedence over daughters and the right of succession belongs to the eldest son. The act institutionalises religious discrimination and male primogeniture.

The Human Rights Act gives UK judges power for the first time to reinterpret statutes to make them compatible "so far as possible" with the European convention.

Mr Robertson considers it may be "possible" for the courts to read the Act of Settlement's language in a way which avoids discrimination against women and some religious faiths but the "express virulence" of the act's anti-Catholic language could only be removed by legislation. If judges find it impossible to re-word the statute, the Human Rights Act allows them to make a "declaration of incompatibility". This leaves the statute in force but puts pressure on the government to reform it, since the UK has signed up to the convention and pledged that it will comply with convention rights.

The Guardian argues in an editorial today that in the new millennium Britain should be given the choice whether to keep the royal family or to become a republic.

Today and over the next few days the paper is running a number of articles advocating republicanism, despite another outdated statute, the Treason Felony Act 1848, which threatens anyone doing so with deportation "for the term of his or her natural life".

The paper's editor, Alan Rusbridger wrote last week to the attorney general, Lord Williams of Mostyn, asking for an assurance that he will not be prosecuted, given that he has no intention of advocating overthrow of the monarchy by force. In his letter, he argued the Treason Felony Act breaches article 10 of the European convention, the right to freedom of expression.

He suggested the attorney general might ask the high court to reinterpret the Treason Felony Act so that only calls to overthrow the monarchy by violence would be an offence. He offered the paper's support in the application.

Lord Williams replied: "I hope you understand that Neither David Calvert-Smith [the director of public prosecutions] nor I can give you an assurance regarding whether or not a prosecution or other action will be taken. You are asking me to take action which sanctions in advance conduct which may be criminal. You should take your own legal advice then decide for yourself whether you will follow it."

Under the Human Rights Act, judges are expected to interpret an existing statute as far as possible so as to be compatible with the human rights convention. Mr Robertson believes the courts may use this power to limit the scope of the Treason Felony Act so it complies with the right to freedom of expression. Only if this is not possible should they make a declaration of incompatibility.

The Guardian believes the Act of Settlement violates article 9 of the convention, the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion. In addition, it breaches article 1 of protocol 1, the right to peaceful enjoyment of possessions - in this case the banned descendants' place in the line of succession - and article 14, banning discrimination in relation to any convention right.

Not only are Catholics banned from succession, but the sovereign must be in communion with the Church of England, must swear to preserve the church, and to uphold the Protestant line of succession. This appears to discriminate against other faiths, including Jews, Muslims and Hindus.

At her coronation in 1953, the Queen pledged to maintain and preserve the church's doctrine, worship and discipline.

In December 1999 the Scottish parliament backed unanimously a motion, spearheaded by the Scottish National party, to abolish the Act of Settlement. The debate had been initiated by Lord Hamilton - Tory whip in the Scottish parliament - who wrote to the Tony Blair asking him to lift the "anachronistic" act.

Soon after the Scottish vote, the Archbishop of York, David Hope, called for the act to be amended to allow the heir to the throne to marry a Catholic.

Officials said amending the act of Settlement . But the Human Rights Act lays down a fast track method for amending statutes judged incompatible with the European convention. Failure to do so would leave the UK open to condemnation by the European court.

"No one can really defend this act," said Mr Rusbridger. "Since MPs are barred from openly debating the role of the monarch we thought a newspaper might set the ball rolling. We very much hope that the odd Hapsburg or Saxe-Coburg might join in."

fields.headline: Daily Telegraph editor condemns jailed sub
fields.standfirst:
Dec 5: Telegraph subeditor jailed
Dec 6: How the New Nation covered it
fields.trailText:
Daily Telegraph editor Charles Moore has condemned one of the paper's subeditors who was jailed yesterday for racist behaviour, writes Lisa O'Carroll

Dec 5: Telegraph subeditor jailed

Dec 6: How the New Nation covered it
fields.body:
Daily Telegraph editor Charles Moore has condemned one of the paper's subeditors who was jailed yesterday for racist behaviour.

He said Dominic Swords, 34, of Denmark Hill in London, who worked on a part-time basis in the arts department, would no longer work for the paper.

"Dominic Swords is not a member of the Daily Telegraph staff but was working on a part-time contract as a subeditor. His employment is at an end," said Mr Moore.

He added: "Although one wants to try to make allowances for people who have a drink problem, his conduct in this case was completely inexcusable.

"He compounded his fault by not informing anyone at the Daily Telegraph about the nature of his offence. So we learned only today what had happened."

webTitle: 'Sleeper' court cases could swing election to Gore

fields.headline: 'Sleeper' court cases could swing election to Gore
fields.standfirst: Republicans illegally filled in absentee ballot forms for voters. Julian Borger explains two cases which may see 25,000 votes, mostly for Bush, annulled
fields.trailText: Republicans illegally filled in absentee ballot forms for voters. Julian Borger in Tallahassee explains two cases which may see 25,000 votes, mostly for Bush, annulled.
fields.body:
The corridors of the Tallahassee courthouse are filled with their usual shifting population of suspects, offenders and felons, but in recent days they have been pushed to the side by a great heaving noisy throng of lawyers and journalists.

A month after election day, the piercing spotlight accompanying the battle for ballots has invaded these normally mundane corridors, and the presidency of the United States will be fought over amid drunk-driving misdemeanours and aggravated assault charges.

While the Florida supreme court mulls over Al Gore's challenge to the state's certified count today, two parallel cases will be heard in these small overcrowded courtrooms across the road, which may yet prove to be just as important.

The cases refer to what happened in Martin county, just north of Palm Beach, and Seminole county, near Orlando, in the months leading up to election day. The circumstances are yet another illustration of the localised, haphazard nature of US democracy and the supervisory power vested in partisan officials to oversee the poll in a supposedly non-partisan manner. These are the fundamental problems that this remarkable dead-heat will force the country to confront.

In an attempt to galvanise support among voters living abroad or out of state, the parties in Florida had ballot application forms printed up for them privately so they could send them off to potential supporters. The forms would already be filled in to make it as easy as possible for the voters to cast their ballots. All they had to do is sign and send them off.

Unfortunately for the Republicans, about 2,000 of the ballots they had printed up in Seminole county had a blank where the voter's identification number was supposed to be. There had been a printing glitch. In Martin county, the voter's date of birth had been printed where the identification number was supposed to be.

Under strict Florida law, which had been tightened up after a corrupt 1997 mayoral election in Miami, the completed ballot application forms should have been put in the bin and that is what Sandra Goard, the Seminole elections supervisor and a Republican, was going to do with them. But Republican party workers found out about them and they made Goard an offer. What if we come in and fill them in?

Goard agreed and provided them a desk and a chair for the Republican officials to sit in her office and correct the errors before the ballots were sent out. In Martin county, the elections supervisor, Peggy Robbins, another Republican, allowed party activists take the ballot forms out of her office and return them a few days later.

This was against Florida law, but probably nobody would have heard about it if a cocky Republican activist had not bragged about it in the Seminole county court building within earshot of a wisecracking, fast-talking and restless personal-injury lawyer called Harry Jacobs. Mr Jacobs, a fishmonger's son from New Jersey who likes nothing better than a good fight, blew the whistle.

When the news broke, the Gore campaign decided not to get directly involved. Elsewhere in Florida it was trying to make the argument that "every vote should be counted". It did not want to start arguing that Republican votes should be thrown away on a technicality. Mr Jacobs had no such scruples. He is an outspoken Democrat with an almost visceral hatred of the Bush family and he went to court calling for the affected votes to be ruled null and void.

As the votes cannot be tracked back to the ballot forms, he argues, all 15,000 absentee ballots cast in Seminole should be thrown out. The Democratic plaintiffs in Martin are calling for about 10,000 ballots to be cast out there. As George W Bush won a majority of absentee votes in both counties, annulling the ballots would switch the election in Al Gore's direction.

So the cameras have arrived in the Tallahassee circuit courts, where excited legal analysts (a constantly growing industry) are calling the Seminole and Martin cases the "sleepers" of the election, unnoticed embers which may yet ignite and change everything.

Yet it will be hard for Gore camp to score a major victory. Did it truly amount to fraud? Even if there was a technical infringement of the law, would it justify a total of 25,000 votes being invalidated? In a legal arena which sets so much store by the intent of the voter, the remedy may look worse than the malady.

webTitle: How the New Nation newspaper reported it

fields.headline: How the New Nation newspaper reported it
fields.standfirst: Dec 5: Telegraph subeditor jailed
fields.trailText: Dec 5: Telegraph subeditor jailed
fields.body:
A Daily Telegraph journalist who jumped into a man's car and said "Take me home, you black bastard" has claimed he has no memory of what happened.

Dominic Swords, 34, a subeditor with the national newspaper, stepped in front of Delbert Husband's car while he was driving on London's Tower Bridge. He then got into the car and started to shout foul, racist abuse at the shocked driver.

Swords was in the car for more than 20 minutes, causing traffic on the busy London road to build up as Delbert refused to drive him home. The police were called and he was arrested and charged with common assault.

But Swords refused to enter a plea of guilty or not guilty on his first appearance before Victoria Court Magistrate on October 13. He demanded to see CCTV evidence before finally pleading guilty to charges of threatening behaviour and racially motivated assault last month.

In a letter to Delbert, Swords wrote: "I have just seen the CCTV footage of what took place between us on Tower Bridge last month. Until now I had no memory of the incident. All I remember is leaving the party I had attended and thinking 'I'm drunk, I'd better get a cab home'.

"I am truly sorry for putting you through the ordeal of having to deal with a lunatic getting in your car and then shouting abuse at you. You obviously did the right thing in staying calm and calling the police. I am amazed and grateful that you did not throw me off the bridge. What I did was utterly awful and if you had given me a thrashing I would have no grounds for complaint."

But Delbert, speaking to New Nation exclusively after his ordeal, feels that the apology, which came one month after the incident, is too late. The 32-year-old maintenance worker for Lewisham Council told New Nation: "This letter has come too late, I read it and thought he was just grovelling. I don't think there's any excuse for what he did.

"A madman jumps in front of your car and walks round and gets inside and I was just sitting there in shock. I explained to him nicely that I wasn't a cab. I even walked round to the passenger's seat and opened the door to let him out and he still didn't get out.

"My blood was boiling but I phoned the police and they asked me to drive him to the nearest station. I refused because I didn't want to go anywhere with him in my car. At one point he took his glasses off like he was going to fight me and the policewoman said, 'Please don't hit him, we're recording it.'"

Delbert, who has a 10-year-old daughter, Trivina, is undergoing counselling after his terrible ordeal with Swords. A respected member of the community, Delbert was given the Lewisham Mayor's award for fending off a mugger who attacked a pensioner earlier this year.

He demanded to see CCTV evidence before finally pleading guilty to charges of threatening behaviour and racially motivated assault last month. In a letter to Delbert, Swords wrote: "I have just seen the CCTV footage of what took place between us on Tower Bridge last month. Until now I had no memory of the incident. All I remember is leaving the party I had attended and thinking 'I'm drunk, I'd better get a cab home'. "I am truly sorry for putting you through the ordeal of having to deal with a lunatic getting in your car and then shouting abuse at you. You obviously did the right thing in staying calm and calling the police. I am amazed and grateful that you did not throw me off the bridge. What I did was utterly awful and if you had given me a thrashing I would have no grounds for complaint." But Delbert, speaking to New Nation exclusively after his ordeal, feels that the apology, which came one month after the incident, is too late. The 32-year-old maintenance worker for Lewisham Council told New Nation: "This letter has come too late, I read it and thought he was just grovelling. I don't think there's any excuse for what he did. "A madman jumps in front of your car and walks round and gets inside and I was just sitting there in shock. I explained to him nicely that I wasn't a cab. I even walked round to the passenger's seat and opened the door to let him out and he still didn't get out. "My blood was boiling but I phoned the police and they asked me to drive him to the nearest station. I refused because I didn't want to go anywhere with him in my car. At one point he took his glasses off like he was going to fight me and the policewoman said, 'Please don't hit him, we're recording it.'" Delbert, who has a 10-year-old daughter, Trivina, is undergoing counselling after his terrible ordeal with Swords. A respected member of the community, Delbert was given the Lewisham Mayor's award for fending off a mugger who attacked a pensioner earlier this year.

webTitle: Obituary: Gordon Smith

fields.headline: Gordon Smith
fields.standfirst: His ingenuity broke the film industry ban and brought movies to BBC television
fields.trailText: His ingenuity broke the film industry ban and brought movies to BBC television
fields.body:
Gordon Smith, who has died aged 88, was BBC Television's film buyer from the days when the film industry was blocking the showing of feature films on television. Instrumental in defeating the ban, he became a key figure in the age of plenty that followed, when flair and discrimination were needed in order to spot the gold among the dross.

Unlike his opposite number in ITV, Leslie Halliwell, whose film and television reference books made him a household name, Smith was content to remain plain Mr Smith, never using his full surname, Sidery-Smith.

In Hollywood, however, where he and Halliwell would go on regular buying trips, he was highly respected, and acquired for the corporation movies like The Sound Of Music, and many of television's own classic titles, including Dr Kildare (United States, 1961), Star Trek (US, 1966), Perry Mason (US, 1957), the Danny Kaye Show (US, 1963) and Rowan And Martin's Laugh-In (US, 1968).

He went straight into show business from Enfield grammar school, working as a personal assistant to W McQueen Pope, remembered now as a writer on the theatre but in his time also an impresario. In 1935, Smith took his first job in films, at Warner Brothers' Teddington studios.

He was commissioned into the Royal Army Ordnance Corps during the second world war, but soon diverted to military film-making, finishing up as a lieutenant-colonel on Mountbatten's staff in the Far East. On demobilisation, he became chief executive of the Crown Film Unit, which had made information features during the war and was now turning its attention to the issues of peace.

Smith joined the BBC in 1947 as a radio drama booking manager. In the early 1950s, he transferred to the television service, then at Lime Grove, as head of purchased programmes, in which capacity he immediately made his mark.

The cinema business was still frightened by the spread of television and, through its Film Industry Defence Organisation (Fido), operated a blacklist against any studio or distributor supplying the enemy. In 1958, Smith contrived to acquire a limited number of old movies from RKO, which had already gone out of business, followed by some classics - including Laurence Olivier's Henry V - from the decaying Rank Organisation.

His great coup came in 1964, when BBC2 was about to go on the air, committed to a regular movie evening. In the nick of time, Smith acquired Paramount's full pre-1948 library, including the Preston Sturges comedies, the Hope-Crosby "Road" films and Sunset Boulevard. With Lew Grade achieving a similar breakthrough at about the same time at ITV, the Fido campaign collapsed.

The preoccupations of film buyers then moved to television's own films and filmed series, a field in which Smith again demonstrated his flair. Early in a vogue for western series, he acquired one of the best of them, The Virginian (US, 1962). Asked to find a replacement for the BBC's own Maigret series, which ran from 1960 to 1963, he came back with Perry Mason.

His programme controllers complained that it was courtroom, not detective, drama, but it was an immediate success with BBC viewers, and was followed by another legal format, The Defenders (US, 1961). Against this, it was also in Smith's time that the BBC launched - and then aborted - the absurd Rat Patrol (1966), which re-wrote the British 8th Army's desert victory in terms of all-American heroics.

Smith was a gentle, if sometimes short-tempered, individual. He had a long feud with the young lions of Grace Wyndham Goldie, the first head of BBC-TV news and current affairs, over the early evening show, Tonight, because they would keep popping film clips on to the air without first clearing them, and Gordon had to square it afterwards with MGM or Disney.

Like Halliwell, he was a valued member of the National Film Archive's television selection committee, which I chaired for a number of years, and a lingering animosity between him and the formidable Mrs Goldie may have been the hidden cause of a fierce screaming match the two conducted, over no obvious difference of opinion, at one of our meetings.

On retirement in 1969, Smith first entered an Anglican community in East Anglia, but later moved to a nearby cottage with his partner, David, whom he had met during his early days at the BBC. David predeceased him.

webTitle: Break out the Bolly! Ab Fab back

fields.headline: Break out the Bolly! Ab Fab back
fields.trailText: 2.00pm: Three years after saying farewell to the nation, the queens of comedy are to be reunited in a brand new series of the hit BBC sitcom,writes Lisa O'Carroll
fields.body:
Oh Dahling, isn't it just wonderful? Absolutely Fabulous is coming back, the BBC announced today.

Three years after saying farewell to the nation, the queens of comedy Jennifer Saunders, Joanna Lumley, June Whitfield and Julia Sawalha are to be reunited in a brand new series of the hit BBC sitcom.

Ms Saunders said today she decided to write a new series after she sat down with the cast for a special one-off comedy, Mirrorball, to be screened over Christmas.

"We had such a great time making Mirrorball that we all wanted to work together again.

"But when I sat down to write the new characters I felt Edina and Patsy and all the other Ab Fab characters vying for my attention," said Ms Saunders.

She added: "So, in the end I gave in...and I'm looking forward to moving on the characters into the millennium, and adding a few new ones."

A new series of Ab Fab is a major coup for BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey who, like her predecessor Peter Salmon, has been ordered to inject some new life into sitcom and comedy drama.

Ab Fab is guaranteed to win the heart of the nation however - it won ratings of over 11 million when originally screened.

The new series will be a cross between Mirrorball and Absolutely Fabulous, with life in the Bollinger-saturated public relations world dramatically changed.

PR disaster Edina, played by Ms Saunders, is now promoting herself as a media celebrity while her straight-laced daughter Saffie, played by Julia Sawalha, has become a "serious" actress.

Saffie's grandmother - June Whitfield - has a new job while darling Patsy, played by Joanna Lumley, finds herself on her uppers, rummaging through bins while she tries to hold her own.

Jane Horrocks, formerly Bubbles, will return as as Yitta Hilberstam, an Icelandic waitress whose command of English is eccentric.

Absolutely Fabulous first hit the screens in 1992 as a BBC2 special, but it went on to become one of BBC1's biggest hits transferring to the station in 1994 for two more series and two specials.

webTitle: Programming highlights of BBC's winter schedule unveiled

fields.headline: BBC unveils highlights of new winter schedule
fields.trailText: As the BBC's experiment Castaway comes to an end, TV executives have already secretly filmed another spectacular live-in experiment. By Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
As the BBC's millennium experiment Castaway comes to an end and the volunteers prepare to escape the ravaged island of Taransay, TV executives have already secretly filmed another spectacular live-in experiment.

BBC1 is sending a team of volunteers back to the iron age in a bid to give viewers a sense of what it was like to live 2,000 years ago.

Surviving the Iron Age revisits an experiment conducted by the BBC 23 years ago, when a group of young people cut themselves off from society and lived for a year like Iron Age Britons in a settlement near Shaftesbury, Dorset.

The 12 adults and three children were denied the comforts of late 20th century life, had to kill their own animals, wash their hair in clay and brush their teeth with hazel twigs.

Today the BBC revealed it had sent 17 volunteers, some of whom were the children of the original participants.

Seven men, seven women and three children have braved the elements of West Wales for nearly seven weeks living in authentic Iron Age round houses, making soap from sheep fat and killing their own chickens and butchering their own cattle.

The programme is one of the highlights of the winter season unveiled by the BBC today.

It also announced it was investing almost £60m in new drama for the winter schedule which will see 13 brand new titles over the next three months.

One of the centrepieces is the controversial drama Rebel Heart, by writer Ronan Bennett, focusing on the passion and patriotism surrounding the 1916 rising in Ireland and the civil war that followed.

Sue Townsend's latest Adrian Mole creation, The Cappuccino Years, will also take centre stage.

Stephen Tomkinson and Nick Berry will be starring as undercover detectives in the gritty drama, In Deep.

And Michelle Collins and comedian Paul Kaye star in Two Thousand Acres Of Sky, a humorous and poignant drama about a single mum desperate to escape inner city life.

John Cleese, with the help of Elizabeth Hurley, sets out to discover the mysteries of life, in The Human Face, a documentary that traces the use and importance of the image of the face through the ages.

Among the comedy highlights for the winter schedule are Lee Evans's first situation comedy, Lee Evans - So What Now.

And Pauline Quirk will star in Office Gossip, her first sitcom since Birds Of A Feather.

BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey said: "The added investment in BBC1 is already visible on the screen. We have been able to offer the viewer 20% more drama than last winter."

webTitle: Marketing Week round-up

fields.headline: Marketing Week round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: December 7.
fields.trailText: December 7: Bartle Bogle Hegarty has resigned the £60m pan-European Sega account to pitch for Microsoft's the X-Box.
fields.body:
Bartle Bogle Hegarty has resigned the £60m pan-European Sega account to pitch for rival Microsoft's planned games console, the X-Box.

Camelot is to drop its trademark lion symbol if it wins the contest for the next National Lottery licence, in a bid to put its fatcat past behind it. The company will commission a new logo.

United Biscuits' top marketeer, Ed Jackson, has been made redundant as part of a management shake-up.

Unilever is to rename Jif cleaner to align the brand across the world. Jif will become Cif, the name it is known by in 80% of markets.

Gameplay is to axe up to 20 people from its marketing department when it closes its Colchester and Wimbledon offices next year.

Matthew Clark Drinks is considering rolling out a range of Babycham clothing and jewellery based on the brand's famous fawn logo.

Seagram is developing a range of pre-mixed Martell cocktails in an attempt to make the brandy more attractive to young consumers.

The BBC has appointed Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO, Fallon and Duckworth Finn Grubb Waters to its advertising roster.

Heineken has admitted it will review its UK advertising when its distribution contract with the Whitbread Beer Company comes to an end. The account is handled by Lowe Lintas.

The BBC has promoted Guy North from its digital marketing division to be head of marketing for sport. Head of brand marketing David Grint becomes head of marketing planning.

webTitle: Millionaire's £2m gift to estate where boy died

fields.headline: Millionaire's £2m gift to estate where boy died
fields.trailText: A millionaire businessman who grew up in the south London street where Damilola Taylor was stabbed is to donate £2m to build a day centre for the local community.
fields.body:
A millionaire businessman who grew up in the south London street where Damilola Taylor was stabbed is to donate £2m to build a day centre for the local community.

Lord Harris, 58, the chief executive of Carpetright, announced yesterday he was working with the government to find ways of regenerating the North Peckham estate where the 10-year-old died on Monday last week following an attack in nearby Blake's Road.

The centre is likely to be named after Damilola and Southwark council has said it will speak to the boy's family to ensure relatives had a chance to contribute to the project.

Damilola's father, Richard, who flew to London from Nigeria last Friday, is expected to speak at a Scotland Yard press conference this morning. Detectives are hoping his appeal will persuade witnesses to come forward.

The murder squad, which now has 80 officers, has been told traces of Damilola's blood were on pieces of two beer bottles found in Blake's Road. But forensic scientists suspect neither bottle was the murder weapon.

They believe Damilola may have dripped blood on the glass as he ran for help.

A pathologist has told Detective Chief Inspector Trevor Shepheard, who is leading the investigation that Damilola was probably stabbed with a knife.

Police are looking for three youths - two black, one white - who tried to walk up the stairwell where Damilola collapsed and died. They were turned away and told to use a lift.

Detectives believe the three boys may have seen a group of youths who were spotted at the bottom of the stairwell by the workman who found him moments earlier. The youths ran off, and have become the prime suspects.

Superintendent Rod Jarman, who is in charge of community policing in Peckham, said he was surprised some young people spoken to by his officers had not even known detectives were appealing for help.

webTitle: UPC shake-up to follow failure of $5bn Excite merger

fields.headline: UPC shake-up to follow failure of $5bn Excite merger
fields.trailText: United Pan-Europe Communications, the cable television group, said yesterday it would merge its high-speed internet unit with its television programming unit following the collapse of a planned $5bn merger with Excite@Home, the US broadband concern.
fields.body:
United Pan-Europe Communications, the cable television group, said yesterday it would merge its high-speed internet unit with its television programming unit following the collapse of a planned $5bn merger with Excite@Home, the US broadband concern.

The announcement came as shares in UPC fell 12% to €11.20 amid disappointment at its failure to pull off the merger of Chello, its internet broadband business, with Excite's international assets.

Excite Chello, as the new company would have been called, was announced in July. The planned venture marked a new international strategy for both Excite and UPC, which had earlier planned to list its internet broadband business on the stock market. It was to have been the largest cable-based internet service provider outside the US with 300,000 subscribers.

Talks between Excite, which is controlled by telecommunications group AT&T, and Chello collapsed late on Monday. UPC and Excite yesterday failed to agree even on the reason for the failure: the US company blamed funding problems while UPC cited a disagreement over management.

Mark Schneider, UPC chairman and chief executive, said: "Although both parties worked hard to resolve outstanding issues, we were unable to reach agreement."

An executive at a rival firm said that UPC and UnitedGlobalCom, which also owns a stake in Chello, are likely to look for other partners in the broadband business.

Analysts believe that NTL and Telewest in the UK may be interested in a deal with Chello, given their plans to expand into continental Europe.

webTitle: BBC entertainment chief wooed

fields.headline: BBC entertainment chief wooed
fields.trailText: Wedenesday 5.30pm: David Young, the golden boy of BBC light entertainment, is being tempted to leave the corporation, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
David Young, the golden boy of BBC light entertainment, is being pressed to quit the corporation.

Speculation has been rife for weeks that tempting offers are being made to the 32-year-old programming executive responsible for hit series including the Weakest Link and Ant and Dec's Friends Like These.

MediaGuardian.co.uk understands that he has been offered a job by leading independent producer Hat Trick Productions.

He is also believed to have been in talks with Channel 4 about a possible executive position.

Hat Trick, the company behind Have I Got News for You and Father Ted, is said to has approached Mr Young about a job that would involve generating new entertainment formats.

But Mr Young, who has injected new life into BBC light entertainment, is unlikely to accept the offer.

He has only been at the BBC for just over 18 months and is believed to be on a lucrative contract, with a salary of around £150,000 plus a fee for new formats he generates.

A BBC spokeswoman said: "David is staying at the BBC for the time being. He has been approached by a number of different companies since joining us, but he has no immediate plans to leave."

webTitle: Oftel tries to cut loop deadlock

fields.headline: Oftel tries to cut loop deadlock
fields.standfirst:
DSL timetable accelerated

Net news
fields.trailText: The telecoms industry regulator, Oftel, yesterday stepped up pressure on BT to open its networks to rivals by ordering it to connect Energis and Thus to its wires so they can provide high-speed internet services.
fields.body:
The telecoms industry regulator, Oftel, yesterday stepped up pressure on BT to open its networks to rivals by ordering it to connect Energis and Thus to its wires so they can provide high-speed internet services.

The move is seen as a means of overcoming the impasse in opening BT's local exchanges -"unbundling the local loop" - to rival operators planning to offer broadband services via digital subscriber lines (DSL).

Oftel's proposal is for BT's rivals to bypass the local loop and provide DSL services direct. It could enable Energis and Thus to connect business subscribers to DSL services much earlier than by using local loop. Other operators are expected to follow suit.

Richard Sweet, Thus's regulatory manager, said it could take until 2002 for BT's competitors to offer high-speed internet services via the loop, while they could gain access to the copper wires as early as next spring under yesterday's Oftel proposal.

The first of BT's local exchanges are due to be open to rivals from July next year.

Thus, majority owned by ScottishPower, and Energis had complained to the regulator in the autumn after failing to conclude a deal with BT to buy wholesale DSL services, enabling them to convert copper wires into internet connections. Oftel sided with them, as it had over complaints about unbundling the local loop.

In its draft proposal Oftel set a deadline for BT to conclude interconnection agreements with its two rivals for DSL services. These agreements would enable them to take their DSL services off BT's network at specified points and on to their own networks.

With a month set for consultations and a further month for negotiations,Thus and Energis expect a deal to be struck by the end of February with, connections possibly available in early May.

Still viewed within the City as being too lenient towards BT, David Edmonds, Oftel's director general, said: "I want operators to have a range of options for providing services, including using BT's services, unbundled local loops or using their own and BT's network."

Thus has begun using BT's wholesale product, IPStream, to offer high-speed services to its Demon customers but the new arrangement, Mr Sweet said, would enable it to carry the traffic back across its own network rather than relying on BT's.

"There are potential benefits provided we can negotiate a sensible price," he said.

It should enable Thus to guarantee a level of service quality not now available. "We would very much want to offer a business such services but they naturally want it available 98% of the time and we can't do that. This will improve matters even though it won't overcome the service level issue entirely."

Mr Sweet said around half the UK's population were within reach of high-speed services but levels of access depend on the length of copper wire and its quality.

Oftel said its proposal applied only to Energis and Thus but Mr Sweet insisted it would benefit the whole industry.2929

webTitle: Freeserve shares suspended

fields.headline: Freeserve shares suspended
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Freeserve looks set to be taken over after shares in the Dixons-owned internet firm were suspended on the stock exchange, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Dixons' internet firm, Freeserve, looks set to be taken over after its shares were suspended on the stock exchange.

The UK's largest internet service provider is expected to be snapped up by French rival Wanadoo, which also had its stock suspended today from the Paris Bourse.

Nearly a third of all UK users subscribe to Freeserve.

The company, which is 80%-owned by high street retailer Dixons, has been the subject of continued bid rumours since the collapse in June of talks with Germany's T-Online.

An announcement is expected later today.

Dixons may rue the collapse of the T-Online deal as at the time Freeserve's shares were earmarked for sale at around 600p each; they are now likely to fetch only 175p.

A successful deal would see Freeserve linking up with some illustrious media partners. Wanadoo's parent company is France Telecom, which owns mobile phone operator Orange and 22% of UK cable giant NTL.

Today's developments could herald the first move in the long-awaited consolidation of the European internet service provider sector, which has been slow to take off owing to market turbulence.

Analysts say European ISPs such as Freeserve and Wanadoo need to boost the scale of their operations to be able to compete with bigger rivals such as AOL.

Tumbling share prices, which have affected T-Online in particular, have also stifled potential deals, since stock remains the favoured currency for takeovers in the internet sector.

webTitle: The act of settlement, 1701

fields.headline: The act of settlement, 1701
fields.trailText: Whereas in the first year of the reign of Your Majesty, and of our late most gracious sovereign lady Queen Mary (of blessed memory), an Act of Parliament was made, entitled, "An Act for declaring the rights and liberties of the subject, and for settling the succession of the crown," wherein it was (amongst other things) enacted, established, and declared that the crown and regal government of the Kingdoms of England, France, and Ireland, and the dominions thereunto belonging, should be and continue to Your Majesty and the said late Queen, during the joint lives of Your Majesty and the said Queen, and to the survivor: and that after the decease of Your Majesty and of the said Queen, the said Crown and regal government should be and remain to the heirs of the body of the said late Queen; and for default of such issue, to Her Royal Highness the Princess Anne of Denmark, and the heirs of her body; and for default of such issue to the heirs of the body of Your Majesty.
fields.body:
Whereas in the first year of the reign of Your Majesty, and of our late most gracious sovereign lady Queen Mary (of blessed memory), an Act of Parliament was made, entitled, "An Act for declaring the rights and liberties of the subject, and for settling the succession of the crown," wherein it was (amongst other things) enacted, established, and declared that the crown and regal government of the Kingdoms of England, France, and Ireland, and the dominions thereunto belonging, should be and continue to Your Majesty and the said late Queen, during the joint lives of Your Majesty and the said Queen, and to the survivor: and that after the decease of Your Majesty and of the said Queen, the said Crown and regal government should be and remain to the heirs of the body of the said late Queen; and for default of such issue, to Her Royal Highness the Princess Anne of Denmark, and the heirs of her body; and for default of such issue to the heirs of the body of Your Majesty.

And it was thereby further enacted, that all and every person and persons that then were, or afterwards should be reconciled to, or shall hold communion with the see or Church of Rome, or should profess the popish religion, or marry a papist, should be excluded, and are by that Act made for ever incapable to inherit, possess, or enjoy the Crown and government of this realm, and Ireland, and the dominions thereunto belonging, or any part of the same, or to have, use, or exercise any regal power, authority, or jurisdiction within the same: and in all and every such case and cases the people of these realms shall be and are thereby absolved of their allegiance: and that the said Crown and government shall from time to time descend to and be enjoyed by such person or persons, being Protestants, as should have inherited and enjoyed the same, in case the said person or persons, so reconciled, holding communion, professing or marrying, as aforesaid, were naturally dead.

After the making of which statute, and the settlement therein contained, your majesty's good subjects, who were restored to the full and free possession and enjoyment of their religion, rights, and liberties, by the providence of God giving success to your majesty's just undertakings and unwearied endeavours for that purpose, had no greater temporal felicity to hope or wish for, that to see a royal progeny descending from Your Majesty, to whom (under God) they owe their tranquillity, and whose ancestors have for many years been principal assertors of the reformed religion and the liberties of Europe, and from our said most gracious sovereign lady, whose memory will always be precious to the subjects of these realms: and it having since pleased Almighty God to take away our said sovereign Lady, and also the most hopeful Prince William, Duke of Gloucester (the only surviving issue of Her Royal Highness the Princess Anne of Denmark) to the unspeakable grief and sorrow of Your Majesty and your said good subjects, who under such losses being sensibly put in mind, that it standeth wholly in the pleasure of Almighty God to prolong the lives of Your Majesty and of Her Royal Highness, and to grant to Your Majesty, or to Her Royal Highness, such issue as may be inheritable to the Crown and regal government aforesaid, by the respective limitations in the said recited act contained, do constantly implore the divine mercy for those blessings: and Your Majesty's said subjects having daily experience of your royal care and concern for the present and future welfare of these Kingdoms, and particularly recommending from your throne a further provision to be made for the succession of the Crown in the Protestant line, for the happiness of the nation, and the security of our religion; and it being absolutely necessary for the safety, peace, and quiet of this realm, to obviate all doubts and contentions in the same, by reason of any pretended title to the Crown, and to maintain a certainty in the succession thereof, to which your subjects may safely have recourse for their protection, in case the limitations in the said recited act should determine.

Therefore for a further provision of the succession of the Crown in the Protestant line, we Your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal subjects, the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, do beseech Your Majesty that it may be enacted and declared, and be it enacted and declared by the King's most excellent majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That the most excellent Princess Sophia, Electress and Duchess Dowager of Hanover, daughter of the most excellent Princess Elizabeth, late Queen of Bohemia, daughter of our late sovereign lord King James the First, of happy memory, be and is hereby declared to be the next in succession, in the Protestant line, to the imperial Crown and dignity of the said Realms of England, France, and Ireland, with the dominions and territories thereunto belonging, after His Majesty, and the Princess Anne of Denmark, and in default of issue of the said Princess Anne, and of His Majesty respectively: and that from and after the deceases of His said Majesty, our now sovereign lord, and of Her Royal Highness the Princess Anne of Denmark, and for default of issue of the said Princess Anne, and of His Majesty respectively, the Crown and regal government of the said Kingdoms of England, France, and Ireland, and of the dominions thereunto belonging, with the royal state and dignity of the said Realms, and all honours, styles, titles, regalities, prerogatives, powers, jurisdictions and authorities, to the same belonging and appertaining, shall be, remain, and continue to the said most excellent Princess Sophia, and the heirs of her body, being Protestants: and thereunto the said Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, shall and will in the name of all the people of this Realm, most humbly and faithfully submit themselves, their heirs and posterities: and do faithfully promise, that after the deceases of His Majesty, and Her Royal Highness, and the failure of the heirs of their respective bodies, to stand to, maintain, and defend the said Princess Sophia, and the heirs of her body, being Protestants, according to the limitation and succession of the Crown in this act specified and contained, to the utmost of their powers, with their lives and estates, against all persons whatsoever that shall attempt anything to the contrary.

II. Provided always, and be it hereby enacted, that all and every person and persons, who shall or may take or inherit the said Crown, by virtue of the limitation of this present act, and is, are or shall be reconciled to, or shall hold communion with, the See or Church of Rome, or shall profess the popish religion, or shall marry a papist, shall be subject to such incapacities, as in such case or cases are by the said recited act provided, enacted, and established; and that every King and Queen of this Realm, who shall come to and succeed in the imperial Crown of this Kingdom, by virtue of this act, shall have the coronation oath administered to him, her or them, at their respective coronations, according to the act of Parliament made in the first year of the reign of His Majesty, and the said late Queen Mary, intituled, An act for establishing the coronation oath, and shall make, subscribe, and repeat the declaration in the act first above recited mentioned or referred to, in the manner and form thereby prescribed.

III. And whereas it is requisite and necessary that some further provision be made for securing our religion, laws and liberties, from and after the death of His Majesty and the Princess Anne of Denmark, and in default of issue of the body of the said Princess, and of His Majesty respectively; be it enacted by the King's most excellent majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That whosoever shall hereafter come to the possession of this Crown, shall join in communion with the Church of England, as by law established;

That in case the Crown and imperial dignity of this Realm shall hereafter come to any person, not being a native of this Kingdom of England, this nation be not obliged to engage in any war for the defence of any dominions or territories which do not belong to the Crown of England, without the consent of Parliament;

That no person who shall hereafter come to the possession of this Crown, shall go out of the dominions of England, Scotland, or Ireland, without the consent of Parliament;

That from and after the time that the further limitation by this act shall take effect, all matters and things relating to the well governing of this Kingdom, which are properly cognizable in the Privy Council by the laws and customs of this Realm, shall be translated there, and all resolutions taken thereupon shall be signed by such of the Privy Council as shall advise and consent to the same;

That after the said limitation shall take effect as aforesaid, no person born out of the Kingdoms of England, Scotland, or Ireland, or the dominions thereunto belonging (although he be naturalized or made a denizen, except such as are born of English parents) shall be capable to be of the Privy Council, or a member of either House of Parliament, or to enjoy any office or place of trust, either civil or military, or to have any grant of lands, tenements or hereditaments from the Crown, to himself or to any other or others in trust for him;

That no person who has an office or place of profit under the King, or receives a pension from the Crown, shall be capable of serving as a member of the House of Commons;

That after the said limitation shall take effect as aforesaid, judges commissions be made quamdiu se bene gesserint, and their salaries ascertained and established; but upon the address of both Houses of Parliament it may be lawful to remove them;

That no pardon under the Great Seal of England be pleadable to an impeachment by the Commons in Parliament.

IV. And whereas the laws of England are the birth-right of the people thereof, and all the Kings and Queens, who shall ascend the throne of this Realm, ought to administer the government of the same according to the said laws, and all their officers and ministers ought to serve them respectively according to the same: the said Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, do therefore further humbly pray, That all the laws and statutes of this Realm for securing the established religion, and the rights and liberties of the people thereof, and all other laws and statutes of the same now in force, may be ratified and confirmed, and the same are by His Majesty, by and with the advice of the said Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, and by authority of the same, ratified and confirmed accordingly.

webTitle: Chancellor offers more cash to fight child poverty

fields.headline: Chancellor offers more cash to fight child poverty
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown promised yesterday that policies to help families with children will be at the heart of Labour's election manifesto. By John Carvel
fields.body:
Gordon Brown promised yesterday that policies to help families with children will be at the heart of Labour's election manifesto.

Addressing the National Council for One Parent Families, the chancellor said 4m children were living in poverty in 1997. By polling day 1m would have been lifted above the poverty threshold.

Outlining what he termed "progressive universalism", the chancellor said the aim of Labour's second term would be to provide enough further help for families to remove a second million children from the poverty that was "a scar on Britain's soul".

Mr Brown said: "The needs of children and families will have priority in the next budget and the future needs of children and families will be a major feature in our manifesto."

He broke fresh ground with a series of questions about what more could be done by government to help parents balance work and family.

Speaking before publication tomorrow of a green paper that is expected to recommend a fortnight of paid paternity leave, he said: "Parents are rightly asking some hard questions. How can we encourage jobs that fit around school hours? How can we make it easier to get on buses with a buggy and a toddler?

"Why are there too many places, such as shops or underground stations, where the only way in is to bump a pushchair up or down two flights of stairs?

"How can we do more to encourage service companies when many still think it reasonable to expect their customers to sit at home for up to eight hours, as if parents had nothing better to do but sit and wait?"

Mr Brown signalled further concessions for families in the next budget. Child tax credits were already scheduled to cost £1.7bn in a full year. Previous announcements suggested they would be worth £8.50 a week for most families.

"I am now consulting on a bolder proposal - £10 a week for families, payable from April next year, which would mean a total tax cut of £2bn," he said.

Child benefit reforms would provide more than £50 a week for a quarter of families from April next year. Two thirds of families would get more than £30 a week and all would get at least £15.50. This was a policy of "progressive universalism".

Mr Brown was responding to an address by J.K. Rowling, author of the Harry Potter books. She spoke about the time before her work was published when she struggled as a single parent to pull herself out of the poverty trap, but was denied help because a health visitor said she was "coping too well".

She described "the reality of anxiously counting the nappies that are left in the pack, of praying for fine weather because of the gas bill... of reaching the checkout and counting out the money in coppers and finding it was two pence short of a tin of baked beans."

Mr Brown said he was moved by the author's story. "I was struck by the enormous barriers she faced in trying to work part time while at the same time spending time with her daughter."

Treasury sources later poured scorn on a report at the weekend that the government was considering withdrawal of benefit from lone parents who did not want to take a job. This made no sense when ministers were preparing to launch a nationwide programme to give single parents more choice.

webTitle: Interest swells in Reebok belly

fields.headline: Interest swells in Reebok belly
fields.standfirst:
Click here for clips from the ad:
Reebok1 Reebok2
fields.trailText:
8am: Reebok's giant hairy beer gut, star of its latest ads, has taken on a life of its own, writes Claire Cozens.
Click here for clips from the ad:Reebok1 Reebok2
fields.body:
It is the grossest sight on television. But this giant hairy beer gut has already taken on a life of its own.

Reebok has been flooded with calls from people wanting to know how they can get hold of their very own beer bellies - and the company is considering producing model versions.

"Everyone's talking about it," said a Reebok spokesman. "We've been on air for a week and already we've had unprecedented levels of interest from both the public and the media."

The belly in question is the star of Reebok's latest 40-second television ad.

The amazingly lifelike belly was designed by Reebok's ad agency, Lowe Lintas, and created by Asylum, a model agency whose credits include the Dome's much-maligned Body Zone.

It is nearly 8ft wide and 5ft tall and is made of foam, which was hollowed out and sprayed with latex before being painted. It was then covered with artificial plastic hairs and synthetic moles for added authenticity.

Incredibly, the ad was shot using an actor who got inside the belly and moved along using a combination of running and jumping to make it bounce and wobble as much as possible.

A stunt man had to be used for the end of the ad, when the belly climbs onto a motorbike and drives after his victim.

The driver could not see out and had to rely on a monitor inside the costume to navigate his way onto and across a roof.

Reassuringly, though, the producers decided that the scene in which the belly plunges into a canal should be done without human involvement.

The actor's legs were removed from the film using post-production techniques in the editing suite and the belly was stretched downwards to make it look as though it dragged along the ground. A long shadow was also painted in.

The ad is part of a new campaign designed to distance Reebok from the slick, aspirational image of rival sports brands Nike and Adidas.

The 40-second commercial ends with the camera panning onto the sole of the runner's shoe, which reads, "Lose your beer belly".

The campaign slogan, "Reebok. Whatever your goal" then appears.

Jeremy Bowles, deputy managing director of Lowe Lintas, said: "Reebok is telling it like it is. People don't just do sport to win at all cost. Many just want to stay in shape, feel good and enjoy it.

"These commercials will strike a chord because the consumer will appreciate their honest intent."
