webTitle: HIV priest accused of abusing schoolboy

fields.headline: HIV priest accused of abusing schoolboy
fields.trailText: The Roman Catholic church was embroiled in new controversy yesterday after it admitted that a former chaplain at one of London's leading state schools, who was HIV-positive when he died two years ago, has been accused of sexually abusing at least one pupil.
fields.body:
The Roman Catholic church was embroiled in new controversy yesterday after it admitted that a former chaplain at one of London's leading state schools, who was HIV-positive when he died two years ago, has been accused of sexually abusing at least one pupil.

Father David Martin, who died of bronchopneumonia at a London hospital at the age of 44 in September 1998, had been acting chaplain one day a week at the Oratory School in west London, where the prime minister's sons, Euan and Nicholas, are now pupils.

Last night a spokesman for the church admitted that successive heads of Father Martin's religious order, the Oratory Fathers, had known that he was HIV positive several years before he was ordained in 1994.

It was not known whether they passed that information to the school before he started work there in 1997.

Claims about his conduct surfaced in a letter to Hammersmith and Fulham social services department last week. Earlier letters making less specific allegations were sent to leading figures in the church including the Archbishop of Westminster, Cormac Murphy O'Connor and to national newspapers in late October and were also referred to Hammersmith and Fulham.

A spokesman for the Westminster diocese said: "Naturally the church is deeply concerned whenever any allegations are made against a priest and especially if there are any victims of abuse. Any allegations need to be fully investigated and the church authorities will cooperate fully."

In a terse statement, Father Ignatius Harrison, provost of the Oratory Fathers, of which Father Martin had been a member, said only that the order was fully aware of the investigation. He later added that there had never been any concerns about Father Martin's behaviour.

Father Michael Napier, the provost of the order at the time Father Martin joined in 1988 and at the time of his ordination in 1994, is now also dead. Church sources said that Martin had been diagnosed HIV positive in 1991 - and had confided in Father Napier. The information was subsequently given to Father Harrison when he succeeded as provost in 1996.

The church was unable to say whether the school had carried out its own checks when he was recommended to them by the order as a governor and chaplain. Father Martin continued to visit the school until July 1998.

Child protection officers were yesterday attempting to establish the identity of the boy who made the complaints. They have only a first name to go on.

"There was a child protection meeting six weeks ago but they considered that there was no evidence with which to base any further investigations, because the letter was anonymous, there was no specific allegation of child abuse, and obviously Father Martin was dead," said a spokeswoman for Hammersmith and Fulham.

The latest letter alleging child abuse came from a boy claiming to be at the school. The allegation is that abuse of one boy took place away from the school and unconnected with school activities, but relating to the priest's church work.

On Monday social services and the police held a meeting and decided to launch an investigation. The council's child protection team met officers yesterday. They are looking again at the earlier letters.

ChildLine founder and chairman Esther Rantzen confirmed that the telephone helpline had been contacted by children making allegations of abuse at the school.

The inquiry is hampered by the unclear lines of responsibility. Father Martin was chaplain at the school for four terms but was employed not by them but by the Oratory Fathers.

Father Martin attended the school weekly, mainly to prepare boys for confirmation. He had previously been director of music at the Brompton Oratory and was instrumental in setting up a choir school there.

Father Martin graduated from St Andrews university in 1976. He entered the priesthood as a novice in 1988.

A statement released on behalf of the priest's father, James Martin, from Ayr, said: "We are devastated by news of this. It has come as a complete shock to us all."

Priests in the dock

1996 Father Adrian McLeish of Durham sentenced to six years for abusing boys aged 10 to 18 and exchanging internet pornography.

1997 Father Michael Walsh jailed for five years for indecent assault and gross indecency over a 19 year period. It emerged that Archbishop Cormac Murphy O'Connor appointed Hill to a succession of posts despite allegations that he was a paedophile. The archbishop has apologised.

1998 Father Eric Taylor jailed for seven years for abusing boys in his care at the Father Hudson Society's home in Warwickshire between 1957 and 1965.

2000 Father Joe Jordan jailed for eight years for sexually abusing boys. He was ordained by the Archbishop of Wales, John Ward, in 1996 despite warnings that he was a potential abuser who had earlier been banned from teaching. In 1998 Archbishop Ward's press officer John Lloyd was also jailed for eight years for indecent assaults on children. The archbishop has refused to resign.

webTitle: "Go north", says London borough

fields.headline: Go north ... where the living is a whole lot easier
fields.standfirst: Partnership between councils in London and Yorkshire seeks to effect migration from crowded bedsits to homes with moorland views
fields.trailText: Partnership between councils in London and Yorkshire seeks to effect migration from crowded bedsits to homes with moorland views
fields.body:
The glossy brochure, evoking a glorious Pennine landscape, could be straight from a travel agent. But the sales pitch, of unsurpassed countryside and historic canalside towns crammed with listed buildings, is not designed for tourists.

Rather, it marks the first serious campaign to persuade people to leave an overcrowded London with the promise of cheaper housing, more space, and a much lower cost of living up north.

Recognising its growing housing shortage, with 5,000 people vainly waiting for council homes, the London borough of Camden has signed an agreement with Kirklees council - otherwise known as Greater Huddersfield - to take families unable to find accommodation in the capital.

"Camden, like most of London's 32 boroughs, simply cannot meet demand for low cost housing with tens of thousands on the waiting list in the capital.

"This is not a case of persuading people to move into unpleasant, difficult to let homes", said Camden's spokesman, David Petrie. "Huddersfield has a lot of empty houses that would be snapped up if they were in London, and it has a lot more to offer as well."

Emie Townsend would certainly agree. After spending a year with her 13-year-old daughter, Maria, living in one room in a cramped bed and breakfast near King's Cross, she became the first person voluntarily to transfer from Camden to Kirklees this week, lured by cheaper accommodation, moorland air, and a two bedroom house with garden at front and rear.

"Brilliant", she smiled yesterday. "This is far more than I expected - seven minutes by bus from the town centre, a shopping centre which seems bigger than Oxford Street, and much cheaper food and clothing. I can't believe my luck."

Camden's promotion, Kirklees - a Beautiful Place to Live, which is backed up with a video presentation for would-be emigrants, pulls no punches.

"London has a serious housing problem", it warns. "The number of people looking for affordable accommodation far exceeds the available supply ... high demand for housing pushes up prices so that property to buy or rent is extremely expensive ... the situation is unlikely to improve in the near future, which means that many people will remain in temporary accommodation, in expensive and insecure private housing or staying in ... overcrowded conditions.

But in contrast to London, it says, there is a surplus in other towns and cities, "where the local population may have decreased and where property prices are much lower".

webTitle: Carlton sets up Spanish joint venture

fields.headline: Carlton sets up Spanish joint venture
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Carlton has expanded its international TV programme-making operation by launching a Spanish production joint venture, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Carlton Communications has expanded its international TV programme-making operation with the creation of a Spanish production joint venture.

MediaCarlton will be a Barcelona-based, 50/50 joint venture with Spanish producer Media Pro, specialising in long running, Spanish language dramas and soaps.

The new outfit will target an estimated global Hispanic audience of 400m in Spain and north and south America.

Michael Foster, Carlton Productions managing director of content, and Steve Hewlett, Carlton Productions director of programmes, will sit on the MediaCarlton board, alongside Media Pro managing director Jaume Roures.

Jonathan Powell, Carlton director of drama, and veteran drama executive producer Ted Childs, whose credits include Inspector Morse, Soldier Soldier and The Sweeney, will also be lending their expertise to the project.

Mr Hewlett said: "Carlton has writing, production and international sales expertise, while Media Pro brings an in-depth knowledge of Spanish language television."

Media Pro has an annual turnover of around £66m and offices in four Spanish cities, as well as Lisbon, Miami and Buenos Aires.

Carlton already has a foothold in the Spanish TV market, with a 7.5% stake in digital terrestrial TV operator Quiero. The company's only other overseas production base in is Los Angeles.

webTitle: Chancellor offers more cash help for parents

fields.headline: Chancellor offers more cash help for parents
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown promised yesterday that policies to help families with children will be at the heart of Labour's election manifesto.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown promised yesterday that policies to help families with children will be at the heart of Labour's election manifesto.

Addressing the National Council for One Parent Families, the chancellor said 4m children were living in poverty in 1997. By polling day 1m would have been lifted above the poverty threshold.

Outlining what he termed "progressive universalism", the chancellor said the aim of Labour's second term would be to provide enough further help for families to remove a second million children from the poverty that was "a scar on Britain's soul".

Mr Brown said: "The needs of children and families will have priority in the next budget and the future needs of children and families will be a major feature in our manifesto."

He broke fresh ground with a series of questions about what more could be done by government to help parents balance work and family.

Speaking before publication tomorrow of a green paper that is expected to recommend a fortnight of paid paternity leave, he said: "Parents are rightly asking some hard questions. How can we encourage jobs that fit around school hours? How can we make it easier to get on buses with a buggy and a toddler?

"Why are there too many places, such as shops or underground stations, where the only way in is to bump a pushchair up or down two flights of stairs?

"How can we do more to encourage service companies when many still think it reasonable to expect their customers to sit at home for up to eight hours, as if parents had nothing better to do but sit and wait?"

Mr Brown signalled further concessions for families in the next budget. Child tax credits were already scheduled to cost £1.7bn in a full year. Previous announcements suggested they would be worth £8.50 a week for most families.

"I am now consulting on a bolder proposal - £10 a week for families, payable from April next year, which would mean a total tax cut of £2bn," he said.

Child benefit reforms would provide more than £50 a week for a quarter of families from April next year. Two thirds of families would get more than £30 a week and all would get at least £15.50. This was a policy of "progressive universalism".

Mr Brown was responding to an address by J.K. Rowling, author of the Harry Potter books. She spoke about the time before her work was published when she struggled as a single parent to pull herself out of the poverty trap, but was denied help because a health visitor said she was "coping too well".

She described "the reality of anxiously counting the nappies that are left in the pack, of praying for fine weather because of the gas bill... of reaching the checkout and counting out the money in coppers and finding it was two pence short of a tin of baked beans."

Mr Brown said he was moved by the author's story. "I was struck by the enormous barriers she faced in trying to work part time while at the same time spending time with her daughter."

Treasury sources later poured scorn on a report at the weekend that the government was considering withdrawal of benefit from lone parents who did not want to take a job. This made no sense when ministers were preparing to launch a nationwide programme to give single parents more choice.

webTitle: Teenagers in poor areas more likely to fall pregnant, less likely to abort

fields.headline: Teenagers in poor areas more likely to fall pregnant, less likely to abort
fields.trailText: Teenagers living in the poorest areas of Britain are more likely to get pregnant, but much less likely to have an abortion, according to a report yesterday from the office for national statistics, writes John Carvel
fields.body:
Teenagers living in the poorest areas of Britain are more likely to get pregnant, but much less likely to have an abortion, according to a report yesterday from the office for national statistics.

It found the London borough of Southwark had the highest teenage conception rate, with 85 pregnancies per 1,000 women aged 15-18. This was more than five times the figure in Chiltern, with the lowest rate of 15.4 per 1,000.

For the most part, poorer areas in coalfields, manufacturing centres and ports tended to have higher teenage pregnancy rates than more prosperous and rural authorities.

Young women who became pregnant in areas with a high level of under-18 conceptions were more likely to have the baby than an abortion. But in parts of the country where teenage pregnancies were uncommon, up to two thirds ended with an abortion.

Manchester had the highest teenage conception rate in the north west region and the lowest percentage of abortions in England. Between 1992 and 1997 the city had an under-18 conception rate of 74.2 per 1,000 and 25.7% of these pregnancies ended in abortion.

By contrast, East Dorset had the lowest rate of teenage conceptions in the south west region (18.9 per 1,000) and the highest proportion of teenage terminations in that region, with 66% having an abortion.

The figures suggested that girls were more likely to keep a baby if they lived in parts of the country where teenage pregnancies were regarded as more socially acceptable.

London was an exception to the national trend, with above average conception rates and a high percentage of abortions.

The study showed that, nationally, Wales had the highest under-18 conception rate and England had the highest percentage leading to abortion. Scotland had low rates of teenage pregnancies and abortion.

The UK has the highest rate of teenage pregnancies in western Europe, with 95,000 conceptions last year, resulting in 58,000 live births. The government's target is to halve these figures by 2010.

Other findings in the ONS report on population trends included a decline in the divorce rate in England and Wales to the lowest figure for 10 years. Last year's 144,600 divorces affected 12.9 married people per 1,000, compared to 13.1 in 1990.

The average age of people divorcing rose, from 40.2 for men and 37.7 for women in 1997, to 40.9 and 38.4 respectively last year. The ONS said this was attributable to people marrying at a later age.

More people are divorcing for at least the second time, with one in five people who split last year having been through divorce before, compared with only one in 10 in 1981.

webTitle: Mental illness survey calls for a new approach

fields.headline: Mental illness survey calls for a new approach
fields.standfirst: In too many cases, people suffering from mental illness have no say in the treatment they receive. Sophie Petit-Zeman reports on a survey urging a holistic re-think
fields.trailText: In too many cases, people suffering from mental illness have no say in the treatment they receive. Sophie Petit-Zeman reports on a survey urging a holistic re-think
fields.body:
You feel a familiar depression slinking back, or a mounting sense of mania, or disembodied, persecuting voices of schizophrenia that you've never heard before. But who or what can help you? According to the largest survey of people's views on treatment for mental illness, to be published on Friday, there are few options available, or informed choices made, when it comes to the use of psychiatric drugs.

A Question of Choice, produced by three charities, the National Schizophrenia Fellowship (NSF), Manic Depression Fellowship and Mind, reveals that 62% of people suffering mental illness had no choice of medication, and almost half stopped taking it without medical advice.

Most of the 2,663 people surveyed had diagnoses of schizophrenia, although many had manic depression or depression. The two main drug treatments for schizophrenia are "typical" and "atypical" antipsychotics.

The typicals (common ones are haloperidol, chlorpromazine and stelazine) have been around longest. While they help some people, they can cause severe long-term side-effects, sometimes irreversible even if treatment is stopped. The drugs are banned in parts of the US, following law suits linked to side-effects, and, according to Gary Hogman, head of policy and campaigns at the NSF, some British experts say such drugs would not be licensed if they were being introduced to the market now.

Atypicals - such as olanzapine, clozapine and risperidone - are the newer, growing group. Their side-effects are usually milder, and a striking finding from the survey relates to people's experiences of these versus typical antipsychotics. Asked "Which was the worst medicine you've ever had?", the highest ranked drugs were the three common typicals. And the best? The three atypicals - plus lithium, used mainly for manic depression.

Doctors can prescribe from either category, yet 84% of drugs used for schizophrenia are typical antipsychotics. The higher cost of atypicals, and conservative tendencies within the medical profession, may override clinical judgment and patient preference. Hogman says the survey shows that what is lacking, and must be provided, is choice. "People want comprehensive information, and to be allowed to choose what works best for them, not always get the cheapest option or whatever the doctor usually gives," he says.

Hogman argues that prescribing cheaper drugs is short-sighted. "Some people on typical antipsychotics need other drugs to combat side-effects. They frequently stop taking medication and, as a result, relapse is common.

"In short, many people are given drugs which they hate, and don't stick with, even though there are alternatives. It's a false economy. Their symptoms are not controlled, they may have repeated hospital admissions, at high cost to health, social care and sometimes the criminal justice system, and have seriously and needlessly impaired quality of life."

The national institute for clinical excellence (Nice), which advises the government on medical interventions, has just announced that it will assess drugs for schizophrenia - a process expected to take a year before yielding recommendations. The NSF hopes that this evaluation will not pay more attention to cold data of controlled trials than to hard evidence - the experiences of people who take the drugs.

The value of medication, for many, is clear from the survey. When asked "What single thing had or could make the biggest difference to quality of life?", the largest number cited medication. This included people for whom medicine has already made the biggest difference and those who view improved medicine as the best thing that could happen.

But the survey does not end there. It also asked people's views about non-drug treatments - from psychotherapy to exercise.

As Hogman says: "Medication was our starting point, but the survey's main colour is its illustration of the importance of a holistic approach. It demonstrates that those who are unwell benefit immensely from the occupational and leisure activities that we all like."

This holistic approach to mental illness is the cornerstone of NSF philosophy, based on recognising the interplay between mental and physical health.

Hogman says: "It's just common sense. There aren't two groups in society, ill people and well people. Mental illness affects all walks of life. Most people know what they need and enjoy - such as having enough money, pleasant accommodation, things to do and people to share them with - and those who are ill are no exception.

"Without these things, the risk of people suffering illness is increased, and getting better and staying well is more difficult. The picture is further complicated by the fact that the illness itself impedes ability to access them."

Mental Health Foundation statistics support these views: psychiatric admissions are three times greater in government-defined "deprived" areas, and the risk of suicide among the unemployed is 11 times higher than among those in work.

These figures and the survey's findings do not solve the mysteries of what causes mental illness, nor do they imply that good housing or jobs can alone prevent people from becoming ill, or cure them.

However, many interacting factors, from genetics to the environment, are important in causing mental illness and give clues as to useful interventions.

One of the survey's most striking statistics is that the most appreciated interventions are not complex or specialised. Exercise, training and education were ranked top by 85% of those who had tried them, and art/music therapy was best liked by 81%. It is another indication from the survey that drawing boundaries between the needs of the well and those of the ill is frequently artificial and unhelpful.

How birdwatching and art brought a new focus

Julian Swan's story illustrates how combining medication, non-drug treatments and social inclusion can dramatically help even those with severe, long-lasting illness.

Diagnosed with schizophrenia in 1992, after hearing voices for 16 years, Julian says freedom to choose his treatment was fundamental to recovery. "I told the psychiatrist that if I wasn't better in three months I'd kill myself," he recalls. "He was so responsive, but imposed nothing. He offered a hospital bed, which I declined, but I accepted sulpiride [a typical antipsychotic]. After a fortnight, the voices and paranoia had gone. After eight years, I recently stopped taking sulpiride, and I feel fine."

Since 1995, Swan has gained a degree in English and philosophy, a postgraduate qualification in social work from Cardiff University, and is about to start a new job in youth homelessness. He is convinced that medication only partly accounts for his recovery.

"It got my brain together by resolving the chemical imbalance," he says. "Then I was offered three or four non-drug treatments, and opted for art and drama therapy. These were incredible. I did lots of painting and expressed so much. I got my mind together through being involved and included."

Swan talks of another passion, for birdwatching, but also of one frustration. "My GP says I can't have psychotherapy. I'd like a 'debriefing' after living somewhere so odd, in my head, for 20 years. Apparently, I'm too well. In a big city, you only get help in a crisis."

For Swan, an empathetic doctor offering genuine choice, and a combination of treatments, education, training and employment have been life-changing. The National Schizophrenia Fellowship survey concludes that money should be spent on more holistic approaches - investments which would ultimately reduce the wide-ranging costs of caring for the mentally ill.

Figuring out the problem

 £76 million is spent on 1.2 m annual prescriptions for schizophrenia.

 84% of drugs prescribed for schizophrenia are old style (typical), yet new drugs (atypicals) account for 76% of medication costs.

 Postcode prescribing does happen; spending on atypicals varies tenfold across health authorities.

 Careful prescribing and individually tailored support can reduce hospital admissions. A week on a psychiatric ward costs about £960 a person, compared to £230 a week at home with support.

 A Question of Choice will be available at www.nsf.org.uk or from Lucy Widenka on 020-7330 9108. The report was prepared without any drug company funding.

webTitle: Sega rethinks £60m Euro business

fields.headline: Sega rethinks £60m Euro business
fields.trailText: 8.15am Sega is planning to review its £60m pan-European business, currently held by Bartle Bogle Hegarty, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Sega is planning to review its £60m pan-European business, currently held by Bartle Bogle Hegarty.

The agency, which has only handled the business since February, will face a full-scale review at the beginning of next year.

A source close to the business confirmed the timing of the review but was unable to say whether BBH will re-pitch for the account.

The move comes as Microsoft is looking for an agency to launch its Xbox games console across Europe next year. BBH's name has been unofficially associated with that pitch.

Sega Dreamcast's launch advertising last year was created by WCRS and was staged around the release of Star Wars: Episode 1 - The Phantom Menace.

Two commercials highlighted the Dreamcast's internet capabilities and the fact that players can challenge each other online. The endline was, "We all play games. Why don't we play together?".

The first execution, "Shave", took place in a barber shop where three barbers race to shave the heads of new army recruits. The other features children throwing stones at a buoy floating in a bay.

No one at BBH or Sega was available for comment.

webTitle: Front Row relaunches with TV ad blitz

fields.headline: Front Row relaunches with TV ad blitz
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Pay-per-view TV outfit Front Row Television this week relaunches with a new national TV ad campaign, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Front Row Television is this week embarking on an ambitious relaunch, kicking off with a new national TV advertising campaign.

Advertising for the pay-per-view venture, jointly owned by NTL and TeleWest, will position it as the must-have cable service for quality movies.

Two 30-second ads, created by banc, will air nationally from Friday and run until the end of the year with the new endline, "Front Row - You decide".

The service recently announced that it had increased its output to include 85% of the available titles at the UK Box Office, which it will claim is equal and possibly greater than any other on-demand movie operator.

The campaign coincides with the recent repackaging of the Front Row service, which now includes increased choice of programming, a revamped on-air presence and more targeted programming.

The first execution features a couple at home in front of the TV basing their choice of film on the toss of a ping-pong ball into a variety of glass containers on the coffee table.

The second shows two girls basing their choice of film on the colour of the underpants of an overweight builder who has been working outside their flat.

The ads were written by Glenn Smith, art directed by Craig Roderick and directed by Dominic Rixson of ON Demand Productions.

webTitle: Watchdog launches inquiry into BSkyB deals with rivals

fields.headline: Watchdog launches inquiry into BSkyB deals with rivals
fields.trailText: The satellite broadcaster BSkyB is facing a full scale Office of Fair Trading investigation into the way it sells its sports and film channels to rival cable and digital broadcasters.
fields.body:
The satellite broadcaster BSkyB is facing a full scale Office of Fair Trading investigation into the way it sells its sports and film channels to rival cable and digital broadcasters.

The new inquiry, expected to take six months, is to be carried out under the Competition Act, which became law in March. The legislation prohibits firms from abusing their market position and making agreements which damage competition.

If the OFT concludes that BSkyB has abused its position or made anti-competitive deals it could fine the company up to 10% of its UK turnover since March - more than £100m.

The investigation - which follows an OFT review into BSkyB launched in January - comes after repeated complaints from the rival broadcaster ONdigital concerning the prices BSkyB charges for its programming.

ONdigital, one of Sky's biggest customers, claims the satellite broadcaster's prices affect the way ONdigital sells its own service and the prices it has to charge its customers.

ONdigital argues that having bought the rights to most of the top UK sports and the best films, BSkyB is now setting prices that prevent competition is therefore abusing its dominant position.

Yesterday the OFT emphasised it was starting the investigation with an open mind, but under the Competition Act the OFT director general, John Vickers, must have reasonable grounds for suspecting breaches of the law before he can start an investigation.

Last night an ONdigital spokesman said: "We welcome this inquiry which we have been asking for for some time."

BSkyB said it would work with the consumer watchdog on the new investigation. In a statement it said: "Sky will continue to cooperate with the OFT." The satellite firm said it had recently been "striking much more attractive deals", such as that with its other rival NTL, as a result of increased competition in broadcasting.

If BSkyB fails to cooperate, the OFT now has a range of powers, including the right to enter premises by force and to take away documents.

BSkyB gave the OFT a number of undertakings in 1996 to soothe fears of an unfair advantage over smaller cable firms. It has already been released from one undertaking which deals with conduct, now regulated by industry regulator the Independent Television Commission, and will soon be released from another applying to analogue satellite TV.

BSkyB is migrating its service from analogue to digital and expects the process to be complete by the end of 2001.

News of the OFT inquiry, however, did not hit BSkyB's share price. They rose by 22p yesterday, closing at 1044p.

webTitle: M&C Saatchi expands into South Africa

fields.headline: M&C Saatchi expands into South Africa
fields.trailText: 8.15am: M&C Saatchi is expanding its network of ad agencies and opening an office in South Africa, its 11th outside the UK. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
M&C Saatchi is expanding its network of agencies and opening an office in South Africa, its 11th outside the UK.

The new office will be run by Angela Jones, the 30-year-old copywriter behind the British Airways 'World Offers' campaign.

She was one of the most senior creatives at the London office, having worked there since it launched in 1995.

She will be joined by Nina Morris, a former business director at Leo Burnett, who becomes managing director.

The new agency launches with one small client - the Spier Festival, an annual music event that has been handled from the London office until now.

The new business drive will be an immediate priority. It may well prove a tough challenge for the new office in light of the fact that much of M&C's existing clients are not global, with the exception of BA, which it handles across six different countries.

M&C Saatchi recently overtook arch-rival Saatchi & Saatchi in terms of quarterly billings in the UK though on a global basis it is still smaller.

In South Africa, Saatchi & Saatchi ranks seventh, with annual billings of £5m.

webTitle: Seven punters in search of an author pay thousands for novel appearance

fields.headline: Seven punters in search of an author pay thousands for novel appearance
fields.trailText: Few of us are talented enough to pen a best-selling novel or carry off literary prizes. But last night book lovers at a charity auction made their own bids for literary immortality by helping out seven authors in search of a character.
fields.body:
Few of us are talented enough to pen a best-selling novel or carry off literary prizes. But last night book lovers at a charity auction made their own bids for literary immortality by helping out seven authors in search of a character.

They each paid up to £6,200 to have their names used in future novels by writers including Kathy Lette, Nick Hornby and Sebastian Faulks. Rose Tremain, Louis de Bernieres, Jim Crace and Hanif Kureishi also took part, ensuring that hopefuls could see their name in print whatever their literary taste.

The top bid, for a role in Ms Lette's next comic romp, was so impressive that the novelist vowed to give winning bidder Shelaine Green a correspondingly hefty part in the plot.

"Size does count, so I'm going to make her a main character," Ms Lette promised. "I'll make her a feisty, gorgeous girl with a black belt in kung fu."

Ms Green, still looking slightly shell-shocked after her £6,200 bid, said: "I want to be outrageous and sassy - but with Kathy Lette that's guaranteed. I did get a bit carried away. I didn't plan to bid quite so much but it's a great cause so it's worth going over the top for."

The Medical Foundation for Victims of Torture raised over £13,000 through the auction, which was held at the British Academy of Film and Television Arts in London. Football-crazy bidders pushed the price for a Nick Hornby character up to £2,050, while a part in the next Sebastian Faulks book went for £2,800.

With no say over how their names are used, the successful bidders have no idea if their identity will go to a hero or villain. In theory, at least, their name could one day be as unpleasantly evocative as unctuous Uriah Heep, demonic Mr Hyde or evil Professor Moriarty.

But the authors pledged to play fair and do the buyers justice. Whitbread prize-winner Jim Crace, whose last novel Being Dead opened with a couple lying dead on a seashore, said: "They shouldn't expect, in my case at least, to be turned into a romantic hero. They are going to get something of a bumpy ride, but I think they'll still be delighted."

Sebastian Faulks offered "at the very least a shopfront" but more probably a diplomat, in his next novel, adding: "With small characters thinking of the names is a tremendous nuisance, so this is actually doing me a favour."

Proceeds from the auction, which was sponsored by bol.com and devised by two Medical Foundation staff members, will go to the charity's £4.7m Under One Roof appeal for a new building to tackle growing waiting lists as demand for its services increases. The foundation is dedicated to helping victims of torture and organised violence and has aided more than 20,000 people. Clients range from former Japanese prisoners of war to asylum-seekers fleeing areas of conflict.

Bizarrely, crime writer Ruth Rendell told the organisers she "loathed" the idea of the auction - then donated £10,000.

Martin Amis and other authors declined to take part after claiming the names of characters were integral parts of their novels.

Medical Foundation director Helen Bamber said the auction had raised a total of £25,000, adding: "We were delighted with the result and certainly plan to repeat the exercise."

webTitle: UN mediator tells Israel: lift blockade or risk war

fields.headline: UN mediator tells Israel: lift blockade or risk war
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText:
The Israeli-Palestinian conflict could rapidly deteriorate
into a regional war, the United Nations special envoy to
the Middle East, Terje Roed-Larsen, warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The Israeli-Palestinian conflict could rapidly deteriorate into a regional war, the United Nations special envoy to the Middle East, Terje Roed-Larsen, warned yesterday.

He urged Israel to lift its blockade of Palestinian areas. "The situation as it is now is not tenable," he said. "It may continue the way it is right now for a few more weeks ... It could deteriorate sharply, dramatically and tragically, which may produce regional spillovers, so we will face a regional war."

Israel imposed the blockade in October, citing security reasons, but Palestinians say it is a collective punishment which has put thousands out of work.

Mr Roed-Larsen, a Norwegian, was a key figure in the secret talks between the PLO and Israel which produced the Oslo accords in 1993, and is a mediator whose views are respected by both sides.

"Palestinian living conditions are falling fast, and safety nets are wearing thin," he said. A "stark increase" in poverty since the beginning of the intifada had left almost half the Palestinians living on less than nine shekels (£1.63) a day, he added. "We need a massive opening up of the Palestinian territories, and we need it very quickly."

He said the Palestinians had succeeded in cutting unemployment in the West Bank and Gaza Strip from 30% in 1996 to 12% last year, but it had risen to 40% - more than 260,000 people - as a result of the blockade.

"Three years of progress have been wiped out in two months of conflict."

Because each worker supports several people, Mr Roed-Larsen estimated that more than 1m Palestinians had suffered a serious loss of income. The Palestinian Authority was no longer able to pay public employees, he added.

He estimated that the Palestinian economy had lost more than £345m in the first 60 days of the crisis, and the losses were continuing at £6.8m a day.

The figures do not include the cost of caring for more than 9,000 wounded Palestinians, nor lost taxes, which are likely to run into the hundreds of millions of pounds, nor the damage to infrastructure.

The al-Mazen Centre for Human Rights in Gaza claims that Israeli heavy weapons partly or totally destroyed 431 houses, 13 public buildings, 10 factories and 14 religious buildings in the first six weeks of the conflict.

The uprooting of trees - which will take years to replace - will also have a lasting impact on livelihoods. The Palestinian agriculture ministry estimates that the Israeli army and settlers have destroyed more than 44,000 trees, mainly grapevines and other agricultural trees.

The Israelis say such measures are necessary for security, though they are also a way of pressuring Palestinians.

Some Israelis want tougher measures, including further economic isolation. There have also been hints that the Israel Electric Corporation, which says it is owed £2.8m by the Palestinian Authority, may cut off power supplies.

Others, including the Shin Bet intelligence service, say a tougher line would make people more desperate and encourage attacks in Israel.

Calling the blockade "completely counter-productive", Mr Roed-Larsen said yesterday: "This policy is fuelling anger and is the major instrument for the radicalisation of the population. The risk here is that one produces through these policies a new generation of Palestinians where hatred, anger and resentment will stay for decades.

"This, in the longer and shorter term, is the greatest threat to the security situation."

Yesterday, some 30,000 Palestinian mourners attended a funeral in Gaza City for Awad Selmi, a senior activist in the armed wing of Hamas who was killed in an explosion, allegedly while planting a bomb. Hamas vowed revenge for his death and dismissed negotiations as an option for peace.

Despite such mass protests, Mr Roed-Larsen believes it "possible to repair the situation and bring the Oslo process back by reviving talks."

"The most important steps on the economic front rest with the Israeli government."

His remarks came after the Israeli group Peace Now called for the immediate evacuation of the 6,500 Israeli settlers in Gaza, followed by the gradual, but not prolonged withdrawal of a further 100,000 settlers from West Bank areas with a large Palestinian population. It also proposed a territorial exchange with the Palestinians of areas in the West Bank with a high Jewish population, such as Gush Etzion.

The plan, reported yesterday in Ha'aretz, said: "The evacuation should take place by offering alternative housing inside Israel, in areas which will be agreed upon with the settlers."

Gun battles continued to rage in the West Bank and Gaza late last night, capping a day in which soldiers shot dead two Palestinians who took part in rock-throwing protests.

Meanwhile, in the Jordanian capital, Amman, unidentified gunmen shot and wounded an Israeli embassy employee as he left a shop in an upmarket area of the city last night. The police said he suffered a gunshot wound to his left foot.

webTitle: Letters: Jamaica was wrongly portrayed

fields.headline: That's not us
fields.trailText:
As a Jamaican, I'm sorry that it took time in my country for Decca Aitkenhead to discover her talents as a tabloid journalist (Paradise island, G2, November 30). A whole year and what does she choose to report? Madness, underage sex, prostitution, drugs, theft. It's a shoddy, sensational piece which reveals a disappointing lack of insight, curiosity and respect for one's hosts.
Sharon Rodney
London

webTitle: Eight years' jail for drunken driver who mowed down three women

fields.headline: Eight years' jail for drunken driver who mowed down three women
fields.standfirst: Relatives of victims protest at 'lenient' sentence on kerb crawler who was three times over limit and failed to stop after accident
fields.trailText: A drunken kerb crawler who killed three young women was jailed for eight years yesterday.
fields.body:
A drunken kerb crawler who killed three young women was jailed for eight years yesterday.

It emerged at Bradford crown court that unemployed car dealer Alan Jackson, who sped away to avoid arrest in Huddersfield's red light area before smashing into the group, had two previous convictions for drink-driving.

Jackson, 39, of Birkby, Huddersfield, pleaded guilty to causing death by dangerous driving to primary school teachers Angela Ovington, 28, and Susan Briggs, 30, and health service website manager Victoria Fisher, 27. The three had been enjoying an evening out with a friend, 28-year-old Louise Tinkler.

Ms Tinkler told police that she felt Jackson's BMW brush against her jeans as she jumped clear.

Jackson, who was more than three times over the alcohol limit, offered no mitigation at Bradford crown court, but claimed in a letter to Judge Roger Scott that he had cried every night since the tragedy in August this year.

He told the judge: "I shall be haunted for the rest of my life. If I could have a choice in this matter I should wish for the law to take my life instead of those three ladies. My punishment will never cease."

After the hearing, which was told that Jackson had crashed a red light, crossed a dual carriageway and then driven on after hitting the women, relatives of the victims protested at the sentence.

Susan Briggs's mother, Pauline, said: "He will be out in less than four years. Is that what the law thinks of innocent people? I would like Alan Jackson to know that my daughter worked hard from the age of 11. He has taken everything away from my family."

Angela Ovington's father, Raymond, said that Jackson, who originally faced a manslaughter charge, had "put on an act" with his emotional letter.

Victoria Fisher's father, Peter, said: "It is disgraceful. He should have been put away for life."

The court heard that Jackson, who is unmarried, had spent the evening drinking and picking up prostitutes.

He had taken one woman home and was just letting a second one into his car when he was stopped by a police patrol. Dressed only in a vest, boxer shorts and slippers, he panicked, left the woman behind, and drove off at high speed.

Andrew Dallas, prosecuting, said that the four women friends, who all lived in Huddersfield, were walking home when they heard the BMW screeching up the road.

He said: "They turned round but they were simply too late. In spite of the violence of the collision and the damage to his car, Jackson drove on, attempted a turn, lost control, and ended up crashing into a church wall."

Two of the women were killed instantly, but Miss Fisher died five days later in hospital.

Judge Scott told Jackson: "The close families of these three girls will forever remember birthdays and Christmases and you must think about that for a long, long time.

"You drove into four human beings. Three were killed. Three women's lives were taken away. Your counsel has said that there is absolutely no mitigation for these offences, and I agree with him."

Sergeant Peter Richmond, of West Yorkshire police traffic division, said that the sentence sent out the "positive message that substantial prison sentences are imposed for this type of offence".

webTitle: Letters: Bush is not legitimate

fields.headline: AmBush
fields.trailText: There is no need for Gore to legitimise a Bush presidency by conceding defeat. Let him merely withdraw from further legal contention, allowing Bush to proclaim himself as victor without formal recognition by the Democratic party.
fields.body:
There is no need for Gore to legitimise a Bush presidency by conceding defeat. Let him merely withdraw from further legal contention, allowing Bush to proclaim himself as victor without formal recognition by the Democratic party. That the Florida state secretary's declaration of an electoral victory for Mr Bush was made on the basis of a partial (in every sense) count of the vote will eventually be clear to all, perhaps even before the Bush regime implodes on its own inadequacies.
W Stephen Gilbert
Corsham
Wilts

webTitle: Letters: Is the Daily Telegraph 'tendenciously selective'?

fields.headline: On selective reporting
fields.trailText: Ronald Stevens' suggestion that the Daily Telegraph was agenda-driven in its reporting of the Sunningdale car crash, in which an elderly couple from Feltham and two brothers, one of whom had just left Eton, were killed, is misleading (A strange kind of truth, Media, December 4). He accuses the paper of giving favourable descriptions of the boys from their friends while giving no information about the elderly couple other than that they came from Feltham.
fields.body:
Ronald Stevens' suggestion that the Daily Telegraph was agenda-driven in its reporting of the Sunningdale car crash, in which an elderly couple from Feltham and two brothers, one of whom had just left Eton, were killed, is misleading (A strange kind of truth, Media, December 4). He accuses the paper of giving favourable descriptions of the boys from their friends while giving no information about the elderly couple other than that they came from Feltham.

In accusing us of being "tendentiously selective", he is being tendentiously selective himself. I made it clear to him in a letter - from which he disingenuously quotes - that the police would not provide any information about the couple other than that they were from Feltham. The police also refused to apportion blame at the time, which is why we did not. Mr Stevens deliberately ignored this information in order to build a picture of bias.
Susan Ryan
Managing editor
The Daily Telegraph

As a former Telegraph economic leader writer, I was interested to read Ronald Stevens. There is a major structural difference between the pre-1986 Conrad Black Telegraph and today's. Peter Eastwood, dreaded and powerful news editor, effectively reported to Lord Hartwell, who insisted on impartiality in news coverage. Maurice Green, known as the editor, controlled the leaders and features pages (Comment in today's parlance) only. The then strongly pro-European stance of his pages was not reflected in the news pages.
John Cockcroft
Chelmsford
Essex

webTitle: Letters: FO authorised humanitarian plane

fields.headline: Hain's pain
fields.trailText: Matthew Norman's claim that the government blocked a recent Moroccan humanitarian flight to Iraq is untrue (Diary, December 5). The UN sanctions committee received details of the flight on a Friday evening. It set a deadline on the following Monday afternoon for committee members to approve or object to the flight and asked the Moroccan authorities to delay the flight until then. In the meantime, Britain placed the flight on hold while we checked its inventory for prohibited items. On the Monday afternoon we approved the flight.
fields.body:
Matthew Norman's claim that the government blocked a recent Moroccan humanitarian flight to Iraq is untrue (Diary, December 5). The UN sanctions committee received details of the flight on a Friday evening. It set a deadline on the following Monday afternoon for committee members to approve or object to the flight and asked the Moroccan authorities to delay the flight until then. In the meantime, Britain placed the flight on hold while we checked its inventory for prohibited items. On the Monday afternoon we approved the flight.

This is not the first time we have been accused - falsely - of blocking genuine humanitarian flights to Iraq, among these one arranged in March by George Galloway MP, and a flight he was on from Bulgaria last month. I happen to believe that Saddam Hussain's murderous rule must be opposed and that sanctions help do this. That is my motivation: not some Matthew Norman fantasy about "cabinet ambitions".
Peter Hain MP
Foreign minister

webTitle: Bush now straining at the bit

fields.headline: Bush now straining at the bit
fields.standfirst:
Battle for the White House Republicans strike bipartisan note but non-white Democrats feel disenfranchised

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: A confident George W Bush said yesterday that he was ready to "seize the moment" as soon as the presidential election dispute was settled, while the Democrat vice-presidential candidate Joe Lieberman acknowledged that the Florida supreme court hearing this week would be the "final arbiter" of the outcome.
fields.body:
A confident George W Bush said yesterday that he was ready to "seize the moment" as soon as the presidential election dispute was settled, while the Democrat vice-presidential candidate Joe Lieberman acknowledged that the Florida supreme court hearing this week would be the "final arbiter" of the outcome.

As Mr Bush spoke in Texas, his Republican running mate Dick Cheney also reflected his party's conviction that the contest with Al Gore is swinging their way by telling congressional leaders in Washington that the transition to a Bush presidency was "up and running and operational".

Republican delight at Monday's dismissal of Mr Gore's legal challenge to the election results in Florida was plain for all to see as the Bush-Cheney team began to increase the tempo of their push for power.

"The judge gave a very thorough opinion yesterday. It was a definitive opinion," Mr Bush said as he arrived at the Texas capitol building in Austin.

Earlier he had received his first direct national security briefing from CIA officials since he and Mr Gore were both briefed on international intelligence developments last week.

Officially the Bush team is sticking to its decision not to appear premature in laying claim to the White House before the Florida courts have finished hearing Mr Gore's challenges.

Mr Bush even went out of his way to appear magnanimous towards his rival yesterday, telling reporters that Mr Gore faced "a difficult decision".

"I can understand what he may be going through. It's been a very interesting time for both of us," he added.

But the reality is that the Bush-Cheney team now believes it is only days away from forcing Mr Gore to concede the election, given Judge N Sanders Sauls's ruling against the vice-president in Tallahassee on Monday.

"We feel very good about what happened," Mr Cheney said on Capitol Hill, where he discussed transition and legislative prospects with the House Speaker, Dennis Hastert, and other Republican congressional leaders.

"Hopefully we will be able to get on in fairly short order with the business of preparing for governing."

That confidence found some support in the latest opinion surveys which showed that 63% of Americans believe Mr Bush has now won the presidency. But they also show that 52% think it is too soon for him to start nominating members of his cabinet.

Mr Cheney and Mr Hastert both struck a bipartisan tone. Mr Cheney confirmed that Mr Bush had discussed a possible cabinet job with the Louisiana Democratic Senator John Breaux, while Mr Hastert said he hoped both legislative houses could join "in a bipartisan way" in an effort "to get good things done for the American people".

In private, however, many Republicans are less charitable. Much of the discussion between Mr Bush and Mr Cheney and congressional Republicans focused on whether there are enough votes on Capitol Hill for Mr Bush to drive through the tax cutting programme which was the centrepiece of his campaign.

Democrats mounted a show of unity behind Mr Gore. "Al Gore and Joe Lieberman enjoy strong support with our caucus for what they're doing to try to get every vote counted on Florida," the party's congressional leader, Dick Gephardt, said on Capitol Hill.

Mr Lieberman said the Florida supreme court, which sits tomorrow, would be the "final arbiter" of the dispute.

He said: "This is an unprecedented situation, but I think every American and both political parties should feel at this moment encouraged and proud of the way we are dealing with this."

The drama of the presidential race overshadowed Hillary Clinton's arrival at the US Senate for the first time since her election a month ago.

webTitle: Letters: The NHS postcode lottery

fields.headline: Watch where you get ill - or pregnant
fields.trailText: I was disgusted to read of the way Nigel Harper was treated by his local hospital during a time when their constant support should have been always available ('He can't come back in two months. He'll be dead', G2, December 5).
fields.body:
I was disgusted to read of the way Nigel Harper was treated by his local hospital during a time when their constant support should have been always available ('He can't come back in two months. He'll be dead', G2, December 5).

I have spent the last two years fighting lymphatic cancer and my treatment at the Royal Marsden in Sutton, purely on the NHS, has been nothing but exemplary. Tests and treatment have always been prompt and never cancelled. Staff have been superb, both in their friendliness and support and in their honesty and frankness. Is it really the sign of a well-run health service that treatment for such serious diseases can be so different and dependent on where one lives?
David Roberts
London

I am delighted Alan Milburn plans to address the postcode lottery for infertile women (Report, December 1) and hope the government will also look at the scandalous anomalies in the provision of abortion services. In 1999, 26% of women still had to pay to obtain a legal abortion - far higher than for any other surgery in the country; 54% of women in Solihull had to pay, whereas only 4% in south and west Devon did so.

In London, 54% of women in Redbridge and Waltham Forest had to pay, compared with 23% in Brent and Harrow health authority and 35% overall. These differences have persisted since 1968, with the West Midlands region always bottom in provision and the northern and south-western regions best for women.

The number of legal abortions is carefully monitored; the earlier the operation is done, the fewer the side effects and distress. There is good evidence about how to set up a service to minimise delay, but because of difficulties with funding and competing priorities, the inequity persists and early medical abortions (which have been introduced widely in Scotland where 95% of abortions are done by the NHS) are hard to obtain in England and Wales.

Lastly the 1967 Act does not extend to Northern Ireland and currently about 1,600 women travel to the mainland to obtain an abortion they are unable to get at home. I hope the government will listen to women and end this situation.
Wendy Savage
Doctors for a Woman's Choice on Abortion
marsh.gate@talk21.com

fields.headline: Welsh on right track
fields.trailText: Martin Wainwright (Long Welsh words could be road hazard, December 5) helps perpetuate some of the myths about the Welsh language. Welsh words, on average, are not longer than English (bilingual documents are the same length in either language).
fields.body:
Martin Wainwright (Long Welsh words could be road hazard, December 5) helps perpetuate some of the myths about the Welsh language. Welsh words, on average, are not longer than English (bilingual documents are the same length in either language). Llanfairpwll etc ( usually Llanfair PG on official signs) is a manufactured name used to boost tourism since Victorian times. Most of our names are no longer than Pontardawe (M4) and certainly not as long or confusing as Ostwaldtwistle (M65) or Heckmondwicke (M62).
Ken Maddocks
Sir Gaerfyrddin

webTitle: Letters: Rections on jury trial

fields.headline: Gunning for the Met
fields.trailText: Deborah Coles is right (No trial for police who shot painter, December 5). The abject decision of the crown prosecution service to take no further proceedings against any Metropolitan police officer for their shooting of our neighbour Harry Stanley deprives the citizens of London of an accountable police force. It is not for the CPS to decide that shooting Harry twice was "...as much force as was necessary".
fields.body:
Deborah Coles is right (No trial for police who shot painter, December 5). The abject decision of the crown prosecution service to take no further proceedings against any Metropolitan police officer for their shooting of our neighbour Harry Stanley deprives the citizens of London of an accountable police force. It is not for the CPS to decide that shooting Harry twice was "...as much force as was necessary".

It is for a jury to decide. Not only on the guilt or innocence of the two firearms officers, but also of the other officers who inadequately assessed the fatally wrong intelligence they received. The people of London deserve better than for the CPS to give a green light to summary execution on the street.

Perhaps mayor Livingstone's proposals for independent judicial review of killings by police will be the answer. But we in Hackney can't wait. Tomorrow the Justice for Harry Stanley Campaign is meeting to debate the issues and continue the endeavour to obtain truth, justice and restitution for Harry's bereaved family.
Mary Pimm
London During Jack Straw's defence of his proposals to erode the right to jury trial he drew parallels with the introduction of majority verdicts. He argued the campaign to defend unanimous verdicts was vociferous but has now sunk without trace and everyone is happy.

Liberty has never changed its opposition to majority verdicts. Unfortunately, the home secretary creates too many new issues for us to be able to keep all the old campaigns alive. The evidence is that too many miscarriages of justice have involved majority verdicts. I thought Jack Straw might reconsider his position on both proposals after the case of Peter Fell (Fantasist bailed over murder convictions, December 2) who was convicted by a majority and served 17 years in prison for something he never did.
John Wadham
Director
Liberty

webTitle: Letters: Opinions on the ANC

fields.headline: ANC: votes for and against
fields.trailText: You deliver a defensible rebuke to the African National Congress for the shortcomings of its government (Rainbow Blues, December 5). It is, however, indefensibly simplistic.
fields.body:
You deliver a defensible rebuke to the African National Congress for the shortcomings of its government (Rainbow Blues, December 5). It is, however, indefensibly simplistic. You say it is not good enough to continue heaping all the blame on the legacy of apartheid, six years after the end of white minority rule. That is true. Yet the legacy is real and persistently malign in the economic disparities between white and black.

The macroeconomic research group (Merg) report of 1993 offered a cautious programme for economic growth with the objective of reducing such disparities. It was shelved by the leadership of the ANC, largely in response to pressures from western governments. In its place there emerged a neo-liberal economic policy, with "black empowerment" at its decorative edges. This has enriched relatively few blacks, while predictably failing to "trickle down" in the socially transforming provision of jobs, schools, housing. Corruption, incidentally part of the apartheid legacy, may thrive in such circumstances. It does so in the US, among other western societies.

Mounting electoral support for the Democratic Alliance may or may not serve to maintain a pluralist democracy. Certainly, it will not confront a failed economic policy with which the Democratic Alliance is even more infatuated.
Ronald Segal
Walton-on-Thames, Surrey

Chris McGreal (Mandela attacks "black stooges" deserting ANC in droves, December 4) claims that the Democratic party (now the Democratic Alliance) ran "a thinly disguised racist presidential campaign last year". It is true that the African National Congress did accuse the DP of "racism" (as well as "neo-Nazism") but this should be seen for what it is - crude propaganda.

The ANC was unable to produce a single quote, policy or pamphlet that could reasonably be construed as "racist". The fact that the ANC made similar accusations of "racism" against the Mail & Guardian earlier this year, should have given McGreal some pause for thought. The DP campaign, although critical of the ANC, was based on liberal and non-racial principles. A survey in February this year found that only 3% of black (African) respondents ascribed the DP's success at the last election to racism. This is compared to the 22% who ascribed it to good organisation and communication, and 17% who ascribed it to the non-racial platform of the party. Propaganda is supposed to sway the ignorant masses, not Guardian foreign correspondents.
James MyburghDemocratic party
Cape Town

London

You say it is not good enough to continue heaping all the blame on the legacy of apartheid, six years after the end of white minority rule. That is true. It was shelved by the leadership of the ANC, largely in response to pressures from western governments. In its place there emerged a neo-liberal economic policy, with "black empowerment" at its decorative edges. This has enriched relatively few blacks, while predictably failing to "trickle down" in the socially transforming provision of jobs, schools, housing. webTitle: Brazilians named by drugs inquiry

fields.headline: Brazilians named by drugs inquiry
fields.trailText: Three congressmen, 12 state deputies and three mayors were due to be named last night in a list of more than 500 people allegedly involved in organised crime and drugs trafficking in Brazil.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Three congressmen, 12 state deputies and three mayors were due to be named last night in a list of more than 500 people allegedly involved in organised crime and drugs trafficking in Brazil.

The list, part of the final report of an 18-month parliamentary inquiry into the drugs trade, includes policemen, lawyers, businesspeople and farmers in 17 of the 27 states.

The inquiry was the most probing look yet into drug trafficking in Brazil, which is estimated to be worth more than £15m.

"It's a massive indictment of all sections of Brazilian society. It touches almost every part," said David Fleischer, professor of politics at Brasilia University. "It shows us that organised crime and money-laundering is a very sophisticated network, much more sophisticated than we thought."

The investigators will hand the 5,000-page report to prosecutors and judges, who are expected to start legal proceedings against the accused.

The three congressmen named can expect to be expelled from congress if found guilty. They are Augusto Farias from the state of Alagoas, and Ildefonco Cordeiro and Jose Aleksandro from Acre, an Amazonian state which borders cocaine-producing Bolivia and Peru.

Mr Aleksandro replaced Hildebrando Pascoal, who was expelled from congress last year after the inquiry discovered that he had sliced off an enemy's arms and legs with a chainsaw.

Several dozen people were jailed as as a result of information discovered by the inquiry. At least 20 witnesses were killed.

Critics of the inquiry have argued that the investigators are interested in easy publicity and in pursuing political enemies.

But David Fleischer said the inquiry did serious work, despite obstruction from vested interests.

"We know they [investigators] could have found out much more but they didn't have much cooperation from the central bank, who didn't give them all the information about cancelled cheques that they asked for."

The report includes suggestions on how to combat organised crime in the future. These include creating a commission to continue the investigations, involving the judiciary, the police, the inland revenue, the central bank and congress.

Moroni Torgan, chairman of the inquiry, said that implementing the proposals was as important as jailing the accused. He suggested that the new commission should be called Operation Holding Hands - in reference to the anti-mafia drive in Italy, Operation Clean Hands.

webTitle: Black voters feel bitter and excluded

fields.headline: Black voters feel bitter and excluded
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: When the Rev Jesse Jackson called on supporters outside the Florida supreme court in Talahassee last week to pray, Bush supporters driving past starting honking their horns and chanting: "Go home, Jesse! Go home, Jesse!"
fields.body:
When the Rev Jesse Jackson called on supporters outside the Florida supreme court in Talahassee last week to pray, Bush supporters driving past starting honking their horns and chanting: "Go home, Jesse! Go home, Jesse!"

There was tension in the air. The biggest Bush demonstrations in the state capital was almost completely white. Then, as the legal battle for votes heated up, the biggest and best-organised Democrat demonstration was outside the supreme court, and it was mostly black.

Now as the election finally approaches its end-game, the racial divide split between the Democrats and Republicans grows wider than ever.

There is a strong sense that the party that represents the African-American voter has lost because many of them were intimidated and disenfranchised, and that a Republican administration would enter the White House deeply distrusted by the black electorate.

"It would be ludicrous to think that there won't be great resentment," Joanne Bland of the National Voting Rights Museum in Selma, Alabama, said yesterday. "But we have to use this as a catalyst and not sit back and lick our wounds."

Ms Bland, a veteran civil rights activist who was jailed more than a dozen times as a teenager in Selma for demonstrating for the right to vote, added: "These things didn't just happen overnight, it's the same old thing with a new face but finally people will see what has been going on."

It was significant that in the final whirlwind days of Al Gore's campaign the places he chose to visit in Memphis and in Philadelphia were black churches in black areas.

Mr Gore may have appeared awkward as he tried to clap along to the gospel choirs which greeted his appearance, but it was nevertheless clear that he and his party enjoyed the wholehearted support of the congregations.

While George W Bush was being greeted and supported by the likes of Hank Williams Jr and Bo Derek, Mr Gore was being sung to on stage by such black stars as Stevie Wonder, Wyclef Jean and the Rev Al Green.

In the end the Republicans had as much difficulty as ever in attracting the black vote. More than 80% of male African Americans - and 90% female - voted for the Democrats.

Although Mr Bush made an effort to have black faces on stage at the Republican convention in Philadelphia, many remarked that the effect was that of a basketball game in Utah: an audience of white people gazing at a stage where black people they had never met were performing.

No one worked harder to mobilise the black vote than Mr Jackson, and if all the intended votes had been counted and the Democrats had taken Florida - as most of the analysis indicates that it should have - Mr Gore would have been for ever in his debt.

When the first indications of the chaotic state of the Florida vote count appeared, it was Mr Jackson who was down in the state leading the protests.

When the legal cases seemed to be going against Mr Gore last week, it was Mr Jackson again who held the stage outside the supreme court along with liberal rabbis and young Democrats, listing the ways in which the black voters in the area had been disenfranchised.

And if it was not Jesse Jackson Sr getting the vote out, it was Jesse Jackson Jr, a young Chicago congressman who played a big part in persuading many on the liberal left to stay with the Democrats and not vote for the Green presidential candidate, Ralph Nader.

While race as such was rarely discussed in the presidential debates, events since the election have put it very much back on the list of issues that divide the parties. Broadly, the Republicans remain opposed to affirmative action while the Democrats support it.

While the Clinton administration has given prominence to more minorities than any previous government, the face of the Bush team has been mainly old white Republicanism, although it is clear that Mr Bush would seek to change this perception.

But the resentment at what is seen as intimidation and disenfranchisement of the black voter will remain.

And because the police erected road blocks which deterred black people from voting, because Creole-speaking Haitian refugees were not helped to understand the ballot, and because so many thousands of black people with convictions, some very minor, were not allowed to vote at all, whatever is finally proved, it will be felt that that the Republicans came to power by excluding black voters.

webTitle: Shake-up puts 6,000 steel jobs at risk

fields.headline: Shake-up puts 6,000 steel jobs at risk
fields.trailText: Up to 6,000 jobs could go in a radical restructuring of Britain's steel industry after the abrupt departure last night of the two joint chief executives at leading producer Corus.
fields.body:
Up to 6,000 jobs could go in a radical restructuring of Britain's steel industry after the abrupt departure last night of the two joint chief executives at leading producer Corus.

Sir Brian Moffatt, chairman of Europe's second-largest steel group and now acting chief executive, said he would draw up a new strategy by February but admitted: "There will probably have to be plant closures."

He blamed a serious deterioration in Corus's trading performance on the strength of sterling and declining demand from UK manufacturers such as car makers.

The two bosses, John Bryant and Fokko van Duyne, who took command following British Steel's merger with its Dutch rival Hoogovens 12 months ago to create Corus, had shown "lack of progress and leadership", Sir Brian said.

But the two will receive substantial pay-offs. Mr Bryant has a two-year rolling contract which could guarantee him a £1m goodbye.

Corus shares rose 5.25p to 75p,- adding £164m to the value of the company, as the City anticipated drastic action to reverse losses that reached £249m after tax in the first nine months of this year.

Most likely victim would be the Llanwern strip mill near Newport, south Wales, where a blast furnace was recently mothballed and £35m needs to be spent on relining a second furnace.

Some 3,000 jobs could go there but plants such as Lackenby on Teesside are also vulnerable, which could bring the redundancy total to 6,000. These would come on top of existing cuts involving 4,500 staff, although Sir Brian refused to say what scale of redundancies was likely.

Jeremy Fletcher, steel analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston, said: "The scale of the restructuring is going to be very large. This [the management changes] signals the board is determined to get this sorted."

The steel union ISTC said Corus employees were "shocked and alarmed" by the day's announcements, which came as the company was seeing growth in demand and a fall in the strength of the pound.

Michael Leahy, ISTC general secretary, called for an early meeting with management and government action over "this alarming threat to the nation's manufacturing base".

Sir Brian admitted the currency situation had eased in recent days but said there was too much uncertainty surrounding its future direction while the trading scene "was not as strong as it was."

Corus has been exporting 50% of its UK steel products, compared to 30% ten years ago.

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: £33,000 for top train drivers
fields.body:
£33,000 for top train drivers

Train drivers at a privatised rail firm have won a 20% pay rise, boosting their salaries to £33,000 and taking them to the top of the wage league for their job.

The deal involves 250 drivers at Great North Eastern Railway, which runs services on the east coast main line, including Hatfield where a derailment in October led to widespread disruption.

The drivers' union Aslef said it wanted the GNER deal to become a benchmark for the industry.

JJB Sports adds to team

JJB Sports has appointed managing director Duncan Sharpe as chief executive effective from February 1. David Whelan, the current executive chairman, will remain as company chairman.

Aberdeen profits double

Fund manager Aberdeen Asset Management yesterday said its profits more than doubled in 2000, driven by acquisitions and organic growth.

Aberdeen said revenue in the year to September 30 rose to £115.7m from £62.7m in 1999. Earnings per share before goodwill amortisation and exceptional costs rose to 16.48p from 7.77p. Overall profit rose to £24.1m from £10.5m a year earlier.

ICI sells parts for £325m

ICI has agreed to sell three of its industrial chemicals operations to privately held Belgian-based firm Ineos for about £325m.

ICI said it expected to complete the sale of its Chlor-Chemicals, Klea and Crosfield units by January and would use the cash proceeds to reduce debt.

Enterprise eyes Wolves pubs

British pubs group Enterprise Inns said yesterday it was in talks to buy pubs from Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries if entrepreneur Robert Breare succeeds in his bid for the regional brewer.

Enterprise, which runs almost 2,600 pubs after a big expansion drive, wants to add those of Wolves, which has about 1,780 pubs and four breweries.

Wolves is facing a possible bid following a fall in first-half profits and an ongoing strategic review.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText:
Pinochet house arrest lifted
14 dead in Ivory Coast clashes
Soldiers rape Bangladesh girl
Nigeria leader given summons
fields.body:
Pinochet house arrest lifted

An appeal court in Chile yesterday overruled the house arrest of General Augusto Pinochet until it decides whether to uphold the former dictator's indictment on homicide and kidnapping charges.

The court, which is scheduled to meet later this week to rule on the indictment issued last Friday by judge Juan Guzman, also lifted a ban on Gen Pinochet travelling abroad.
AP, Santiago

14 dead in Ivory Coast clashes

Supporters of the former prime minister Alassane Ouattara fought the police in Ivory Coast's main city, Abidjan, yesterday, in a second day of violence. At least 14 people have been killed.

The police dispersed protesters and rival groups with teargas after vigilantes attacked one another with clubs, machetes and catapults.

Mr Ouattara's supporters insist that he should be allowed to stand in Sunday's parliamentary elections.
Reuters, Abidjan

Soldiers rape Bangladesh girl

The rape of a teenage girl by a group of soldiers on Sunday has sent shock waves across Bangladesh.

The victim was thrown from a moving train as she tried to resist the attack. The army promised exemplary punishment of the perpetrators when their identities are established.
Arshad Mahmud, Dhaka

Nigeria leader given summons

The Nigerian human rights commission has summoned President Olusegun Obasanjo and two generals to answer questions about the burning of late pop idol Fela Kuti's house in 1977, officials said yesterday.

Mr Obasanjo, the military ruler when soldiers attacked the house, set up the commission last year.
Reuters, Lagos

webTitle: Setback for Star Wars firm

fields.headline: Setback for Star Wars firm
fields.standfirst: 100 jobs to go as Character losses intensify
fields.trailText: Character Group, the merchandising firm that saw its share price shattered after overestimating demand for products relating to the film Star Wars: The Phantom Menace, felt the force of market disapproval again yesterday when it reported wider than expected losses.
fields.body:
Character Group, the merchandising firm that saw its share price shattered after overestimating demand for products relating to the film Star Wars: The Phantom Menace, felt the force of market disapproval again yesterday when it reported wider than expected losses.

The beleaguered shares fell a further 6p yesterday to 34p and now stand at less than one tenth of the amount they were changing hands for a year ago.

Character, which also produces product for the animated film Chicken Run, said trading in August had been worse than expected leading to a greater than expected full year loss of £13.8m for the year to August 31. Around 100 jobs will be cut as a result.

Chairman Richard King was contrite about the losses and tried to draw a line under the episode by insisting that the worst was over following a strategic review and signs of better trading.

"This year was the first blip in our history and followed nine years of solid growth," Mr King said.

"I guess we got a little bit complacent. Things went wrong badly but we have dealt with them and I have every faith that we're back on track.

"Despite the severity of the continued difficult trading conditions, both within our own and the other consumer sectors, and these conditions being further exacerbated by the recent fuel crisis, abysmal weather and flooding, the start of the new financial year has shown a significant turnaround in our profitability."

Management has cut around £1.8m costs out of the business and plans to reduce headcount by around 30% to 214 by March next year.
