webTitle: Low rates ease mortgage burden

fields.headline: Borrowers need not be put on red alert - yet
fields.standfirst: Low rates ease mortgage burden
fields.trailText: An end to boom and bust Britain is Gordon Brown's favourite mantra, and a glance at the inflation, interest rate and growth figures since 1997 suggest his prayers are being answered. But the boom and bust that just won't go away is the house price cycle.
fields.body:
An end to boom and bust Britain is Gordon Brown's favourite mantra, and a glance at the inflation, interest rate and growth figures since 1997 suggest his prayers are being answered. But the boom and bust that just won't go away is the house price cycle.

Those with long memories will recall the greatest ever property boom, in the early 1970s, followed by an equally great collapse, although one masked by galloping inflation.

The boomlet of 1978-79 ended in the early 1980s recession, and the late 1980s boom took most of the 1990s to unwind. This government, pencilling in an election, hardly wants its best-laid plans blown aside by the 1999-2000 property boom ending in the collapse of 2001. This week Mr Brown's lieutenant, City watchdog Howard Davies, was lecturing mortgage bosses about excessive lending, and the "danger zone" of London property prices.

Many found his comments curiously ill-timed; after all, annualised house price inflation peaked at 18% earlier this year and has fallen steadily since.

Yesterday's figures from Halifax show a fresh upturn, but hardly another boom. What's more, as Mr Davies said himself, the typical new mortgage as a percentage of the purchase price has actually fallen, with 75%-plus loans less common.

So why his concern? One real worry is the fast-rising level of household in debtedness, once personal loans, credit cards and other debts are brought into the picture.

But no matter how much Mr Davies and others exhort the industry about worsening debt levels, the government has done nothing to stop the tide of cheap loan junk mail. In any case, some of the new borrowing is perfectly reasonable, as individuals swap expensive credit card debt for cheaper personal loan debt.

But Mr Davies' main concern is the stretching of income multiples on mortgages. His figures show that more than a third of lending is now above the traditional limit of three times' salary.

Is such lending truly excessive? Since the last boom and bust, lenders have become a lot more sophisticated about who they lend to; affordability, judged by a range of outgoings, is the password to a home loan rather than simple salary levels.

It is also time to question whether the traditional limits on income multiples make any sense in a period of sustained low interest rates.

The price of a house is not the figure in the estate agent's window, it is how much it takes from your salary cheque each month to pay for it. Thus a £200,000 house at 5% interest costs little more than a £100,000 house at 10% interest.

Increasing the income multiple limit doesn't automatically suggest that homebuyers are over-extending themselves.

If the British economy really is successful in maintaining low long-term interest rates, we may have to grin and bear huge mortgage debts, made cheap by low servicing costs.

But heaven help us if interest rates break back upwards again. We may be in some sort of a new economy, but cycles have a nasty habit of reasserting themselves.

Rich folly

The rewards for failure were once again laid bare in brazen fashion yesterday. John Bryant, amiable but ineffectual co-chief executive of Corus, the Anglo-Dutch steel group, "resigned" (kicked out by a unanimous decision of the board) with his Dutch counterpart after a series of half-hearted efforts to restore it to profitability. Mr Bryant's pay-off is a hot-rolled, stainless £1m.

In the nearly two years since he became chief executive, first of British Steel and then, with Fokko van Duyne, of Corus, Mr Bryant has axed several thousand steelmakers' jobs - some 4,500 in the past year alone - to raise efficiency and reduce costs. They all leave with a few thousand in their back-pockets, the casualties of a merger dreamed up by Bryant and van Duyne that has manifestly failed to deliver.

In the first half of this year the old British Steel lost £226m in carbon steel while Hoogovens, its Dutch merger partner, made £74m profit in the same segment. Mr Bryant can blame the strength of the pound and the weak euro for the UK operation's failings and he has a point.

But the Corus board, correctly, blamed Mr Bryant and his colleague for failing to grasp the magnitude of the task. This is the failure of executive inability to see beyond the immediate market forces and plan for the future. Mr Bryant simply failed to cut UK capacity when all around him knew the writing was on the wall.

In the UK the rewards for overseeing a collapse in share price, profits and, above all, corporate morale are the same as Judith Keppel guessing the name of Eleanor of Aquitaine's husband. The latter is questionable but the former, repeated throughout boardrooms, is unacceptable.

webTitle: Fed chief sparks US rally

fields.headline: Fed chief sparks US rally
fields.trailText: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, provided some much needed cheer for US stock market investors yesterday when he signalled that the central bank may be willing to reduce the cost of borrowing next year.
fields.body:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, provided some much needed cheer for US stock market investors yesterday when he signalled that the central bank may be willing to reduce the cost of borrowing next year.

Share prices in the US staged their strongest rally in months as investors took heart from his comments and signs that the presidential contest may be nearing conclusion.

The Nasdaq composite was up more than 7%, or 200 points, at midday at 2,820, while the Dow Jones rose almost 3% to 10,835. Trading curbs, used frequently in the past few months to prevent a freefall, were triggered to stop the Dow rising too quickly as investors welcomed signs that the Fed may cut interest rates amid signs of a slowing economy.

There was a knock-on effect for stock markets in Europe, with London closing 2% higher and 3% gains being recorded in Paris and Frankfurt. Prices of US treasury bonds also rose as investors rushed to buy the notes.

Mr Greenspan said that the pace of economic growth had "moderated appreciably". His comments were taken as a clear sign that the Fed would soften its hawkish stance on inflation when it next meets later this month as a prelude to cutting rates next year.

The Fed has raised interest rates six times since June 1999 in an effort to calm inflation fears and cool a raging US economy. Since April, however, US stock markets have plummeted as consumers and corporations have stopped spending and doubts have been raised about the value of internet shares.

Speaking to a group of community bankers in New York yesterday, Mr Greenspan said: "In an economy that already has lost some momentum, one must remain alert to the possibility that greater caution and weakening asset values in financial markets could precipitate an excessive softening in household and business spending."

His remarks were taken as a sign that the Fed no longer sees inflation as the greatest threat to the US economy and could cut rates to ensure a soft rather than a hard landing.

Kevin Logan, a senior market economist at Dresdner Bank in New York, said Mr Greenspan's remarks made it clear that the Fed was contemplating a rate cut, perhaps as early as January.

American markets were also cheered by two court decisions that dealt a blow to the presidential ambitions of Al Gore late on Monday.

Companies felt to have most to gain from a George W Bush presidency led yesterday's advance, including Microsoft, the software group which is appealing the competition lawsuit brought by the US government, and Philip Morris, the world's largest tobacco company.

webTitle: Rail firms count cost of Hatfield

fields.headline: Rail firms count cost of Hatfield
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Two rail companies revealed yesterday that they had lost millions of pounds in the first financial fall out from the Hatfield rail crash, and that the losses would continue.
fields.body:
Two rail companies revealed yesterday that they had lost millions of pounds in the first financial fall out from the Hatfield rail crash, and that the losses would continue.

The transport group, Stagecoach, which has a 49% stake in Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Rail, disclosed that Virgin's revenue was down 33% in the four weeks to November 11.

Midland Mainline, owned by National Express, announced that it had lost millions in ticket sales, and that business was down 20%. It normally carries 20,000 passengers daily.

Keith Cochrane, Stagecoach's chief executive, said he was confident that it would be able to secure compensation from Railtrack to cover both the loss in revenue from the disruption and payments for delayed passengers.

The group has earmarked £3m as compensation for travellers on South West Trains, one of its operators and £2 m for rail passengers. He said that each business made a loss of £2m in the four weeks to November 11, and the scale of disruption has continued.

Mr Cochrane said that the initial revenue losses had already been offset by compensation payments from Railtrack, and there was a "strong case" for reaching an agreement over the rest.

Railtrack has set aside £150m for the impact of the Hatfield crash on the industry, but the 25 train operating companies suggest that the final bill will exceed £300m.

Mr Cochrane stressed that there was still a bright future for the railways. "The best way to win people back is to demonstrate that we can operate a reliable service," he said.

He explained that Stagecoach's bid for an extended South West Trains franchise outlined the urgent need for extra capacity at London's Waterloo station. Part of the Stagecoach plan is a £300m facelift for three key London commuter stations, Clapham Junction, Vauxhall and Queeenstown Road.

Stagecoach's interim results published yesterday show that the rail companies were making a profit before Hatfield. Operating profits for SWT for the six months to the end of October rose from £19.5m to £24.3m. Stagecoach's share of Virgin Rail profits rose 29% from £5.9m to £7.6m. The interim dividend is raised 8.3% to 1.3p.

Stagecoach's group figures were well down on last year. Six month pre-tax profits were £57.5m against £112m last year. The shortfall was largely due to the loss of contribution from the profitable train leasing company, Porterbrook, sold to Abbey National for £773m in April. Stagecoach's US bus subsidiary, Coach USA, also put in a disappointing performance. Its margins were squeezed from 19.7 % to 13.7% by rising costs.

Kevin Johnson, Midland Mainline spokesman, said that the operator's slump followed the imposition of speed restrictions while the rail network was tested and repaired.

Passengers on one of its trains, who took nine hours to complete what would normally have been a two-hour journey from London to Nottingham, are to receive up to £100 compensation plus the price of their ticket.

A Reader's Digest survey yesterday showed that passengers are continuing to receive "inaccurate and inconsistent" information on fares from the national rail inquiry system. British Airways said yesterday that its domestic business was good this month thanks to chaos on the nation's railways, which is luring people away from trains. But bad weather in early November hurt business at Europe's largest airline, helping pull overall traffic down 3.4%.

webTitle: Technicolor sell-off lifts Carlton shares

fields.headline: Technicolor relief gives Carlton shares a lift
fields.trailText: Carlton Communications said yesterday that its long-expected disposal of its video and film processing unit Technicolor is likely to be completed "in the coming weeks".
fields.body:
Carlton Communications said yesterday that its long-expected disposal of its video and film processing unit Technicolor is likely to be completed "in the coming weeks".

Chief executive Gerry Murphy said talks were taking place with a trade buyer for a unit that analysts value at £900m to £1.5bn. "We won't accept less than £1bn for [Technicolor] and if we don't get an offer of that level we'll keep it," he said.

Mr Murphy was speaking as the ITV broadcaster unveiled an 8% rise in full year pre-tax profits and a 9% in net advertising revenues. Shares in Carlton climbed 18p to 543p.

Technicolor was put on the block when Carlton chairman Michael Green announced earlier in the year that he planned to merge the business with United News & Media. It became unclear if the sale was still on when those talks collapsed.

Mr Murphy, who joined Carlton after the United deal was first mooted, said that he still planned to sell the business which operates in the declining market for video tape production but a booming one for DVDs. Microsoft has contracted Technicolor to produce DVDs for its X-Box games console and then distribute both the disks and the machines across the US.

The cash from any sale of Technicolor is likely be used to reduce Carlton's net debt of £510m and for further investment in its digital media division.

An eventful year for the terrestrial commercial broadcasters saw Carlton's turnover break the £2bn barrier for the first time at £2.08bn. However, heavy digital media costs largely relating to losses absorbed from its ONdigital terrestrial television joint-venture with Granada, turned last year's pre-tax profit of £152.4m into a £241.9m loss.

Uncertainty surrounding the health of the television advertising market has weighed heavily on the share prices of the leading broadcasters and Mr Murphy said that the fourth calender quarter of the year is likely to be weak overall.

webTitle: Brewer blames weather for sales

fields.headline: Brewer blames weather for sales
fields.trailText: Brewers Scottish & Newcastle yesterday blamed "a miserable summer and a very wet winter" for a 2.6% slump in first-half sales to pubs and clubs.
fields.body:
Brewers Scottish & Newcastle yesterday blamed "a miserable summer and a very wet winter" for a 2.6% slump in first-half sales to pubs and clubs.

Managing director Guy Dickson said the group had outperformed the industry which had seen pub and club sales fall 5%.

In addition, the downturn had been partially offset by better sales through supermarkets and off-licences and a sharp improvement in international sales.

The interim results, however, were overshadowed by the losses the group incurred through the sale earlier this year of its main leisure interests, the Center Parcs and Pontin holiday centres.

The disposals resulted in an exceptional loss of £329.9m, leaving the group with a pretax loss of £95.6m, against a comparable pretax profit of £205.8m last year.

Chairman Brian Stewart confirmed that the group was planning to further reduce its pub estate but said details would be announced next month when those affected had been told.

He added that the group, unlike its rivals, was committed to remaining an integrated business owning both pubs and brewing operations.

S&N sold about 400 pubs earlier this year and is planning to sell a further unspecified number which it believes will be more viable without the overhead burdens of being part of a large group.

webTitle: Smiths clears leftovers

fields.headline: Smiths clears leftovers
fields.trailText: Shareholders of Smiths Group, the aerospace specialist, could soon have something else to cheer about, aside from the dubious benefits of promotion to the FTSE 100. Market gossips reckon news on the disposal of its automotive division, a leftover from its merger with engineering concern TI Group, could be on the way.
fields.body:
Shareholders of Smiths Group, the aerospace specialist, could soon have something else to cheer about, aside from the dubious benefits of promotion to the FTSE 100. Market gossips reckon news on the disposal of its automotive division, a leftover from its merger with engineering concern TI Group, could be on the way.

The deadline for bids was Monday and, according to the gossips, three high-profile private equity groups have tabled offers. This should ensure a lively auction for the operation, which makes fuel-storage and delivery systems, and could push the asking price up to the £1.2bn Smiths is said to be looking for.

According to the chatter, Bain Capital, Blackstone, the US firm that owns the Savoy and Claridge's, and Doughty Hanson, which recently acquired RMH, the food production arm of conglomerate Tomkins, for £1.25bn, are the interested parties.

webTitle: At this price?  Dataflex

fields.headline: At this price?  Dataflex
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: A quick glance at the performance of Dataflex Holdings' share price indicates that the networking equipment company is in need of a bit of good news.
fields.body:
A quick glance at the performance of Dataflex Holdings' share price indicates that the networking equipment company is in need of a bit of good news.

The company was floated 10 months ago at 195p a share, giving it a stock market value of £130m. But it has felt the brunt of the changing sentiment towards hi-techs.

Ahead of yesterday's trading statement, the shares were down to 155p, valuing the company at £104m.

Dataflex, which makes routers for telecom companies, then produced a bit of good news of its own.

webTitle: Blue chips bounce back

fields.headline: Blue chips bounce back
fields.trailText: One could be forgiven for thinking that promotion to the FTSE 100 brings with it massive share price outperformance, such is interest in the quarterly reshuffle of the blue-chip benchmark.
fields.body:
One could be forgiven for thinking that promotion to the FTSE 100 brings with it massive share price outperformance, such is interest in the quarterly reshuffle of the blue-chip benchmark.

Every time reshuffle day approaches pundits across the Square Mile tell investors how the demand from index tracking funds will push the share price of those companies lucky enough to be promoted into the stratosphere.

Well, the last review of the year happens today - oddly enough based on last night's closing prices - and before going any further one thing needs to be made clear: there is no evidence to support the widespread assumption that stocks entering the FTSE 100 outperform. In fact the opposite is true.

As mentioned in these pages yesterday, Schroder Salomon Smith Barney has analysed all the instances since the inception of the FTSE 100 in 1983 where stocks have been promoted. The analysis shows that, contrary to popular opinion, on average, stocks promoted underperform, and stocks relegated, on average, outperform.

This, Schroder suggests, is because most index trackers follow the broader FTSE 350 and those that track the FTSE 100 have completed most of their buying before a new stock joins.

But did such evidence have any bearing on events yesterday? Of course not. As usual there were all sorts of odd prices movements.

Brewer Scottish & Newcastle - in position for a place on Monday - just missed out after its shares fell 36p to 460p following interim figures, which if not exactly sparkling did not warrant a 7.2% mark down. It was pipped to the post by aero-engineer Rolls-Royce, whose shares advanced 10p to 214p, helped by a bullish note from Merrill Lynch - its joint broker. Upgrading the stock to "accumulate", Merrill said Rolls had made good progress in the last quarter.

Subject to confirmation at today's FTSE meeting, it looks as if AB Foods, up 13p at 491p, Smiths Group, 1.5p better at 819p, Autonomy, 237p higher at £27.86p, and Safeway, off 2p at 318p, will be joining Rolls-Royce in the index.

They will be taking the places of Sema, 17p stronger at 288p, Baltimore, up 55p at 390p, Bookham, 110p higher at £10.70, Emap, down 11p at 774p and P&O Princess, up 0.5p at 252.5p.

In the wider market, technology, media and telecom shares were on fire, with many notching double-digit percentage gains thanks to a cocktail of good news.

First, there was news of progress in the battle for the White House - with a pair of court rulings pointing in favour of a victory for George W Bush. Then Nokia increased its revenue forecasts and in doing so sent Nasdaq wild. And to top things off, Fed chairman Alan Greenspan indicated the US economy had slowed from its breakneck pace, boosting hopes of a rate cut.

All of which helped the FTSE 100 index jump 140.3 points to 6,299 - its biggest one day points gain since July 3.

The FTSE Techmark 100 advanced 141.19 points to close at 2,717.97, with telecom companies in the lead.

Vodafone rose 6.5p to 256.5p, while BT was 31p higher at 657p, both benefiting from Nokia's comments.

Over the banking sector things were hotting up. Although the bid by Lloyds TSB (down 23p to 642p) for Abbey National (up 11p to £11.56) failed to materialise punters were not moaning after Lloyds' late revelation that it is interested in a possible "combination".

Bank of Scotland fell 5.5p to 690p on the news.

Standard Chartered eased 6p to 922p, after Cazenove - one of its brokers - was said to have reduced its earnings forecasts for next year on expectations of lower lending growth in Asia.

Barclays dipped 51p to £19.24 after a disappointing trading update.

webTitle: Radiant picks up the net access slack

fields.headline: Radiant picks up the net access slack
fields.standfirst:
Internet start-up hopes to bypass land-based broadband and take to the skies

Net news
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's shiny new economy received a blow last month when the government's much vaunted auction of licences to run wireless web services raised only a fraction of the anticipated proceeds and left most of the licences unsold.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's shiny new economy received a blow last month when the government's much vaunted auction of licences to run wireless web services raised only a fraction of the anticipated proceeds and left most of the licences unsold.

The failure means 40% of the population could be left with web access 20 times slower than the rest of the country. The auction of licences saw firms bidding for the right to beam internet signals to rooftop aerials and was seen as a way of breaking BT's stranglehold on high-speed internet access. But all may not be lost. Many small start-ups are experimenting with technology that may rescue ministers' ambitious plans.

Radiant Networks, a Cambridge-based start-up, has developed a novel way of connecting to the net at high speed over the airwaves. Rather than plugging into a phone socket, your computer is connected to a 50cm-tall cylinder containing a directional antenna that seeks another of its kind that is already online through which it can link you to the net.

Radiant claims its mesh-network system is up to 50 times more efficient than existing wireless broadband access methods and guarantees every subscriber a 4Mbit per second connection - enough bandwidth for always-on two-way video-telephony and all those other digital dreams.

"We thought it was such a simple idea and we tried for some time to prove that it didn't work," says Tim Jackson Radiant's founder. "But we couldn't find a fault and so, after a few weeks, we decided to accept it worked, and started a company to develop the technology instead."

That was back in 1997. Since then Radiant has moved quickly. In April it closed its third round of funding, raising £12m from UK-based Advent Venture Partners and the American venture capital firm Sandler Capital Management. Mr Jackson is looking to float at the start of 2002 and so far the company is well on track.

There are many who believe that "wireless broadband" will take off. Washington-based telecoms analysts, Strategis, estimate the wireless broadband access market will be worth $10bn by 2003. But sentiment towards the sector is volatile. The government's auction of wireless licences raised just £38.16m, compared with independent estimates of £1bn.

Unlike Radiant's technology, existing wireless broadband systems work in a similar way to mobile phone networks. Your antenna connects directly to a network base station. Unfortunately, because of the high frequencies involved in broadband, there has to be a clear line of sight between the two points. This means that in urban locations tall buildings and trees obscure the signal and many costly base-stations have to be installed to boost coverage.

Radiant says its system does not have this problem. It does away with base stations and instead bounces signals off neighbouring antennas to get around buildings and other obstructions. Your antenna need only be able to see another sibling antenna and you are connected.

However it is not without drawbacks. FirstMark, the German internet access provider, is field testing Radiant's systems in the next few months and says that there are disadvantages with its network.

"Mesh deployment only starts working well in a saturated market - the more customers the better and easier it is to make new installations," says Bill Best, FirstMark's chief technology officer.

"The drawback of Radiant's technology is that in its early days you may not have line of sight from a new customer to the existing network and therefore have to put in an extra node to connect them up. That's a sunk cost really because you wouldn't get any benefit from that extra node until more customers sign up. Rival conventional systems try to get over this problem by boosting the power signal at the base station," he said.

"With base stations that use high power from a high vantage point - say the top of a hill overlooking a city - you can cover a huge area all at once."

Radiant is not the only firm aiming to deliver broadband. Other wireless rivals have already got kit on the market. Tele2, a Reading-based company owned by Dutch telcom Millicom InternationalCellular, offers wireless broadband services - using existing technology - in Reading, Leeds, Bradford and Leicester. It is investing heavily to extend its coverage to 40 other areas over the next 18 months. In October it launched its 128Kbit per second residential wireless service at £9.99 a month - enough for fast internet access but not for digital video on demand.

"We expect to have 200,000 users within the next three years," says Elliott Mueller, chief executive of Tele2. "Our main focus will be SMEs [small and medium sized enterprises] who pay between £65 and £1,500 a month for dedicated services, depending on the bandwidth they require. But in future we hope to cover more residential customers too and provide them with enough bandwidth for video on demand."

Tele2 secured a licence on the 3.6GHz waveband earlier this year without having to participate in the government's fixed wireless broadband licence auction. "We only have to pay an annual subscription fee to the government to use the bandwidth," says Mr Mueller. Analysts say Tele2 pays hundreds of thousands of pounds a year in fees for the privilege.

Tim Johnson, an analyst at Ovum, is sceptical about Tele2's plans. "Most companies say 'we'll go for SMEs. SMEs need broadband'. The problem is every broadband provider is saying that and there are not enough SMEs to go around," he says. "I think that realisation was one of the reasons why the broadband wireless auction was so unexciting."

FirstMark has been snapping up broadband wireless licences across Europe - but was one of the companies that backed out of the UK's recent auction. It will begin field testing Radiant's systems in the next few months and is considering other wavebands on offer outside the auction.

Radiant estimates an antenna will cost around £1,000 and hopes the price will drop to £600 by 2003. "When its available in volume we'll be making a residential offer," says Mr Best. "Until then our main markets will be [small businesses]."

FirstMark has not priced its service yet, but Mr Best says he intends to be competitive with ADSL. "I think the price of wireless broadband will drop the same way mobile phone costs did over the last ten years," he says. "In the 1980s the Motorola 'brick' phone cost £1,000, now you can get one for free. For broadband wireless it's just a matter of time."

webTitle: Ebola kills doctor who led war on outbreak

fields.headline: Ebola kills doctor who led war on outbreak
fields.trailText: The Ugandan doctor who has been leading the battle against Ebola haemorrhagic fever died from the virus yesterday as the death toll rose to 156.
fields.body:
The Ugandan doctor who has been leading the battle against Ebola haemorrhagic fever died from the virus yesterday as the death toll rose to 156.

"Last night at 1.20am we lost one of our gallant sons of the country, who has been spearheading the fight against Ebola in Gulu - the late Dr Matthew Lukwiya," Alex Opio, the assistant commissioner for disease control, said.

Lukwiya, medical superintendent of St Mary's hospital in Lacor, northern Uganda, close to where the outbreak began in September, was the first to realise that a viral haemorrhagic fever might be to blame for a string of strange deaths in the area.

"He was the individual who brought it to the world's attention," said Ray Arthur, the World Health Organisation's Ebola coordinator in Gulu. "Possibly he got infected while caring for one of the staff members at the hospital."

The well-equipped hospital, three miles west of Gulu town, has dealt with most of the 370 suspected Ebola cases in the district, and in the past few weeks several of its nursing staff have died from the virus.

Mr Opio said tiredness might have been partly responsible for the deaths of Lukwiya and the 12 nurses who have died since the outbreak began.

Most victims die from shock after days of high fever, chest pains, vomiting and extensive internal bleeding. Doctors can do little except provide rehydration.

In the adjoining Masindi district there have been five Ebola deaths and nine more confirmed cases since last Friday, bringing the total number of cases there to 24. All but two belong to the same family.

Despite the steadily rising death toll, Mr Opio said the epidemic was still under control.

"If things were out of control, you would have seen a big explosion in the number of new cases," he added.

There is no cure yet for Ebola, although last week researchers in Paris reported successful vaccine tests on monkeys. Reuters

webTitle: TV and Radio: Random views

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What people at heavy metal gigs are watching
fields.trailText: What people at heavy metal gigs are watching
fields.body:
Dennis Leanman

"I'm not interested in watching TV much, but I do like Buffy a lot. Why? She's cute, she's smart, and the programme is really good. It's funny and it's very clever, it's done very well. No wonder people like it. If you give them good programmes then they watch them, if you give them shit, then they don't. It's like anything, really. Programme I hate? Well most of them - I don't like daytime TV, I think it's patronising. I never watch it at all. I hate... let me think, I really hate that Andi Peters one, Celebrity, that's it. Vacuous shit."

Martha Gray

"Oh gee, I'm American, so I guess you wouldn't have heard of any of the shows over there. Ur, you have the Simpsons? That's great. Really funny - well the first few thousand episodes are, unless you've seen them a lot, like I have. So I guess I don't find them that funny any more, hey. Do you have Futurama? That's not so good, is it? I suppose you have Friends. That's sick, all those nice looking women and men being funny. Heurgh."

Stewart Potter

"I like Star Trek Deep Space Nine and I like Buffy and TFI Friday. Why? They have some good bands on, I think. Oh, and I saw Slash on CD UK and I thought he was a genius. They pulled him off air for talking about sex! Great. I don't really like TV, I prefer to listen to music anyway."

Hi Manson

"What are you talking about?? TV?? Oh, I think TV sucks. [Walks off.]"

Nicky Fijalkowska

"Gosh, I don't know. I really don't know. Let me think now. I like Robot Wars and the last thing I watched was... probably The Weakest Link. I love Anne Robinson, I think she's very cruel and I like that. She's my hero. Honestly."

 Sian Pattenden spoke to people at the Slash's Snakepit gig, Underworld, London.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Misfits | Bound | Midnight In The Garden Of Good And Evil | The Big Knife
fields.body:
The Misfits

(John Huston, 1961)

6pm, FilmFour

As the last film of Marilyn Monroe and Clark Gable, this is a slice of raw Hollywood history. Monroe's then husband Arthur Miller provided his only film script, a wordy affair about broken-down rodeo stars gathering in Reno for the big show. Gable died of a heart attack soon after; Monroe, playing a sad showgirl, lived on only a couple of years. Montgomery Clift's disillusioned rider reinforces the sense of the finality.

Bound

(Larry Wachowski, Andy Wachowski, 1996)

10pm, FilmFour

It's interesting to see what the Wachowski brothers were doing before The Matrix, even if it's pretty disappointing. The arresting pulp-plot has Jennifer Tilly and Gina Gershon in a lesbians-against-the-mob pairing, with Joe Pantoliano a laughably nasty boss. With a little more humour and a little less heavy contrivance it might have made a great cult movie, but instead it's like a tacky Thelma And Louise.

Midnight In The Garden Of Good And Evil

(Clint Eastwood, 1997)

1.25am, Sky Premier

At a grand Christmas party in Savannah, Georgia, the host (Kevin Spacey) shoots dead his lover (Jude Law): in the ensuing investigation, visiting journalist John Cusack is left gawping at the bizarre reality beneath the town's genteel veneer. Eastwood's version of John Berendt's book about the murder is full of vivid characters, from Irma P Hall's voodoo woman to the vibrant transvestite, Lady Chablis; and though the drama gets lost in a baroque swirl, it's a fascinating portrait of time and place.

The Big Knife

(Robert Aldrich, 1955)

11pm, Carlton Cinema

Adapted from a play by Clifford "Sweet Smell Of Success" Odets, this is about as anti- Hollywood as you can make a film without being booted out of Hollywood for good. Jack Palance is tormented as a star actor, who realises the extent of his slavery when he tries to break free from the shackles of director-from-hell Rod Steiger. webTitle: Intelligentsia revolts as Putin brings back Soviet anthem

fields.headline: Intelligentsia revolts as Putin brings back Soviet anthem
fields.trailText: A group of influential Russian film-makers, writers and musicians expressed their disgust yesterday at President Vladimir Putin's decision to resurrect the national anthem of the Soviet Union.
fields.body:
A group of influential Russian film-makers, writers and musicians expressed their disgust yesterday at President Vladimir Putin's decision to resurrect the national anthem of the Soviet Union.

An open letter published in the daily newspaper Izvestiya marked the latest controversy in a prolonged search for appropriate symbols to represent post-communist Russia.

This week the Duma is expected to approve a bizarre mixture of soviet and tsarist emblems as the official iconography of new Russia, including the old anthem, (with new, as yet undecided verses), the tsarist two-headed eagle as the state coat of arms, and the pre-revolutionary tricolor as the national flag.

Designed as a compromise package to ensure a sense of continuity with all the conflicting strands of Russia's past, this solution was championed by Mr Putin. But its announcement prompted the outrage of members of the liberal intelligentsia, who said it caused "revulsion".

Alexander Alexandrov's stirring anthem was written in 1943, when much of European Russia was under German occupation, and the Soviet dicta tor Joseph Stalin gave it his personal approval. As statues of Lenin toppled with the collapse of communism in 1991, it was abandoned by former president Boris Yeltsin and the hunt began for a replacement.

Music by the 19th-century composer Mikhail Glinka was taken up, but politicians could not agree on suitable words and most people said the score was not sufficiently rousing.

Yesterday's open letter stressed that reviving Alexandrov's music would be wounding to the memory of the victims of soviet political repression. Even stripped of the original text, the tune alone was too redolent of Russia's painful Bolshevik past. "No new lyrics will ever be able to erase the words attached to it that for ever glorify Lenin and Stalin.

"Because we have a memory, we are convinced that it will not be possible to join seamlessly the history of Russia to the history of the Soviet Union without. The seams are there and they still drip blood."

The head of the Russian orthodox church, Patriarch Alexei, gave unexpected support to this former hymn of atheism, which he said represented "continuity with the soviet era, which of course was a terrible tragedy, but during which there was also a lot of good".

In a separate development, relations between Russia and its neighbour Georgia became further strained yesterday when the Kremlin imposed visa restrictions on travel between the two countries.

Russia said the measure was introduced as a result of Georgia's continuing lax control on the passage of rebel fighters across its mountainous border with the separatist republic of Chechnya.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Last night's TV

fields.headline: A fake's progress
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: ID | Who Killed Mark Faulkner? | Cutting Edge: Moving On Up
fields.body:
It was, you have to admit, an easy mistake to make. With his expansive forehead, beady little eyes and spout of a mouth - which work together to bless him with the countenance of a nervous Toby jug - it is quite understandable that you might have assumed Keith Andrews was indeed a member of the aristocracy. With his title, the Marquis of St Leger, sounding enough like it could be the name of a pub to make it seem authentic, even some posh folks thought him one of their own and clasped him to their hefty, mothball-smelling bosom.

Only Keith wasn't landed or gentry at all. He was a social worker who lived on a Swindon housing estate with his mother and was one of the impostors revealed in the rather intriguing ID (Channel 5).

Others discussed in the programme used devious means to achieve dishonest ends when they traded identities and denied their selves. One Lee Simm claimed to the police that Carl Hackett had died in the Ladbroke Grove rail disaster only to be unmasked as Carl himself attempting to kill off his original identity and start a new life, while sneaky Stuart Ashley tried to claim two lots of compensation for the same tragedy. Andrews, though, just seemed a little sad, inadequate and in need of a bit of excitement in his life. And if you lived on a Swindon housing estate, you would too. (The Melinda Messenger or Billie routes out of the town simply weren't available to the poor man).

Often verging on the superficial, the analysis on ID was interesting, if not enlightening. Imposters want to be heroes, said the talking head in residence, though his point was an over statement in the case of Andrews. All he seemed to want was not to be a nobody, to be anyone but himself.

It would seem Mark Faulkner wasn't comfortable in his own skin either. The riveting and tragic Who Killed Mark Faulkner? (BBC2) charted his descent from a troubled youth sleeping rough with only his demons for company, to a cold cadaver on a mortuary slab.

Fragments of an interview with Faulkner showed him to be articulate, smart and witty but perhaps too naïve and timid for a cruel city like London. If Hell is a city much like London, populous and smoky, Faulkner was ill-equipped for tackling its monsters. Not only was he severely epileptic, he was also emotionally handicapped, unsure of his own sexuality and prey to other people's whims because of it. This is the kind of programme you'd like Baroness Young and her rabid cronies to watch so they can understand the real cost of their bitter prejudice.

The impassioned documentary, fronted by friends of Faulkner, asked how a young disabled man can die on the streets of one of the world's richest cities. The answer was depressing - just because. Who killed Mark Faulkner? We all did. He was so lonely, he didn't want to be with himself any more.

London, that great sea, whose ebb and flow/At once is deaf and loud, and on the shore/Vomits its wrecks and still howls on for more. (Shelley)

Cutting Edge: Moving On Up (Channel 4) supposedly represented that to which we all aspire, and that of which the Marquis of St Leger could only dream, a big house in the country.

With glorious aspects, flagpoles and lakes, when you buy a house in Surrey, you are buying a lifestyle. So said Tommy de Mallet Morgan, who might have formerly been a telesales executive from Harrogate. He was an über-estate agent in the area, guiding people with too much money and not enough sense around delightful and bijou properties, ranging from the extravagant to the obscene. One, a safari lodge-style affair in which Mr Atkinson and his houseboy Sam lived, was testament to the fact that money may well buy you a more comfortable misery or even happiness, but it cannot buy you taste.

In this land of riches and personal woodland, a new species of parasitical helper has sprung up - the house relocator. For those who are cash rich and time poor (though what these people actually did with their time other than look miserable is anyone's guess), house relocators helped them find new abodes in which to moan, wail and gnash their horsey teeth. As the other half traipsed through their mausoleum-like residences, it was hard not to get angry thinking of Mark Faulkner dying a death in Charing Cross Station.

webTitle: Berlusconi strives for the last laugh

fields.headline: Berlusconi strives for the last laugh
fields.standfirst: Italian tycoon subverts poll parodies into endorsements
fields.trailText: Italian tycoon subverts poll parodies into endorsements
fields.body:
The Italian election campaign has turned into a surreal battle to see which side can laugh loudest at a political parody which is gripping the country.

The opposition leader Silvio Berlusconi has launched a competition to find the best poster from dozens that ridicule his baldness as well as his policies and ambition. By urging supporters to laugh at them he hopes to neutralise a potent threat to his centre-right coalition.

Samples of the posters have been posted on his party's website, www.forza-italia.it on the grounds that they confirm the success of its campaign.

Denouncing the stunt as an outrageous hijack, supporters of the centre-left government vowed to devise more parodies.

In the past two months Mr Berlusconi, 64, has flooded Italy with pictures of his smiling face next to slogans promising a brighter future if, as polls suggest, he wins the elections due in spring. Each week he has unveiled a new "concrete promise" - "less tax for all", "safer cities", "a good job also for you".

But the suspicion that the photograph of the media magnate was taken 10 years ago, when he had more hair and fewer wrinkles, prompted a wave of puns.

"A concrete promise: more hair for all," was followed swiftly by other posters promising toys, cannabis and sex.

Caricatures of Mr Berlusconi in costume have become hugely popular. As a Star Trek Klingon he promises a teletransporter, as a shaman he promises to find the yeti, as an astronaut he promises a lunar colony, as a cardinal he promises to become Pope, and as Darth Vader he promises to conquer Saturn.

Newspapers and television stations not owned by Mr Berlusconi have gleefully paraded the exposure of what critics call his overweening ambition.

A depiction of the former prime minister with a pencil moustache and Sicilian cap, promising "a good contract for all", reminded voters of the corruption allegations he faced.

Chuckling at a press conference last month, Mr Berlusconi praised the parodies. Now that their popularity has ballooned, he has claimed them as endorsements.

The Forza Italia party website said yesterday: "As promised by Silvio Berlusconi, we are drawing up the rules of the competition for the best mock posters."

"We are proposing a selection of 'classics', which started this nice counter-campaign and established the success of our real campaign. Have fun."

webTitle: Tv and Radio: Programmes on gambling

fields.headline: Racing demon
fields.standfirst: Gambling is a gripping activity - if it's your cash at stake. But it's never really made for great television. Channel 4's The Gambler is hoping to change all that, although Giles Foden thinks it could be the start of a sinister trend
fields.trailText: Gambling is a gripping activity - if it's your cash at stake. But it's never really made for great television. Channel 4's The Gambler is hoping to change all that, although Giles Foden thinks it could be the start of a sinister trend.
fields.body:
Does gambling make good television? Channel 4's celebrity poker, even with the help of Stephen Fry, Martin Amis and Patrick Marber, didn't quite deliver the visual goods. That was because it's only a human story that can make gambling interesting, and the whole point of poker - thus the phrase poker-faced - is that there ought to be no human story.

In this sense a new Channel 4 series, The Gambler, has much more going for it. The channel gave author Jonathan Rendall £12,000 to see if he could turn it into a profit.

Sound familiar? It ought to, because a few years back Rendall pulled the same trick with his publisher, to produce a book called... Twelve Grand. On that occasion he spent a good bit of it on ordinary living, and the book turned out a funny, strangely moving novelisation of the chancer's life.

And now the chancer has another chance. Is he a fool not just to pocket the money, and say byee to the commissioning editor? Any bookie - whether one sitting behind a counter in the traditional, smoke-filled box, or one operating the brave new whirligigs of online gaming - would be likely to think so.

"My bookmaker's instinct tells me he will lose", says William Hill's Graham Sharpe - against whom, at odds of 9-2, Rendall has backed himself to triumph.

"He's an exceedingly optimistic gambler. A mug punter believes that every bet will win; in that sense, Jonathan will fit the bill."

And so at first it seems, as he pours coins into, but not out of, slot machines in Great Yarmouth. Then it's off to the Cheltenham Gold Cup, where, chain-smoking, he watches his horse stumble at the last fence and come in second. There goes £1,000.

Rendall reacts pretty badly to this (there is a touch of cruel voyeurism for the viewer here). "My legs are fucking shaking," he tells us. "That has totally done me. It's a bloody lonely place when you lose. I need a drink."

It's not the first time he's been down on his luck. In a previous book, This Bloody Mary Is The Last Thing I Own, he told of how, hanging around the fringes of boxing, he suddenly found himself manager of a welterweight champion. Things were looking good, he was on a nice percentage. But then his fighter dislocated his shoulder and it was all over.

This programme and its successors (which take him to Australia, Macau and, inevitably, Vegas) are a nice way to while away the fag-end of a Wednesday evening. You too can enjoy, with little risk to yourself, Rendall's flirtations with the aleatory and the downright fixed.

All the systems, you might readily reckon, are irrational at base. But when Rendall says that the point of his gambling is "a way of avoiding his real responsibilities while sustaining, if only for a while, the possibility that you are going to be fabulously wealthy", he begins to make perfect sense. As great a thinker as Walter Benjamin thought much the same: that gambling is a refusal to accept the normal passage of time, that its appeal is the collapse of ordinarily administered life into a few dreamy moments of anticipatory escape.

But it remains true that gamblers are set up to fail - by men like Graham Sharpe and, often (though they may not realise it), by the players too. In the final series, Rendall himself talks of the pleasure of the losing bender - until a 40-1 one shot coming off on an American dirt track puts paid to the bitter pleasure of his serial defeats.

Coming off? It means winning, you mug, and has nothing to do with sex. Or does it? Benjamin also talked of gambling as being like never quite bringing a woman to orgasm. Presumably this is because the gambler's index of success might as well stretch out to infinity (otherwise known as Camelot) and still demand satisfaction.

The way Rendall twists and grimaces during the resolution of his bets you'd think he was actually the one being brought off. In the end though, come what may, there is still the matter of whether he will end in profit or not. He decides to plump for "the only thing I've ever consistently won at". That's to say, boxing: he puts a bet on a fighter called Mosely, his last chance to go home up on the original twelve grand.

Whether he does or doesn't viewers will have to wait two weeks to discover. By that time they will presumably have made up their own minds about whether gambling makes good television.

Puritans will still argue that gambling is (in one way anyway) a cheap form of suspense, and watching it on television an even cheaper one. But when interactive, digital, account-linked TV really takes off, when armchair punters are able to send their hard-earned down the Swanee with the press of a few buttons on the remote as they watch the onscreen event, well then it might get a bit more expensive. And a lot more dangerous.

 The Gambler, tonight, 10.35pm, Channel 4

webTitle: G2: A country diary

fields.headline: A country diary
fields.standfirst: Wenlock Edge
fields.trailText: Wenlock Edge
fields.body:
The soil is sodden, the paths are muddy and the lack of light disorientating. Slogging up the wet fields I become aware of a new sound - a sort of creaking, murmuring. This is the sound of water trickling down the field, through the gooey clay and roots of grass, grazed short by sheep. The sheep have been moved off and the field is empty.

Only a couple of owls call dispassionately from hanging woods above the field. The evening is surprisingly warm and the rain has stopped. The moon is rising and seems to be caught in the upper branches of trees high above in the woods. At the top of the field I pause at a stile and feel suspended above the lights of a cluster of houses in the hamlet below. I take another, equally slippy, route back down the field and suddenly come across a large unfamiliar form in the growing darkness, which turns out to be a tangle of branches. A huge limb has broken away from an old oak.

As I take this in, another sense takes me over completely - smell. The leaves and broken wood give off the powerful aroma of oak: a dark, peaty, beer-like tannin scent which increases in potency as I breathe it in. As the smell intensifies it becomes sweeter, until it is more like the fragrance of summer roses. It evokes strings of memory which weave into an experience beyond itself, into something new.

There are so few words to describe smells; we have an olfactory memory which is an associative thing and we only seem to be able to describe it by saying it is like something else. This smell has become unlike anything else and although it conjures up experience it is also creating it. Night sets in.
fields.bodyText: The soil is sodden, the paths are muddy and the lack of light disorientating. Slogging up the wet fields I become aware of a new sound - a sort of creaking, murmuring. This is the sound of water trickling down the field, through the gooey clay and roots of grass, grazed short by sheep. The sheep have been moved off and the field is empty. Only a couple of owls call dispassionately from hanging woods above the field. The evening is surprisingly warm and the rain has stopped. The moon is rising and seems to be caught in the upper branches of trees high above in the woods. At the top of the field I pause at a stile and feel suspended above the lights of a cluster of houses in the hamlet below. I take another, equally slippy, route back down the field and suddenly come across a large unfamiliar form in the growing darkness, which turns out to be a tangle of branches. A huge limb has broken away from an old oak. As I take this in, another sense takes me over completely - smell. The leaves and broken wood give off the powerful aroma of oak: a dark, peaty, beer-like tannin scent which increases in potency as I breathe it in. As the smell intensifies it becomes sweeter, until it is more like the fragrance of summer roses. It evokes strings of memory which weave into an experience beyond itself, into something new. webTitle: TV and Radio: Court circular

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.body:
Something of a treat this week for anyone who savours the undignified spectacle of a pair of irate septuagenarians slugging it out with the lawyers, as legendary rock'n'roll pianist Johnnie Johnson - the Johnnie, to be exact, referred to in Johnnie B Goode - filed suit against that song's author and his venerable ex-frontman, Chuck Berry).

In the action, filed last week in East Missouri District Court, Johnson alleges he co-wrote (and is therefore entitled to royalties for) a sizeable swathe of Berry's back catalogue, including Roll Over Beethoven and No Particular Place To Go, and that the duck-walking guitarist "took advantage" of his alcoholism to convince him to relinquish co-authorship. Faced with a claim for "all profits realised" from the songs in question, Berry's camp remained tight-lipped, with his agent Dick Allen observing that his famously foul-mouthed and bad-tempered client was simply "disappointed".

On a rather more sprightly note, meanwhile, pouting boy band N'Sync have found themselves on the business end of a copyright infringement suit from puppet makers Sid and Marty Krofft, the men behind such US children's favourites as The Bugaloos and HR Pufnstuf.

In a move which has provoked predictable hilarity in the American media, the Kroffts took their action after making a series of 25-foot mannequins of the group to gyrate behind the genuine article at the recent American Music Awards: a scene later immortalised on the band's tour programmes without the puppet-masters' permission, despite being told they were "in" on any future merchandising involving their handiwork.

Now seeking a retrospective 10 per cent of proceeds from programme sales, the Kroffts' lawyer Bruce Isaacs told reporters that "we bent over backwards to keep this out of the papers", before breaking down in tears after failing to properly enunciate the phrase "bottle of beer".

webTitle: TV and Radio: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Soaps On The Couch | Parliamentary Questions
fields.body:
It's claimed that a quarter of the British population watches EastEnders and Coronation Street and that another two million tune in regularly to The Archers. In Soaps On The Couch (11.0am, Radio 4) Tina Baker tries to analyse this addiction. She talks, among others, to academics who have built an entire discipline around the phenomenon. Apparently it affects much of the globe, regardless of class or nationality.

Steve Richards's political quiz Parliamentary Questions (1.30pm, Radio 4) kicks off its season with the Labour Party's erstwhile dream team, Neil Kinnock (pictured) and Roy Hattersley, reassembled to compete against Sir Patrick Cormack and Anthony Howard. If the programme's subliminal aim is to persuade voters that politicians care for them it had better start gingering up some of its panellists. In this round neither Kinnock nor Hattersley can remember the title they gave the 1983 manifesto they expected the electorate to back.

webTitle: G2: Profile of Ahmad Shah Masood

fields.headline: Angel of the north
fields.standfirst: Ahmad Shah Masood is adored by the people of northern Afghanistan. Why? He is the only  military leader still holding out against the Taliban. Rory McCarthy meets up with the 'Lion of Panjsher'.
fields.trailText: Ahmad Shah Masood is adored by the people of northern Afghanistan. Why? He is the only military leader still holding out against the Taliban. Rory McCarthy meets up with the 'Lion of Panjsher'.
fields.body:
High on a dusty hilltop close to the ruins of an ancient Greek city, Afghanistan's toughest military commander sits on a red carpet sipping tea and sucking on a boiled sweet. Ahmad Shah Masood is the last man holding out against the hardline Taliban militia and his war is not going well. He peers though his binoculars at the enemy positions on the distant hills, draws a quick diagram in the dust for the other commanders and then angrily barks new orders over the radio in Persian.

Across the Kokcha river just below this hill, Masood faces the artillery positions of the Taliban, the Islamic students who chased him out of the capital, Kabul, four years ago. A stone's throw to his right is the border with Tajikistan, a key military supply route through which his allies Russia, Iran and India send equipment and support. Behind him lies Badakshan, the mountainous province he cannot afford to lose and the last in Afghanistan under his complete control.

For the past four months the Taliban have fought harder than ever to push back Masood's forces and draw a noose around his military base and family home in the Panjsher valley, in central Afghanistan. "If they win Badakshan, they win the war," the gaunt 47-year-old says in halting French. "The Taliban think they can take Badakshan and encircle the Panjsher. But in the end they will never succeed in Afghanistan."

To his men Masood is revered as the Lion of the Panjsher. Well-educated, a devout Muslim and a brilliant military tactician, he defended the Panjsher Valley against the invading Soviet army through 10 years of war. His face and his trademark brown wool cap are still plastered on teahouse walls across northern Afghanistan.

After the Soviets retreated, the mojahedin commanders fought between themselves and in 1992 Masood's forces won control of Kabul. But four years later, when the Taliban swept through southern Afghanistan and into Kabul, Masood fled to the Panjsher and returned to his guerrilla war. Today he holds less than 10% of the country.

Yet the people of the north still adore him. His intellect and his charm seem oddly out of place in a nation destroyed by two decades of fighting and so different from the poorly educated, doctrinaire and misogynistic Taliban. "I used to read Che Guevara and Mao Tse-tung. I learned from Mao, but not Che. He was too simple. Victor Hugo is still the writer I prefer. But now there is little time to read."

Masood has never been in a more dangerous position. In early September, after days of heavy jet and artillery bombardments, the Taliban seized the strategic town of Taloqan, the ousted government's administrative headquarters. Masood's forces fled.

As the Taliban advanced they imposed their strict brand of Islam, beating men who trim their beards and interrupting football matches to make the crowds pray. Women are banned from working and rarely allowed to leave their homes. Men were encouraged to black out their windows so their wives and daughters could not be seen from outside the home.

More than 80,000 people fled the area around Taloqan as the fighting grew closer. Packing their few belongings onto their donkeys they walked east in search of shelter. Most now face a bitterly cold winter in Badakshan, living under plastic sheeting praying for food handouts from aid agencies. They came with harrowing accounts of the brutality of Taliban occupation: houses burned and looted, civilians killed and young men and women abducted.

"I saw Taliban soldiers knock on the door of the house next to ours during the night and they took a young girl. She was 25 and her name was Bekea," says Farzana, a 27-year-old woman who fled with her children to Faizabad, the largest town still under opposition control. "The Taliban said one of them would marry her. Now we don't know if she is alive or dead."

The fall of Taloqan was a bitter blow for Masood, cutting a major supply route linking Tajikistan and the Panjsher. Nearly 350 of his fighters, the mojahedin or "holy warriors", were killed in the battle and 500 injured. "We had some problems with logistics and transport. We can't fight in every part of Afghanistan at the same time," he says.

He claimed the Taliban suffered 2,000 killed and injured. Analysts have put the Taliban's death toll at 1,500 in the fighting this summer.

Masood has been awake since before dawn, kneeling in prayer in the cold autumn morning outside the shabby, four-roomed house which has become his base, an hour's drive from the frontline. After praying he paces alone in the rose garden watching the sun rise before breakfast and the first of his meetings with his commanders and military allies. Over a meal of tea, a slice of Afghan bread and cheese, he plans the day's attack.

By the afternoon Masood is back at the front, stopping his tank drivers to give them final instructions before his artillery and multi-barrel rocket launchers open up on the Taliban positions. His khaki trousers tucked into polished, black boots, Masood watches through binoculars as three mojahedin tanks climb the distant hill towards the Taliban posts. He breaks from the fighting just once, to lead his men in prayer before sunset when they kneel facing west to their enemy and to Mecca beyond.

"This is just the beginning," he says. "Our first target is to take back Taloqan, God willing, before the winter. But these days the Taliban are advancing more cautiously and now they have Pakistani backing and tanks." Pakistan's military government is the Taliban's biggest ally and one of only three countries to recognise the regime, but Islamabad has always denied its troops are fighting in Afghanistan.

Masood has said he is ready for negotiations with the Taliban and tentative talks have begun, but few observers expect the Islamic militia to give up their dominant military position. "There will be resistance inside Afghanistan and we need pressure from the outside on Pakistan," he says. "Even if the fighting is finished, the Taliban movement cannot continue, they cannot stay united." There is a note of resignation in his voice. Afghanistan's last mojahedin commander knows he must win back Taloqan before the winter, or face a final defeat.

webTitle: South Africans killed near polling station

fields.headline: South Africans killed near polling station
fields.trailText: Shooting near a polling station killed five men and a woman yesterday during the municipal elections in South Africa.
fields.body:
Shooting near a polling station killed five men and a woman yesterday during the municipal elections in South Africa.

Five suspects were arrested in Katlehong, a poor township near Johannesburg, but the police said they did not know whether the shooting was election related. The opposition United Democratic Movement said three of its members were killed.

A voter was killed in Somkele, 120 miles north of Durban, but officials said it was unlikely to be election related. Despite the deaths, election officials said the poll was orderly and relatively free of violence .

The African National Congress is expected to win most of the reduced number of councils and six metropolitan authorities covering big cities and their townships, but it is being strongly challenged by the Democratic Alliance in some areas.

webTitle: Arts: The Christmas theatre circuit

fields.headline: A quick one
fields.trailText: One sign that Christmas is coming is that somewhere very far away and very hot Mike Atherton is grinding out a draw in a Test match. Another is the sudden proliferation of well-dressed drunks weaving around the streets.
fields.body:
One sign that Christmas is coming is that somewhere very far away and very hot Mike Atherton is grinding out a draw in a Test match. Another is the sudden proliferation of well-dressed drunks weaving around the streets. The Christmas office party serves up its winter bacchanal.

For the comedian, the Christmas firm do provides extra cash and very tough gigs. You are liable to have to follow the company panto, written by the marketing manager, whose secret ambition is to get a sketch on The News Huddlines. Although it is very, very bad, it is hugely successful because everyone loves to see their co-workers make arses of themselves.

The comic is greeted with indifference - the real business being to get drunk, settle scores and choose a candidate for the traditional embrace in the photocopying room. There must, by law, be an "incident" to sustain office gossip through the long, pointless months of January and February.

A few years ago I was on stage at such an event. The audience was irredeemably pissed - too pissed to understand my most Neanderthal joke. I tried the classic one-liner - "Arsenal are shit" - but even this was too sophisticated. I resorted to getting one of the sottish hecklers on stage, where he announced exuberantly, "I'm so arseholed!" Not much of an insight but it was met with clapping and cheering. He seemed to run out of material, so I asked him how long he'd worked for the company. "Too fucking long!" More cheering. "What do you think of the managing director?" I asked. "He's a cunt!" This caused a tumult of laughter and applause.

As I left, he was sitting on the stairs, head in hands. He had been fired by the MD in question, a man clearly determined to confirm his by now public sobriquet. I was inadvertently responsible, so I mumbled an apology. But his hangover was arriving along with the realisation he no longer had a job, and he didn't register me.

Back in the party I could hear a very loud, very raucous rendition of Silent Night. Drive carefully this Christmas, folks.

webTitle: Arts: Lyn Gardner on Christmas pantomimes

fields.headline: Do you believe in fairies?
fields.standfirst: The children's play season is upon us. Lyn Gardner despairs
fields.trailText: The children's play season is upon us. Lyn Gardner despairs.
fields.body:
If you are looking for a family alternative to panto this Christmas, you could be forgiven for thinking no one still writes plays in Britain. They do, of course, but few seem to do it for young people. What is mainly on offer is adaptations or musical versions of children's novels, usually harking back to the Victorian or Edwardian era.

The enduring popularity of these books is not in doubt. We relive our own childhoods by encouraging our children to read what we once read, feel what we once felt. It is what makes the adaptations good box office. But the translation from page to stage rarely rises above the literal, and creates the impression that theatre has nothing to do with the reality of modern lives and everything to do with nostalgia and Victorian sentimentality.

It is worth remembering that while the Victorians invented childhood and children's literature, they were reserved only for the privileged classes. Lower-class children were too busy working to learn to read, let alone linger over Alice's Adventures in Wonderland. This blue-velvet-dress culture extends to modern-day theatre. I have never seen quite so many Alice bands in one place as on a trip to see The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe at the Barbican a couple of years back.

What is curious about the shows that usually pop up at this time of year, such as Alice, The Secret Garden and The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe, is that parents and theatre managements see them as central to our culture. There is a feeling that these texts are classic and beyond reproach. Yet we are experiencing our own golden age of children's literature, with novelists such as Melvin Burgess, David Almond, Philip Pullman and Jacqueline Wilson engaging with the realities of modern childhood.

It seems odd that theatre should hark back to a body of work, a lot of it more than 100 years old, written by authors who in many cases were at best unhappy or socially inadequate, at worst possibly paedophiles. As Tony Graham of London's Unicorn Theatre points out: "Writers such as David Almond are creating work where the metaphors are as big as anything in The Secret Garden."

One reason for our constant return to a theatre of Victorian values is economic. Sweden has a thriving children's theatre because it spends around a quarter of its entire budget for the arts on children's arts. Our Arts Council doesn't have a department dedicated to children. When theatre for children has so little status, no one wants to do it.

These adaptations also have a strong psychological appeal for worried parents. We no longer let our children play alone in the park, yet in the safety of the theatre we are happy to send them into someone else's garden or enchanted wardrobe. We would, of course, be horrified if our children really did run away with the pirates (Treasure Island) or fly off to Never Never Land. We'd be ringing 999 before you could say, "I believe in fairies".

But Philip Ridley, who writes plays for adults as well as younger audiences, believes that these stage adaptations can serve a useful purpose for children themselves and don't just have to be a backwards glance at a lost Arcadia.

"What the wardrobe and the garden symbolise is not necessarily a retreat but a way of connecting our children with their feelings. These landscapes are symbolic landscapes of feeling. We need them, perhaps more than we've ever needed them. We have a whole generation of children who are dislocated and alienated and laugh when someone gets hurt. They don't know how to feel," he says. Marsha Norman's musical version of The Secret Garden, now being staged by the Royal Shakespeare Company, has often been used in the US as part of a programme of grief counselling.

Tony Graham agrees that too often these adaptations are deadly dull but, like Ridley, believes the stories can be made relevant. "For many children today, childhood is being whittled away. There is even more reason to want to stay in the garden. That is not a nostalgic issue, but a contemporary one."

There is no reason that we shouldn't return to these texts, any more than we shouldn't return to Shakespeare. But Shakespeare is only part of a range of work in the adult theatre that also includes new writing, physical and visual theatre, musicals and performance.

"We do have to challenge traditional ideas about children's theatre," says Graham, "and we do have to find other ways of going through the looking glass. After all, what is the equivalent of the looking glass for today's children? The internet. We need to create theatre that reflects that."

Ridley believes that theatre must rise to the challenge. "We can have new plays that do all the old things and have as many big metaphors as those old, familiar stories do. We don't have to languish in a whimsical post-Victorian world."

The wardrobe door is ajar: we just have to push it open and escape.

But Philip Ridley, who writes plays for adults as well as younger audiences, believes that these stage adaptations can serve a useful purpose for children themselves and don't just have to be a backwards glance at a lost Arcadia. "What the wardrobe and the garden symbolise is not necessarily a retreat but a way of connecting our children with their feelings. These landscapes are symbolic landscapes of feeling. We need them, perhaps more than we've ever needed them. We have a whole generation of children who are dislocated and alienated and laugh when someone gets hurt. They don't know how to feel," he says. Marsha Norman's musical version of The Secret Garden, now being staged by the Royal Shakespeare Company, has often been used in the US as part of a programme of grief counselling. Tony Graham agrees that too often these adaptations are deadly dull but, like Ridley, believes the stories can be made relevant. "For many children today, childhood is being whittled away. There is even more reason to want to stay in the garden. That is not a nostalgic issue, but a contemporary one." There is no reason that we shouldn't return to these texts, any more than we shouldn't return to Shakespeare. But Shakespeare is only part of a range of work in the adult theatre that also includes new writing, physical and visual theatre, musicals and performance. "We do have to challenge traditional ideas about children's theatre," says Graham, "and we do have to find other ways of going through the looking glass. After all, what is the equivalent of the looking glass for today's children? The internet. We need to create theatre that reflects that." Ridley believes that theatre must rise to the challenge. "We can have new plays that do all the old things and have as many big metaphors as those old, familiar stories do. We don't have to languish in a whimsical post-Victorian world." The wardrobe door is ajar: we just have to push it open and escape.

webTitle: Arts: Why people want to be famous?

fields.headline: Look at me
fields.standfirst: What makes people long to be famous? Shelagh Stephenson, author of a new play on celebrity, thinks they just want to live for ever
fields.trailText: What makes people long to be famous? Shelagh Stephenson, author of a new play on celebrity, thinks they just want to live for ever.
fields.body:
Four years ago, when Jenny Topper commissioned me to write a play for Hampstead Theatre, she asked what it might be about. "The celebrification of culture," I said gaily, off the top of my head, not entirely sure if such a word existed. (It doesn't, but it should.) Celebrity was big business then, and it's even bigger now. We're obsessed with it, apparently.

Newspapers and magazines are constantly telling us just how obsessed we are, ignoring the fact that the phenomenon is entirely a media creation. Articles purporting to explore the issue are full of celebrity snaps - mainly young women in minute dresses at film premieres or outside fashionable restaurants. Go for dinner at the Ivy and you have to wade through paparazzi to get in the door. What's going on? What does it all mean?

Being famous for trivial reasons is nothing new: a fashionable 18th-century woman might have achieved celebrity status because of a predilection for outrageous wigs, or, indeed, sleeping with this or that society figure. But her fame was local and contained. Then, if you appeared regularly at the theatre with your wig done up like a galleon, all London might know your name. Now, thanks to the media, the entire world could know not only your name, but where you buy your underwear. (The more famous you are, the more such minutiae is deemed to be of legitimate interest.) Presumably, the desire for attention existed then, as it does now, but now, if that's what you crave, you can have so much more of it.

Perhaps the feeling of being visible and known somehow heightens your sense of your own reality - "I'm here, I exist, I'm real." Conversely, does invisibility make you somehow less than real? In a culture snowed under with images, both live and virtual, being looked at would seem to be a validation in itself. When we think of celebrities, we see them as somehow more real than the rest of us and, at the same time, less so.

More real, because of the heightened nature of their reality - huge cinema images, constant media portrayals. Less real because the nature of celebrity blurs the distinction between public and private. It's easy to assume that all aspects of a celebrity life are there purely to be picked over because he or she is on show, which means he or she doesn't have the same reality as everyone else.

Look at Princess Diana. By conferring iconic status on her, we coincidentally removed some of her humanity, and consequently thought it reasonable to rummage through her private life with impunity because, actually, she wasn't real.

Given this ghastly invasion of one's life, why is celebrity status so desirable? Ask an average bunch of 10-year-olds what they want to do with their lives, and a large proportion of them will tell you they'd like to "be famous". Not for anything in particular. Just famous, period. In the adult population, otherwise perfectly normal people think nothing of spilling the beans about their personal tragedies on daytime television. As if somehow your tragedy hasn't really happened until it is witnessed and dissected by the viewing public.

Fame allows you to transcend the time you live in. Perhaps this is what we are seeking in our hunger for celebrity: nothing less than immortality. In an irreligious age, we've lost the notion of an afterlife. We no longer believe our lives have any meaning outside ourselves and the quotidian stumble from birth to grave. Celebrity status gives the illusion that you will survive beyond this precise moment.

But which "you" is that? The problem with being caught up in the attention of others is that the viewer is the one who decides who you are and what you mean. In fact, you will mean whatever the viewer wants you to mean. Which is probably not what you meant at all. In seeking to be a personality, the celebrity concedes her essential personality in favour of an ersatz one, invented and invested in by strangers.

I'm describing a world of which we're all part. Most of us, thank god, aren't "celebrities". But we're all caught up in the roaring cult of personality which threatens all notions of meaning and proportion in our dealings with the world. We can't avoid it unless we banish our television sets, never go to the cinema, and refuse forthwith to ever open a newspaper. Everything - art, literature, politics - is sold to us via the spurious conduit of "personality".

It's no longer just the book that counts, it's the person who wrote it, and whether or not they have marketable attributes such as youth or beauty (preferably both). This seems to me to be damaging not just for the consumer of art or politics, but for the person whose personality is being plundered for such marketing purposes. The self is a fragile and complex thing. A person is not a marketing tool. The fact that most of us are seduced, one way or another, by the glitter of celebrity, doesn't make it less disturbing.

I leave you with some words by William Faulkner: "It is my ambition, as a private individual, to be abolished and voided from history, leaving it markless, no refuse save the printed words. I wish I'd had enough sense to see that 30 years ago and not signed them." Can you imagine anyone saying that now?

 Shelagh Stephenson's play, Ancient Lights, is at the Hampstead Theatre, London NW3 until January 6. Box office: 020-7722 9301.
