webTitle: Moribund Venice joins the league of dockland cities

fields.headline: Moribund Venice joins the league of dockland cities
fields.trailText: Venice has started demolishing dilapidated canalside buildings to make way for a concrete and glass campus modelled on London's Docklands and other famous urban waterfronts.
fields.body:
Venice has started demolishing dilapidated canalside buildings to make way for a concrete and glass campus modelled on London's Docklands and other famous urban waterfronts.

It aims to reverse centuries of population drain by attracting students to an ultra-modern site designed to offer a dramatic contrast to the surrounding Renaissance palaces. Some call it postmodern.

Such a bold step was thought necessary to prevent Venice becoming entirely populated by tourists.

This week dignitaries toasted the levelling of a former refrigeration warehouse. Cranes are about to start razing about half a mile of decaying customs houses, harbours and houses on both sides of the Giudecca canal, near the area known as Zattere.

The late Spanish architect Enrico Miralles Moya drew on the waterfronts of London, Sydney and Copenhagen to beat 500 entries in an international competition.

He described his plan as a way to invent and build in a city which adopted repetition as its way of growing. His "citadel" will house libraries, shops, cultural centres, auditoriums and lecture halls.

There will also be banks, bars and restaurants: the citadel will be open to all.

The urgency of attracting new blood overcame Venetian qualms about erecting a monumental incongruity.

Only 50,000 people live in the city now, but 10m visit each year, an invasion that has sent residents fleeing to the mainland.

"It is a sign of change in the traditional Venetian dialectic between doing and not doing," the mayor, Paolo Costa, said. "I hope that Venice can enrich the album of western architecture with contemporary pages such as this."

Zattere is where heavy goods were unloaded, but it is now a popular spot for strolls and picnics. The church of Santa Maria del Rosario, with ceiling frescoes by Tiepolo, is nearby.

A transparent corridor will run through the campus to a wide staircase sweeping down to the canal.

"We will soon see the return of a city teeming with life, with students, with tourists," commented La Repubblica newspaper.

"A challenge that will broaden the confines of Venice and create another fragment of beauty that has been hidden until now."

Yesterday Mr Costa unveiled the Venice Laboratory of Culture, an attempt to control the tourist influx which may worsen next year since there are many attractive events, including the reopening of the Malibran theatre after a 15-year restoration, and a new wing of the Guggenheim museum dedicated to the landscape artist Giovanni Segantini.

Thirty public and private institutions will join forces to run www.veneziacultura.it, a website intended to monitor and regulate prospective visits.

Mr Costa revived the question of squeezing money from tourists to fund building maintenance.

"We risk disappearing due to excess love," he said.

Last month hundreds of shopkeepers marched in St Mark's Square in protest at the authorities' failure to stop high tides flooding the city.

webTitle: Blair alerted on EU integration moves

fields.headline: Blair alerted on EU integration moves
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was given notice of a long term ambition to achieve closer EU integration last night with the disclosure of a German-Italian plan for another inter-governmental conference, similar to this week's in Nice, as early as 2004.
fields.byline: Michael White, Patrick Wintour  and Ian Black in Brussels
fields.body:
Tony Blair was given notice of a long term ambition to achieve closer EU integration last night with the disclosure of a German-Italian plan for another inter-governmental conference, similar to this week's in Nice, as early as 2004.

The proposal, disclosed in a joint paper sent to France, holder of the EU's rotating presidency, has no official status and may be part of a negotiating strategy to win concessions in France. But it runs counter to Labour's stance on IGCs with Mr Blair previously insisting that such a conference should not take place until after EU expansion had begun.

Plans for a so-called "post-Nice" agenda have emerged in the last few days as the most significant item on the summit agenda, with more integrationist-minded countries pushing for a commitment to further change in the coming years.

Germany and Italy are calling for discussion of the future status of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, simplification of existing EU treaties, a charter of competences defining the powers of the union and those of national governments, and possibly also changes to the European parliament.

From a British point of view, this is a highly toxic mixture of issues with a clear integrationist bent and as such is certain to be unwelcome to a government already highly conscious of Eurosceptic criticism.

Britain won the battle for the charter of rights not to be incorporated into the new treaty, agreeing that it be simply "proclaimed" at Nice. But the issue has not gone away. The only surprise is that it has come back so soon.

The new paper has appeared on the same day that Peter Mandelson, the fiercely pro-Europe Northern Ireland secretary, rejected the project of the EU's founding fathers, pronouncing the death of "ever closer European union" which they envisaged in the 1956 Treaty of Rome.

His remarks on the eve of this week's Nice summit strengthen a call by a pro-European thinktank urging Britain to campaign for the removal of the key clause in the preamble to the 1956 treaty which founded the original "common market". The call has been made by the Foreign Policy Centre, known to be close to Foreign Office thinking.

Speaking at an FPC meeting, Mr Mandelson said future historians would see the Nice summit as "a landmark in the reunification of Europe drawing a clear line on the turmoils and divisions of the past century".

His remarks came as Downing Street outlined Mr Blair's five aims for Nice and renewed its attack on the Eurosceptic British media for relentless criticism of the EU.

Mr Blair will seek an enlarged union to include former communist states to the east; more influence for Britain via extra votes in EU councils; a smaller and better EU bureaucracy; a more flexible EU with no "pioneer" group; and fewer national vetoes, but only where it is in the UK's interests.

The Tories attacked Labour's agenda, but insisted they "passionately" want to see enlargement too.

In remarks designed to outflank British Eurosceptics, Mr Mandelson predicted the Nice treaty would not be fundamental in content, but would have great significance in its effect by "opening the EU's door" to a dozen applicants.

He also claimed pro Europeans were now "amongst those who are least committed to the traditions of the EU's founding fathers".

He stressed it would be a "tremendous setback" for the whole of Europe, including the applicant countries to the east, if there was no agreement at Nice. An enlarged EU was a key strategic objective for Britain and absolutely vital to the future prosperity and security of the EU.

webTitle: Analysis: Attlee succeeded where Blair failed

fields.headline: Compare Blair with Attlee: one failed, one succeeded
fields.standfirst:
New Labour's line is that Attlee failed to win a second full term

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Apparently Gordon Brown thinks Labour has put behind it the "old-fashioned" redistributive philosophy it once embraced. Yesterday he offered "targeted tax cuts". Presumably redistributing wealth, like nationalising things, is considered part of the baggage which New Labour believes it has to jettison. The trouble, though, is that redistributing wealth, unlike nationalising things, is the real reason that Labour exists, and the real reason why people vote for it. Without redistribution, it's nothing.
fields.body:
Apparently Gordon Brown thinks Labour has put behind it the "old-fashioned" redistributive philosophy it once embraced. Yesterday he offered "targeted tax cuts". Presumably redistributing wealth, like nationalising things, is considered part of the baggage which New Labour believes it has to jettison. The trouble, though, is that redistributing wealth, unlike nationalising things, is the real reason that Labour exists, and the real reason why people vote for it. Without redistribution, it's nothing.

That's why, of the five Labour prime ministers we have seen so far, the only one whose government still exerts magic over Labour's supporters is the one led by Clement Attlee between 1945 and 1951. Becoming prime minister in the harshest economic circumstances faced by any post-war government, he never had the smallest doubt that he was there, as modern politicians would put it, to tax and spend. His first chancellor, Hugh Dalton, said he would find money to revive deprived areas "with a song in my heart".

Attlee opposed targeted benefits, let alone targeted tax cuts. He believed that welfare benefits and other public services were for everyone, not just the poor. Services for the poor are generally poor services.

Attlee, Labour's most successful prime minister, is a problem for New Labour. The Attlee government, which created the National Health Service and the welfare state, is too strong an icon in Labour circles to be openly derided, but was far too radical to be emulated. The New Labour line on Attlee, therefore, is that he failed because he did not win a full second term.

But what's Attlee's line on Blair? Attlee would have disliked pretty well everything about New Labour, both the style and the substance.

The unforgiving way in which New Labour isolates and marginalises its leftwing critics would have appalled Attlee. He had seen it happen under Labour's first prime minister, Ramsay Macdonald, and did not like it. Macdonald excluded the key figure on the left, former housing minister John Wheatley, as well as all the other leftwing leaders, from his 1929 government. Wheatley was a towering figure in the 1920s, and his exclusion was seen by the Times, rightly, as "a declaration of war on the left".

The nearest equivalent to Wheatley in 1945 was Nye Bevan, and Attlee gave him the key job of health and housing, even though Bevan had almost been expelled from the party just a year earlier, and had been a thorn in the side of the leadership for 15 years. Bevan would surely not have found a place in a Macdonald cabinet or a Blair cabinet.

John Strachey had a place in Attlee's government, despite years flirting with the communists. So did George Buchanan, who had been expelled from the Labour party as a member of the rebel leftwing Independent Labour party. Ellen Wilkinson became minister of education, even though she had been a leftwing rebel in the 1920s and had spent the 1930s plotting to get Attlee ejected as leader and replaced by Herbert Morrison.

Attlee liked the unions, and his closest friend and ally, Ernest Bevin, was a union man first, and only a politician as a very late afterthought. You did not hear union chiefs complaining, as John Monks once did about Mr Blair, that they were being treated like "embarrassing elderly relatives at a family gathering".

It is said that Attlee's terse, understated manner would have had him destined for oblivion. He was naked to the world, with no spin doctors and no image. People seem to think that images and spin doctors were personally invented by Peter Mandelson after a visit to Washington. Attlee's spin doctor was an experienced Fleet Street editor called Francis Williams. If his name was not well known, it is because, unlike Blair's various spin doctors, Williams was a good professional, and understood that the moment the press officer is as well known to the public as his boss, he is on his way to becoming useless.

Williams did his work quietly, and Attlee left him to get on with it. Attlee did not want to know the details. When Williams wanted a telex machine in Number 10, so that he could see what stories the news agencies were running, he sold the idea by telling the prime minister that it would give him the up to date score at Lords, and Attlee was startled one day to see "my cricket machine" churning out the decisions of that morning's cabinet. He had not realised that Williams routinely briefed the political correspondents, but was not at all taken aback when this was explained to him.

Attlee had an image, too. A wise man, he avoided Neil Kinnock's ambitious, doomed attempt to create an entirely new persona. He ensured that his image was fairly close to the reality. It suited him to be thought a dull little man, and to sound rather like a suburban bank manager. Such people can make revolutions, as Attlee did, and no one will be frightened. It is exactly the opposite method to the present PM, who has no revolution to offer, but calls every piddling initiative a "crusade".

Most of all, Attlee would have revolted against the totemic use of the words "new" and "modern", suspecting they were euphemisms for abandoning the underdog for whom he believed Labour existed. We can be quite sure about this. In 1950 Herbert Morrison became the first Labour politician - his grandson Peter Mandelson is the latest - to use control of the publicity machine to in fluence policy. He wrote a paper for the national executive saying Labour must "modernise." Britain was becoming more middle class, so the only question for policy-makers was: how much of Labour's traditional agenda will middle-class voters stand for? Attlee stifled the idea, and would have stifled "modernisation" at birth if he were leader today.

Of course, New Labour could say that this simply proves their point. Had he accepted the Morrison initiative he might not have lost the 1951 election. I doubt it. There were deeper factors at work on the electorate than Labour's refusal to "modernise". The Conservatives had spent their six wilderness years rethinking their policies, and were led by a national hero. Today's Conservatives have wasted their opposition years, and are led by a national joke.

Labour narrowly lost in 1951 to a reinvigorated Conservative party, which had taken to its heart the lessons of its 1945 defeat and adapted accordingly, and was led by Winston Churchill. That's a very different animal to the Conservative party that New Labour will face next year. If all the disappointments have been in the cause of winning a second term, then New Labour had better win it, or some very awkward questions will be asked about the benefits of "modernisation".

 Francis Beckett's book, Clem Attlee, is published by Politicos at £12.99.

The Attlee government, which created the National Health Service and the welfare state, is too strong an icon in Labour circles to be openly derided, but was far too radical to be emulated. The New Labour line on Attlee, therefore, is that he failed because he did not win a full second term. But what's Attlee's line on Blair? Attlee would have disliked pretty well everything about New Labour, both the style and the substance. The unforgiving way in which New Labour isolates and marginalises its leftwing critics would have appalled Attlee. He had seen it happen under Labour's first prime minister, Ramsay Macdonald, and did not like it. Macdonald excluded the key figure on the left, former housing minister John Wheatley, as well as all the other leftwing leaders, from his 1929 government. Wheatley was a towering figure in the 1920s, and his exclusion was seen by the Times, rightly, as "a declaration of war on the left". The nearest equivalent to Wheatley in 1945 was Nye Bevan, and Attlee gave him the key job of health and housing, even though Bevan had almost been expelled from the party just a year earlier, and had been a thorn in the side of the leadership for 15 years. Bevan would surely not have found a place in a Macdonald cabinet or a Blair cabinet. John Strachey had a place in Attlee's government, despite years flirting with the communists. So did George Buchanan, who had been expelled from the Labour party as a member of the rebel leftwing Independent Labour party. Ellen Wilkinson became minister of education, even though she had been a leftwing rebel in the 1920s and had spent the 1930s plotting to get Attlee ejected as leader and replaced by Herbert Morrison. Attlee liked the unions, and his closest friend and ally, Ernest Bevin, was a union man first, and only a politician as a very late afterthought. You did not hear union chiefs complaining, as John Monks once did about Mr Blair, that they were being treated like "embarrassing elderly relatives at a family gathering". It is said that Attlee's terse, understated manner would have had him destined for oblivion. He was naked to the world, with no spin doctors and no image. People seem to think that images and spin doctors were personally invented by Peter Mandelson after a visit to Washington. Attlee's spin doctor was an experienced Fleet Street editor called Francis Williams. If his name was not well known, it is because, unlike Blair's various spin doctors, Williams was a good professional, and understood that the moment the press officer is as well known to the public as his boss, he is on his way to becoming useless. Williams did his work quietly, and Attlee left him to get on with it. Attlee did not want to know the details. When Williams wanted a telex machine in Number 10, so that he could see what stories the news agencies were running, he sold the idea by telling the prime minister that it would give him the up to date score at Lords, and Attlee was startled one day to see "my cricket machine" churning out the decisions of that morning's cabinet. He had not realised that Williams routinely briefed the political correspondents, but was not at all taken aback when this was explained to him. Attlee had an image, too. A wise man, he avoided Neil Kinnock's ambitious, doomed attempt to create an entirely new persona. He ensured that his image was fairly close to the reality. It suited him to be thought a dull little man, and to sound rather like a suburban bank manager. Such people can make revolutions, as Attlee did, and no one will be frightened. It is exactly the opposite method to the present PM, who has no revolution to offer, but calls every piddling initiative a "crusade". Most of all, Attlee would have revolted against the totemic use of the words "new" and "modern", suspecting they were euphemisms for abandoning the underdog for whom he believed Labour existed. We can be quite sure about this. In 1950 Herbert Morrison became the first Labour politician - his grandson Peter Mandelson is the latest - to use control of the publicity machine to in fluence policy. He wrote a paper for the national executive saying Labour must "modernise." Britain was becoming more middle class, so the only question for policy-makers was: how much of Labour's traditional agenda will middle-class voters stand for? Attlee stifled the idea, and would have stifled "modernisation" at birth if he were leader today. Of course, New Labour could say that this simply proves their point. Had he accepted the Morrison initiative he might not have lost the 1951 election. I doubt it. There were deeper factors at work on the electorate than Labour's refusal to "modernise". The Conservatives had spent their six wilderness years rethinking their policies, and were led by a national hero. Today's Conservatives have wasted their opposition years, and are led by a national joke. Labour narrowly lost in 1951 to a reinvigorated Conservative party, which had taken to its heart the lessons of its 1945 defeat and adapted accordingly, and was led by Winston Churchill. That's a very different animal to the Conservative party that New Labour will face next year. If all the disappointments have been in the cause of winning a second term, then New Labour had better win it, or some very awkward questions will be asked about the benefits of "modernisation".  Francis Beckett's book, Clem Attlee, is published by Politicos at £12.99. comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: US warns of Nato risk in EU rapid reaction force

fields.headline: US warns of Nato risk in EU rapid reaction force
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Nato could become a "relic of history" if European members of the Atlantic alliance do not sort out their new relationship with it, the US defence secretary, William Cohen, warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Nato could become a "relic of history" if European members of the Atlantic alliance do not sort out their new relationship with it, the US defence secretary, William Cohen, warned yesterday.

Speaking in Brussels, Mr Cohen issued the starkest warning yet that plans to forge an autonomous European Union defence capability must be closely coordinated with Nato or cause real damage.

"There will be no EU caucus in Nato," Mr Cohen insisted in an unusually passionate and unscripted speech to alliance defence ministers, including Britain's Geoff Hoon.

"If ... they try to or are desirous of a separate operational planning capability, separate and distinct from Nato itself, then that is going to weaken ties between the US and Nato and Nato and the EU," he said .

"There should be a single planning operation, and not duplicative and redundant, because that will only weaken Nato itself."

The American defence secretary also warned there were "too many questions" hanging over the project. Mr Cohen, leaving office with the outgoing Clinton administration, was backed, though more cautiously, by the alliance secretary-general, Lord Robertson.

Diplomats insisted last night that Mr Cohen's remarks were "valedictory and philosophical" rather than representing a change of policy by Washington.

It was the latest sign of anxiety in the US at EU plans, unveiled last month, for a 60,000-strong rapid reaction corps separate from Nato but likely to use alliance equipment and assets.

Mr Hoon later played down Mr Cohen's remarks. He dismissed suggestions that Mr Cohen had opened up an untimely rift over the new Euro force.

"He in a sense is warning about the same things that we have been warning about: we should not duplicate," he said.

Lord Robertson said: "I think secretary Cohen was right to warn us. And ministers were right to listen carefully to what he said."

webTitle: Britain backs new Chernobyl plants

fields.headline: Britain backs new Chernobyl plants
fields.standfirst: Special report: Britain's nuclear industry
fields.trailText: The government is to put £49m into building two nuclear reactors in the Ukraine to replace the remaining Chernobyl reactor due to close next week.
fields.body:
The government is to put £49m into building two nuclear reactors in the Ukraine to replace the remaining Chernobyl reactor due to close next week.

Britain has pledged the money even though it seems there will be no jobs or other financial benefit, and the Ukraine does not need the electricity from the new reactors. All the jobs involved will go to Framatome, the French nuclear company, and its German counterpart, Siemens.

In a letter to protesters Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, said he had instructed the UK to vote for the project's go-ahead on Thursday at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. In a statement he said he felt bound to support the project because of a memorandum of understanding signed in 1995 between the Ukraine and G7 countries in which the two reactors known as K2/R4 would replace the dangerous Chernobyl reactors. About 40% of the UK money would go towards making the reactors safer, the Department of Trade and Industry said yesterday.

Since the 1995 agreement, the economy in the Ukraine has gone down so much that electricity demand has fallen to half its 1990 level, and only 7% is paid for by consumers. There have been repeated reports into the project and all except one have shown that energy efficiency measures and gas power turbines would be cheaper and better, since gas can be used to meet peak demand whereas nuclear stations are working all the time.

But the bank has decided to go ahead with the nuclear option because the Ukraine government prefers it since the stations are already 80% built. The bank said yesterday it believed nuclear was still the best option.

In the past two years corruption has reached such a level in the Ukraine that all export credit guarantees have been withdrawn because the DTI has abandoned all hope of payment.

Yet the bank is counting on the UK granting credits of $28m (£19m) in export credit guarantees towards the cost, and Euratom, the nuclear arm of the EU, expects Britain to pay another £30m.

In a letter explaining the UK position, Mr Byers said: "Any ECGD [export credit guarantee department] support will depend upon a potential UK exporter being involved and will be subject to ECGD's due diligence and underwriting requirements."

Yesterday Tony Juniper, campaigns director of Friends of the Earth, said: "The Ukraine needs more Soviet designed nuclear reactors like it needs a hole in the head. If the UK government has millions of pounds to spare for energy projects in the former Soviet bloc it should spend them on energy efficiency projects and renewable energy, both of which are more economically viable and still better, safe."

Tobias Muenchmeyer, from Greenpeace International said: "The last thing the world needs are more two hazardous reactors to replace the hazardous Chernobyl reactor."

webTitle: Ryanair on a victory roll as judge swears advert attacking BA is honest and fair

fields.headline: Ryanair on a victory roll as judge swears advert attacking BA is honest and fair
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: British Airways was fairly branded "expensive bastards" who charge passengers many times more than some of their rivals, a high court judge ruled yesterday.
fields.body:
British Airways was fairly branded "expensive bastards" who charge passengers many times more than some of their rivals, a high court judge ruled yesterday.

The judgment came at the end of a court battle in which the budget airline Ryanair won vindication for its advertising campaign that claimed BA, which describes itself as the world's favourite airline, charged five times as much as the low-cost Irish firm on some fares.

A series of aggressive Ryanair advertisements in newspapers had compared BA midweek return fares to six European destinations, including Frankfurt, Genoa and Turin, with its own ticket prices. BA objected that the comparisons - which appeared under the headings "Expensive BA" and "Expensive Ba----ds" - were unfair.

But giving his ruling at the high court in London yesterday, Mr Justice Robin Jacob described the Ryanair campaign as "honest comparative advertising".

"I do not think that the average consumer would find the price comparison misleading," he said. "He would expect there to be some sort of conditions - and indeed the small print makes that clear. In substance, the advertisements were true. In substance, you are comparing like with like as far as fares go."

Speculating on BA's motives for pursuing the Irish airline, he said: "I suspect the real reason BA do not like it is precisely because it is true."

BA, which was suing over trademark infringement and malicious falsehood, had argued that Ryanair's claims of price differences were exaggerated and that details of the flight comparisons did not compare like for like journeys.

Mr Justice Jacob rejected these arguments, though he conceded that elements of the Ryanair campaign amounted to "no more than vulgar abuse".

He ordered BA to pay its own costs, estimated to be £260,000, and an immediate payment of £60,000 towards Ryanair's £120,000 bill.

Later, an elated Michael O'Leary, chief executive of Ryanair, said he felt vindicated by the ruling. "I would like to thank BA for taking this action to prove what everybody already knows - that they are expensive.

"The key issue here is that BA have pursued us in the courts in the hope that newspapers would stop running the adverts. They hoped Ryanair would not be able to afford the costs of going to court."

Mr O'Leary said two newspapers had refused to carry the advert after it began to cause controversy. He estimated that if Ryanair had lost the case it would have cost the airline about £500,000 in legal bills. "These bully boy tactics are typical of BA, and the attempt to gag Ryanair or frighten the national newspapers was doomed to failure. It is time BA learned that the days of its high fare monopoly are over."

He promised to run another series of adverts from today highlighting Mr Justice Jacob's ruling in Ryanair's favour.

The original "Expensive Ba----ds" advert appeared in a number of newspapers, including the Guardian, in February and March of last year and was referred to the Advertising Standards Authority after a complaint from a member of the public who found it offensive. In June 1999, the ASA ruled that the headline was likely to cause "serious or widespread offence" and asked Ryanair not to use it again. Ryanair agreed, and modified its headline to "Expensive BA".

But this did not satisfy BA, which took its case to court.

A spokeswoman for BA said the airline would be looking at the judgment and is considering an appeal.

The ruling comes less than two months after BA's German subsidiary was ordered by a Düsseldorf court to withdraw claims made to the press about its rival, Lufthansa, acting anti-competitively.

Under the heading "Deut-sche BA fears for German domestic market competition", the BA-owned company set out a list of questions and answers designed to highlight its concern over Lufthansa's intention to buy a stake in Eurowings, the third biggest player in the market.

The publicity claimed: "Lufthansa shows its true face - the airline is not interested in the welfare of its passengers, rather in the preservation of its power _

"There must not be a return to the past when Lufthansa squeezed the German market like a lemon."

webTitle: New talks lift hopes of climate breakthrough

fields.headline: New talks lift hopes of climate breakthrough
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Key countries involved in the collapse of the climate talks in the Hague 10 days ago are meeting in the Canadian capital, Ottawa, today in the hope of striking a deal before the Clinton presidency ends in January.
fields.body:
Key countries involved in the collapse of the climate talks in the Hague 10 days ago are meeting in the Canadian capital, Ottawa, today in the hope of striking a deal before the Clinton presidency ends in January.

The acrimony at the end of the talks between John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, and the forthright French environment minister, Dominique Voynet, masked the fact that agreement had been close.

The United States, Canada and Japan will meet representatives of the EU, plus officials from France, Sweden, Britain and Germany, to see if a political deal can be rescued from the wreckage.

The EU summit in Nice, starting tomorrow, will discuss the results of the Ottawa talks and attempt to rescue the 1997 Kyoto agreement, which was meant to begin the fightback against the threat of global warming.

If the EU summit reaches agreement, a ministerial meeting could be arranged in Oslo next week to formulate a political document. If the Nice summit fails to approve the outcome of the Ottawa talks, EU environment ministers will meet in Luxembourg on December 18 and 19.

The Kyoto deal aimed to reduce the developed world's output of greenhouse gases by 5.2%. But well before the Hague talks began the US knew it could not deliver on its targets and tried to create a number of loopholes which ultimately led to the Hague breakdown.

Despite the entertaining spat between the brusque trade union style of Mr Prescott, dubbed "inveterate macho man" by Mrs Voynet and the pugnacious French green minister, the US got the blame across the world for the failure to get agreement.

That was despite an American pledge of $1bn (£690m) in extra funding for the developing world through the World Bank for green energy projects and technology transfer which had satisfied the bloc of G77 countries, but not Europe, which remained adamant that real cuts were needed in US greenhouse gas emissions.

President Clinton particularly does not want the collapse to be a stain at the end of his presidency and be forced to pass the baton to George W Bush who is reported not even to believe that climate change is a threat.

In the Hague Mrs Voynet, speaking for the EU as France holds the presidency, was sharply critical of the US "loopholes". These involved counting growing forests to soak up carbon in tree trunks rather than cutting domestic emissions.

She complained that a compromise deal worked out by Jan Pronk, the Dutch environment minister, was a step backwards on the Kyoto agreement and said the reductions in greenhouse gases would only amount to 3.5% instead of 5.2% because of the loopholes.

It was here that Mr Prescott intervened and believed he had reached agreement but Mrs Voynet, the Danes, Dutch and Germans felt it was too soft on the US and the deal fell apart after several hours of wrangling. Mr Prescott said Mrs Voynet was "too tired to understand what was going on".

Last night the Department of Environment was playing down the chances of a new agreement. "We are just trying to assess where we have got to."

The Conservative environment spokesman, Damian Green, urged Mr Prescott to stay away from the next round of talks. He said: "Britain's first gesture in getting these talks back on the table should be to say that John Prescott will take no further part in the negotiations, and that Downing Street will send another minister instead."

Tony Juniper of Friends of the Earth said: "This is welcome news. However, it is vital that any agreement reached leads to real cuts in emissions rather than allowing the US and its allies yet more scope to carry on polluting."

webTitle: G2: Profile of Cold Feet's Karen

fields.headline: 'Common as muck, me'
fields.standfirst: In ITV's hit drama Cold Feet she's the middle-class wife of a pompous husband, but in real life she's more 'Southend-on-Sea'.  Gareth McLean meets Hermione Norris - and her peculiar boyfriend
fields.trailText: In ITV's hit drama Cold Feet she's the middle-class wife of a pompous husband, but in real life she's more 'Southend-on-Sea'. Gareth McLean meets Hermione Norris - and her peculiar boyfriend.
fields.body:
When I told friends I was interviewing Hermione Norris, their faces fogged with bewilderment. She plays Karen in Cold Feet, the ITV drama charting the ups and downs of three thirtysomething couples, I had to explain, to which their response was, without exception, "Oh, the blonde one. I do like her." She is "warm and sensible", "quite mumsy", "an anchor, a confidante".

With such thoughts in mind, it is a surprise to meet Norris, especially when she introduces me to her boyfriend. "This is him," she says, patting a Cat in the Hat cloth bag. Right, I reply. If there was a scale - a Flaky Actress Indicator perhaps - her statement might register somewhere up by Completely Doolally.

She is more delicate and elfin than her TV character Karen Marsden - younger-looking, funkier - and also more "out there" than her screen persona, even when she explains that her boyfriend is just one of convenience. "The other night, I wanted to book a cinema ticket but they said they didn't take bookings for just one ticket. So I booked two tickets and took my boyfriend," she nods towards the bag, "and he sat in the seat beside me."

Norris says she likes Karen a lot, considering her a "sorted bird", but has been frustrated with her passivity. "Mike Bullen [the writer] had developed her so much but then, by virtue of the fact she had two kids at the end of the last series, she has been domesticated. She is a rock while David [her husband] is going off doing all his shenanigans, and I did feel a bit like the straight man to his midlife crisis."

With David's infidelity (namely his affair with a foxy political activist, Jessica) set to be exposed, Karen provides the emotional apogee of the series. Norris's performance is raw, fierce and outstanding. "Before it, I was like, 'She would not put up with this shit'. She is someone who cuts through David's bullshit and that's precisely why she is able to be with him. I felt quite strongly about the resolution of it and when this angry pressure cooker goes off in the Marsden household, I was very pleased."

As for what she thinks should happen next, Norris is adamant. "I think she should get a fucking divorce." Not that Norris would have married David in the first place. "He's silly, small-minded, petty, pompous and humourless. I couldn't be doing with any of that. Karen's lifestyle would be my idea of hell."

Norris cherishes her own lifestyle. She doesn't do much press because she doesn't like it. "Give me a script and I'll do anything. That's what I do: I'm an actress. But when it comes to talking about me and my private life, it makes me feel very uncomfortable."

She says she doesn't like people "knowing my shit" and thinks that actors give so much of themselves anyway - "more than you realise sometimes" - it's important that she has something that is just hers. "It's really important for me to base my life in normality. Otherwise, how can you possibly act and show people in their true colours, how they are in relationships and how they relate to the world?"

This isn't faux philosophy or mock modesty - it is something she genuinely believes. She is disparaging of the "famous for being famous" aspect of popular culture and tends to avoid celebrity bashes. "I might go for an hour and enjoy it," she concedes. "But it's not something I'm interested in."

Norris's work is her passion. She has a distinguised theatrical pedigree, starring in work as diverse as The Seagull at the Moscow Arts Theatre, Stephen Poliakoff's Blinded By the Sun at the National and the world premiere of Ariel Dorfman's Reader at Edinburgh's Traverse Theatre. On television, along with the usual guest roles on shows such as Heartbeat and a starring role in the BBC1 costume drama Berkeley Square, she was Millennium Woman to Christopher Ecclestone's Millennium Man in Killing Time, an epic collaboration between poet Simon Armitage and director Brian Hill.

"I like to take a bit of a holiday from myself because I'm fucking hard work, I can tell you."

Her parents divorced when she was four, prompting a move from Essex to Derbyshire, where her maternal grandmother lived. Her mother, a health visitor and "a wonderful woman", raised Norris, her three sisters and, later, two half-sisters, while Norris maintained what she calls a "formal relationship" with her father.

"On Sundays we'd go to depressing places like Colchester zoo and the amusement arcades on the pier at Southend-on-Sea, but when my mum moved to Derbyshire the Sundays petered out". It was her father who named her, after Helen of Troy's daughter, Norris's mother being Helen. "It was his idea of being romantic," she smirks. "I think he was disappointed that I wasn't a boy so he decided to curse me with this name to lug around."

She rolls it round her tongue like a boiled sweet. " Her-mi-on-e ." Sometimes she hates it. "It makes a statement, my name. It's not an anonymous, blanket name like Susan or Jane or Helen. webTitle: Hague's 'moral' case for tax cuts

fields.headline: Hague's 'moral' case for tax cuts
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday staked out his claim to the moral high ground in the running controversy over tax-and-spend policies when he argued that an efficient Conservative government can both cut taxes by £8bn and protect key public services - in contrast to an inefficient Labour one.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday staked out his claim to the moral high ground in the running controversy over tax-and-spend policies when he argued that an efficient Conservative government can both cut taxes by £8bn and protect key public services - in contrast to an inefficient Labour one.

Amid mockery from senior ministers the Tory leader and his shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, detailed £5bn worth of spending cuts - and promised £3bn more in the weeks ahead - to finance promised tax cuts, equivalent to a 4p cut in income tax.

They insisted that there will be no cuts in health or education spending - only a guarantee that the Tories will "match Labour's spending pound for pound... and ensure our pounds go direct to frontline improvements in our hospitals and education system".

Partnership

The pair, whose partnership has been buffeted by speculation for the past week, also set out five principles that will govern the way a Hague administration will "restructure the way the state spends money". It should only spend what it can afford; spend no more than necessary to do the job; do only what it is necessary for governments to do; where appropriate finance some public services, but not actually provide them itself; and encourage "personal responsibility and choice."

Specifically, Mr Portillo cited £1.8bn of savings to be made by cutting the growing cost of government itself. He promised to cut an extra £1bn by curbing welfare fraud (and the number of MPs, MEPs and political advisers in Whitehall); to cut £400m out of regional bureaucracies and £300m worth of red tape at the Department of Trade and Industry.

He would save £400m a year from a better welfare-to-work scheme and a similar amount from replacing industrial injuries benefit and the transfer of council homes to housing associations. A cut in unconditional income support for lone parents with children over 11 would yield another £900m, Mr Portillo said. The Tory leadership's well-trailed speeches had already been attacked by Labour and the Liberal Democrats before they had even been delivered as impractical and improbable. Labour has long claimed that only £16bn worth of spending cuts can deliver Mr Hague's tax promises.

In his speech to the Institute of Economic Affairs Mr Hague dismissed such claims as "wild exaggeration". Far from lower taxes being a sign of greed, it was essential to the health of a moral society in which citizens choose how to spend the money they earn.

"Less tax means that people have more of their own money to spend in the way that they choose. And it is that choice, whether it be between different types of soap powder or holidays or personal pension plans, that lies at the heart of a free and caring society," he said.

The reference to personal pensions appeared optimistic in the light of revised estimates of the £10bn cost of the 1980s pensions mis-selling scandal. But Mr Hague argued that Labour's stealth taxes are gradually squeezing the dynamism out of the economy Tony Blair and Gordon Brown inherited in 1997.

webTitle: MP wants police to live on murder estate

fields.headline: MP wants police to live on murder estate
fields.standfirst:
Property prices forcing officers out, says Harriet Harman, while discrimination means disaffected youths turn to knives as status symbols

More about the Damilola Taylor case
Gallery: the CCTV shots
fields.trailText: The MP for the constituency where 10-year-old Damilola Taylor was murdered yesterday called for police officers to be housed on the deprived inner city estate where he was killed, in a bid to crack down on crime and solve the crisis in police recruitment.
fields.body:
The MP for the constituency where 10-year-old Damilola Taylor was murdered yesterday called for police officers to be housed on the deprived inner city estate where he was killed, in a bid to crack down on crime and solve the crisis in police recruitment.

Harriet Harman, a former social security secretary and the MP for Camberwell and Peckham, said police were deserting her borough, forced out by central London property prices.

The only hope of recruiting and retaining them was for the council to offer them new houses, even if it meant forcing out other tenants.

"It is controversial because it means you are reducing the number of homes available, but I think we have to have police living in the community," she said. "We can't recruit police without sorting out the housing issue - but we also need this to regenerate society.

"People feel safer when they have police living on their estate, and they are also pleased because they feel that if police live among them, they are totally in tune with their issues."

Ms Harman's call came after the Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir John Stevens, warned of an inner city policing crisis, with London having a 3,000 shortfall. In Southwark, the borough in which Damilola was fatally stabbed, the quota of 800 officers is 46 down.

In an area where the average cost of a terraced house is £185,000, police, in common with nurses and teachers, can no longer afford to buy or rent in the private sector on salaries which start at £23,000 including a housing allowance of £3,327, Ms Harman said.

The problem has been exacerbated by the previous government's decision, in 1994, to sell off police housing stock and freeze the housing allowance.

"They find they are earning enough to buy in a suburb and then they start to question why they should travel into central London when they can earn the same amount and do easier work policing near their home," she warned.

She added that the home secretary, Jack Straw, should back the move.

But Glen Smyth, chairman of the Metropolitan Police Federation, last night warned it would prove unpopular with police, who felt they needed to live outside areas they patrolled, for their own protection.

Touring the half-demolished north Peckham estate where Damilola bled to death, Ms Harman said its inhabitants were increasingly carrying knives as status symbols in a community where their chances of good jobs were consistently curtailed by discrimination.

"There is clearly a sense that this is an unequal society where you are blocked by the colour of your skin, and there is a feeling that you achieve status not by getting a degree or by qualifications but by having a knife," she said.

The growing problem of knife carrying appeared to have developed since children on Peckham's five neighbouring estates had seen their well-educated immigrant parents unable to put their degrees to good use in London.

"Three quarters of the African cab drivers in Peckham have degrees. So how can their children believe their education is worth striving for?" Ms Harman said.

"It is in this atmosphere that some carry knives and turn to crime."

The solution, she added, might lie, in increased resources for Peckham's schools, which, in the case of the Oliver Goldsmith which Damilola attended, had one of the lowest scores in national league tables, with only one in four of its 11-year-olds gaining the expected standard in English.

In the meantime, parents on the Peckham estate were trying to rectify the problems themselves - either by sending children back home to the West Indies or Africa to be educated, or by dispatching them to a private, Christian Fellowship school on the estate that they could ill afford.

webTitle: Operators fail to deliver Christmas timetable

fields.headline: Operators fail to deliver Christmas timetable
fields.standfirst:
Chaos on the tracks New delays and warnings over train cancellations threaten fresh misery for frustrated travellers

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Rail passengers are facing more misery because of delays over the new Christmas train timetable, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
Rail passengers are facing more misery because of delays over the new Christmas train timetable, it emerged last night.

Staff manning the central 0345 passenger inquiry line said they were unable to give accurate information because many train operators have failed to deliver their Christmas timetable on time, blaming disruption caused by the speed restrictions.

Some train companies have also warned that passengers who booked Christmas train trips several weeks ago face disruption as services are altered or cancelled altogether due to timetable changes.

Last night a spokesman for GNER said their delayed Christmas train timetable would be released on Monday. But he warned that some passengers who had booked Christmas rail trips weeks ago will face having their train times altered.

Alan Hyde, a GNER spokesman, blamed speed restrictions for delaying timetables, saying it was impossible to give accurate timetable information until Railtrack provided exact details of restrictions.

"We wanted to put together a robust and deliverable timetable, which will be published in full on Monday."

He said they have been taking Christmas bookings since October but confirmed that timetable delays will mean some passengers who booked in advance will have to be reallocated to other train times.

Virgin Trains said their Christmas timetable up to January 5 was issued yesterday. A spokesman said some of the information may not have filtered through to passenger inquiry staff as it still had to be keyed into their system.

But Virgin warned passengers who had pre-booked Christmas journeys to confirm times as they may be altered.

Anthony Smith, director of the Rail Passengers Council, condemned the timetable delays. "It is extremely disappointing, given that we were led to believe that we could expect rail stability by December 4. Now we discover that passengers cannot even get basic information about Christmas train times, making it impossible to plan their holidays. It is disgraceful that fresh misery is being piled on top of cancelled and delayed services."

Midland Mainline also announced that around 30 passengers who recently endured a nightmare nine-hour journey from London to Nottingham will be offered compensation of up to £100, plus the price of their ticket.

Another 70 people who were delayed by up to seven hours because of a power failure on the same line south of Bedford will receive similar payments.

The train companies face big compensation bills from delayed passengers, though some of these may be passed on to Railtrack. Spread across the country, with all 25 passenger companies affected, losses are mounting by millions a week.

Meanwhile, an insurance broker spent 11 hours 22 minutes travelling from his Penrith home to Euston, a journey that normally takes five hours.

Mike Bohling, 59, used a website yesterday to select the 4.13pm Virgin West Coast service, scheduled to reach London at 9.18. But the train came to a stop "somewhere between Oxenholme and Lancaster and stayed there for 2 hours".

Preston was the next stop. Mr Bohling and the 100 or so passengers waited for more than three hours until the connecting train arrived at 11.10.

"We eventually arrived at Euston at 3.35am," he said. "It was an absolute nightmare of a trip. I was travelling to London for a 9am meeting in the City - I just about made it."

A Virgin spokesman said: "There were severe delays on the approach to Lancaster. Railtrack was carrying out work and two wheels of a freight wagon jumped the track. A broken-down train also blocked the line for a while."

He said the train had been advertised as terminating at Preston with a connection for Euston. But the connecting train, which should have left Preston at 7.07, did not do so until 11.10 because it was also held up by the derailment.

webTitle: Former football manager cleared of child abuse charges

fields.headline: Former football manager cleared of child abuse charges
fields.trailText: The former manager of Southampton football club, David Jones, was cleared of 14 charges of sexually and physically abusing children after his trial collapsed yesterday when one of the alleged victims refused to give evidence.
fields.body:
The former manager of Southampton football club, David Jones, was cleared of 14 charges of sexually and physically abusing children after his trial collapsed yesterday when one of the alleged victims refused to give evidence.

Mr Jones had denied 10 charges of indecent assault, three of assault causing actual bodily harm and one of buggery, said to have been committed against four boys aged between 10 and 17, when he worked as a carer at a Merseyside special school between January 1986 and May 1990.

On the fourth day of the trial at Liverpool crown court, the judge, David Clarke, discharged the jury after ordering them to return formal not guilty verdicts on four charges against one alleged victim who declined to turn up.

The jury was told by David Aubrey QC, prosecuting, that the alleged victim - the first to complain to police about Mr Jones - had contacted a social worker saying he was not prepared to give evidence in court.

Earlier, before the jury was sworn in, two other alleged victims had pulled out, reducing the charges from 21 to 14.

After yesterday's witness failed to appear, the judge ruled that Mr Jones could not receive a fair trial before the same jury on the remaining 10 charges against him because the jurors had already heard allegations on which evidence would not now be delivered. He said it was only after publicity had been given to Mr Jones's arrest over the absent victim's allegations, that the three further complainants had come forward.

Both prosecution and defence submitted that it would not be safe to proceed with the trial and after two hours' deliberation, the crown prosecution service decided against a retrial.

Mr Clarke recorded not guilty verdicts on all remaining charges. He told Mr Jones: "You leave this court as you entered it - an innocent man. I have no doubt that there will be people who may be tempted to think there is no smoke without fire. I can do nothing about that except to say that attitude would be entirely wrong. No wrongdoing has been established. Many of the charges originally brought against you have not been pursued."

Mr Clarke praised Mr Jones's "restraint and dignity" throughout the trial, and said: "I hope that in time you can rebuild your professional career in whatever you choose to do."

After the verdict, Mr Jones described his arrest and trial as a nightmare and said he regretted taking the job at the care home saying: "It was the wrong place at the wrong time."

"I think it's fair that allegations have to be investigated. I think that's a must because I have children myself," he said.

"The lowest point was being accused. It had just come out of the blue, total shock. I honestly thought I would go to the police station, give my interview and that was going to be it... I think what has gone on over the last 18 months has been a shock and embarrassment to me and my family."

He said he intended to return to football.

Mr Jones, from Chilworth, near Southampton, was arrested on June 15 last year in connection with Operation Care, a long-running police and social services investigation into child abuse in children's homes and voluntary groups on Merseyside in the 1970s and 1980s.

At the time of his arrest Mr Jones was manager of Southampton, but in the late 1980s, after a knee injury forced him to retire from his career as a professional player, he had worked as a carer at a Merseyside residential school for children with emotional and behavioural difficulties.

Operation Care began in 1996 following a series of sex abuse scandals at children's homes and special schools in North Wales, Cheshire and Merseyside. It has so far led to the investigation of 84 institutions. The operation team, which includes 12 detectives, seven social workers and five special incident room staff working from a headquarters on the Wirral, use a similar method in each case. After a written statement is given to police by a complainant, the team take a "dip sample" of people who were at the home in question. This involves writing to or interviewing people asking if they remember any abuse. More than 2,250 statements have been taken.

A total of 27 people, including a vicar, 17 care workers and the millionaire coach firm businessman Andrew Christian, have been convicted and sentenced to more than a combined 120 years imprisonment, four years' suspended imprisonment and five years' probation. In the case of 78 investigations no further action has been taken by police to bring investigations to trial.

Mr Jones is the fifth acquittal in the history of Operation Care. Earlier this year, proceedings at Liverpool crown court were dropped against Thomas Williams, a 71-year-old accused of sexual abuse and cruelty against 20 boys at two residential care homes in north Merseyside. His solicitor, Paul Watson, said at the time that Operation Care was "out of control". Yesterday, commenting on the Jones case, assistant chief constable Mike Tonge said: "Merseyside police have a proven track record in sensitively and sympathetically investigating such cases. We will continue to thoroughly investigate complaints relating to care homes that are made whatever the circumstances."

A CPS spokeswoman said the decision not to seek a retrial was informed by a series of factors, including whether it was possible for Mr Jones to have a fair trial in view of the publicity surrounding the case and whether it was in the interests of one of the witnesses to give evidence again. She said the decision to prosecute Mr Jones was taken by a team expert in dealing with instances of child abuse that happened a long time ago.

webTitle: Jeremy Hardy: If you want to die, ask a policeman

fields.headline: If you want to die, ask a policeman
fields.standfirst:
So they mistook a table leg for a sawn-off shotgun. How reassuring
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: After last week's column, I wouldn't want readers to glean the impression that only black or Irish people die at the hands of agents of the state. Harry Stanley was a white Scotsman, who popped into a Hackney pub for a quick soft drink, and minutes later was gunned down by armed police.
fields.body:
After last week's column, I wouldn't want readers to glean the impression that only black or Irish people die at the hands of agents of the state. Harry Stanley was a white Scotsman, who popped into a Hackney pub for a quick soft drink, and minutes later was gunned down by armed police.

It has to be said, however, that whoever phoned 999 to report a suspicious looking man in the pub, described him as having an Irish accent. In future, East End villains will be able to save a fortune on their hit-man bills. They'll simply report a person as being Irish and the police will do it for them. And what better way to deal with nuisance neighbours?

The Crown Prosecution Service announced on Monday that no officers in this case are to be charged. One might take the words "insufficient evidence" seriously were it not for the fact that the crown has for years ushered legions of innocent people into jail on the flimsiest of evidence and then fought tooth and nail to keep them there. I'm sure if that, if the Metropolitan Police had decided to fit Harry Stanley up with something instead of shooting him in the head, the CPS would have done everything possible to assist them.

However, crown prosecutors must weigh evidence carefully and one should not make light of the difficulties they face. On the one hand, Harry Stanley was walking down the road, carrying a table leg in a plastic bag, when he was shot dead. On the other hand, the people who shot him were policemen. Hence, the internal investigation was initially headed by a Surrey officer who is himself facing disciplinary charges in relation to a shooting incident.

You may say that everybody makes mistakes. We have come to accept that police officers fail to investigate crimes, frame people and suppress the enjoyment of cannabis. But when they kill us, I think we are entitled to ask what we are paying them for.

Everybody does make mistakes. Whoever phoned the police that day made two: one relating to Harry's accent, and another in imagining a table leg was a sawn-off shotgun. The first need not necessarily have mattered. An accent is no use in identifying a man walking down the street. Some of the press have suggested that the mistaken belief that Harry was Irish justified the shooting, ignoring the fact that being Irish is not actually proof of anything. It certainly wouldn't shed any light on whether a plastic bag might have a shotgun in it.

Paramilitary organisations are apt to be secretive. Otherwise, Cyril Ramaphosa and Marti Artisarii would not need to be driven blindfold around the Irish countryside examining arms dumps. They could just pop in and out of bars looking in people's bags to see whether their guns had been fired lately. And sawn-off shotguns are not used in paramilitary operations anyway.

The suspicion that a man is carrying a gun, however, is something to take seriously. In fact, before challenging a potentially armed suspect, officers are supposed to take cover. It is no part of their guidelines to simply walk behind a gunman and shout: "Police!"

As it was, Harry Stanley had no reason to know anyone was shouting at him and perhaps didn't hear, so kept walking. The officers shouted again and he turned, probably quite curious. His turning was sufficient provocation for the officers to open fire. Perhaps the public should be trained in how we must react to shouting police if we don't want to die.

We are used to people in possession of toy guns being shot, despite the fact that the police are supposed to try not to shoot even those people whom they know for certain are genuinely armed. Harry Stanley was carrying a bag with a table leg in it. I would have thought that it should have crossed someone's mind that it might not be a sawn-off shotgun. The witness who got so carried away had an excuse: a car chase involving armed police had by chance ended outside the pub that day, and doubtless imaginations were racing in what was after all a licensed premises. All the more reason why officers should have been sceptical.

But perhaps the police themselves were a bit fired-up too. On Monday, Glen Smyth of the Police Federation described facing an armed suspect as "exciting"; and that was an attempt to defend this shooting.

Maybe the killers of Harry Stanley will describe the excitement when they give evidence at the inquest, although they won't have to say anything that might incriminate them, and they will be hidden by screens, to protect them from table legs.

webTitle: Lockerbie trial told of bombs confession

fields.headline: Lockerbie trial told of bombs confession
fields.standfirst: Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: A bomb maker confessed to supplying explosive devices similar to the one used in the destruction of Pan Am flight 103 to Palestinian terrorists, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A bomb maker confessed to supplying explosive devices similar to the one used in the destruction of Pan Am flight 103 to Palestinian terrorists, a court heard yesterday.

Lawyers for the two Libyan accused in the Lockerbie trial at the Scottish court in the Netherlands have lodged a special defence of incrimination, blaming, among others, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command for the atrocity which claimed 270 lives.

FBI agent Edward Marshman yesterday told the court of an interview with a Jordanian bomb maker, Marwan Khreesat, where he confessed to supplying five explosive devices to the PLFP-GC similar to the one used to bring down Pan Am flight 103 on December 21, 1988.

Khreesat also told the FBI he had met the leader of the PFLP-GC, Ahmed Jibril, and other Palestinian extremists while working in Germany for Jordanian intelligence.

The bomb maker has refused to give evidence to the court and defence lawyers were yesterday forced to rely on transcripts from his interviews with the FBI.

webTitle: IRA calls for dismantling of border security bases

fields.headline: IRA calls for dismantling of border security bases
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Tony Blair came under pressure last night to dismantle the British army's high-profile security bases along the Irish border when the IRA said it was up to the government to break the deadlock in the peace process.
fields.body:
Tony Blair came under pressure last night to dismantle the British army's high-profile security bases along the Irish border when the IRA said it was up to the government to break the deadlock in the peace process.

In a statement issued only days before President Clinton's visit to Northern Ireland, the IRA made clear that republicans were unwilling to offer any further gestures on disarmament until the government fully implements the Good Friday agreement.

The IRA, which stressed its continuing support for the peace process, said that it was still committed to putting its arms beyond use.

But the republican leadership made clear that the ball was now in the government's court. Republicans are angry with the government for its alleged watering down of the Patten report on policing and for its alleged failure to scale down security measures across the province.

The IRA's tough language indicates that republicans are unlikely to step up their disarmament efforts until the government reduces the army's presence. Sinn Fein has made clear that as a first step the government should remove a series of high-profile security bases along Northern Ireland's border.

The government attempted to take heart from the IRA statement, saying that it was encouraged that the republicans had reaffirmed their commitment to putting their arms beyond use.

However, government sources indicated that they were unlikely to meet the IRA's demand for border security bases to be closed, because of the threat from dissident republicans.

webTitle: McGuinness 'had troubled conscience' over shooting

fields.headline: McGuinness 'had troubled conscience' over shooting
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Bloody Sunday inquiry
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness "seemed to have it on his conscience" that he fired the first shot on Bloody Sunday, according to a document shown at the Saville inquiry at the Guildhall in Derry yesterday.
fields.body:
Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness "seemed to have it on his conscience" that he fired the first shot on Bloody Sunday, according to a document shown at the Saville inquiry at the Guildhall in Derry yesterday.

Mr McGuinness, who "found himself" officer commanding the IRA in Derry, was alleged to have confessed to the shooting in Derry 28 years ago of a member of the Provos who also was an agent for the security service, codenamed Infliction.

The claim was contained in an account of a service officer's debriefing of Infliction - a document put on the screen at the public hearings into the killings of 13 men during a civil rights march on January 30, 1972.

Mr McGuinness, now Northern Ireland education minister and Westminster MP for Mid Ulster, was also alleged in the heavily censored document to have "this conflict because of his Catholicism".

It noted: "McGuinness seems to be Mr Nice Guy, although really he was a pretty hard terrorist."

The communication added: "One thing that bothers McGuinness about the Bloody Sunday thing was that he fired the first shot and no one knows this. This seems to be on McGuinness's conscience. He has spoken to Infliction about it several times."

Secret intelligence documents from 1984 alleging that Mr McGuinness fired the shot which precipitated Bloody Sunday emerged in the spring and were emphatically denied by him outside the tribunal.

The latest material was shown as the tribunal started considering government attempts to restrict evidence shown publicly and to screen security service personnel called to testify.

Public interest immunity certificates were submitted by the home secretary, Jack Straw, and the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon.

Mr Straw wanted the censored parts of the Infliction notes to remain blacked out and a tape recording of the debriefing held back altogether, alleging that full disclosure could cause real harm to the department's work.

He was also seeking to edit documents supplied about another agent - Observer B, who alleged he was told the IRA fired first on Bloody Sunday.

Infliction was described as a security service agent resettled outside the UK. Observer B was now "a former agent".

The Ministry of Defence application concerned secret documents but the background was not disclosed.

webTitle: HIV priest accused of abusing schoolboy

fields.headline: HIV priest accused of abusing schoolboy
fields.standfirst:
Search begins for anonymous Oratory letter writer as Catholic church admits it knew late chaplain had virus before he was ordained

Special report: religion in the UK
Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: The Roman Catholic church was embroiled in new controversy yesterday after it admitted that a former chaplain at one of London's leading state schools, who was HIV-positive when he died two years ago, has been accused of sexually abusing at least one pupil.
fields.body:
The Roman Catholic church was embroiled in new controversy yesterday after it admitted that a former chaplain at one of London's leading state schools, who was HIV-positive when he died two years ago, has been accused of sexually abusing at least one pupil.

Father David Martin, who died of bronchopneumonia at a London hospital at the age of 44 in September 1998, had been acting chaplain one day a week at the Oratory School in west London, where the prime minister's sons, Euan and Nicholas, are now pupils.

Last night a spokesman for the church admitted that successive heads of Father Martin's religious order, the Oratory Fathers, had known that he was HIV positive several years before he was ordained in 1994.

It was not known whether they passed that information to the school before he started work there in 1997.

Claims about his conduct surfaced in a letter to Hammersmith and Fulham social services department last week. Earlier letters making less specific allegations were sent to leading figures in the church including the Archbishop of Westminster, Cormac Murphy O'Connor and to national newspapers in late October and were also referred to Hammersmith and Fulham.

A spokesman for the Westminster diocese said: "Naturally the church is deeply concerned whenever any allegations are made against a priest and especially if there are any victims of abuse. Any allegations need to be fully investigated and the church authorities will cooperate fully."

In a terse statement, Father Ignatius Harrison, provost of the Oratory Fathers, of which Father Martin had been a member, said only that the order was fully aware of the investigation. He later added that there had never been any concerns about Father Martin's behaviour.

Father Michael Napier, the provost of the order at the time Father Martin joined in 1988 and at the time of his ordination in 1994, is now also dead. Church sources said that Martin had been diagnosed HIV positive in 1991 - and had confided in Father Napier. The information was subsequently given to Father Harrison when he succeeded as provost in 1996.

The church was unable to say whether the school had carried out its own checks when he was recommended to them by the order as a governor and chaplain. Father Martin continued to visit the school until July 1998.

Child protection officers were yesterday attempting to establish the identity of the boy who made the complaints. They have only a first name to go on.

"There was a child protection meeting six weeks ago but they considered that there was no evidence with which to base any further investigations, because the letter was anonymous, there was no specific allegation of child abuse, and obviously Father Martin was dead," said a spokeswoman for Hammersmith and Fulham.

The latest letter alleging child abuse came from a boy claiming to be at the school. The allegation is that abuse of one boy took place away from the school and unconnected with school activities, but relating to the priest's church work.

On Monday social services and the police held a meeting and decided to launch an investigation. The council's child protection team met officers yesterday. They are looking again at the earlier letters.

ChildLine founder and chairman Esther Rantzen confirmed that the telephone helpline had been contacted by children making allegations of abuse at the school.

The inquiry is hampered by the unclear lines of responsibility. Father Martin was chaplain at the school for four terms but was employed not by them but by the Oratory Fathers.

Father Martin attended the school weekly, mainly to prepare boys for confirmation. He had previously been director of music at the Brompton Oratory and was instrumental in setting up a choir school there.

Father Martin graduated from St Andrews university in 1976. He entered the priesthood as a novice in 1988.

A statement released on behalf of the priest's father, James Martin, from Ayr, said: "We are devastated by news of this. It has come as a complete shock to us all."

Priests in the dock

1996 Father Adrian McLeish of Durham sentenced to six years for abusing boys aged 10 to 18 and exchanging internet pornography.

1997 Father Michael Walsh jailed for five years for indecent assault and gross indecency over a 19 year period. It emerged that Archbishop Cormac Murphy O'Connor appointed Hill to a succession of posts despite allegations that he was a paedophile. The archbishop has apologised.

1998 Father Eric Taylor jailed for seven years for abusing boys in his care at the Father Hudson Society's home in Warwickshire between 1957 and 1965.

2000 Father Joe Jordan jailed for eight years for sexually abusing boys. He was ordained by the Archbishop of Wales, John Ward, in 1996 despite warnings that he was a potential abuser who had earlier been banned from teaching. In 1998 Archbishop Ward's press officer John Lloyd was also jailed for eight years for indecent assaults on children. The archbishop has refused to resign.

A spokesman for the Westminster diocese said: "Naturally the church is deeply concerned whenever any allegations are made against a priest and especially if there are any victims of abuse. Any allegations need to be fully investigated and the church authorities will cooperate fully." In a terse statement, Father Ignatius Harrison, provost of the Oratory Fathers, of which Father Martin had been a member, said only that the order was fully aware of the investigation. He later added that there had never been any concerns about Father Martin's behaviour. Father Michael Napier, the provost of the order at the time Father Martin joined in 1988 and at the time of his ordination in 1994, is now also dead. Church sources said that Martin had been diagnosed HIV positive in 1991 - and had confided in Father Napier. The information was subsequently given to Father Harrison when he succeeded as provost in 1996. The church was unable to say whether the school had carried out its own checks when he was recommended to them by the order as a governor and chaplain. Father Martin continued to visit the school until July 1998. Child protection officers were yesterday attempting to establish the identity of the boy who made the complaints. They have only a first name to go on. "There was a child protection meeting six weeks ago but they considered that there was no evidence with which to base any further investigations, because the letter was anonymous, there was no specific allegation of child abuse, and obviously Father Martin was dead," said a spokeswoman for Hammersmith and Fulham. The latest letter alleging child abuse came from a boy claiming to be at the school. The allegation is that abuse of one boy took place away from the school and unconnected with school activities, but relating to the priest's church work. On Monday social services and the police held a meeting and decided to launch an investigation. The council's child protection team met officers yesterday. They are looking again at the earlier letters. ChildLine founder and chairman Esther Rantzen confirmed that the telephone helpline had been contacted by children making allegations of abuse at the school. The inquiry is hampered by the unclear lines of responsibility. Father Martin was chaplain at the school for four terms but was employed not by them but by the Oratory Fathers. Father Martin attended the school weekly, mainly to prepare boys for confirmation. He had previously been director of music at the Brompton Oratory and was instrumental in setting up a choir school there. Father Martin graduated from St Andrews university in 1976. He entered the priesthood as a novice in 1988. A statement released on behalf of the priest's father, James Martin, from Ayr, said: "We are devastated by news of this. It has come as a complete shock to us all." Priests in the dock 1996 Father Adrian McLeish of Durham sentenced to six years for abusing boys aged 10 to 18 and exchanging internet pornography. 1997 Father Michael Walsh jailed for five years for indecent assault and gross indecency over a 19 year period. It emerged that Archbishop Cormac Murphy O'Connor appointed Hill to a succession of posts despite allegations that he was a paedophile. The archbishop has apologised. 1998 Father Eric Taylor jailed for seven years for abusing boys in his care at the Father Hudson Society's home in Warwickshire between 1957 and 1965. 2000 Father Joe Jordan jailed for eight years for sexually abusing boys. He was ordained by the Archbishop of Wales, John Ward, in 1996 despite warnings that he was a potential abuser who had earlier been banned from teaching. In 1998 Archbishop Ward's press officer John Lloyd was also jailed for eight years for indecent assaults on children. The archbishop has refused to resign.
