webTitle: UK News in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Payne inquiry setback
fields.body:
Payne inquiry setback

Investigations into the murder of eight-year-old Sarah Payne received a setback yesterday when clothes found near where her body was discovered were ruled unlikely to be hers. Police had hoped a shoe and scraps of material, found near Thakeham, West Sussex, might yield DNA clues to the killer's identity.

Fonteyn rescue plan

The National Art Collections Fund said last night that it was considering helping to rescue mementoes of Dame Margot Fonteyn from being sold to private collectors abroad.

Amphibious initiative

Britain yesterday agreed to participate in a "European Amphibious Initiative" in a move designed to give additional practical effect to the EU's plans for a joint rapid reaction force

Rail chaos boosts BA

Rail disruption boosted passenger figures on British Airways' domestic flights last month, the group announced yesterday.

Big day for the Archers

Fans of Britain's longest running radio soap, The Archers, can expect a cliffhanging storyline to mark the programme's 50th anniversary on New Year's Day. The cast has already recorded the episode behind closed doors to keep the story secret.

Pottering away from tradition

Harry Potter will appear on the front of the Christmas issue of Radio Times, the first time Santa, or a traditional Yuletide scene, has been dropped for a quarter of a century. His appearance marks the unabridged reading of Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone on Radio 4 on Boxing Day.

Lords reject driver's plea

Five law lords yesterday rejected a motorist's attempt to escape prosecution for drink-driving after she claimed the Road Traffic Act breached her right to privacy under the European law.

Margaret Brown of Dunfermline claimed she was being forced to incriminate herself in a case which has implications for thousands of prosecutions for speeding.

Aids worker honoured

The United Nations civil society award was last night presented in Vienna to Release, the London drugs and legal advice charity, posthumously honouring the work of a founding member, Roger Lewis.

He provided health services for drug users, prostitutes and gay men in Ediburgh in the 1980s, while promoting an understanding of the HIV/Aids epidemic. Alan Travis

Prescott ruling reserved

The high court yersterday reserved judgment on whether deputy prime minister John Prescott deciding on planning applications is "incompatible" with the Human Rights Act.

During the five-day hearing on four test cases, it was argued that his intervention as environment secretary denied interested parties "a fair hearing by an impartial tribunal"

Christmas post deadlines

The deadline for worldwide deliveries of cards and packages up to two kilograms is tomorrow while the European deadline is Thursday next week, the Royal Mail said yesterday.

Deadlines for domestic letters and parcels are December 18 for second class and December 21 for first.

webTitle: Gore's hopes rest with Florida court

fields.headline: Gore's hopes rest with Florida court
fields.standfirst:
Democrat pledge that new challenge will be their last paves way for final decision on presidency by end of week

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The stage was set yesterday for a final showdown in Florida's supreme court between George W Bush and Al Gore over the results of last month's presidential election, in what Democrats promised would be their last effort to win the White House in the wake of severe legal setbacks.
fields.body:
The stage was set yesterday for a final showdown in Florida's supreme court between George W Bush and Al Gore over the results of last month's presidential election, in what Democrats promised would be their last effort to win the White House in the wake of severe legal setbacks.

The court accepted an urgent appeal by lawyers for the Gore campaign, which aims to force a hand recount of at least 14,000 disputed votes before a December 12 deadline, in the hope of overturning Mr Bush's 537-vote margin in Florida.

Four weeks after the election and with just a week to go before Florida must decide which way to cast its deciding votes for the presidency, the court in Tallahassee established a brisk timetable, calling for written briefs to be submitted by both sides today and for oral arguments to be heard tomorrow.

Each side will be given only half an hour to argue its case, and a final decision is expected by the end of the week. Court spokesman Craig Waters said immediate consideration would be given to the case, stressing: "The court takes the word 'immediate' very seriously."

Most legal analysts said the Democrats had a steep mountain to climb after a judge in a lower court comprehensively rejected their arguments the day before.

Meanwhile, the Florida supreme court was also due to consider a call for clarification from the US supreme court over its decision on November 21 to extend the deadline for vote recounts, but the issue was expected to take a back seat to the far more urgent matter of the 14,000 disputed votes.

Preparing for that battle, the Gore camp pointed to what it said were weaknesses in Monday's ruling by circuit court judge, N Sanders Sauls, and drew some hope from the fact that the Florida supreme court has a liberal reputation. Six of its justices were appointed by Democrats, and the seventh was put in place by bipartisan consensus.

The Democratic legal team will argue that Judge Sauls failed to examine any of the 14,000 disputed ballot papers from Palm Beach and Miami-Dade counties, which it argued were the best evidence of voter intent. The ballots, the Gore camp claims, cast doubt on the outcome of the election.

Even if the court decides in Mr Gore's favour, however, it is questionable whether so many disputed ballots could be counted in time. It is not even clear who would count them.

As the odds tipped against Mr Gore with every passing hour, his running mate, Joe Lieberman was dispatched to Capitol Hill yesterday to stave off a potential defection of nervous Democrats.

He insisted that he was hopeful of a last-round victory in the courts and confirmed that the Florida supreme court's decision would be considered final. Mr Lieberman declared: "We've always said that the Florida supreme court will be the final arbiter."

Across the road from the state supreme court in Tallahassee, a pair of legal wild cards are due to be dealt today in lower courts which offered the possibility of a last-minute upset. Local Democrats in two Florida counties, Seminole and Martin, are calling for a total of about 25,000 absentee ballots to be excluded from the final tally because Republican officials had illegally tampered with ballot application forms. The forms had been incorrectly printed, omitting voter identification numbers, and in each county, the local election supervisor allowed party workers to fill in the missing information before the papers were sent out.

Republican lawyers filed a motion yesterday calling for the Seminole county case to be thrown out as groundless. They pointed out that it was not the ballots but the application forms that were altered, and that there had been "substantial compliance" with the law required by Florida statutes.

The Seminole and Martin cases could offer a lifeline to Mr Gore, but the vice-president's campaign has deliberately distanced itself from both lawsuits, as their success would involve the highly controversial disenfranchisement of thousands of voters.

A Republican attorney Miller Baker said yesterday: "The most telling point about this case is that Al Gore has not joined it. That just tells you how weak it is."

Republicans mounted a legal counter-attack in a federal appeals court in Atlanta, Georgia, yesterday, arguing that manual recounts in selected counties were inherently unconstitutional as they treated some votes differently from others.

That case may set an important constitutional precedent, but it is unlikely to decide the election. In the final days of the long electoral ordeal, that burden will almost certainly fall to the seven judges of the Florida supreme court.

webTitle: British Museum Great court opens

fields.headline: Two years and £100m later, the court opens
fields.standfirst: British Museum all set for royal ceremony tonight, but while officials play a straight bat, row over substitution of stone refuses to die away
fields.trailText: After two years, £100m, 478 tonnes of steel, 315 tonnes of glass, 16,000 tonnes of concrete, a forest of newsprint and 1,000 tonnes of multi-pedigree limestone, the British Museum's Great Court is ready for the Queen to open tonight.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
After two years, £100m, 478 tonnes of steel, 315 tonnes of glass, 16,000 tonnes of concrete, a forest of newsprint and 1,000 tonnes of multi-pedigree limestone, the British Museum's Great Court is ready for the Queen to open tonight.

She should feel at home: her name is inscribed in giant letters around the great drum of the round reading room - she gets even bigger letters than the carved thank you notes to sponsors like the Weston Foundation and Vivien Duffield - and the courtyard is 96 metres long, the same length as the facade of Buckingham Palace.

Yesterday, as the court opened for invitation only previews, the British Museum wanted to talk about the blue and gold glory of the restored reading room, the new temporary exhibition gallery, the suite of education rooms and lecture theatres, and the new computer system giving desktop access to the vast collections. All the visitors wanted to talk about was limestone.

People who could hardly have told chalk from cheddar were passionately debating the rival merits of the French Anstrude Roche Claire actually used on the portico, and the thoroughly British Portland with added heritage grime of the surrounding walls.

The director of the British Museum, Robert Anderson, sighed deeply.

"French is still the language of courts," he said. "Her Majesty might think French stone quite appropriate."

It was not much of a joke, but under the circumstances it was heroic. The row has rumbled on all year over the substitution of cheaper French stone for the specified Portland, and the decision of the British Museum trustees to let the building work continue when the substitution was discovered.

It was fuelled by the exciting threat that either English Heritage or Camden council might order the entire portico to be demolished, by the retention of part of the promised heritage lottery grant, and by an unprecedented rebuke of the trustees, for "dereliction of their duty to the building" from English Heritage chief Sir Neil Cossons.

His predecessor, Sir Jocelyn Stevens, demanded the resignation of chairman, Graham Greene, and the entire board. A British Museum spokesman said yesterday: "As far as we are aware, Sir Jocelyn has never actually seen the south portico."

Richard Ireland, a conservator who worked on the reading room, and invented a solution for the 150-year-old problem of the cracking dome, had sympathy for both sides.

"The attempt to substitute the stone was appalling. Having said that, new Portland would still look new, and very white. I think it will tone down in time. Aesthetically, I think it is fine. But I do think it is something of a national embarrassment that it is not Portland stone."

Sir Norman Foster, architect of the Great Court, looked exhausted.

"As a collective endeavour, you all do the best you can on every building, every structure. You can strive for perfection, but buildings are made by humans, designed by humans, used by humans."

Little clumps of people were still gathered in front of the south portico, peering from new to old stone and back again.

"Now would you call that colour mouseback, milk or string?" said a woman from the National Trust.

"I know what it looks like," said Vicky Dyer, political officer at the arts charity The Art Fund. "It looks just like an airport"

The British Museum will be closed all day today, for the opening ceremony. The Great Court will open to the public for the first time at 9am tomorrow.

webTitle: Teaching union leader to quit early

fields.headline: Teaching union leader to quit early
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Britain's most high profile teachers' leader is to step down from his job a year earlier than his retirement date, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's most high profile teachers' leader is to step down from his job a year earlier than his retirement date, it emerged yesterday.

Nigel de Gruchy, the vociferous general secretary of the second largest teaching union, the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, will step down at Easter 2002. Mr de Gruchy, 57, plans to work with his successor for a year before representing his union as president of the TUC for a year. Advertisements for his £72,000-a-year post will appear today.

The former economics teacher, who has been a thorn in the side of both Labour and Conservative governments, is a popular leader well known for his soundbites and his quick-witted responses to educational developments.

Although outsiders will be able to apply for his job, all applicants must have the support of local associations and the successful candidate is likely to be somebody with considerable experience with the NASUWT. The leading woman in the field is Chris Keates, assistant secretary (policy co-ordination), while the male contenders are treasurer Mick Carney and deputy general secretary Eamonn O'Kane.

Mr de Gruchy has fought to support the right of heads and their staff to expel uncontrollable pupils. Arguably his finest hour was at the Ridings school in Yorkshire, where he arrived to support staff after a breakdown in discipline led to a strike threat. The union's membership has swollen under Mr de Gruchy, from 120,000 in 1990 to nearly 200,000 now.

Mr de Gruchy, known to want to spend more time playing golf as well as writing a history of the NAUWT, said: "This last decade, like the 1980s, has been one of non-stop turbulence. I have been proud to be part of a team of elected representatives and full-time staff who have succeeded in increasing the influence of NASUWT."

webTitle: Church faithful shamed by child-sex scandals

fields.headline: Faithful shamed by scandals as church appears slow to act
fields.standfirst:
Special report: child protection
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: A bishop of the Church of England sighed yesterday on hearing of the Roman Catholic church's latest turmoil over sex abuse and said: "It's not just them, you know. We have our problems too."
fields.body:
A bishop of the Church of England sighed yesterday on hearing of the Roman Catholic church's latest turmoil over sex abuse and said: "It's not just them, you know. We have our problems too."

The Church of England has the advantage of not collating statistics of prosecutions and it is the Catholic church which is perceived to have the gravest problems.

About 25 priests out of 5,600 have been convicted in the past five years and the cases keep on coming - an average of one every three months.

Archbishop Cormac Murphy O'Connor, head of the Roman Catholic church in England and Wales, who was criticised in the summer after he admitted reappointing a priest accused of sex abuse to a new post in his former diocese of Brighton and Arundel, said recently: "I think the paedophile scandals have indeed done damage to the church.

"The vast majority of priests who are good and faithful feel ashamed."

With its moral authoritarianism, the church makes a good target for accusations of hypocrisy.

Priestly celibacy may or may not be a contributory factor. Tom Horwood of the Catholic Media Office said: "It seems not to be a question of sex rather than of power over victims and the exercise of that power. Paedophiles seem to have some deep psychosis. Whether an institutional environment attracts a certain sort of personality is hard to say."

What is certain is that the church has been slow to take allegations seriously and has been perceived to be more concerned about protecting its priests rather than their victims.

It introduced guidelines for the priesthood in 1994 - the year Father David Martin was ordained - but the case of Father Joe Jordan, jailed in Cardiff last month two years after his ordination following convictions for sexually abusing boys, shows they have not always been followed.

The church authorities in September brought in the former public standards watchdog Lord Nolan to inquire into the working of the guidelines in the hope of heading off accusations of complacency. They have recently instituted checks with police for every candidate for priesthood.

webTitle: Teenagers in poor areas more likely to fall pregnant, less likely to abort

fields.headline: Teenagers in poor areas more likely to fall pregnant, less likely to abort
fields.trailText: Teenagers living in the poorest areas of Britain are more likely to get pregnant, but much less likely to have an abortion, according to a report yesterday from the office for national statistics.
fields.body:
Teenagers living in the poorest areas of Britain are more likely to get pregnant, but much less likely to have an abortion, according to a report yesterday from the office for national statistics.

It found the London borough of Southwark had the highest teenage conception rate, with 85 pregnancies per 1,000 women aged 15-18. This was more than five times the figure in Chiltern, with the lowest rate of 15.4 per 1,000.

For the most part, poorer areas in coalfields, manufacturing centres and ports tended to have higher teenage pregnancy rates than more prosperous and rural authorities.

Young women who became pregnant in areas with a high level of under-18 conceptions were more likely to have the baby than an abortion. But in parts of the country where teenage pregnancies were uncommon, up to two thirds ended with an abortion.

Manchester had the highest teenage conception rate in the north west region and the lowest percentage of abortions in England. Between 1992 and 1997 the city had an under-18 conception rate of 74.2 per 1,000 and 25.7% of these pregnancies ended in abortion.

By contrast, East Dorset had the lowest rate of teenage conceptions in the south west region (18.9 per 1,000) and the highest proportion of teenage terminations in that region, with 66% having an abortion.

The figures suggested that girls were more likely to keep a baby if they lived in parts of the country where teenage pregnancies were regarded as more socially acceptable.

London was an exception to the national trend, with above average conception rates and a high percentage of abortions.

The study showed that, nationally, Wales had the highest under-18 conception rate and England had the highest percentage leading to abortion. Scotland had low rates of teenage pregnancies and abortion.

The UK has the highest rate of teenage pregnancies in western Europe, with 95,000 conceptions last year, resulting in 58,000 live births. The government's target is to halve these figures by 2010.

Other findings in the ONS report on population trends included a decline in the divorce rate in England and Wales to the lowest figure for 10 years. Last year's 144,600 divorces affected 12.9 married people per 1,000, compared to 13.1 in 1990.

The average age of people divorcing rose, from 40.2 for men and 37.7 for women in 1997, to 40.9 and 38.4 respectively last year. The ONS said this was attributable to people marrying at a later age.

More people are divorcing for at least the second time, with one in five people who split last year having been through divorce before, compared with only one in 10 in 1981.

webTitle: Mandelson speaks up for Portillo

fields.headline: Mandelson speaks up for Portillo
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson yesterday praised Michael Portillo's efforts to make the Conservative party more socially tolerant in the face of the "macho strain of culture" bequeathed to society by the Thatcher era.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson yesterday praised Michael Portillo's efforts to make the Conservative party more socially tolerant in the face of the "macho strain of culture" bequeathed to society by the Thatcher era.

The Northern Ireland secretary argued that Britain's economic prosperity as well as its social stability depended on "that key British value, outward-looking open-mindedness."

"It is time for New Labour to reassert tolerance as a fundamental virtue, to reaffirm our belief in the equal worth of every human being. This duty falls on political leaders in every generation. The prime minister has given a strong lead. Michael Portillo is trying to do so with his emphasis on social inclusiveness in his own party," said Mr Mandelson.

That amounted to a barely coded defence of Labour's package of liberal reforms in the 1960s.

He coupled this with an attack on racial hatred, xenophobic intolerance and the "socking it to people" culture of aggression which, he suggested, found frequent expression in newspaper headlines and the tone of reporting.

That amounted to a milder critique of "macho" tabloid media culture than Mr Blair and other senior colleagues have started making, notably over Europe. In similar Middle England vein he used a keynote speech to a Labour Friends of Israel meeting in London to balance his liberal message with an admission that the Thatcher-led backlash against the 1960s reforms had some justification.

These became "associated with greater freedom in personal relationships, which in turn became equated with family breakdown, community dysfunction and even the rise in crime", he conceded.

With that in mind, Tony Blair's closest personal ally in politics dared to admit that when Margaret Thatcher "trumpeted her intolerance" and denounced liberalism as a vice, some of her targets were justified.

"Many of the things of which she was famously intolerant, she was right to be, the aggression of General Galtieri [over the Falklands], the behaviour of the Wapping mob [ printers who besieged Rupert Murdoch's union-busting plant], the excesses of the ultra left," Mr Mandelson said.

But the backlash had produced the "macho strain of culture", which expressed itself in road rage, rudeness, yob culture on the street, and bullying in the workplace.

webTitle: Less than three weeks to go and still travelling blind

fields.headline: Less than three weeks to go and still travelling blind
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: With rail travel in chaos many companies have still not provided timetables for the Christmas period.
fields.body:
With rail travel in chaos many companies have still not provided timetables for the Christmas period.

With under three weeks to go until Christmas the Guardian tried to book five possible train journeys, calling the 0345 passenger inquiry line to find out times of trains.

Some operators refused to give out details saying the information would be a "waste of time" as they were still waiting for the timetables. Others tried to be helpful but said the information was liable to be inaccurate and advised customers to call nearer Christmas to check.

Operators sounded stressed as they tried to field inquiries without up-to-date train information. One said: "We have been getting some abuse from angry customers who are trying to plan their Christmas. We accept it is very frustrating for them as they have already faced long delays and now can't even get accurate information about Christmas train times".

The Guardian attempted to book outward trains on December 22 and returning on Boxing Day.

Journey 1. Manchester to Penzance

We succeeded in booking an 11.03am Manchester Piccadilly train to Penzance on December 22 but had no luck with a return journey on Boxing Day as no timetable information is available yet. "We only have Virgin Train times for December 22 and nothing later."

Because of the speed restrictions train companies are reluctant to bring out the Christmas timetable till the last minute because the information could change. "It is supposed to be running but the Boxing Day connection from Birmingham has not been confirmed yet".

Journey 2. Nottingham to Plymouth

We managed to book a Nottingham to Plymouth train on December 22 but again no information on Boxing Day services. "We have still not got the timetable in place and are hoping it will arrive on Saturday."

Journey 3. Ipswich to Edinburgh

We could get to Edinburgh on December 22 but no Boxing Day train back to Ipswich. But we were warned to double check timetables nearer departure as more accurate information becomes available. We were warned the train could be cancelled or altered.

"We can get you to Edinburgh but there are no trains back to Ipswich from there on Boxing Day. We can only give you provisional times on the way out. You will have to double check later."

Journey 4. Oxford to Newcastle

We were unable to book as no information was available about Christmas timetables.

"Great North Eastern Railways have not yet given us the timetable so we can't give you any train times." When told other operators had been more helpful, they replied they should not have even provided provisional train times until they receive the Christmas timetable. "Trains running on December 22 are changing all the time. They are cutting some services altogether."

Journey 5. Slough to Sheffield

We obtained some details of the outward journey to Sheffield but were told there were no timetables that far in advance for December 22. There may not be a Boxing Day service.

The companies should have provided the Christmas timetable on Monday but failed to do so.

webTitle: Millionaire's £2m gift to estate where boy died

fields.headline: Millionaire's £2m gift to estate where boy died
fields.standfirst:
More about the Damilola Taylor case
Gallery: the CCTV shots
fields.trailText: A millionaire businessman who grew up in the south London street where Damilola Taylor was stabbed is to donate £2m to build a day centre for the local community.
fields.body:
A millionaire businessman who grew up in the south London street where Damilola Taylor was stabbed is to donate £2m to build a day centre for the local community.

Lord Harris, 58, the chief executive of Carpetright, announced yesterday he was working with the government to find ways of regenerating the North Peckham estate where the 10-year-old died on Monday last week following an attack in nearby Blake's Road.

The centre is likely to be named after Damilola and Southwark council has said it will speak to the boy's family to ensure relatives had a chance to contribute to the project.

Damilola's father, Richard, who flew to London from Nigeria last Friday, is expected to speak at a Scotland Yard press conference this morning. Detectives are hoping his appeal will persuade witnesses to come forward.

The murder squad, which now has 80 officers, has been told traces of Damilola's blood were on pieces of two beer bottles found in Blake's Road. But forensic scientists suspect neither bottle was the murder weapon.

They believe Damilola may have dripped blood on the glass as he ran for help.

A pathologist has told Detective Chief Inspector Trevor Shepheard, who is leading the investigation that Damilola was probably stabbed with a knife.

Police are looking for three youths - two black, one white - who tried to walk up the stairwell where Damilola collapsed and died. They were turned away and told to use a lift.

Detectives believe the three boys may have seen a group of youths who were spotted at the bottom of the stairwell by the workman who found him moments earlier. The youths ran off, and have become the prime suspects.

Superintendent Rod Jarman, who is in charge of community policing in Peckham, said he was surprised some young people spoken to by his officers had not even known detectives were appealing for help.

webTitle: Spending pledge would paralyse Whitehall, warns Labour

fields.headline: Spending pledge would paralyse Whitehall, warns Labour
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: A headline-grabbing pledge by William Hague to shave £1.8bn off central government spending was based on an over-ambitious interpretation of the figures which would be virtually impossible to meet, Labour said last night.
fields.body:
A headline-grabbing pledge by William Hague to shave £1.8bn off central government spending was based on an over-ambitious interpretation of the figures which would be virtually impossible to meet, Labour said last night.

In his speech, Mr Hague hailed his plans to cut government spending, saying that voters know there is scope to cut back on "bureaucracy, bad government and political gimmicks".

A briefing document accompanying the speech pledges to cut what it claims is the £1.8bn added by Labour to the government's running costs since the general election.

However, the document fails to point out that this will mean a cut of more than 10% in the running costs of government, a huge reduction which would virtually paralyse Whitehall.

The Tory plan would return government running costs to the actual level of 1997, without taking into account inflation.

Andrew Smith, the chief secretary, said that the Tory figures were alarming. "The Tories' figures do not add up," he said. "Under serious examination their proposals unravel."

A Tory spokesman maintained there would be no difficulty in cutting 10% from government running costs, although such a specific commitment is not outlined in the Tory document. Their solution would be to freeze recruitment and slash the government's non-salary bill.

Mr Hague yesterday outlined a 15-point plan to cut £5.3bn from the government's spending plans in a first phase of cuts which will total £8bn. Cuts in other areas include:

 The industrial injuries benefit scheme which pays out money to injured workers. Employers would have to take out insurance to cover injured employees.

 Cutting down on welfare fraud to create savings of £1bn, by giving benefit inspectors the same powers as tax inspectors..

 Saving £500m by forcing lone parents off lone parents benefit when their child reaches the age of 11.

 Saving £25m in interest payments by selling off the Queen Elizabeth Conference Centre in London, privatisating the Ordnance Survey and selling government buildings at 2 Marsham Street in London.

 Replacing the government's flagship New Deal jobs scheme to create savings of £400m.

webTitle: G2: Pass Notes on Leicester

fields.headline: No: 1776
fields.standfirst: Leicester
fields.trailText: Leicester
fields.body:
Age: 3,000 or so.

Appearance: Flat, grey, featureless.

Reputation: England's most boring town.

Claims to fame: Rebel baron Simon de Montfort was the Earl of Leicester (though there is no evidence that he ever visited the town). Richard III was buried in Leicester (though his body was later dug up). Henry IV was born there (though no one can remember when he reigned), as was the playwright Joe Orton (though he left as soon as he could).

There seem to be a lot of "thoughs" in Leicester's history. Any unqualified high spots? Daniel Lambert, Britain's fattest man, lived in Leicester.

Big deal. Gary Lineker, CP Snow, Sue Townsend, the Attenborough brothers, King Lear (allegedly), and Engelbert Humperdinck (incontrovertibly) all come from Leicester. The first Thomas Cook excursion left from Leicester station.

I'm not surprised ... I think I'll find out what's on page 4. Hang on, there's some really big news about Leicester.

This had better be good. It has just been proved that Leicester is where the English language began!

How so, my liege? Back in AD1000 Leicester (or Ledecstre as it was then called) was the front line between the Vikings of the north and the Anglo-Saxons of the south. Their dialects intermingled and, hey presto, English was born.

What did it all mean linguistically? I thought you'd never ask. "Modern English comes from the Leicester dialect," says historian Michael Wood. "Before, we constructed sentences like the Germans, with the verbs at the end."

Fascinating (but irrelevant) fact: Leicester City FC, aka the Foxes, used to be called the Fossils (from Fosse Way, which, significantly, runs through Leicester).

Leicester English not to be confused with: Estuary English.

Do say: "What an illuminating and meticulously researched Pass Notes."

Don't say: "Tomorrow Luton, cradle of the Renaissance."

webTitle: Beckers end their landmark marriage

fields.headline: Beckers end their landmark marriage
fields.trailText: Germany's most celebrated inter-racial marriage is on the rocks. The former tennis ace Boris Becker announced yesterday that he and his black wife, Barbara Feltus, had split up.
fields.body:
Germany's most celebrated inter-racial marriage is on the rocks. The former tennis ace Boris Becker announced yesterday that he and his black wife, Barbara Feltus, had split up.

Their seven-year marriage acquired huge significance as a symbol of Germany's evolution into a multi-ethnic society. Earlier this year Mr Becker was among the first recruits to a government-sponsored campaign urging the public to stand up to racism.

In a statement Mr Becker ruled out a divorce, but said: "Our views on the priorities of our relationship are too far apart. We have recognised that we cannot go on in this way."

The break-up poses a problem for Coca-Cola: Ms Feltus revealed at the weekend that she had made a television commercial for the company.

A spokeswoman said the advert was due to go out in February, but added: "How far the latest news might influence our decisions in the future is still being discussed internally".

The news that the sporting idol was to marry an unknown black actress and model astonished many Germans.

"Barbara is black and beautiful and I am supposed to be the typical German - blond and blue-eyed," Mr Becker said later. "When we got engaged, we received threats."

Throughout their marriage, the couple complained repeatedly of racial discrimination.

"Sometimes ... I am someone who cannot get served because I'm black. The next minute I'm Frau Becker and treated like a queen. Sometimes I find both awful," Ms Feltus once said.

Though they did not meet until 1991, Mr Becker and his wife grew up within a short distance of each other, near Heidelberg in southern Germany. Ms Feltus has a German mother and an African-American father.

She and Mr Becker have two sons, Noah, six, and Elias, who was born last year.

In 1996 Mr Becker said he wanted Noah to go to school in the US so that he could grow up in a more ethnically diverse society. But despite rumours that they were about to go abroad, they settled in Munich. Mr Becker said last year: "The public have accepted us."

webTitle: Obituaries: Crawford White

fields.headline: Crawford White
fields.standfirst: Crisp chronicler of cricket's great days
fields.trailText: Crisp chronicler of cricket's great days
fields.body:
Hours after the death of Lord Cowdrey yesterday, the man who chronicled as much of his career as anyone was quietly buried in Surrey. Crawford White was a frontline cricket writer for 28 years, most famously on the Daily Express. He died aged 90, days after his newspaper entered the latest and most terrifying phase of its long decline.

There was an Express tradition that reporters should have sonorous bylines. If necessary, Lord Beaverbrook encouraged his writers to reinvent themselves: Sefton Delmer, Logan Gourlay and Chapman Pincher started out as Tom, Jack and Harry. Crawford White, the son of a Glasgow engraver, had the asset of his distinguished first name from the start.

He was a skilful cricketer too. When his family moved to Lancashire, he soon began playing in the local leagues. He was 6ft 4in tall and a genuinely sharp, right-arm fast bowler, good enough to get into the Lancashire Second XI in 1934, when both the first and second team won their championships. Neville Cardus reputedly hinted that he might play for England.

But White kept his day job on the Darwen News, while playing as a professional for St Anne's and Royton, a combination that was a shade more lucrative (or less pauperish) than becoming a county pro. In the end, his nearest approach to on-field greatness was almost being picked to play for the MCC in British Guiana during an injury crisis in 1947-48.

By that time he was cricket correspondent of the News Chronicle. When that newspaper folded in 1960, he was briefly on the Daily Mail before being headhunted by the Express, where he stayed until retirement in 1975. For much of that time, the Express circulation was above 3m, and White's byline was as much part of the litany of summer as May, Cowdrey and Dexter.

With his upright, military bearing (he was an intelligence officer in wartime Bomber Command), White was imposing in person as well as in print. Players respected him. He was no literary stylist, but his writing had a crisp, simple authority. And he was well out of the game before popular paper correspondents were expected to get their fingers dirty by reporting events off the field. His most difficult job was ghosting Denis Compton's column, which he was inclined to do after an interview conducted at Worplesdon golf club.

Well into his 80s, White remained a familiar figure in the press box, doing public relations for the Test match sponsors, Cornhill. He would pour journalists their lunchtime wine with a gentle reminder: "Remember the magic word", ie make sure Cornhill gets a mention. There was a famous occasion when John Arlott was refused an extra bottle, and the Guardian failed to spot that he called it the Prudential Test. Nearly always, the White style was so amiable that everyone complied.

His marriage to Dorothy, childless but evidently blissful, lasted 64 years.

Crawford White, cricket writer, born October 31 1910; died November 29 2000

webTitle: Diary: Matthew Norman

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • I fear for my friend Alastair Campbell, who appears to be going through a dreadful mid-life crisis. The signs are unmistakable. According to Tony Bevins in the Express, Ali has taken up gruelling daily runs to turn himself into a lean, mean fighting machine. Last Friday he was up and running in the north-east, mobile in hand, by 6am. Further evidence includes his rejection at a Press Gallery lunch of roast beef and Yorkshire pud for an off-the-menu risotto; his complaint that the actor who played him so well on Rory Bremner's show was "too fat"; and his status as Britney Spears's keenest and (by 31 years) oldest fan.
fields.body:
 I fear for my friend Alastair Campbell, who appears to be going through a dreadful mid-life crisis. The signs are unmistakable. According to Tony Bevins in the Express, Ali has taken up gruelling daily runs to turn himself into a lean, mean fighting machine. Last Friday he was up and running in the north-east, mobile in hand, by 6am. Further evidence includes his rejection at a Press Gallery lunch of roast beef and Yorkshire pud for an off-the-menu risotto; his complaint that the actor who played him so well on Rory Bremner's show was "too fat"; and his status as Britney Spears's keenest and (by 31 years) oldest fan.

Put it together and what have you got? Burnley's answer to Lester Burnham, the Kevin Spacey character in American Beauty (albeit without the dope and, please God, the bullet in the back of the head). Alastair, we know what you're going through. If the memory of being pulled for questioning by the Jill Dando police team makes it hard to share it with us, talk to Gordon Brown. He dyes his hair. He feels your pain. Talk to him.

 Woundingly, there is nothing from Ali's oeuvre in Best of Forum Vol 7 No 9, our Magazine of the Month. Far from concerning the Riviera Gigolo or the deep-lunged hero of Busking With Bagpipes, our first extract from this stablemate of the Express in Richard Desmond's mucky empire concerns a domestic appliance.

"I have tried wanking using a vacuum cleaner," writes AS of Shropshire, "but was very careful to wrap my penis in a thin cloth before inserting it into the tube for fear that the suction, which was very strong, would damage the skin around my shaft." Quite right to be cautious. "I once went to a dominatrix who also used a vacuum cleaner," he goes on, but since he doesn't mention if it was a Dyson or a conventional Hoover, we'd better leave it there.

 There is no room for the full list of candidates for the Turncoat of Turncoats competition which will run between now and the day Mr T calls an election. This will appear tomorrow, along with further particulars.

 Boris the Jackal Johnson has been spotted with a car again ... not this time with the Corniche convertible RR1 but posing for a photographer in Doughty Street "while leaning up against a swanky new silver BMW X5 (an upmarket 4x4)". Well, strike me pink! "The underside was rather muddied, suggesting he had taken it for a spin down some rough country tracks," our informant relates. He must have had a little deposit to make, and no harm in that. Once the motorway bridge construction industry picks up, these forays to the countryside won't be necessary. Until then, needs must as the Jackal drives.

 An email arrives about my mother's chicken soup. "I've been following the recipe as closely as I can," writes Mick McTienan."The soup has been simmering nicely since last week but I'm having difficulty keeping the water topped up ..." Thank you. And so to the giblets. After 1) quartering the boiler, 2) bringing to boil in saucepan full of water, 3) turning flame down to simmer and skimming thrice, and 4) simmering very slowly for two hours ... we arrive at 5) wash neck, gizzard and heart and insert (but not liver); 6) add one large onion (not Spanish), two carrots, two sticks of celery and petrushka (a white root); 7) add salt and pepper; 8) bring back to boil and skim again; 9) simmer with lid on for a further two hours. Eggs next.

 In a bid to resolve the escalating crisis over selecting a Book of the Month from between Peter Hitchens's Monday Morning Blues and Steve Chalke's He Never Said - Discover the Real Message of Jesus, the Lord moves in unmysterious ways. All he did, by way of portent, was stick the Diary vicar on the radio on Monday night when I chanced to tune in, and Steve's latest profundities will debut tomorrow.

webTitle: Kelda chief appeals for help to save water industry

fields.headline: Kelda chief appeals for help to save water industry
fields.trailText: Kelda, the water and sewerage group, yesterday appealed to ministers and the regulator Ofwat for a strategic review of the UK industry to help it meet its investment needs and save it from foreign takeover.
fields.body:
Kelda, the water and sewerage group, yesterday appealed to ministers and the regulator Ofwat for a strategic review of the UK industry to help it meet its investment needs and save it from foreign takeover.

John Napier, the group's chairman, said the current "penal" regulatory controls and uncertainty about future structures were "crucifying an essential industry" already 51% in foreign hands.

He said: "Why can't we be allowed to make a slightly higher return in exchange for significantly higher rates of investment? The sums involved for consumers are so modest."

He suggested that bills, now averaging £4 a week, would have to rise only slightly if Ofwat allowed the industry to increase its rate of return and gain access to lower-cost capital to invest in meeting increasingly tough environmental standards.

Behind Mr Napier's passionate plea to ministers to "show leadership" is Ofwat's rejection last summer of Kelda's plans to return Yorkshire Water to its customers in the form of a mutual and then to run and manage its operations in an exclusive three- to five-year contract.

These plans came in response to the decision by the then regulator, Sir Ian Byatt, to impose a 14.5% price cut on Yorkshire Water, a reduction that took its toll with yesterday's news that Kelda's first-half pre-tax profits slumped from £122.2m to £81m.

The high court has since ruled that outsourcing of water and sewerage services management must be put out to competitive tender and Glas Cymru, a not-for-profit "people's company", has submitted an agreed £1.85bn bid to acquire Welsh Water. Sir Ian's successor, Philip Fletcher, is due to rule on the Welsh case early in the new year.

Mr Napier is worried that European groups such as the French Vivendi and Suez Lyonnaise and German RWE, which recently bought Thames Water for £6bn, could win the bulk of outsourcing contracts and effectively take over UK Water plc.

webTitle: House prices take off again

fields.headline: House prices take off again
fields.trailText: Further evidence that the recovery in the housing market is gathering strength emerged yesterday after the Halifax said house prices rose by 0.4% last month.
fields.body:
Further evidence that the recovery in the housing market is gathering strength emerged yesterday after the Halifax said house prices rose by 0.4% last month.

In October the average property price rose to £88,613 from £86,289, pushing up the annual rate of house price inflation from 5.7% to 7.1%. Prices paid by first-time buyers fell during the month, to £61,038 from £61,412, but rose strongly among other buyers, from £101,718 to £103,382.

Average house prices fell in four out of the five months between February and June but have since been on an upward trend apart from a 0.2% fall in October.

"The underlying trend shows that house prices have been increasing at a moderate pace since June on a monthly basis," Halifax said. Its figures accord with Nationwide's index, which showed a 0.9% rise in prices in November.

Rising prices mean further pain for low-paid workers such as nurses and teachers who are being priced out of the housing market. A report this week showed average house prices have risen 135% in real terms over the past 30 years, compared to a rise in salaries of just 60%.

Howard Davies, financial services authority chairman, warned this week of house prices in the "danger zone", particularly in the London area.

But Halifax says its figures show house prices are not above the long-term average. It says that since 1983 house prices have averaged 3.7 times average income, reaching a peak of 5.0 in May 1989 but standing at 3.6 times income today.

It adds that house price rises will slow next year to about 4%, little more than the average growth in earnings.

"Housing demand should continue to be underpinned by a sound economic background and affordability levels that are broadly in line with long-term averages over the next few months.

"However, slowing economic growth during the coming quarters is likely to constrain housing demand and house price growth."

In today's Queen's Speech, the government is expected to announce a home selling bill which is intended to speed up transactions and reduce gazumping. The bill is expected to require sellers to prepare a pack, costing £500-£600, shifting much of the responsibility for gathering information about a property from buyer to seller.

When home owners put properties on the market they will have to provide information including a local search, a survey, a draft contract and replies to standard inquiries. The legislation is likely to come into force in 2003.

Not everyone shares the government's enthusiasm for the new rules, despite the claimed success of a pilot scheme in Bristol. Although a £500 bill for preparing the pack might be relatively painless for a Londoner selling a £250,000 house, it could deter the many vendors with houses worth less than the £88,000 average.

Some critics warn that the changes will be a severe blow to the market by tipping the balance for sellers who are in undecided about whether or not to move.

webTitle: Sci-fi  Ford and government agency take car design into the future

fields.headline: Sci-fi  Ford and government agency take car design into the future
fields.trailText: Holograms may soon be used to design the cars and tanks of the future as a result of a science-fiction style project announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Holograms may soon be used to design the cars and tanks of the future as a result of a science-fiction style project announced yesterday.

Ford is teaming up with the government's defence evaluation and research agency to take computer aided design (CAD) into a new era, pictured above.

The two organisations have formed a multi-million pound joint venture to develop a system that enables designers and engineers to work together on 3D holograms.

Special gloves or tools will enable the designers to reach into a 3D image of an object projected in front of their screens and manipulate it.

Tom Scott, Ford's advanced design director, said a designer would, for example, be able to change the appearance of a model by moving the wheels further apart and then view the result from all angles.

He could "sit" behind the steering wheel in the computer generated hologram and see the effect of changing the dashboard layout. Eventually he might be able to hear the sound made by a knock on the car's body.

The commercial benefit of such a system to Ford will be the ability to reduce design times and do away with costly reworking of full-scale clay models and prototypes created by conventional CAD systems.

Mr Scott said that the brain made allowances for various visual clues thrown up by CAD systems, and the problems only became apparent when the scale model was made.

The US motor industry alone spends more than $100bn (£69bn) a year on reworking CAD designs. The new system will enable the designer to scale up the area he is working on, see all the clues and make the corrections immediately.

Ford said that senior management decisions on new models would be taken much earlier on the basis of quality information.

The time from starting a design to delivering a model to the market, which has fallen from five years to two years in recent years, could be reduced still further.

Photograph: Tom Davey

webTitle: Nasdaq warned off by Lord Mayor

fields.headline: Nasdaq warned off by Lord Mayor
fields.trailText: The Lord Mayor of London, Charles Howard, yesterday fired a warning shot across the bows of Nasdaq by expressing opposition to any attempted takeover of the London Stock Exchange by the technology-heavy US bourse.
fields.body:
The Lord Mayor of London, Charles Howard, yesterday fired a warning shot across the bows of Nasdaq by expressing opposition to any attempted takeover of the London Stock Exchange by the technology-heavy US bourse.

Mr Howard, chairman of private client stockbroker Charles Stanley, said it was not in London's best interests for the LSE to join hands with the Americans unless it was an "even-handed" partnership.

He confirmed that Nasdaq officials had been pressing their case with Charles Stanley and other stockbroking firms over recent weeks .

But the mayor, who took office less than a month ago, is concerned about the London exchange becoming the subsidiary of a foreign concern.

He believes this would pose regulatory problems and potentially could cause political friction if there were to be a confrontation between an Anglo-US exchange and a rival alliance in mainland Europe.

But some sort of partnership with Nasdaq would have attractions, particularly if it allowed London firms to become members of and trade on the US exchange, Mr Howard said.

He favoured a partnership of the LSE, Nasdaq, Deutsche Börse and Euronext, the merged Paris, Brussels and Amsterdam exchanges. However, he conceded that this was "not realistic".

There was potential, too, for an alliance with Sweden's OM, which failed to clinch an audacious hostile bid for the LSE.

Mr Howard has just returned from Sweden where he assured government officials that the OM bid had not damaged its reputation in London.

OM was an "obvious" joint venture partner for London, although he stressed there would be no place for any further attempt by the Swedes to gain ownership.

Speaking at a media lunch, Mr Howard defended LSE chairman Don Cruickshank, who was attacked by MPs last month for providing "dismal leadership".

webTitle: Obituaries: Lord Cowdrey of Tonbridge

fields.headline: Lord Cowdrey of Tonbridge
fields.standfirst: Outstanding Kent and England batsman who captained his country with courage and tenacity in a life devoted to cricket
fields.trailText: Outstanding Kent and England batsman who captained his country with courage and tenacity in a life devoted to cricket
fields.body:
Colin Cowdrey, the former Kent and England batsman, who has died aged 67, was the first cricketer to gain 100 Test caps, and one of the game's enigmas. A right-hander of an elegance matched only by Tom Graveney among his contemporaries, and courageous as they come, he made 42,719 first-class runs, 7,624 of them in 114 Tests at an average of 44.06, with 22 of his 107 centuries coming in them. He made a thousand runs in a season 27 times, a tally surpassed only by WG Grace and Frank Woolley.

He was adept on front or back foot, easing the ball to the boundary rather than belting it - "hard enough for four is hard enough", he would say. He could swivel to pull the fastest bowlers, and developed a paddle sweep from an upright stance to fine leg off the spinners. His comfortable bulk belied an agility that made him a top-class slip fielder, and his 120 catches, a world Test record at the time, has been exceeded since by only five other cricketers, none of them English.

As well as leading Kent from 1957 to 1971, Cowdrey also captained England on 27 occasions, but in five stints, having had trouble convincing the selectors that he had the necessary steel or drive and dynamism for the job. It was said that he was too sensitive - and too fond of cricketers to want to upset them with uncomfortable decisions - and, at various stages, he lost the captaincy to Peter May, Ted Dexter, Brian Close, and Raymond Illingworth, each of whom had no such inhibitions.

To Cowdrey's immense disappointment, not one of his six Ashes tours was as captain, and he thought long and hard before accepting the vice-captaincy under Illingworth in 1971-72, a trip on which he failed to do himself justice. He was awarded the CBE in 1972, knighted 20 years on and elevated to the peerage, as Baron Cowdrey of Tonbridge, in 1997.

Cowdrey was a complex character given to passages where his play reached sublime levels, but then subject to such bemusing introspection that ordinary journeymen county bowlers could be made to seem world-beaters. At his best, the fastest bowlers could be caressed around the field as if medium pace; at his most reflective, when he scratched around for no reward, he was infuriating to those who recognised a supreme talent. The game was either incredibly simple or bafflingly complex, depending on his mood.

He was not universally popular within the game, despite a beaming benevolent exterior, innate kindliness and chivalry towards his opponents, and he had his enemies. Many mistrusted him, for example, for his ethics of "walking" for obvious decisions, and then not doing so for the less obvious, in the hope that his reputation would fool the umpire, although he was by no means alone in this gamesmanship.

Perhaps any antipathy had something to do with the fact that Cowdrey - Tonbridge school and Brasenose College, Oxford - had been an amateur playing in an increasingly professional game, turning up for matches in his Jaguar - registration MCC 307 to mark his initials and highest score - already changed in his pristine tailored flannels and blazer, and departing at close of play likewise. Maybe, as well, they resented the notion that his crust did not depend on his success at the crease, and so he could afford to be less pragmatic than them. It is hard to get close to players in those circumstances.

Later in life, his connection with cricket continued, at first as president of the MCC during the club's bicentenary in 1987, and then as president of the International Cricket Council, potentially the most powerful administrative position in the sport, during which time he introduced an international code of conduct and match referees to help clean up the tarnished image of the game, and oversaw the reintroduction of South Africa to international cricket.

He was, however, regarded as indecisive and malleable, and was pressurised into allowing the decision to hold the 1996 World Cup in England to be overturned. It went to the sub-continent.

Born in Putumala, India, it seemed that Cowdrey was destined for the game from the moment that his cricket-mad father, a tea planter in Bangalore, gave him the initials MCC. He was regarded as an infant prodigy; his enthusiasm was said to have been fuelled by a letter he received from Jack Hobbs as a seven-year-old after winning a bat for scoring 93 in an inter-school match.

He went on to become an outstanding schools player, having been introduced to the Tonbridge first XI at the age of 13, primarily as a legspinner but working his way up to No 3 batsman. He was the youngest schoolboy to appear in a match at Lord's, when he made 75 and 44 and took eight wickets, and actually played for Kent while still at school, becoming their youngest ever capped player at 18.

Cowdrey might well have played for England while still at Oxford, but, at the age of 21, he found himself on the boat to Australia with Len Hutton's Ashes-winning side of 1954-55. His third Test, over new year and in front of 63,000 spectators in the vast Melbourne cricket ground, brought his first, and, many argue, his finest Test hundred - 102 made out of a total of 191, an innings on an unreliable pitch, which rescued England from a Lindwall-Miller induced 41 for four, and set the ground for Frank Tyson to blast his side to victory. Later in the tour, he made a century in each innings against New South Wales.

Two years on, Cowdrey and Peter May compiled what was then the highest partnership for any wicket in Tests, and which remains the highest for the fourth wicket, when they added 411 together against West Indies at Edgbaston, Cowdrey devising his own method of frustrating the mysterious West Indian spinner, Sonny Ramadhin, by judicious use of the front pad as a second, and frequently first, line of defence.

May made 285 not out and Cowdrey 154, the first time he had made a Test hundred through occupation rather than strokeplay, and together they ensured that Ramadhin, who had shouted himself hoarse appealing to no avail for lbw against Cowdrey, was never the same force again.

In 1963, as the Lord's Test against West Indies headed towards a thrilling climax, Cowdrey contributed one of the game's most dramatic moments. In the second innings, he had had his left wrist fractured by a rising ball from Wes Hall, and now, with just two balls of the match remaining, six runs needed and no further wickets in hand other than his, he reappeared, beaming, down the steps, arm in plaster, ready to face, if necessary, the final ball. His fortitude was not tested, and the match was drawn.

Early in 1968, he led England to victory in the series in the Caribbean, the last time an England captain has done so. The clinching match came in the fourth Test in Trinidad after three mundane draws. His go-slow tactics so infuriated the West Indies captain, Garfield Sobers, that he declared with a meagre lead and time in hand, allowing England to win the match, and ultimately the series.

But even then it took some gentle, last-ditch persuasion from Graveney and John Edrich before Cowdrey agreed the run chase should be attempted. Typically, having been convinced of the viability, his calm, controlled 71 helped win the day. Sobers has never been forgiven his indiscretion, and his effigy was burnt throughout the Caribbean.

In 1974, at the age of 41, Cowdrey enjoyed a fine season, and might have expected to tour Australia for a seventh time that winter. However, although omitted from Mike Denness's party, he received an emergency call from a side that was in the process of being worked over on fast uncompromising pitches by Dennis Lillee and Jeff Thomson.

Five days after arriving in Perth, and three years since he had last played a Test, he was facing the duo on the fastest pitch in the world - and acquitting himself courageously with scores of 22 and 41, giving an astounding display of defensive batting against high pace. It was to be his last series.

The following season was to be his final one with Kent, and, six months after the battering in Australia, he marked it in the finest style by scoring 151 not out at Canterbury, as the county successfully chased 354 to beat the Australians by four wickets. It was his last century, and the grandest of hurrahs on the ground he cherished.

Cowdrey's private life was not without controversy. In 1956, he married Penny Chiesman, whose family were wealthy store-owners in Kent, and together they had three sons and a daughter. Two of the sons, Chris and Graham, went on to play for Kent; Chris also saw six Tests for England, five during David Gower's successful tour of India in 1984-85, and one, against West Indies at Headingley in 1988, as captain. When Chris took his first Test wicket, Cowdrey senior, listening in his car, marked the occasion by driving in astonishment the wrong way up a one-way street and receiving a caution.

That same year, he divorced Penny and married one of the daughters of the Duke of Norfolk, Lady Herries of Terregles. The family lived at Angmering Park, Littlehampton, where Cowdrey died; he had suffered a stroke in July. His wife survives him, as do his children.

Michael Colin Cowdrey, Lord Cowdrey of Tonbridge, cricketer, born December 24 1932; died December 5 2000

webTitle: Hopes of 3p off petrol as oil price falls

fields.headline: Hopes of 3p off petrol as oil price falls
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Motorists could see petrol prices fall by as much as 3p a litre in the coming weeks after world oil prices fell yesterday and hopes rose that Iraq would soon resume crude exports, writes Mark Atkinson.
fields.body:
Motorists could see petrol prices fall by as much as 3p a litre in the coming weeks after world oil prices fell yesterday and hopes rose that Iraq would soon resume crude exports, writes Mark Atkinson.

London Brent fell 70 cents to $28.60 a barrel, the first time it has dropped below $29 a barrel in four months, while US light crude shed 82 cents to $30.40.

Brent has fallen more than $3 since last Thursday, despite the stoppage by Iraq of crude sales under its oil-for-food exchange with the United Nations. Baghdad wants to charge customers a 50 cents surcharge to be paid into an Iraqi account outside UN control.

Iraq's Oil Minister Amir Rasheed said yesterday that he was hopeful that the dispute could be resolved quickly. He confirmed to the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) that Iraq was having urgent negotiations with the UN and a solution could be found in the next day or two.

Average British pump prices stand at 81.7p a litre. "At the very least we are looking towards two to three pence off a litre (of unleaded)," said Stephen Brooks, a petrol consultant at Wood Mackenzie. Gross retail margins were now in excess of 8p a litre.

webTitle: Pay cuts on the way as care crisis bites

fields.headline: Pay cuts on the way as care crisis bites
fields.trailText: The mounting crisis in the care home sector is starting to hit staff, with the GMB general union claiming that employees of Servite Houses, in London, face earnings cuts of up to £250 a month under new contracts.
fields.body:
The mounting crisis in the care home sector is starting to hit staff, with the GMB general union claiming that employees of Servite Houses, in London, face earnings cuts of up to £250 a month under new contracts.

Servite is among care home providers reviewing staff costs in an effort to balance the books. Martin Smith, GMB regional organiser, says: "Cutting wages cuts care levels, so the current position is self-defeating. You can't have high standards and cheap labour."

According to Servite, the new contracts have been accepted by a majority of staff concerned. The GMB, it says, represents only a small minority. Although some staff do face a shorter working week, with corresponding reduction of hourly earnings, many of them will in practice make up any shortfall through overtime.

"We are under increased economic pressure," says a company spokeswoman.

The Servite dispute comes ahead of next week's first meeting of a "strategic group" set up by the government to develop a concordat between care home providers and local authorities. Under the plan, local - and health - authorities will be urged to act to stimulate development of care home capacity where there is an evident shortage.

Official figures published last week suggest that the number of residential homes in England remained broadly stable at April 2000, compared to April 1999, but that the number of nursing homes fell 4% - equivalent to a loss of 8,000 beds.

Home operators say they are fighting a losing battle for survival, as local authorities squeeze payment rates for state-funded residents. In one case, a nursing home run by Highcare Group, in Bridgwater, Somerset, is planning to evict 13 residents by December 22 in a dispute over fees.

webTitle: Refugees revel in a breath of fresh air

fields.headline: Refugees revel in a breath of fresh air
fields.standfirst: Sue Beenstock reports on a project that helps refugees escape the city and make new friends
fields.trailText: Sue Beenstock reports on a project that helps refugees escape the city and make new friends
fields.body:
It's typical tree-planting weather: wintery, with a stiff breeze blowing off Loch Lomond. The mist clears and the hills beneath are the dull russets and greens of an ageing Cox's apple. But the band of stalwarts out planting saplings on a Saturday morning are not your typical conservation enthusiasts. All arrived in Britain just a few months ago. They are still struggling to learn English, find schools and nursery places for their kids, survive on vouchers and a few pounds in cash each week and get used to life on Glasgow housing estates. You might think that replanting a native forest in Cashel Farm, a 40-minute drive north of Glasgow, would be low on their list of priorities. You'd be wrong.

Nasrin, a hairdresser, and her engineer husband and their two children, aged 10 and four, came to Britain from Iran five months ago. After two weeks sitting on the bare floor of a truck, they arrived in Dover sick and exhausted, but within a couple of weeks of being sent to Glasgow, they'd heard about a unique project run by the Black Environment Network (BEN), the Scottish Refugee Council and British Trust for Conservation Volunteers.

"We came every month from then on," says Nasrin, keeping an eye on her children, who are chasing each other round the saplings. "It's green and beautiful and there is clean air here. In Iran, we would go to the countryside every two weeks, and for children there was the park, the cinema, many other entertainments. But here we have nothing, nothing."

Her eldest child, Ashkan, can go to school, but there's no nursery place for their pre-school daughter and she has no opportunity to mix with other children. "This is a big space for all the children to play," says Nasrin. "We like the lake and the people are so friendly. If we couldn't come for some reason, my children would go mad - they have so much energy."

They're not the only ones. Sorour and her five-year-old daughter Sheida are also regular attendees. Unlike Nasrin and her family, Sorour fled Iran without her husband. "I was in danger, so we had to leave," she says. "I could complain to you about many things here in Glasgow, and I will. But coming on our nature days is fantastic. It is something ordinary; we are treated like normal people."

It is also a rare chance for Sorour to meet other Iranians and refugees, with whom she can chat and share advice and experiences in a relaxing and sociable atmosphere. Lunch is a boisterous affair and often means Iranians, Iraqis, Scots, Somalians, Pakistanis and Nigerians sitting round a table tucking into a help-yourself lunch of sandwiches, olives, dates, fresh fruit - and lots of noisy chat.

"Excuse me," says Dorna, a primary school teacher from Isfahan, in Iran, turning to a student from Glasgow University, as they tuck into sandwiches. "What do you think the British government is doing to improve relations with Iran?" There is a silence. "I'm not sure," he answers truthfully. "Probably not much."

During the day, everyone plants a tree and writes a dedication that will eventually appear in a book recording the Cashel Forest For A Thousand Years project. "To my father," says one. "For my grandfather," writes another. And others put: "To the people of Scotland" - all written in a slow and careful hand.

According to Elaine Gibb, development worker at BEN, the day is as much about socialising in the fresh air as getting involved with environmental conservation. "This isn't hardcore environmental action," she admits. "For most people here today, it's a family day out. But on other trips we've had people along who will take their volunteering and an involvement in conservation further."

Two such people are Nigel, from Somalia (see below), and Ranna Judge, 39, from Pakistan. "I feel as if I'm making myself helpful," says Judge, a full-time student who has lived in Glasgow for 10 years. "I'm having problems getting citizenship. I use the Refugee Council drop-in centre and although I'm asthmatic, when a friend mentioned this project, I knew I'd love to work outdoors. I have no garden and live in a polluted area, so this is a wonderful chance to be in the countryside, to try to improve our environment - and volunteering is very much part of my culture."

But for most, the idea of volunteering isn't a primary reason for getting involved. "You may say we are volunteers, and I agree that it is good to put something back," says Fred Anafchi, 22, from Iran. "But it is also a lovely day out, it is free and, for us, who can never get out of the city, this is fresh air and peacefulness. In return, we plant trees."

Nature's comforts

Nigel, 17, has lived alone in Glasgow since fleeing Somalia following the murder of his father and death threats to him and his mother. He is studying for Highers and hopes to go on to do aeronautical engineering at university. He is a fluent English speaker since this was the common language between his Somalian mother and Brazilian father.

"My father was mayor of Mogadishu and was murdered on February 14 this year," he says. "My mother was pregnant with my only sibling at the time and she fled elsewhere in Africa, I have no idea where, but the Red Cross is helping me to trace her. I left shortly after her, hiding in a cargo plane.

"In Glasgow, I am alone, but I can look after myself. The difficulty is that it's hard to get out of the city. Like most refugees, I've less than £10 a week in cash. I love being in the countryside. You need that time; it helps you to understand your new life, get to know the place and the people, and also it's a comfort to feel that the cycle of nature continues even when people's lives are over.

"To me that is so important. I needed it in Somalia and I need it even more here."
