According to Elaine Gibb, development worker at BEN, the day is as much about socialising in the fresh air as getting involved with environmental conservation. "This isn't hardcore environmental action," she admits. "For most people here today, it's a family day out. But on other trips we've had people along who will take their volunteering and an involvement in conservation further." Two such people are Nigel, from Somalia (see below), and Ranna Judge, 39, from Pakistan. "I feel as if I'm making myself helpful," says Judge, a full-time student who has lived in Glasgow for 10 years. "I'm having problems getting citizenship. I use the Refugee Council drop-in centre and although I'm asthmatic, when a friend mentioned this project, I knew I'd love to work outdoors. I have no garden and live in a polluted area, so this is a wonderful chance to be in the countryside, to try to improve our environment - and volunteering is very much part of my culture." But for most, the idea of volunteering isn't a primary reason for getting involved. "You may say we are volunteers, and I agree that it is good to put something back," says Fred Anafchi, 22, from Iran. "But it is also a lovely day out, it is free and, for us, who can never get out of the city, this is fresh air and peacefulness. In return, we plant trees." Nature's comforts Nigel, 17, has lived alone in Glasgow since fleeing Somalia following the murder of his father and death threats to him and his mother. He is studying for Highers and hopes to go on to do aeronautical engineering at university. He is a fluent English speaker since this was the common language between his Somalian mother and Brazilian father. "My father was mayor of Mogadishu and was murdered on February 14 this year," he says. "My mother was pregnant with my only sibling at the time and she fled elsewhere in Africa, I have no idea where, but the Red Cross is helping me to trace her. I left shortly after her, hiding in a cargo plane. "In Glasgow, I am alone, but I can look after myself. The difficulty is that it's hard to get out of the city. Like most refugees, I've less than £10 a week in cash. I love being in the countryside. You need that time; it helps you to understand your new life, get to know the place and the people, and also it's a comfort to feel that the cycle of nature continues even when people's lives are over. "To me that is so important. I needed it in Somalia and I need it even more here."

webTitle: Urban areas adopt parish democracy

fields.headline: Urban areas adopt parish democracy
fields.standfirst: With local democracy in crisis around the country, as election turnouts in inner cities plunge to well below 20%, the slow revival of parish government - labelled micro-democracy - has finally been recognised by the government as an idea worth developing.
fields.trailText: With local democracy in crisis around the country, as election turnouts in inner cities plunge to well below 20%, the slow revival of parish government - labelled micro-democracy - has finally been recognised by the government as an idea worth developing, writes Peter Hetherington
fields.body:
Ken Ralphs can best be described as an active citizen. As chairman of the residents' association on the Offerton estate in Stockport, Greater Manchester, his relentless campaigning for a parish council put him on a collision course with the Liberal Democrats, who run the metropolitan authority.

The Lib Dems, self-styled community champions themselves, seemed unkeen on the idea of someone else campaigning for grassroots democracy. They threw everything against Mr Ralphs, including the results of a "survey" designed to show that his initiative was unpopular.

After battling for more than a year, and sending the council a statutory petition outlining support from at least 10% of residents, Mr Ralphs has finally won the argument. Offerton (population 4,165) is in line for a parish council, with the approval of the deputy prime minister, John Prescott. Giving the go-ahead, Mr Prescott's officials recently told Mr Ralphs, a security guard and caterer, that they would be consulting "in due course" on a draft order setting up the council.

Offerton will join another 60 parish councils created in the past three years alone, bringing the total - including small town councils - to more than 10,000 in England and Wales. With local democracy in crisis around the country, as election turnouts in inner cities plunge to well below 20%, the slow revival of parish government - what some have labelled micro-democracy - has finally been recognised by the government as an idea worth developing.

In last week's rural white paper, Mr Prescott offered parish and town councils a stronger role and wider powers to promote community life. They will be invited to prepare village and town plans and encouraged to deliver wider services beyond, say, providing allotments, maintaining churchyards and protecting common land and greens. With the agreement of district and county councils, these new services could include responsibility for litter collection, maintaining street lighting and managing a range of other local facilities. Parishes will also be able to apply for a £10,000 grant to buy, or fund, community transport - from a taxi to a people carrier.

But, as one parish chairman remarked, the devil is in the detail: councils will have to pass a "quality test" to show they are competent and democratic. Before drawing up detailed plans, the government will consult with the Local Government Association and other bodies, although ministers have raised the prospect of "piloted, innovative and imaginative" partnerships involving "quality councils".

Far from seeing this as a fudge, the National Association of Local Councils (NALC) - the voice of parish and town government - believes the white paper has opened the way for a significant expansion in the number of councils and the range of services offered.

"Giving parishes and town councils a greater role is all about giving a local voice back to the people," said John Findlay, the NALC's chief executive. "This is about common sense government. Where it is efficient and sensible, the government clearly wants to see services moving down to town and parish level."

Parish and town government, in fact, is bigger than many realise: the 10,000 councils (with 80,000 councillors) employ more than 25,000 staff, full and part-time, and annual spending exceeds £200m. Funded by a small precept on council tax, total spending in any financial year cannot exceed £3.50 per elector in parish or town. But under the 1997 Local Government Act, local people can decide where to draw the boundaries of their new parish and, within reason, what powers they want to take on.

As Mr Ralphs can testify, this can be easier said than done. His complaint is a familiar one. "We were tired of waiting for improvements to the estate, felt it was being left to rot, and wanted to take more control of things," he said. "For years, the community had been neglected - nowhere for kids to play, no community centre - and then I found out about parish councils and thought: 'This will do for us.'"

Offerton may be a far cry from the popular image of a rural parish, but the complaints about remote government and out-of-touch officialdom are heard in city and shire.

To be fair, not every large council is obstructive. In Birmingham, campaigners for a parish in the Frankley area have been applauded by the city council. When they presented their petition for parish status, with the required 10% support, they were even granted a civic reception.

 Peter Hetherington is the Guardian's regional affairs correspondent. His booklet on local democracy, First Thoughts on a Local Constitution: Back to the Future?, is available at £7.50 inc. from IDeA Publication Sales, Layden House, Turnmill Street, London EC1M 5LG (020-7296 6600).

webTitle: 'No blame' culture for bullies is not a soft option

fields.headline: 'No blame' culture for bullies is not a soft option
fields.standfirst: Long before the tragis death of Damilola, the Family Service Unit was getting bullies to face up to their behaviour
fields.trailText: Comment: Long before the tragis death of Damilola, the Family Service Unit was getting bullies to face up to their behaviour, writes Malcolm Dean
fields.body:
The behaviour is probably as old as man. It affects all age groups but is most acute - both as victims and perpetrators - among children. Yet, until recently, the problem was ignored. Now, following the tragic murder of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor, it is front page news. But will ministers adopt the right approach to bullying?

A front-page splash in the Times on Saturday suggested ministers would shift the emphasis away from the current "no blame" culture embraced by the 1994 official guidance. New guidance is being promised before Christmas. An election approaches. No doubt the Mail would applaud a more macho approach - not just for schools but for children's homes, hostels and youth clubs.

Do not despair. Ministers were planning a new initiative before Damilola's death. David Blunkett had already agreed to be the keynote speaker at a one-day conference on a non-punitive approach to anti-bullying next Wednesday (Details: 0207-402 5175). It is being run by the Family Service Units (FSU), which helps support 27,500 inner-city children from 19 centres.

The problem with "no blame" is not its approach but its name. It implies exoneration and escape for perpetrators. But it is much more subtle than that. It tackles head on the biggest challenge: persuading children to tell. Victims are worried by the reaction of tormentors. Hence the importance of involving both bullied and bullies in solutions. Recent surveys suggest that the mushrooming of new schemes - peer counsellors, support groups, mediation - has helped cut refusal to tell from 50% to 30%.

"No blame" began in the early 1990s. Bullied and bullies, who are not identified, join with neutrals to bring out the problem and talk it through. Each pupil is required to propose a solution. FSU teams have made two further developments. The first, with 12 pilots under way, is a support code for an entire school or children's home. The aim is to involve entire institutions "because it is bystanders who allow bullying". The goal is to reduce aggression and promote caring skills.

The second, set up in Leeds, is a pro-active group of 13 to 16-year-olds helping victims. Started by a multi-racial group of the bullied and bullies, they've made a video of their work and are already on the lecture circuit. They've learned about conflict, been taught mediation skills and understand the importance of getting all people involved to sort out a solution. As they sing on their video: "If you are not part of the solution, you are a part of the problem." But please, "no blame", change your name. You sound like a soft option - even though you are subtly forcing bullies to face up to their behaviour.

Feedback: do you agree? Please send your comments to editor@societytheguardian.com

webTitle: UK in flood: the hidden damage

fields.headline: UK in flood: the hidden damage
fields.standfirst: What happens when floods are no longer front page news? Judy Hirst reports on how councils and voluntary agencies are trying to deal with the human damage from Britain's worst hit areas
fields.trailText: What happens when floods are no longer front page news? Judy Hirst reports on how councils and voluntary agencies are trying to deal with the human damage from Britain's worst hit areas
fields.body:
Five-year old Shannon is still having nightmares and cries a lot. She was rescued by lifeboat out of her first-floor flat window, with 15 feet of water swirling menacingly beneath. Now she won't take a bath or go swimming, and doesn't want to go to school. As with many other children at her school in Lewes, east Sussex, the recent floods have left her anxious and withdrawn.

Unlike in countries such as Bangladesh or Mozambique, severe flooding causes few physical health risks in industrialised nations. The residents of Lewes or York are unlikely to go down with dysentry or cholera.

However, up to 20% of natural disaster victims may suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder. Many will feel depressed and isolated, losing their sense of place and attachment, or developing obsessive anxieties as a result of their ordeal. The British Medical Journal has recently highlighted that the psychological costs of climate change are likely to be considerable.

"Shannon needs help," says her mother, Irene Hoad. And so does Irene. A young, single parent, she relied heavily on the network of neighbours in her block. Now all the ground-floor tenants have gone, decanted from their sodden, ruined homes into temporary accommodation. The council says it will take until next summer to make their homes habitable. Most will not be coming back.

Four hundred families were made homeless by the Lewes floods. A third of them had no insurance or were underinsured. According to the Association of British Insurers (ABI) an estimated six million homeowners do not have contents cover. Some are living out of mobile homes in their gardens. Many more are in caravans, B&Bs and rented accommodation all over the district. And some, the council frankly admits, it doesn't have a clue about. With families displaced and split up, and anxieties about insurance mounting by the day, the floods are taking a huge emotional toll.

The good news is that increased social support, along with practical help, can significantly mitigate the less quantifiable psychological effects. By and large, though, this is being left up to voluntary agencies and community-minded individuals to provide.

In Lewes, it's the volunteer bureau - run on a shoestring and under threat of closure - that's helping the uninsured to clear out their homes, get together some clothes and furniture, and start rebuilding their lives. A charitable "hardship" fund has also been set up to distribute to residents who have suffered distress. To date, more than £140,000 has been raised - much of it from members of the public.

Mind, Age Concern and East Sussex Disability Association are among the voluntary groups which have set up a flood aftercare group with social services funding. More than 100 calls to the helpline range from people desperate to find a dehumidifier, to parents of children with drowned pets, to those - often with previous psychological problems - who have been deeply disturbed by the recent events. Many just want to talk. The more severely affected are being offered counselling and other specialist services.

It's not just the flood victims who need support. There's the bin man who broke down in tears after clearing out countless contaminated homes; the firefighter racked with guilt because he was out helping others when his own family's home was flooded; the care staff dealing with loss and trauma at emergency centres. Many of these workers need a chance to unburden their own feelings.

"The full impact of these floods is unlikely to be felt for some time," says Phil Dodgson, head of adult psychology services at South Downs health trust, Sussex. "Many people will be experiencing anger, guilt and feelings of dread. Some, the ones having persistent flash-backs or feeling very depressed and confused, will need help to reprocess their feelings."

The psychological effect of severe flooding, as compared with a train crash or other major trauma, should not be underestimated, he says. The speed and force with which the water has risen, smashing down doors and sending furniture crashing against walls, has thrown whole communities into a state of shock.

The most vulnerable people at a time like this are the young, old, disabled and mentally ill. In Crawley, West Sussex, 42 frail, elderly residents of a care home had to be evacuated in the early hours because the ground floor was under water. They left without anything, in their nightclothes, and ended up dispersed all over the county to residential homes as far away as Worthing. With few vacancies nearby, and their care home badly damaged, instant decisions had to be made about whether these transfers would be short-term or long-term. "The psychological effect on these residents can only be imagined," says local operations manager, Pat Howe.

In York, too, emergency decisions had to be made about evacuating elderly people when the River Ouse burst its banks. In one case, the community services director, Jim Crook, opted for sandbagging a care home which has very dependent residents, rather than risk moving them. Fortunately, the gamble paid off.

In another instance, there was no choice. Thirty-five older residents had to be moved out of their riverside sheltered homes, and into temporary accommodation, after the floods took out a local power station. York's joint social services and housing department was able to do this relatively efficiently, Crook says, and to help the emergency services identify the most vulnerable people thoughout the worst of the flooding.

For Peter Smurthwaite, who is severely visually impaired, the floods brought not just shock, trauma and the loss of his Lewes home, but also endless battles with his insurers over whether he can stay in a town where he knows his way around, or whether he must move to cheaper temporary accommodation miles away.

East Sussex social services, like many around the country, has been hard-pressed to make even these imperfect arrangements. "Because of the pressures on our community care budget, there's a lot less in-house provision," says Phil Gander, head of mental health services. "We can't find money to ease bed-blocking, let alone provide an emergency infrastructure for evacuees."

It was the aftercare group, run by Mind and other voluntary groups, that laid on a creche for flood-hit families, and which is starting up counselling sessions in Shannon's school. Irene hopes they will help. Sitting in her sunny living room, on a crisp cold morning, it's hard to imagine the day, just a few weeks ago, when the water came from nowhere, turning the road outside into a torrent. But it was real enough, and there have been several flood warnings since.

Shannon keeps saying: "Mummy, it's happening again." Irene and her neighbours try to brush her worries aside. They're concentrating instead on giving her a really good Christmas.

Counting the cost
Alison Benjamin

The Association of British Insurers estimates that the floods may have caused up to £500m of damage. East Sussex county council and Lewes district council estimate that the cost to them is in the region of £7m. Of this, £150,000 covers the cost of short-term care packages, extra staffing and the flood aftercare group. Other councils are still counting the initial costs. Damages to bridges and roads may not be fully known until water levels have dropped considerably.

The Bellwin scheme allows councils, in theory, to claim back spending on emergencies from central government above a threshold. Currently councils have to put aside 0.2% of their budgets for emergency expenditure. A claim for any additional costs is then lodged with the government. Following the floods, deputy prime minister, John Prescott, pledged to increase the percentage the government covers from 85% to 100% of a claim.

However, East Sussex has already had the majority of its claim rejected. Council leader David Rodgers says: "We have been disappointed by the response of government to our application. It has confirmed what we thought about the scheme: it does not cover the costs of this type of disaster."

This was one of the topics on the agenda at yesterday's central-local partnership, a forum chaired by Prescott where issues affecting local government are discussed. The Local Government Association fed in the main concerns from local authorities around the country - not least, who will foot the £1.2bn bill for increased flood defences. The government has agreed to look at the whole funding mechanism.

webTitle: £100m cost of Nice advice

fields.headline: £100m cost of Nice advice
fields.standfirst: The national institute for clinical excellence has revealed that implementing its advice cost £100m last year
fields.trailText: The national institute for clinical excellence has revealed that implementing its advice cost £100m last year, writes David Brindle
fields.body:
Ministers have been told to forget any idea that their new health care appraisal agency will save money. So far, according to the man chairing the agency, it has cost "well in excess of £100m".

When the national institute for clinical excellence (Nice) was set up, it was widely seen as a means of rationing costly new drugs and procedures. But Sir Michael Rawlins, its chairman, last week told the organisation's annual conference that the cost of implementing its advice in its first full year had been more than £150m. Savings from the advice had been £47m.

Sir Michael also dismissed suggestions, fuelled by Nice's change of heart on anti-flu treatment Relenza, that the agency has been pressured by the government. There had, he said, been "no overt - or covert - attempt by ministers or officials to influence our guidance" and no guidance about available resources.

"Although the secretary of state does have reserve powers if we do 'lose the plot', we have never had a steer - formally or informally - about the nature of the guidance we should give," he insisted.

Nice's forthcoming work programme includes production of clinical guidelines for conditions ranging from dyspepsia to schizophrenia, as well as for pre-operative investigations.

Egon Jonsson, director of Nice's equivalent body in Sweden, told the conference in Harrogate that as a consequence of his agency's recommendation, routine pre-operative testing of younger patients in Swedish hospitals had all but ceased. Savings had amounted to five times the agency's budget.

As a result, Mr Jonsson said, health ministers had offered to double the budget. "Watch out, Nice, this could happen over and over again," he warned, "and it's not that easy to spend money wisely."

Mr Jonsson called for greater collaboration among appraisal bodies - of which there were 20 in Europe, assessing 600 drugs and procedures at any one time. He said: "I notice that many of the topics that Nice is going to look at are topics that many other agencies, including my own, have already done."

The British agency was uniquely strong, however. "Nice has the power to say no," Mr Jonsson said. "The potential is enormous."

webTitle: Town hall reform boldly goes further

fields.headline: Town hall reform boldly goes further
fields.standfirst: The first shake-up in town hall structures for more than a century, combined with the new best-value regime, represents unprecedented change for local authorities, writes Alison Benjamin
fields.trailText: The first shake-up in town hall structures for more than a century, combined with the new best-value regime, represents unprecedented change for local authorities, writes Alison Benjamin
fields.body:
Buckinghamshire county council this week became the latest local authority to introduce cabinet-style administration. Chief executive Ian Crookall will tomorrow be describing the transition in a presentation entitled: "It's a structure, Jim, but not as we know it."

The Star Trek allusion will strike a chord with many in local government who feel they are boldly going into the unknown. The first shake-up in town hall structures for more than a century, combined with the new best-value regime, represents unprecedented change.

Crookall will be address council leaders from across south-east England at the South East Employers (SEE) conference, which starts today in Hythe, Kent. Councillors and officers from 74 member authorities will be discussing ways to tackle the opportunities and risks presented by the government's drive to modernise municipal affairs.

"The pace of change for people in local government is enormous," says Madeleine Sumison, SEE regional director. "The trick is to identify skills and knowledge to take themselves through it. They have to focus on quality and internal procedures without losing sight of what this means externally for their citizens."

Buckinghamshire's journey to cabinet-style government has taken 18 months. The process culminated in a survey of 8,500 residents, the majority of whom backed the new approach, under which there will be lead councillors responsible for policy areas such as children's services, care services, community services, planning and transport.

Crookall says: "Some members find this level of change very threatening; others see the opportunities for the future. They are different sides of the same coin. It means more time commitment from cabinet level councillors and they will also be more high profile and accountable." His advice to others contemplating such change is: "Plan it carefully, take time, minimise risks and take everyone with you."

The conference, which is supported by the Guardian, will also look at the emergence of public/ private partnerships, such as the contract for support services at Lincolnshire county council.

Gail Shadlock, human resources manager for Hyder Business Services, has overseen the partnership. She was one of 1,000 council employees who relinquished their jobs with the authority - in her case, as head of personnel and development - to transfer to the private company.

The council went down the partnership route, says Shadlock, in a bid to secure investment, savings and growth in personnel, finance, IT, property and catering services. In the first year, IT has received a £5m cash injection. She says: "We went for a partnership, rather than outsourcing, because this way the public and the private partners have mutually agreed objectives and sit on a joint partnership board. In contrast, outsourcing can lead to a blame culture."

Middlesbrough council is about to enter a similar partnership with Hyder, starting in April. For other councils thinking of taking a similar step, Shadlock warns: "It is a major culture change and people are apprehensive. It is crucial that unions and employee representatives are involved from the start."

webTitle: Childminders say no to smacking

fields.headline: Childminders say no to smacking
fields.trailText: Childminders will today march on Downing Street against "barmy" proposals giving them the right to smack children in their care and smoke in front of them, writes Alison Benjamin
fields.body:
Registered childminders are planning today to deliver a giant postcard to Tony Blair, asking him to block proposals to give them rights to smack children in their care and smoke in front of them.

Under draft national standards on daycare and childminding issued by the government, registered childminders would be allowed to administer physical discipline to children and smoke in their presence if parental permission had been given.

Lynn Daley, chairperson of the National Childminding Association for England and Wales (NCMA), who is leading the delegation to Downing Street, calls the proposals "barmy". She said: "Registered childminders have not asked for, and do not want, these so-called rights."

The proposals are out of line with the NCMA's own quality standards, which explicitly rule out smacking or shaking as methods of controlling children's behaviour. The draft national guidelines on daycare and childminding in England cover creches, day nurseries, playgroups, after school clubs, holiday play schemes and childminders. The 14 standards, designed to introduce consistency across the country, will be used by the early years directorate - a new arm of schools inspectorate Oftsed - when it takes over the registration and inspection of childminders in England in autumn next year.

The rights to smack and smoke with parental consent apply only to childminders.

The standards, issued by the Department for Education and Employment, have been out for consultation, and responses are being considered. A department spokeswoman said: "The rationale behind the draft standards was a matter of parental choice. The government doesn't bring up children and we believe it is important to ensure continuity of discipline between parents and childminders."

webTitle: Earnings cuts on the way as care home sector crisis bites

fields.headline: Battle of the books
fields.standfirst: Earnings cuts on the way as care home sector crisis bites
fields.trailText: Earnings cuts on the way as care home sector crisis bites
fields.body:
The mounting crisis in the care home sector is starting to hit staff, with the GMB general union claiming that employees of Servite Houses, in London, face earnings cuts of up to £250 a month under new contracts.

Servite is among care home providers reviewing staff costs in an effort to balance the books. Martin Smith, GMB regional organiser, says: "Cutting wages cuts care levels, so the current position is self-defeating. You can't have high standards and cheap labour."

According to Servite, the new contracts have been accepted by a majority of staff concerned. The GMB, it says, represents only a small minority. Although some staff do face a shorter working week, with corresponding reduction of hourly earnings, many of them will in practice make up any shortfall through overtime.

"We are under increased economic pressure," says a company spokeswoman.

The Servite dispute comes ahead of next week's first meeting of a "strategic group" set up by the government to develop a concordat between care home providers and local authorities. Under the plan, local - and health - authorities will be urged to act to stimulate development of care home capacity where there is an evident shortage.

Official figures published last week suggest that the number of residential homes in England remained broadly stable at April 2000, compared to April 1999, but that the number of nursing homes fell 4% - equivalent to a loss of 8,000 beds.

Home operators say they are fighting a losing battle for survival, as local authorities squeeze payment rates for state-funded residents. In one case, a nursing home run by Highcare Group, in Bridgwater, Somerset, is planning to evict 13 residents by December 22 in a dispute over fees.

webTitle: The bucolic image of parish councils is changing rapidly

fields.headline: Pump action
fields.standfirst: The bucolic image of parish councils is changing rapidly.  Peter Hetherington on the rise of micro democracy
fields.trailText: The bucolic image of parish councils is changing rapidly. Peter Hetherington on the rise of micro democracy
fields.body:
Ken Ralphs can best be described as an active citizen. As chairman of the residents' association on the Offerton estate in Stockport, Greater Manchester, his relentless campaigning for a parish council put him on a collision course with the Liberal Democrats, who run the metropolitan authority.

The Lib Dems, self-styled community champions themselves, seemed unkeen on the idea of someone else campaigning for grassroots democracy. They threw everything against Ralphs, including the results of a "survey" designed to show that his initiative was unpopular.

After battling for more than a year, and sending the council a statutory petition outlining support from at least 10% of residents, Ralphs has finally won the argument. Offerton (population 4,165) is in line for a parish council, with the approval of the deputy prime minister, John Prescott. Giving the go-ahead, Prescott's officials recently told Ralphs, a security guard and caterer, that they would be consulting "in due course" on a draft order setting up the council.

Offerton will join another 60 parish councils created in the past three years alone, bringing the total - including small town councils - to more than 10,000 in England and Wales. With local democracy in crisis around the country, as election turnouts in inner cities plunge to well below 20%, the slow revival of parish government - what some have labelled micro-democracy - has finally been recognised by the government as an idea worth developing.

In last week's rural white paper, Prescott offered parish and town councils a stronger role and wider powers to promote community life. They will be invited to prepare village and town plans and encouraged to deliver wider services beyond, say, providing allotments, maintaining churchyards and protecting common land and greens. With the agreement of district and county councils, these new services could include responsibility for litter collection, maintaining street lighting and managing a range of other local facilities. Parishes will also be able to apply for a £10,000 grant to buy, or fund, community transport - from a taxi to a people carrier.

But, as one parish chairman remarked, the devil is in the detail: councils will have to pass a "quality test" to show they are competent and democratic. Before drawing up detailed plans, the government will consult with the Local Government Association and other bodies, although ministers have raised the prospect of "piloted, innovative and imaginative" partnerships involving "quality councils".

Far from seeing this as a fudge, the National Association of Local Councils (NALC) - the voice of parish and town government - believes the white paper has opened the way for a significant expansion in the number of councils and the range of services offered.

"Giving parishes and town councils a greater role is all about giving a local voice back to the people," says John Findlay, the NALC's chief executive. "This is about common sense government. Where it is efficient and sensible, the government clearly wants to see services moving down to town and parish level."

Parish and town government, in fact, is bigger than many realise: the 10,000 councils (with 80,000 councillors) employ more than 25,000 staff, full and part-time, and annual spending exceeds £200m. Funded by a small precept on council tax, total spending in any financial year cannot exceed £3.50 per elector in parish or town. But under the 1997 Local Government Act, local people can decide where to draw the boundaries of their new parish and, within reason, what powers they want to take on.

As Ralphs can testify, this can be easier said than done. His complaint is a familiar one. "We were tired of waiting for improvements to the estate, felt it was being left to rot, and wanted to take more control of things," he says. "For years, the community had been neglected - nowhere for kids to play, no community centre - and then I found out about parish councils and thought: 'This will do for us.'"

Offerton may be a far cry from the popular image of a rural parish, but the complaints about remote government and out-of-touch officialdom are heard in city and shire.

To be fair, not every large council is obstructive. In Birmingham, campaigners for a parish in the Frankley area have been applauded by the city council. When they presented their petition for parish status, with the required 10% support, they were even granted a civic reception.

 Peter Hetherington is the Guardian's regional affairs correspondent. His booklet on local democracy, First Thoughts on a Local Constitution: Back to the Future?, is available at £7.50 inc. from IDeA Publication Sales, Layden House, Turnmill Street, London EC1M 5LG (020-7296 6600).

webTitle: How world food resources are threatened by seed patents

fields.headline: Ours to have and to hold
fields.standfirst: How world food resources are threatened by seed patents
fields.trailText: How world food resources are threatened by seed patents
fields.body:
Just as the Prince of Wales launched a millennium genebank last month to conserve 10% of the plant kingdom, over in Switzerland a major threat appeared to the future availability of the seeds used to feed the world. Negotiations to keep their ownership in the public domain were only rescued at the 11th hour.

These negotiations on food crops are a life insurance for humanity against rapid environmental, social and economic changes. Future food supplies will be under threat unless the talks succeed.

At issue is the International Undertaking on Plant Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture, or IU for short. It covers all the major food crops in the world and aims to ensure the conservation, sustainable use and "free flow" of these seeds so that they are "preserved . . . and freely available for use, for the benefit of present and future generations".

The IU could keep access open to all crop, forage and agroforestry species used to maintain food security, including the 500,000 samples already in public sector genebanks - which transnational industries would dearly love to patent and exploit - as well as the many hundreds of thousands of varieties out in farmers' fields.

Smallholder farmers, the backbone of the economy in many countries, have developed and managed a wide number of seed varieties over centuries. Despite the expanding global trade in brand-name seeds and foodstuffs, up to 90% of the seeds used by these smallholder farmers are saved on the farm and exchanged freely among their networks. These provide food for nearly two-thirds of the world's population.

But patenting of whole varieties and parts of the genome, and intellectual property rights regimes which support the biotechnology industries, are increasing the rate of appropriation of genetic resources from the south into private ownership in the north - so-called "biopiracy".

The IU would provide specific rules for a particular category of genetic resources useful to mankind which are covered generically by the World Trade Organisation's trade related aspects of intellectual property rights agreement (Trips).

Trips obliges countries to have measures for the intellectual property protection of plant varieties. The contentious central articles of the IU would ensure the free flow of these genetic resources and reduce biopiracy. It would also ensure that farmers reap benefits from commercial use of genetic resources they have developed. Best of all, it would be legally binding within the framework of the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD).

When the nations who have signed the CBD last met, in May, the Intermediate Technology Development Group (ITDG) - a UK-based charity which uses technology for to find practical answers to poverty - and partner NGOs brought smallholder farmers from across Africa to the policy table: they demanded that the IU negotiations be swiftly concluded. The CBD issued a call for action and has entrusted the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) to host the negotiations. A contact group of 41 countries is preparing text for FAO's conference of its 180 member states next year, and then to the CBD in 2002.

In August, the contact group agreed text on the contentious articles, but at its meeting in Switzerland last month, four countries - the US, Canada, Australia and New Zealand - reopened that text and blocked progress. It was almost the same group which had tried to stall the biosafety protocol to the CBD, and the climate change meeting at the Hague.

If these negotiations fail, large companies would have the unique capacity to provide seeds needed for the changing global environment. Earlier this year, for instance, a large seed company in Mexico "de-listed" 2,000 seed varieties, originally collected from farmers, in order to "streamline" its business.

Tewolde Debre Egziabher, the Ethiopian negotiator and leader of the African group, said recently: "The IU is a crucial agreement for us and the majority of the south because it will be legally binding on all countries and will ensure that none can register intellectual property rights on our farmers' crop varieties.

"It will also facilitate everybody's continued access to crop varieties the world over and provide us with long overdue benefits from the commercial use of these varieties in plant breeding, for industry and for food. We hope the EU will increase pressure on its OECD allies to secure this agreement."

So what should be done? First, the EU must seek an agreement that is strong on binding commitments. It should give its negotiators a mandate to negotiate at the table without continually returning to their domestic departments and the council of ministers.

Second, while it is appropriate that agriculture ministries are leading, this is about agriculture in its environmental context, so environment ministers should line up strongly behind the process.

At stake is the world's access to a set of patent-free genetic resources on which we all depend. Is that not worth an extra push?

 Patrick Mulvany is food security policy adviser and Don Redding head of public affairs for ITDG.

In August, the contact group agreed text on the contentious articles, but at its meeting in Switzerland last month, four countries - the US, Canada, Australia and New Zealand - reopened that text and blocked progress. It was almost the same group which had tried to stall the biosafety protocol to the CBD, and the climate change meeting at the Hague. If these negotiations fail, large companies would have the unique capacity to provide seeds needed for the changing global environment. Earlier this year, for instance, a large seed company in Mexico "de-listed" 2,000 seed varieties, originally collected from farmers, in order to "streamline" its business. Tewolde Debre Egziabher, the Ethiopian negotiator and leader of the African group, said recently: "The IU is a crucial agreement for us and the majority of the south because it will be legally binding on all countries and will ensure that none can register intellectual property rights on our farmers' crop varieties. "It will also facilitate everybody's continued access to crop varieties the world over and provide us with long overdue benefits from the commercial use of these varieties in plant breeding, for industry and for food. We hope the EU will increase pressure on its OECD allies to secure this agreement." So what should be done? First, the EU must seek an agreement that is strong on binding commitments. It should give its negotiators a mandate to negotiate at the table without continually returning to their domestic departments and the council of ministers. Second, while it is appropriate that agriculture ministries are leading, this is about agriculture in its environmental context, so environment ministers should line up strongly behind the process. At stake is the world's access to a set of patent-free genetic resources on which we all depend. Is that not worth an extra push?  Patrick Mulvany is food security policy adviser and Don Redding head of public affairs for ITDG.

webTitle: A high-flyer planning to cash in on Muslim success

fields.headline: Club culture
fields.standfirst: Reedah Nijabat, a high-flyer planning to cash in on Muslim success
fields.trailText: Profile: Reedah Nijabat, a high-flyer planning to cash in on Muslim success
fields.body:
Many British Muslims would be surprised to hear that their community needs a plush London club where those earning at least £30k a year can network, enjoy Islamic culture, drink non-alcoholic cocktails, and escape from the stress of success in the on-site prayer room.

Reedah Nijabat, a young barrister whose family is from Pakistan, isn't one of them. She is convinced that what high-flyers like herself lack is their own watering hole - based on Soho's fabled Groucho Club - and has made it her mission to start one.

So far, 30-year-old Nijabat has got a lease on three adjoining shops awaiting conversion and been promised bank loans of £200,000. The site of the ArRum club is in the heart of loft-living, warehouse-clubbing, multi-racial Clerkenwell. So why do Muslims need a separate place to socialise?

"Because most of them feel a bit uncomfortable about going to a bar or being offered alcohol," Nijabat says. While it's true that many second and third generation Muslims here feel more integrated and outgoing than their parents, Nijabat reckons their specific needs are not being met by the commercial sector.

She's tired, too, of negative images of Islam in the media. There's a whole vibrant side of Muslim culture - marked by an interest in art, architecture and literature. Some of this she plans to bring to ArRum.

Her club will be cashing in on several congruent trends. There's the economic and professional success of many young Asians - enough of them for the journal Asian Eye and the Financial Times to jointly compile an Asian "rich list". Only a proportion of those are Muslim, of course, but she reckons there is substantial "new money" being earned by her co-religionists.

Nijabat herself is an example. Her father had a lifelong career in the army; she qualified as a barrister, but then felt she had the entrepreneurial gene, and decided to give herself two years to see if she could fill a niche she'd identified "at the upper end of the Muslim market".

While Nijabat isn't shy about saying that she wants to make big money - though her immediate preoccupation is with borrowing to get the club running early in the new year - she believes the venture will be giving something back to the community. Members will be encouraged to mentor young hopefuls in their business or professional fields.

Her efforts have proved that a network already operates among professional Muslims, but also revealsome weaknesses. Several Muslim architects were among those she consulted about converting the shops into a club. However, their designs were disappointingly traditional for her taste, and the contract went elsewhere.

Even more surprising is the reluctance of young Muslim entrepreneurs to put up a sizeable slice of the £300,000 ArRum requires, though several have offered a few thousand pounds. Other enterprises, based on identifying such niche markets as the grey pound and the pink pound, have found it easier to get started. Can it be that Nijabat is alone in believing that the Muslim pound also likes to relax and be shown a good time?

 For details of ArRum, telephone 020-7415 7111.

webTitle: Re-thinking the treatment of mental illness

fields.headline: Choice of a new life
fields.standfirst: In too many cases, people suffering from mental illness have no say in the treatment they receive.  Sophie Petit-Zeman reports on a survey urging a holistic re-think
fields.trailText: In too many cases, people suffering from mental illness have no say in the treatment they receive. Sophie Petit-Zeman reports on a survey urging a holistic re-think
fields.body:
You feel a familiar depression slinking back, or a mounting sense of mania, or disembodied, persecuting voices of schizophrenia that you've never heard before. But who or what can help you? According to the largest survey of people's views on treatment for mental illness, to be published on Friday, there are few options available, or informed choices made, when it comes to the use of psychiatric drugs.

A Question of Choice, produced by three charities, the National Schizophrenia Fellowship (NSF), Manic Depression Fellowship and Mind, reveals that 62% of people suffering mental illness had no choice of medication, and almost half stopped taking it without medical advice.

Most of the 2,663 people surveyed had diagnoses of schizophrenia, although many had manic depression or depression. The two main drug treatments for schizophrenia are "typical" and "atypical" antipsychotics.

The typicals (common ones are haloperidol, chlorpromazine and stelazine) have been around longest. While they help some people, they can cause severe long-term side-effects, sometimes irreversible even if treatment is stopped. The drugs are banned in parts of the US, following law suits linked to side-effects, and, according to Gary Hogman, head of policy and campaigns at the NSF, some British experts say such drugs would not be licensed if they were being introduced to the market now.

Atypicals - such as olanzapine, clozapine and risperidone - are the newer, growing group. Their side-effects are usually milder, and a striking finding from the survey relates to people's experiences of these versus typical antipsychotics. Asked "Which was the worst medicine you've ever had?", the highest ranked drugs were the three common typicals. And the best? The three atypicals - plus lithium, used mainly for manic depression.

Doctors can prescribe from either category, yet 84% of drugs used for schizophrenia are typical antipsychotics. The higher cost of atypicals, and conservative tendencies within the medical profession, may override clinical judgment and patient preference. Hogman says the survey shows that what is lacking, and must be provided, is choice. "People want comprehensive information, and to be allowed to choose what works best for them, not always get the cheapest option or whatever the doctor usually gives," he says.

Hogman argues that prescribing cheaper drugs is short-sighted. "Some people on typical antipsychotics need other drugs to combat side-effects. They frequently stop taking medication and, as a result, relapse is common.

"In short, many people are given drugs which they hate, and don't stick with, even though there are alternatives. It's a false economy. Their symptoms are not controlled, they may have repeated hospital admissions, at high cost to health, social care and sometimes the criminal justice system, and have seriously and needlessly impaired quality of life."

The national institute for clinical excellence (Nice), which advises the government on medical interventions, has just announced that it will assess drugs for schizophrenia - a process expected to take a year before yielding recommendations. The NSF hopes that this evaluation will not pay more attention to cold data of controlled trials than to hard evidence - the experiences of people who take the drugs.

The value of medication, for many, is clear from the survey. When asked "What single thing had or could make the biggest difference to quality of life?", the largest number cited medication. This included people for whom medicine has already made the biggest difference and those who view improved medicine as the best thing that could happen.

But the survey does not end there. It also asked people's views about non-drug treatments - from psychotherapy to exercise.

As Hogman says: "Medication was our starting point, but the survey's main colour is its illustration of the importance of a holistic approach. It demonstrates that those who are unwell benefit immensely from the occupational and leisure activities that we all like."

This holistic approach to mental illness is the cornerstone of NSF philosophy, based on recognising the interplay between mental and physical health.

Hogman says: "It's just common sense. There aren't two groups in society, ill people and well people. Mental illness affects all walks of life. Most people know what they need and enjoy - such as having enough money, pleasant accommodation, things to do and people to share them with - and those who are ill are no exception.

"Without these things, the risk of people suffering illness is increased, and getting better and staying well is more difficult. The picture is further complicated by the fact that the illness itself impedes ability to access them."

Mental Health Foundation statistics support these views: psychiatric admissions are three times greater in government-defined "deprived" areas, and the risk of suicide among the unemployed is 11 times higher than among those in work.

These figures and the survey's findings do not solve the mysteries of what causes mental illness, nor do they imply that good housing or jobs can alone prevent people from becoming ill, or cure them.

However, many interacting factors, from genetics to the environment, are important in causing mental illness and give clues as to useful interventions.

One of the survey's most striking statistics is that the most appreciated interventions are not complex or specialised. Exercise, training and education were ranked top by 85% of those who had tried them, and art/music therapy was best liked by 81%. It is another indication from the survey that drawing boundaries between the needs of the well and those of the ill is frequently artificial and unhelpful.

How birdwatching and art brought a new focus

Julian Swan's story illustrates how combining medication, non-drug treatments and social inclusion can dramatically help even those with severe, long-lasting illness.

Diagnosed with schizophrenia in 1992, after hearing voices for 16 years, Julian says freedom to choose his treatment was fundamental to recovery. "I told the psychiatrist that if I wasn't better in three months I'd kill myself," he recalls. "He was so responsive, but imposed nothing. He offered a hospital bed, which I declined, but I accepted sulpiride [a typical antipsychotic]. After a fortnight, the voices and paranoia had gone. After eight years, I recently stopped taking sulpiride, and I feel fine."

Since 1995, Swan has gained a degree in English and philosophy, a postgraduate qualification in social work from Cardiff University, and is about to start a new job in youth homelessness. He is convinced that medication only partly accounts for his recovery.

"It got my brain together by resolving the chemical imbalance," he says. "Then I was offered three or four non-drug treatments, and opted for art and drama therapy. These were incredible. I did lots of painting and expressed so much. I got my mind together through being involved and included."

Swan talks of another passion, for birdwatching, but also of one frustration. "My GP says I can't have psychotherapy. I'd like a 'debriefing' after living somewhere so odd, in my head, for 20 years. Apparently, I'm too well. In a big city, you only get help in a crisis."

For Swan, an empathetic doctor offering genuine choice, and a combination of treatments, education, training and employment have been life-changing. The National Schizophrenia Fellowship survey concludes that money should be spent on more holistic approaches - investments which would ultimately reduce the wide-ranging costs of caring for the mentally ill.

Figuring out the problem

 £76 million is spent on 1.2 m annual prescriptions for schizophrenia.

 84% of drugs prescribed for schizophrenia are old style (typical), yet new drugs (atypicals) account for 76% of medication costs.

 Postcode prescribing does happen; spending on atypicals varies tenfold across health authorities.

 Careful prescribing and individually tailored support can reduce hospital admissions. A week on a psychiatric ward costs about £960 a person, compared to £230 a week at home with support.

 A Question of Choice will be available at www.nsf.org.uk or from Lucy Widenka on 020-7330 9108. The report was prepared without any drug company funding.

webTitle: Why  plans to build two dams on the Achelöos river makes no sense

fields.headline: Waters of life
fields.standfirst: Tim Salmon  on why the Greek government's plans to build two dams on the Achelöos river makes no sense
fields.trailText: Tim Salmon on why the Greek government's plans to build two dams on the Achelöos river makes no sense
fields.body:
With its dry Mediterranean climate, Greece does not have many rivers. The Achelöos is its longest and most beautiful. It rises in the alpine pastures of the Pindos mountains, where transhumant shepherds bring their flocks in summertime, and flows into the Ionian sea near the mouth of the Gulf of Corinth.

From its headwaters, it flows south through a valley clad with forests of pine and fir, joined in its course by countless side streams - some flowing down out of bare mountain valleys; others, more bucolic, enclosed in defiles lush with greenery.

In winter, swollen with storm and snow water, it boils and roars, impassable, except by half a dozen Bailey bridges. In summer it is a gentler creature; its waters, shrunk to knee-deep, wind like a blue-green snake along a bed of dazzling stones that give it its local name of Aspropotamos - White River.

Here and there shepherds and goatherds make their summer camps in the shade of the plane trees that line the banks. There is no sound but the murmur of the rapids and the clatter of the plane leaves as summer breezes funnel down the gorges. Rare birds and plants live on the valley sides and heights above. There is no effluent - industrial, urban or agricultural - to pollute the water. Villages are few and far between. There is little traffic on the few dirt roads. It is one of the largest tracts of pristine mountain landscape left in Europe. The hand of man has scarcely ever been visible for the first 100km of the river's course ... until now.

In the 80s, the Greek government decided to go ahead with a scheme to build two dams on the upper section of the river, creating two artificial lakes. The first, at Sikia, will flood more than 20km of the river's natural course; the second, at Mesohora, will flood a further 12km, as well as the lower reaches of numerous tributaries, leaving scarcely 15km of the river's entire length unaffected by human intervention.

The purpose of the scheme is to power two hydro-electric stations and to divert water from the Sikia lake, via a 17.4km tunnel, to the farms and towns of the plain of Thessaly to the east of the Pindos mountains, for irrigation and drinking.

And the villages on either side of the river will have their communications cut.

Do the benefits constitute an "overriding public interest", as is supposed to be the case when states give precedence to economic development over such environment protection regimes? It is far from certain that they do. In 1988, a Morgan Grenfell analysis concluded that the scheme would only just break even if everything proceeded according to schedule. EU farmers are now being paid to leave their fields uncultivated.

Is it wise to embark on a project aimed at increasing production when Greece is already facing fines for overproduction of cotton? Is it wise to be growing thirsty crops such as maize and cotton in an area where summertime temperatures often reach 40C, where irrigation has already lowered the water table by a catastrophic amount, when water loss by evaporation from sprinklers can amount to 40%, and at a time of evident climate change when the snow and rainfall that replenish the waters of the Achelöos are diminishing?

Why is there no large-scale popular protest? Why has the archaeological service responsible for the endangered monuments not spoken up in their defence? Why has the Church not come to the defence of its own property and a significant part of the nation's heritage?

By and large, Greeks are still in thrall to an old-fashioned model of development, where the bulldozer is king. Concern for the environment is in its infancy, and the country's mountainous heartlands, although the cradle of the modern nation, are regarded as barren and useless by the predominantly urban population.

Fine words and gestures, however, are not lacking. What village does not sport a notice admonishing people to respect the environment, usually in the middle of a rubbish tip? And I did come across two "green tourism" projects - agrotourismos - financed under the EU's Leader programme. They were the repair of the Karakounisiou bridge and the Mirofillo monastery - both condemned to be drowned by the Sikia lake.

"Diversion of the Achelöos: diversion from reason, is how Greek opponents of the scheme refer to it. And one can see why.

webTitle: Eco soundings

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: A tall story
fields.body:
A tall story

Good to see Brent MP and home office minister Paul Boateng planting a tree last week to encourage people to improve their local environments. Perhaps he could have a quiet word with the local Labour council which is expected today to give permission to Alfred McAlpine homes to cut down more than 70 mature trees on the edge of the former Wasps rugby ground. And why do the developers want to cut them down? It couldn't possibly be that they want to cram in as many homes as possible? Of course not, they say. It's just because they think residents would find them a "nuisance". Needless to say, the residents are claiming that there was inadequate consultation - and the sort of swearing usually only heard in rugby scrums is now flying around Boateng's constituency.

Through the house

Crikey. After nearly four years of no environmental legislation, we now have two acts. The countryside and wildlife bill survived unbelievable pressure but was steered home last week, following the less noticed warm homes bill which got through with a squeak. This latter is a lesson on how many different groups, from Friends of the Earth to Help the Aged and Unison, worked together to raise an issue and then get legislation on the statute books. Although Labour is now supporting it strongly, several times the government tried actively to stop it in its tracks. As it is, more than 5.5m homes will now by law have to be insulated and Tony Blair is going to make political capital out of it.

Meeting of minds

Glory be. After years of exclusion, the Green party was so taken by Tony Blair's "green" speech that it wrote in asking for a meeting. And, lo, within weeks of seeking one, the PM's special environmental adviser will meet three members tomorrow. Whatever next? A coalition?

Pens at the ready

Just in case any more readers want to write to Canada to congratulate the British Columbian government for jailing great-grandmother Betty Krawczyk for standing up against logging old forests, International Forest Products is at 3,500 Dunsmuir Street, Vancouver, and the premier of British Columbia is Ujjal Dosangjh, whose office is best contacted at PO Box 9041, Victoria V8W 9E1, Canada.

webTitle: 'No blame' is not a soft option

fields.headline: 'No blame' is not a soft option
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: Long before the tragis death of Damilola, the Family Service Unit was getting bullies to face up to their behaviour
fields.body:
The behaviour is probably as old as man. It affects all age groups but is most acute - both as victims and perpetrators - among children. Yet, until recently, the problem was ignored. Now, following the tragic murder of 10-year-old Damilola Taylor, it is front page news. But will ministers adopt the right approach to bullying?

A front-page splash in the Times on Saturday suggested ministers would shift the emphasis away from the current "no blame" culture embraced by the 1994 official guidance. New guidance is being promised before Christmas. An election approaches. No doubt the Mail would applaud a more macho approach - not just for schools but for children's homes, hostels and youth clubs.

Do not despair. Ministers were planning a new initiative before Damilola's death. David Blunkett had already agreed to be the keynote speaker at a one-day conference on a non-punitive approach to anti-bullying next Wednesday (Details: 0207-402 5175). It is being run by the Family Service Units (FSU), which helps support 27,500 inner-city children from 19 centres.

The problem with "no blame" is not its approach but its name. It implies exoneration and escape for perpetrators. But it is much more subtle than that. It tackles head on the biggest challenge: persuading children to tell. Victims are worried by the reaction of tormentors. Hence the importance of involving both bullied and bullies in solutions. Recent surveys suggest that the mushrooming of new schemes - peer counsellors, support groups, mediation - has helped cut refusal to tell from 50% to 30%.

"No blame" began in the early 1990s. Bullied and bullies, who are not identified, join with neutrals to bring out the problem and talk it through. Each pupil is required to propose a solution. FSU teams have made two further developments. The first, with 12 pilots under way, is a support code for an entire school or children's home. The aim is to involve entire institutions "because it is bystanders who allow bullying". The goal is to reduce aggression and promote caring skills.

The second, set up in Leeds, is a pro-active group of 13 to 16-year-olds helping victims. Started by a multi-racial group of the bullied and bullies, they've made a video of their work and are already on the lecture circuit. They've learned about conflict, been taught mediation skills and understand the importance of getting all people involved to sort out a solution. As they sing on their video: "If you are not part of the solution, you are a part of the problem." But please, "no blame", change your name. You sound like a soft option - even though you are subtly forcing bullies to face up to their behaviour.

webTitle: A project that helps refugees escape the city and make new friends

fields.headline: Growing confidence
fields.standfirst: Sue Beenstock  on a project that helps refugees escape the city and make new friends
fields.trailText: Sue Beenstock on a project that helps refugees escape the city and make new friends
fields.body:
It's typical tree-planting weather: wintery, with a stiff breeze blowing off Loch Lomond. The mist clears and the hills beneath are the dull russets and greens of an ageing Cox's apple. But the band of stalwarts out planting saplings on a Saturday morning are not your typical conservation enthusiasts. All arrived in Britain just a few months ago. They are still struggling to learn English, find schools and nursery places for their kids, survive on vouchers and a few pounds in cash each week and get used to life on Glasgow housing estates. You might think that replanting a native forest in Cashel Farm, a 40-minute drive north of Glasgow, would be low on their list of priorities. You'd be wrong.

Nasrin, a hairdresser, and her engineer husband and their two children, aged 10 and four, came to Britain from Iran five months ago. After two weeks sitting on the bare floor of a truck, they arrived in Dover sick and exhausted, but within a couple of weeks of being sent to Glasgow, they'd heard about a unique project run by the Black Environment Network (BEN), the Scottish Refugee Council and British Trust for Conservation Volunteers.

"We came every month from then on," says Nasrin, keeping an eye on her children, who are chasing each other round the saplings. "It's green and beautiful and there is clean air here. In Iran, we would go to the countryside every two weeks, and for children there was the park, the cinema, many other entertainments. But here we have nothing, nothing."

Her eldest child, Ashkan, can go to school, but there's no nursery place for their pre-school daughter and she has no opportunity to mix with other children. "This is a big space for all the children to play," says Nasrin. "We like the lake and the people are so friendly. If we couldn't come for some reason, my children would go mad - they have so much energy."

They're not the only ones. Sorour and her five-year-old daughter Sheida are also regular attendees. Unlike Nasrin and her family, Sorour fled Iran without her husband. "I was in danger, so we had to leave," she says. "I could complain to you about many things here in Glasgow, and I will. But coming on our nature days is fantastic. It is something ordinary; we are treated like normal people."

It is also a rare chance for Sorour to meet other Iranians and refugees, with whom she can chat and share advice and experiences in a relaxing and sociable atmosphere. Lunch is a boisterous affair and often means Iranians, Iraqis, Scots, Somalians, Pakistanis and Nigerians sitting round a table tucking into a help-yourself lunch of sandwiches, olives, dates, fresh fruit - and lots of noisy chat.

"Excuse me," says Dorna, a primary school teacher from Isfahan, in Iran, turning to a student from Glasgow University, as they tuck into sandwiches. "What do you think the British government is doing to improve relations with Iran?" There is a silence. "I'm not sure," he answers truthfully. "Probably not much."

During the day, everyone plants a tree and writes a dedication that will eventually appear in a book recording the Cashel Forest For A Thousand Years project. "To my father," says one. "For my grandfather," writes another. And others put: "To the people of Scotland" - all written in a slow and careful hand.

According to Elaine Gibb, development worker at BEN, the day is as much about socialising in the fresh air as getting involved with environmental conservation. "This isn't hardcore environmental action," she admits. "For most people here today, it's a family day out. But on other trips we've had people along who will take their volunteering and an involvement in conservation further."

Two such people are Nigel, from Somalia (see below), and Ranna Judge, 39, from Pakistan. "I feel as if I'm making myself helpful," says Judge, a full-time student who has lived in Glasgow for 10 years. "I'm having problems getting citizenship. I use the Refugee Council drop-in centre and although I'm asthmatic, when a friend mentioned this project, I knew I'd love to work outdoors. I have no garden and live in a polluted area, so this is a wonderful chance to be in the countryside, to try to improve our environment - and volunteering is very much part of my culture."

But for most, the idea of volunteering isn't a primary reason for getting involved. "You may say we are volunteers, and I agree that it is good to put something back," says Fred Anafchi, 22, from Iran. "But it is also a lovely day out, it is free and, for us, who can never get out of the city, this is fresh air and peacefulness. In return, we plant trees."

Nature's comforts

Nigel, 17, has lived alone in Glasgow since fleeing Somalia following the murder of his father and death threats to him and his mother. He is studying for Highers and hopes to go on to do aeronautical engineering at university. He is a fluent English speaker since this was the common language between his Somalian mother and Brazilian father.

"My father was mayor of Mogadishu and was murdered on February 14 this year," he says. "My mother was pregnant with my only sibling at the time and she fled elsewhere in Africa, I have no idea where, but the Red Cross is helping me to trace her. I left shortly after her, hiding in a cargo plane.

"In Glasgow, I am alone, but I can look after myself. The difficulty is that it's hard to get out of the city. Like most refugees, I've less than £10 a week in cash. I love being in the countryside. You need that time; it helps you to understand your new life, get to know the place and the people, and also it's a comfort to feel that the cycle of nature continues even when people's lives are over.

"To me that is so important. I needed it in Somalia and I need it even more here."

webTitle: Readers' letters

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: Rough figures | Sweeter charities | Customer disservice | Double standards
fields.body:
Rough figures

I represent an area which is home to one of Cambridge's permanent night shelters. It is where Alexander Masters will have met many of those whose plight he wrote about (The cold shoulder, November 29).

I very much welcome his effort to draw attention to the suffering and misery experienced by those whom he met. But I am concerned that he misrepresents their needs, by lumping "these people" (his words) together, as if they were all rough sleepers. They are not. I can identify individuals whom Masters met, and who beg on the streets. They need many forms of support, but not night shelter accommodation because they are already permanently housed.

Those whom Masters met do indeed face serious and often life-threatening conditions, sometimes multiple. These include alcohol and drug addiction, a variety of serious mental and physical health problems, and poverty because they have slipped through the welfare net. Some are sleeping rough - how many is a matter of dispute. Unfortunately, all sources of figures are likely to be tainted by some form of perceived self-interest. Earlier (and higher) counts were carried out by organisations whose claim to funding depended on a high count.

Masters' own interests tend to focus his attention on changes in rough sleeper provision in Cambridge, to the exclusion of the more complex variety of problems faced, in my ward and elsewhere, by those about whom he writes. He might have scrutinised instead the effectiveness of health providers and Cambridgeshire county council's struggling social services department in responding to those problems as they should.

Ben Bradnack

Petersfield ward councillor and deputy Labour group leader, Cambridge council

Sweeter charities

There are thousands of charities, most of whom are not Dickensian in their outlook, who offer a better service than that mentioned by Jane Muir (Sweet charity, November 15).

Our charity is a small occupational benevolent fund that helps people who have worked in the confectionery industry. We help anyone who qualifies through length of service and levels of income and savings.

If Muir was interested in finding out about charities that help teachers like her, she would find a dozen listed in Grants for Individuals in Need, which is available in most libraries. The Occupational Benevolent Fund Alliance runs a helpline on 01707-651777 to help members of the public and organisations find a relevant charity.

From Muir's comments about holidays, she appears to feel that she is entitled to a greater level of support than many working people can afford. Many of our own beneficiaries would be overjoyed to be given a holiday at Butlins or Center Parcs.

Liz Harthill

director of welfare, Confectioners Benevolent Fund

 I sympathise with Jane Muir and others who care for those with disabilities. But I do not read about her fight to get the correct equipment from the government, or about her lobbying her local MP. I do not read about her joining forces with other parents in a similar situation, or calling for funding levels to be increased for NHS provision of services.

I also take exception to the comments that "one well-known charity used to have a system where parents had to phone on the first Monday of each month to put your name on a waiting list". As Whizz-Kidz closed its old application system in October 1999, I presume she means us.

Our new application process ensures that all parents must first approach the NHS for provision of mobility equipment. This avoids duplication of service and, more important, ensures that children with the greatest need are served first.

Muir mistakenly says our system changed "in response to a plethora of complaints from parents". Quite the contrary, no such complaints existed. Claims that our staff made comments such as "could you try again next year" are pure fiction.

Rosalind Ham

director of children's services, Whizz-Kidz

Customer disservice

No councillor would be surprised by the British Social Attitudes survey finding that more than 75% of council tenants want the council to remain their landlord (Fair renting, November 29).

Evidence from the National Housing Federation, based on 11 stock transfers to housing associations, concluded that "few residents thought things had improved across the board". What councillors and tenants may not know is that in over half the stock transfers that took place before 1996, rents have increased by more than 20% over the past five years. The impact of high rents is creating social exclusion and undermining welfare to work policies.

The Treasury does not want to modernise the financial framework to allow councils to borrow against their asset base and rental streams to improve housing. Housing minister Nick Raynsford seems convinced of the invincibility of private sector management in housing, no matter what our customers say.

Nigel Long

housing policy officer, Local Government Information Unit

Double standards

Simon Marr-Johnson, writing from London, expresses deep concern (Letters, November 29) over local, vocal criticism of the turbine he has erected at his Welsh home in the Black Mountains.

He might care to reduce his carbon emissions by relinquishing one of his two homes - leading to less travel, reduced house building, improved availability of homes for our rural residents and less conspicious consumption all round.

Tom Lamb

Middlesbrough

webTitle: Childminders say no to smacking

fields.headline: Wrong rights
fields.standfirst: Childminders say no to smacking
fields.trailText: Childminders say no to smacking
fields.body:
Registered childminders are planning today to deliver a giant postcard to Tony Blair, asking him to block proposals to give them rights to smack children in their care and smoke in front of them.

Under draft national standards on daycare and childminding, issued by the government, registered childminders would be allowed to administer physical discipline to children and smoke in their presence if parental permission had been given.

Lynn Daley, chair of the National Childminding Association for England and Wales (NCMA), who is leading the delegation to Downing Street, calls the proposals "barmy". She says: "Registered childminders have not asked for, and do not want, these so-called rights."

The proposals are out of line with the NCMA's own quality standards, which explicitly rule out smacking or shaking as methods of controlling children's behaviour. The draft national guidelines on daycare and childminding in England cover creches, day nurseries, playgroups, after school clubs, holiday play schemes and childminders. The 14 standards, designed to introduce consistency across the country, will be used by the early years directorate - a new arm of schools inspectorate Oftsed - when it takes over the registration and inspection of childminders in England in autumn next year.

The rights to smack and smoke with parental consent apply only to childminders.

The standards, issued by the Department for Education and Employment, have been out for consultation, and responses are being considered. A department spokeswoman says: "The rationale behind the draft standards was a matter of parental choice. The government doesn't bring up children and we believe it is important to ensure continuity of discipline between parents and childminders."
