webTitle: Are Sure Starts living up to their promises?

fields.headline: Flying start
fields.standfirst:
When the government launched Sure Start projects they were trumpeted as vital to the strategy for eradicating child poverty. Are they living up to that promise? John Cunningham reports
Society special report: social care
fields.trailText: When the government launched Sure Start projects they were trumpeted as vital to the strategy for eradicating child poverty. Are they living up to that promise? John Cunningham reports
fields.body:
In the offices of one of Birmingham's Sure Start schemes, there is a fat book, a 150-page plan detailing how the project, when it's up and running, could transform the lives of children under the age of four in disadvantaged families in Ladywood. At the other scheme, a few miles away in Billesley, months spent preparing sums and surveys have been distilled into a leaflet listing the help now at hand.

It is user-friendly - and needs to be - to guide parents through the web of midwife, health visitor, social worker, speech therapist, childminder, parent support coordinator, creche co-ordinator, inclusion worker (special needs), home start volunteers (practical home support) for a suburban area where about 800 families have children aged four and under.

The government has identified 200 deprived areas needing assistance, where 500 Sure Start schemes will be up and running by 2004.

Coloured dots mark the different waves of Sure Starts on the wallmap in Naomi Eisenstadt's office in London. As head of unit, she's charged with implementing the partnerships which link a locality's childcare needs (as listed by parents) with a guaranteed budget of £2-3m, professional input and advice, and monitoring of targets. This is managed through a public service agreement between the agency and local projects. Eisenstadt calls it "a very elegant, innovative combination of top down [Sure Start is funded by the health and education ministries] and bottom up [parents and local services]".

Ministers have set the targets, mostly expressed as percentage improvements to be attained. These cover the social and emotional development, and the health and ability to learn, of the under-fours. Since the scheme started 18 months ago, Eisenstadt says one aim - a 5% reduction in the number of low birthweight babies - has been replaced by the clearer aim of getting mothers-to-be not to smoke during pregnancy. Also, there is a greater emphasis on links with employment, such as New Deal for lone parents.

"In terms of specific targets, we are setting ones that individual communities can work towards," says Eisenstadt. "We have never worked this way before, so we'll have to learn as we go along

Setting goals and adopting a seemingly prescriptive approach could give the impression that it is yet another preachy New Labour policy. But Sure Starts have been conceived as partnerships on the basis that, in order to work, they have to be parent-friendly, non-judgmental towards families with problems, and locally-led.

You can see the importance of getting a community to make a bid for Sure Start money, and for local people to be involved, in the two Birmingham projects. In Ladywood, a small local charity, Karis, took the lead. Angie King, a former nurse onsecondment from Karis to get the scheme off the ground, says the community was so used to being overlooked that it could scarcely believe it was really getting a grant.

Enthusiastic parents quickly listed their wants. Top of the list was something quite simple - a support team of volunteers who could help with other children when one child in a family was ill or when parents were out shopping. But the scheme is developing from there. King says that because supermarkets are distant from the area, one aim is to help teach parents about nutrition by starting a centre which serves and sells cheap, nourishing foods.

In Billesley, local people were anxious to expand an existing facility with a good reputation, the Chinnbrook Children and Parents' Project. Bhavna Solanki, programme manager, says it is an excellent core; and Sure Start will be spending about £1m on a building programme, to offer more services and attract more parents.

Home visits by childcare staff are a key element of Sure Start's approach, but almost all the projects also want their own centre - either purpose-built or suitably adapted premises - with clinics, play areas and the rest.

Billesley has got off to a flying start because there is an existing community centre on which to graft. Ladywood (which came in a later batch of Sure Starts) has a much more difficult job to get established.

Sure Start's physical presence there at the moment is a ground-floor office in a block of flats. King works there, and has set aside part of the room for a play area. Plans for a purpose-built centre are still on the architect's drawing board.

She is not daunted, but says that getting the structure in place is hard work. Unlike other cities, none of the places of worship or community groups in Ladywood run groups for the under-fours and their parents. So everything has to start from scratch.

Ladywood is in the process of appointing most of the 30 staff to its team. In Billesley, they are already in place, with Solanki at the hub. But until Chinnbrook is extended to provide permanent offices, their base is the offices of a local church - and will be for another year at least.

This does not seem to worry them too much. Child centres are crucial to Sure Start's success; but the input of staff is equally, if not more, important. Several who worked with health or social services in the Birmingham area before joining Solanki's team feel liberated. In Sure Start, they say, they are able to do preventive work with families where the life chances of young kids are bleak. Before, their work was mostly post-crisis.

They are learning from each other, too, and doing new things. Ruth Field, a former childminder, now networks among other childminders - giving them, for the first time, support and encouragement, while monitoring the standards of a group much in demand as more mothers go out to work.

The scale of what Sure Start is doing is not always apparent in Ladywood. There are isolated single teenage mothers for Angela Rainbow, parent support coordinator, to cheer up and chat to. And there are parents who know no nursery rhymes to teach their babies; they will be glad that team member Christina Ali has specially compiled a book for them to use.

The Billesley team hums with good humour; there is almost an air of novelty that different disciplines can work together. One of the tests of Sure Start's success will be professional cooperation. Eisenstadt says: "It's my experience that between health, education and social services, two work well together - though which two is completely random. Getting the three to work together is extremely difficult."

Her other concern is that one of these service providers might be tempted to reduce provision in places which have a Sure Start scheme. They would be unwise to do so, for although the projects are being funded for three years initially, it is likely that they will become community focal points and fixtures for much longer.

From the frontline, there is concern about the initial time limit. King says that the targets are fine, but she thinks that they might take longer to meet than civil servants and ministers have allowed.

Maybe it is just as well that the government has given itself 20 years in which to eradicate child poverty. Well before then, though, we should be able to see if Sure Start has made much difference to a raft of problems that has long perplexed the social policy makers.

Schemes and dreams

Alison Benjamin

By 2004, the government will have poured more than £1bn into 500 Sure Stuart schemes providing support for one-third of disadvantaged children under four years old across England - some 400,000 in all.

Initially, £452m was earmarked for some 250 schemes being set up between1999 -2002.

The first 21 trailblazers got the go- ahead in April 1999 and were up and running by the autumn. Since then more than 100 schemes have received a share of the funding.

In this year's government spending review, an extra £580m was announced up until March 2004.

New Sure Start schemes are starting up each week. They are led by a variety of agencies - from charities to health authorities and local community organistions.

For example, a Leeds partnership, led by the NSPCC, has received £2.8m to provide extra childcare, health visitor drop in sessions and additional playgroups for 1,080 children under the age of four.

In the Ore Valley, Hastings, three Sure Start centres are already providing a health and baby clinic, "cooking on a budget" classes, and speech and language therapy.

webTitle: Town hall reform boldly goes further

fields.headline: Star qualities
fields.standfirst:
Town hall reform boldly goes further
Society special report: Local government
fields.trailText: Town hall reform boldly goes further
fields.body:
Buckinghamshire county council this week became the latest local authority to introduce cabinet-style administration. Chief executive Ian Crookall will tomorrow be describing the transition in a presentation entitled: "It's a structure, Jim, but not as we know it."

The Star Trek allusion will strike a chord with many in local government who feel they are boldly going into the unknown. The first shake-up in town hall structures for more than a century, combined with the new best-value regime, represents unprecedented change.

Crookall will be address council leaders from across south-east England at the South East Employers (SEE) conference, which starts today in Hythe, Kent. Councillors and officers from 74 member authorities will be discussing ways to tackle the opportunities and risks presented by the government's drive to modernise municipal affairs.

"The pace of change for people in local government is enormous," says Madeleine Sumison, SEE regional director. "The trick is to identify skills and knowledge to take themselves through it. They have to focus on quality and internal procedures without losing sight of what this means externally for their citizens."

Buckinghamshire's journey to cabinet-style government has taken 18 months. The process culminated in a survey of 8,500 residents, the majority of whom backed the new approach, under which there will be lead councillors responsible for policy areas such as children's services, care services, community services, planning and transport.

Crookall says: "Some members find this level of change very threatening; others see the opportunities for the future. They are different sides of the same coin. It means more time commitment from cabinet level councillors and they will also be more high profile and accountable." His advice to others contemplating such change is: "Plan it carefully, take time, minimise risks and take everyone with you."

The conference, which is supported by the Guardian, will also look at the emergence of public/ private partnerships, such as the contract for support services at Lincolnshire county council.

Gail Shadlock, human resources manager for Hyder Business Services, has overseen the partnership. She was one of 1,000 council employees who relinquished their jobs with the authority - in her case, as head of personnel and development - to transfer to the private company.

The council went down the partnership route, says Shadlock, in a bid to secure investment, savings and growth in personnel, finance, IT, property and catering services. In the first year, IT has received a £5m cash injection. She says: "We went for a partnership, rather than outsourcing, because this way the public and the private partners have mutually agreed objectives and sit on a joint partnership board. In contrast, outsourcing can lead to a blame culture."

Middlesbrough council is about to enter a similar partnership with Hyder, starting in April. For other councils thinking of taking a similar step, Shadlock warns: "It is a major culture change and people are apprehensive. It is crucial that unions and employee representatives are involved from the start."

Gail Shadlock, human resources manager for Hyder Business Services, has overseen the partnership. She was one of 1,000 council employees who relinquished their jobs with the authority - in her case, as head of personnel and development - to transfer to the private company. The council went down the partnership route, says Shadlock, in a bid to secure investment, savings and growth in personnel, finance, IT, property and catering services. In the first year, IT has received a £5m cash injection. She says: "We went for a partnership, rather than outsourcing, because this way the public and the private partners have mutually agreed objectives and sit on a joint partnership board. In contrast, outsourcing can lead to a blame culture." Middlesbrough council is about to enter a similar partnership with Hyder, starting in April. For other councils thinking of taking a similar step, Shadlock warns: "It is a major culture change and people are apprehensive. It is crucial that unions and employee representatives are involved from the start."

webTitle: No nice little earner for health ministers

fields.headline: No nice little earner for health ministers
fields.standfirst: National institute for clinical excellence reveals £100m costs of implementing advice in first year
fields.trailText: National institute for clinical excellence reveals £100m costs of implementing advice in first year
fields.body:
Ministers have been told to forget any idea that their new health care appraisal agency will save money. So far, according to the man chairing the agency, it has cost "well in excess of £100m".

When the national institute for clinical excellence (Nice) was set up, it was widely seen as a means of rationing costly new drugs and procedures. But Sir Michael Rawlins, its chair, last week told the organisation's annual conference that the cost of implementing its advice in its first full year had been more than £150m. Savings from the advice had been £47m.

Rawlins also dismissed suggestions, fuelled by Nice's change of heart on anti-flu treatment Relenza, that the agency has been pressured by the government. There had, he said, been "no overt - or covert - attempt by ministers or officials to influence our guidance" and no guidance about available resources.

"Although the secretary of state does have reserve powers if we do 'lose the plot', we have never had a steer - formally or informally - about the nature of the guidance we should give," Rawlins insisted.

Nice's forthcoming work programme includes production of clinical guidelines for conditions ranging from dyspepsia to schizophrenia, as well as for pre-operative investigations.

Egon Jonsson, director of Nice's equivalent body in Sweden, told the conference in Harrogate that as a consequence of his agency's recommendation, routine pre-operative testing of younger patients in Swedish hospitals had all but ceased. Savings had amounted to five times the agency's budget.

As a result, Jonsson said, health ministers had offered to double the budget. "Watch out, Nice, this could happen over and over again," he warned, "and it's not that easy to spend money wisely."

Jonsson called for greater collaboration among appraisal bodies - of which there were 20 in Europe, assessing 600 drugs and procedures at any one time. He said: "I notice that many of the topics that Nice is going to look at are topics that many other agencies, including my own, have already done."

The British agency was uniquely strong, however. "Nice has the power to say no," Jonsson said. "The potential is enormous."

webTitle: The human damage after the floods

fields.headline: In deep trouble
fields.standfirst: What happens when floods are no longer front page news?  Judy Hirst reports on how councils and voluntary agencies are trying to deal with the human damage from Britain's worst hit areas
fields.trailText: What happens when floods are no longer front page news? Judy Hirst reports on how councils and voluntary agencies are trying to deal with the human damage from Britain's worst hit areas
fields.body:
Five-year old Shannon is still having nightmares and cries a lot. She was rescued by lifeboat out of her first-floor flat window, with 15 feet of water swirling menacingly beneath. Now she won't take a bath or go swimming, and doesn't want to go to school. As with many other children at her school in Lewes, east Sussex, the recent floods have left her anxious and withdrawn.

Unlike in countries such as Bangladesh or Mozambique, severe flooding causes few physical health risks in industrialised nations. The residents of Lewes or York are unlikely to go down with dysentry or cholera.

However, up to 20% of natural disaster victims may suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder. Many will feel depressed and isolated, losing their sense of place and attachment, or developing obsessive anxieties as a result of their ordeal. The British Medical Journal has recently highlighted that the psychological costs of climate change are likely to be considerable.

"Shannon needs help," says her mother, Irene Hoad. And so does Irene. A young, single parent, she relied heavily on the network of neighbours in her block. Now all the ground-floor tenants have gone, decanted from their sodden, ruined homes into temporary accommodation. The council says it will take until next summer to make their homes habitable. Most will not be coming back.

Four hundred families were made homeless by the Lewes floods. A third of them had no insurance or were underinsured. According to the Association of British Insurers (ABI) an estimated six million homeowners do not have contents cover. Some are living out of mobile homes in their gardens. Many more are in caravans, B&Bs and rented accommodation all over the district. And some, the council frankly admits, it doesn't have a clue about. With families displaced and split up, and anxieties about insurance mounting by the day, the floods are taking a huge emotional toll.

The good news is that increased social support, along with practical help, can significantly mitigate the less quantifiable psychological effects. By and large, though, this is being left up to voluntary agencies and community-minded individuals to provide.

In Lewes, it's the volunteer bureau - run on a shoestring and under threat of closure - that's helping the uninsured to clear out their homes, get together some clothes and furniture, and start rebuilding their lives. A charitable "hardship" fund has also been set up to distribute to residents who have suffered distress. To date, more than £140,000 has been raised - much of it from members of the public.

Mind, Age Concern and East Sussex Disability Association are among the voluntary groups which have set up a flood aftercare group with social services funding. More than 100 calls to the helpline range from people desperate to find a dehumidifier, to parents of children with drowned pets, to those - often with previous psychological problems - who have been deeply disturbed by the recent events. Many just want to talk. The more severely affected are being offered counselling and other specialist services.

It's not just the flood victims who need support. There's the bin man who broke down in tears after clear ing out countless contaminated homes; the firefighter racked with guilt because he was out helping others when his own family's home was flooded; the care staff dealing with loss and trauma at emergency centres. Many of these workers need a chance to unburden their own feelings.

"The full impact of these floods is unlikely to be felt for some time," says Phil Dodgson, head of adult psychology services at South Downs health trust, Sussex. "Many people will be experiencing anger, guilt and feelings of dread. Some, the ones having persistent flash-backs or feeling very depressed and confused, will need help to reprocess their feelings."

The psychological effect of severe flooding, as compared with a train crash or other major trauma, should not be underestimated, he says. The speed and force with which the water has risen, smashing down doors and sending furniture crashing against walls, has thrown whole communities into a state of shock.

The most vulnerable people at a time like this are the young, old, disabled and mentally ill. In Crawley, West Sussex, 42 frail, elderly residents of a care home had to be evacuated in the early hours because the ground floor was under water. They left without anything, in their nightclothes, and ended up dispersed all over the county to residential homes as far away as Worthing. With few vacancies nearby, and their care home badly damaged, instant decisions had to be made about whether these transfers would be short-term or long-term. "The psychological effect on these residents can only be imagined," says local operations manager, Pat Howe.

In York, too, emergency decisions had to be made about evacuating elderly people when the River Ouse burst its banks. In one case, the community services director, Jim Crook, opted for sandbagging a care home which has very dependent residents, rather than risk moving them. Fortunately, the gamble paid off.

In another instance, there was no choice. Thirty-five older residents had to be moved out of their riverside sheltered homes, and into temporary accommodation, after the floods took out a local power station. York's joint social services and housing department was able to do this relatively efficiently, Crook says, and to help the emergency services identify the most vulnerable people thoughout the worst of the flooding.

For Peter Smurthwaite, who is severely visually impaired, the floods brought not just shock, trauma and the loss of his Lewes home, but also endless battles with his insurers over whether he can stay in a town where he knows his way around, or whether he must move to cheaper temporary accommodation miles away.

East Sussex social services, like many around the country, has been hard-pressed to make even these imperfect arrangements. "Because of the pressures on our community care budget, there's a lot less in-house provision," says Phil Gander, head of mental health services. "We can't find money to ease bed-blocking, let alone provide an emergency infrastructure for evacuees."

It was the aftercare group, run by Mind and other voluntary groups, that laid on a creche for flood-hit families, and which is starting up counselling sessions in Shannon's school. Irene hopes they will help. Sitting in her sunny living room, on a crisp cold morning, it's hard to imagine the day, just a few weeks ago, when the water came from nowhere, turning the road outside into a torrent. But it was real enough, and there have been several flood warnings since.

Shannon keeps saying: "Mummy, it's happening again." Irene and her neighbours try to brush her worries aside. They're concentrating instead on giving her a really good Christmas.

Counting the cost

Alison Benjamin

The Association of British Insurers estimates that the floods may have caused up to £500m of damage. East Sussex county council and Lewes district council estimate that the cost to them is in the region of £7m. Of this, £150,000 covers the cost of short-term care packages, extra staffing and the flood aftercare group. Other councils are still counting the initial costs. Damages to bridges and roads may not be fully known until water levels have dropped considerably.

The Bellwin scheme allows councils, in theory, to claim back spending on emergencies from central government above a threshold. Currently councils have to put aside 0.2% of their budgets for emergency expenditure. A claim for any additional costs is then lodged with the government. Following the floods, deputy prime minister, John Prescott, pledged to increase the percentage the government covers from 85% to 100% of a claim.

However, East Sussex has already had the majority of its claim rejected. Council leader David Rodgers says: "We have been disappointed by the response of government to our application. It has confirmed what we thought about the scheme: it does not cover the costs of this type of disaster."

This was one of the topics on the agenda at yesterday's central-local partnership, a forum chaired by Prescott where issues affecting local government are discussed. The Local Government Association fed in the main concerns from local authorities around the country - not least, who will foot the £1.2bn bill for increased flood defences. The government has agreed to look at the whole funding mechanism.

webTitle: Film: The best home-coming scene

fields.headline: The best home-coming scene
fields.standfirst: Chopper
fields.trailText: Chopper
fields.body:
Having just been released from a decade in prison, Mark "Chopper" Read has spent his first day of liberty taking drugs with his girlfriend Tanya (Kate Beahan). Eventually he girds himself and pays a visit to his father Keith (Kenny Graham). The house is badly lit and virtually stripped of furniture. Fast asleep in the front room, Keith is woken by Chopper (Eric Bana) coming through the front door.

"Mark, is that you?"

"Sorry, Dad, didn't know you were asleep."

"Come in here, Mark."

"No, you're alright. Go back to sleep, Dad."

"Nah, come in here. You haven't been out for ten years ... where've you been all day?"

Peering at his father, Chopper ignores the question.

"You alright Dad? You look tired. Go back to sleep."

"Get in here and talk to your old dad," insists his father. "You've been away for ten years."

Reluctantly, Chopper takes a seat opposite his father.

"Don't sit there! Sit over here in this chair."

As Chopper moves to a chair beside his father, he notices a rather forlorn banner taped above the curtains:

WELCOME HOME MARK

"I've been sitting around all day waiting for you."

Father and son sit in complete silence. After what seems like an age, Keith turns to Chopper.

"So, you want a drink?"

"Yeah."

See also: Festen, Le Retour de Martin Guerre, Psycho II, Passion Fish, Flight Of The Navigator

Don't see also: Coming Home

Pointless trivia: Chopper topped box office charts in its native Australia, dislodging Mel Gibson's The Patriot in the process.

webTitle: Sure Start's bold aims assessed

fields.headline: Sure Start's bold aims assessed
fields.standfirst: When the government launched Sure Start projects they were trumpeted as vital to the strategy for eradicating child poverty. Are they living up to that promise?  John Cunningham  reports
fields.trailText: When the government launched Sure Start projects they were trumpeted as vital to the strategy for eradicating child poverty. Are they living up to that promise? John Cunningham reports
fields.body:
In the offices of one of Birmingham's Sure Start schemes, there is a fat book, a 150-page plan detailing how the project, when it's up and running, could transform the lives of children under the age of four in disadvantaged families in Ladywood. At the other scheme, a few miles away in Billesley, months spent preparing sums and surveys have been distilled into a leaflet listing the help now at hand.

It is user-friendly - and needs to be - to guide parents through the web of midwife, health visitor, social worker, speech therapist, childminder, parent support coordinator, creche co-ordinator, inclusion worker (special needs), home start volunteers (practical home support) for a suburban area where about 800 families have children aged four and under.

The government has identified 200 deprived areas needing assistance, where 500 Sure Start schemes will be up and running by 2004.

Coloured dots mark the different waves of Sure Starts on the wallmap in Naomi Eisenstadt's office in London. As head of unit, she's charged with implementing the partnerships which link a locality's childcare needs (as listed by parents) with a guaranteed budget of £2-3m, professional input and advice, and monitoring of targets. This is managed through a public service agreement between the agency and local projects. Eisenstadt calls it "a very elegant, innovative combination of top down [Sure Start is funded by the health and education ministries] and bottom up [parents and local services]".

Ministers have set the targets, mostly expressed as percentage improvements to be attained. These cover the social and emotional development, and the health and ability to learn, of the under-fours. Since the scheme started 18 months ago, Eisenstadt says one aim - a 5% reduction in the number of low birthweight babies - has been replaced by the clearer aim of getting mothers-to-be not to smoke during pregnancy. Also, there is a greater emphasis on links with employment, such as New Deal for lone parents.

"In terms of specific targets, we are setting ones that individual communities can work towards," says Eisenstadt. "We have never worked this way before, so we'll have to learn as we go along

Setting goals and adopting a seemingly prescriptive approach could give the impression that it is yet another preachy New Labour policy. But Sure Starts have been conceived as partnerships on the basis that, in order to work, they have to be parent-friendly, non-judgmental towards families with problems, and locally-led.

You can see the importance of getting a community to make a bid for Sure Start money, and for local people to be involved, in the two Birmingham projects. In Ladywood, a small local charity, Karis, took the lead. Angie King, a former nurse onsecondment from Karis to get the scheme off the ground, says the community was so used to being overlooked that it could scarcely believe it was really getting a grant.

Enthusiastic parents quickly listed their wants. Top of the list was something quite simple - a support team of volunteers who could help with other children when one child in a family was ill or when parents were out shopping. But the scheme is developing from there. King says that because supermarkets are distant from the area, one aim is to help teach parents about nutrition by starting a centre which serves and sells cheap, nourishing foods.

In Billesley, local people were anxious to expand an existing facility with a good reputation, the Chinnbrook Children and Parents' Project. Bhavna Solanki, programme manager, says it is an excellent core; and Sure Start will be spending about £1m on a building programme, to offer more services and attract more parents.

Home visits by childcare staff are a key element of Sure Start's approach, but almost all the projects also want their own centre - either purpose-built or suitably adapted premises - with clinics, play areas and the rest.

Billesley has got off to a flying start because there is an existing community centre on which to graft. Ladywood (which came in a later batch of Sure Starts) has a much more difficult job to get established.

Sure Start's physical presence there at the moment is a ground-floor office in a block of flats. King works there, and has set aside part of the room for a play area. Plans for a purpose-built centre are still on the architect's drawing board.

She is not daunted, but says that getting the structure in place is hard work. Unlike other cities, none of the places of worship or community groups in Ladywood run groups for the under-fours and their parents. So everything has to start from scratch.

Ladywood is in the process of appointing most of the 30 staff to its team. In Billesley, they are already in place, with Solanki at the hub. But until Chinnbrook is extended to provide permanent offices, their base is the offices of a local church - and will be for another year at least.

This does not seem to worry them too much. Child centres are crucial to Sure Start's success; but the input of staff is equally, if not more, important. Several who worked with health or social services in the Birmingham area before joining Solanki's team feel liberated. In Sure Start, they say, they are able to do preventive work with families where the life chances of young kids are bleak. Before, their work was mostly post-crisis.

They are learning from each other, too, and doing new things. Ruth Field, a former childminder, now networks among other childminders - giving them, for the first time, support and encouragement, while monitoring the standards of a group much in demand as more mothers go out to work.

The scale of what Sure Start is doing is not always apparent in Ladywood. There are isolated single teenage mothers for Angela Rainbow, parent support coordinator, to cheer up and chat to. And there are parents who know no nursery rhymes to teach their babies; they will be glad that team member Christina Ali has specially compiled a book for them to use.

The Billesley team hums with good humour; there is almost an air of novelty that different disciplines can work together. One of the tests of Sure Start's success will be professional cooperation. Eisenstadt says: "It's my experience that between health, education and social services, two work well together - though which two is completely random. Getting the three to work together is extremely difficult."

Her other concern is that one of these service providers might be tempted to reduce provision in places which have a Sure Start scheme. They would be unwise to do so, for although the projects are being funded for three years initially, it is likely that they will become community focal points and fixtures for much longer.

From the frontline, there is concern about the initial time limit. King says that the targets are fine, but she thinks that they might take longer to meet than civil servants and ministers have allowed.

Maybe it is just as well that the government has given itself 20 years in which to eradicate child poverty. Well before then, though, we should be able to see if Sure Start has made much difference to a raft of problems that has long perplexed the social policy makers.

Schemes and dreams
Alison Benjamin

By 2004, the government will have poured more than £1bn into 500 Sure Stuart schemes providing support for one-third of disadvantaged children under four years old across England - some 400,000 in all.

Initially, £452m was earmarked for some 250 schemes being set up between1999 -2002.

The first 21 trailblazers got the go- ahead in April 1999 and were up and running by the autumn. Since then more than 100 schemes have received a share of the funding.

In this year's government spending review, an extra £580m was announced up until March 2004.

New Sure Start schemes are starting up each week. They are led by a variety of agencies - from charities to health authorities and local community organistions.

For example, a Leeds partnership, led by the NSPCC, has received £2.8m to provide extra childcare, health visitor drop in sessions and additional playgroups for 1,080 children under the age of four.

In the Ore Valley, Hastings, three Sure Start centres are already providing a health and baby clinic, "cooking on a budget" classes, and speech and language therapy.

The government has identified 200 deprived areas needing assistance, where 500 Sure Start schemes will be up and running by 2004. Coloured dots mark the different waves of Sure Starts on the wallmap in Naomi Eisenstadt's office in London. As head of unit, she's charged with implementing the partnerships which link a locality's childcare needs (as listed by parents) with a guaranteed budget of £2-3m, professional input and advice, and monitoring of targets. This is managed through a public service agreement between the agency and local projects. Eisenstadt calls it "a very elegant, innovative combination of top down [Sure Start is funded by the health and education ministries] and bottom up [parents and local services]". Ministers have set the targets, mostly expressed as percentage improvements to be attained. These cover the social and emotional development, and the health and ability to learn, of the under-fours. Since the scheme started 18 months ago, Eisenstadt says one aim - a 5% reduction in the number of low birthweight babies - has been replaced by the clearer aim of getting mothers-to-be not to smoke during pregnancy. Also, there is a greater emphasis on links with employment, such as New Deal for lone parents. "In terms of specific targets, we are setting ones that individual communities can work towards," says Eisenstadt. "We have never worked this way before, so we'll have to learn as we go along Setting goals and adopting a seemingly prescriptive approach could give the impression that it is yet another preachy New Labour policy. But Sure Starts have been conceived as partnerships on the basis that, in order to work, they have to be parent-friendly, non-judgmental towards families with problems, and locally-led. You can see the importance of getting a community to make a bid for Sure Start money, and for local people to be involved, in the two Birmingham projects. In Ladywood, a small local charity, Karis, took the lead. Angie King, a former nurse onsecondment from Karis to get the scheme off the ground, says the community was so used to being overlooked that it could scarcely believe it was really getting a grant. Enthusiastic parents quickly listed their wants. Top of the list was something quite simple - a support team of volunteers who could help with other children when one child in a family was ill or when parents were out shopping. But the scheme is developing from there. King says that because supermarkets are distant from the area, one aim is to help teach parents about nutrition by starting a centre which serves and sells cheap, nourishing foods. In Billesley, local people were anxious to expand an existing facility with a good reputation, the Chinnbrook Children and Parents' Project. Bhavna Solanki, programme manager, says it is an excellent core; and Sure Start will be spending about £1m on a building programme, to offer more services and attract more parents. Home visits by childcare staff are a key element of Sure Start's approach, but almost all the projects also want their own centre - either purpose-built or suitably adapted premises - with clinics, play areas and the rest. Billesley has got off to a flying start because there is an existing community centre on which to graft. Ladywood (which came in a later batch of Sure Starts) has a much more difficult job to get established. Sure Start's physical presence there at the moment is a ground-floor office in a block of flats. King works there, and has set aside part of the room for a play area. Plans for a purpose-built centre are still on the architect's drawing board. She is not daunted, but says that getting the structure in place is hard work. Unlike other cities, none of the places of worship or community groups in Ladywood run groups for the under-fours and their parents. So everything has to start from scratch. Ladywood is in the process of appointing most of the 30 staff to its team. In Billesley, they are already in place, with Solanki at the hub. But until Chinnbrook is extended to provide permanent offices, their base is the offices of a local church - and will be for another year at least. This does not seem to worry them too much. Child centres are crucial to Sure Start's success; but the input of staff is equally, if not more, important. Several who worked with health or social services in the Birmingham area before joining Solanki's team feel liberated. In Sure Start, they say, they are able to do preventive work with families where the life chances of young kids are bleak. Before, their work was mostly post-crisis. They are learning from each other, too, and doing new things. Ruth Field, a former childminder, now networks among other childminders - giving them, for the first time, support and encouragement, while monitoring the standards of a group much in demand as more mothers go out to work. The scale of what Sure Start is doing is not always apparent in Ladywood. There are isolated single teenage mothers for Angela Rainbow, parent support coordinator, to cheer up and chat to. And there are parents who know no nursery rhymes to teach their babies; they will be glad that team member Christina Ali has specially compiled a book for them to use. The Billesley team hums with good humour; there is almost an air of novelty that different disciplines can work together. One of the tests of Sure Start's success will be professional cooperation. Eisenstadt says: "It's my experience that between health, education and social services, two work well together - though which two is completely random. Getting the three to work together is extremely difficult." Her other concern is that one of these service providers might be tempted to reduce provision in places which have a Sure Start scheme. They would be unwise to do so, for although the projects are being funded for three years initially, it is likely that they will become community focal points and fixtures for much longer. From the frontline, there is concern about the initial time limit. King says that the targets are fine, but she thinks that they might take longer to meet than civil servants and ministers have allowed. Maybe it is just as well that the government has given itself 20 years in which to eradicate child poverty. Well before then, though, we should be able to see if Sure Start has made much difference to a raft of problems that has long perplexed the social policy makers. Schemes and dreams Alison Benjamin By 2004, the government will have poured more than £1bn into 500 Sure Stuart schemes providing support for one-third of disadvantaged children under four years old across England - some 400,000 in all. Initially, £452m was earmarked for some 250 schemes being set up between1999 -2002. The first 21 trailblazers got the go- ahead in April 1999 and were up and running by the autumn. Since then more than 100 schemes have received a share of the funding. In this year's government spending review, an extra £580m was announced up until March 2004. New Sure Start schemes are starting up each week. They are led by a variety of agencies - from charities to health authorities and local community organistions. For example, a Leeds partnership, led by the NSPCC, has received £2.8m to provide extra childcare, health visitor drop in sessions and additional playgroups for 1,080 children under the age of four. In the Ore Valley, Hastings, three Sure Start centres are already providing a health and baby clinic, "cooking on a budget" classes, and speech and language therapy.

webTitle: A guide to Sure Start

fields.headline: A guide to Sure Start
fields.trailText:
What is Sure Start?

Sure Start aims to improve the health and well-being of families and children before and from birth, as part of the government's drive to tackle child poverty and social exclusion.
It does this by setting up local programmes to improve services for families with children under four.
fields.body:
What is Sure Start?

Sure Start aims to improve the health and well-being of families and children before and from birth, as part of the government's drive to tackle child poverty and social exclusion.
It does this by setting up local programmes to improve services for families with children under four.

How many programmes are there?

By 2002, there will be at least 250 Sure Start local programmes. They will be concentrated in neighbourhoods where a high proportion of children are living in poverty.

How do the programmes work?

Local programmes work with parents and parents-to-be to improve children's life chances through better access to:
&#149 Family support
&#149 Advice on nurturing
&#149 Health services
&#149 Early learning

How much is the government investing in Sure Start?
The government is investing £452m for the period 1999-2000 to 2001-02. The spending review in July announced an extra £580m for Sure Start over the period April 2001 to March 2004.

What is the aim of Sure Start?
&#149 To work with parents and children to promote the physical, intellectual and social development of pre-school children, particularly those who are disadvantaged.
&#149 To improve health by supporting parents in caring for their children to promote healthy development before and after birth.
&#149 To improve social and emotional development by supporting early bonding between parents and their children.
&#149 To help families to function and by enabling the early identification and support of children with emotional and behavioural difficulties.
&#149 To improve the ability to learn by encouraging stimulating and enjoyable play, improving language skills and through early identification and support of children with learning difficulties

What are the targets of the Sure Start programme?
&#149 Parenting support and information for all parents.
&#149 A 10 per cent reduction in children re-registered on a child protection register.
&#149 Identifying, caring for and supporting mothers with post-natal depression.
&#149 A 5 per cent reduction in proportion of low birth-weight babies.
&#149 A 10 per cent reduction in children admitted to hospital as an emergency during their first year of life with gastro-enteritis, a respiratory infection, or a severe injury.
&#149 At least 90 per cent of children with normal speech and language development at 18 months and 3 years.
&#149 100 per cent of children in sure start areas to have access to good quality play and early learning opportunities, helping progress towards early learning goals when they get to school.

webTitle: Ferguson not losing sleep over red devils

fields.headline: Ferguson not losing sleep over red devils
fields.standfirst: Daniel Taylor finds United aiming to breach Graz's home security
fields.trailText: Daniel Taylor finds United aiming to breach Graz's home security.
fields.body:
Graz may be, as the city's slogan has it, Europe's "secret love" but for Manchester United the attractions on offer here last night could be viewed only as possible distractions.

While Austria's second city reverberated to its annual Krampustag festival, Styria's bigger and better equivalent of Hallowe'en, United were keeping their distance ahead of tonight's renewal of acquaintances with Sturm Graz. They have found a more sedate retreat on the city's outskirts after learning that anywhere near the central Hauptplatz would be tantamount to taking a shotgun to their feet.

Sleep, they were warned, would be a precious commodity while hundreds of fancy-dress devils carrying inflatable pitchforks partied beneath their hotel windows. The custom apparently is to swish each other's legs with twigs, although it is a safe bet Sir Alex Ferguson declined a local newspaper's offer to take part.

Ferguson will be looking for his players to rediscover the streak of fearlessness on their travels they showed in this competition two seasons ago.

Although Graz are seen as the weak link in Group A, losing their opening game at Valencia 2-0 while United beat Panathinaikos 3-1, the Austrians possess a formidable home record, having beaten Monaco, Galatasaray and Rangers to qualify from the first phase. "They are home specialists, that's their forte," Ferguson said yesterday. "In those three games they gave away only two clear chances."

Whether United fare any better depends on them adapting more readily to the fact that their presence can inspire the smaller clubs in Europe. Since winning the European Cup in 1999 they have won only three out of 10 games on the Continent and it is only their excellence at Old Trafford that has preserved their interest in the competition.

Even so, having beaten Graz home and away last season, tonight's game at the Arnold Schwarzenegger stadium should provide a reasonable opportunity for Ferguson to find an antidote for the travel sickness. "We need to change our mentality in Europe," said his assistant Steve McClaren. "Away matches are more difficult now because defeating us is so much of a scalp." That seems to have been borne out by the fact all 15,000 tickets were bought within 30 minutes of going on sale. The atmosphere promises to be on the warm side even if the temperature dropped to -1C yesterday.

David Beckham is sure of a hot reception. Last season he upset Graz with a bad tackle on Tomislav Kocijan. Their midfielder Roman Mählich said: "I was furious and I told him I didn't like his wife's music." Judging by sales of the Spice Girls' new CD, he is not alone.

Sturm Graz (probable, 3-5-2): Sidorczuk; Neukirchner, Mamedov, Prilasnig; Schopp, Korsos, Fleurquin, Mählich, Minavand; Vastic, Kocijan.

Manchester United (probable, 4-4-2): Barthez; P Neville, Brown, G Neville, Irwin; Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs; Sheringham, Yorke.

webTitle: Morrison's double helps evict awkward tenants

fields.headline: Morrison's double helps evict awkward tenants
fields.standfirst: Crystal Palace 3 - 1 Wimbledon
fields.trailText: Crystal Palace 3 - 1 Wimbledon
fields.body:
The most local derby in the league ended with victory for Crystal Palace, who came from behind to continue their resolute climb up the table. For the Dons it was another blow after losing at home to West Brom on Saturday.

Wimbledon came into the game boasting a very strange record: no team in the four divisions had triumphed in more away games while only Middlesbrough have won fewer at home. So they were optimistic that their away status in this landlord v tenant encounter would count in their favour. Sure enough, they went ahead after only 27 minutes.

Neal Ardley broke down the right, leaving Tommy Black in his wake, before firing in a cross to the far post where Andy Roberts, running in, steered a precise shot past Aleksandrs Kolinko in his former club's goal. The record books posted a more dismal entry for Kolinko: that made it 13 league games running in which he had failed to keep a clean sheet.

Palace, however, on the back of an unbeaten six-game run, had been the first to threaten, Clinton Morrison and Neil Ruddock both spurning inviting headers. But Wimbledon soon picked themselves up: Roberts went close and after Damien Francis was put clean through, only a precise tackle from Ruddock denied him.

In that sense the Dons' lead was well merited, though a minute after going behind Palace should have equalised. The on-loan striker Mikael Forssell fired in a shot which Kelvin Davis spilled and though Morrison pounced on the rebound, the goalkeeper make amends and blocked the shot.

The football was basic and even the passion which fuelled some memorable battles between the pair when they were in the Premiership was conspicuous by its absence.

But Palace came out for the second half looking as though strong words from the manager had been served up with the tea. And they soon equalised. Black broke down the left and pulled back a cross to the near post where Forssell squeezed the ball over the line for his fourth goal in three games.

Nine minutes later they took the lead. Jamie Pollock made a surging run into the heart of the Wimbledon defence, played the ball out right to Jamie Smith who fired in a shot which Davis could only parry. Morrison easily headed in the rebound for his 11th of the season. They added a third 12 minutes from time, Morrison scoring his second after Davis had only parried Forssell's shot.

webTitle: Collymore in clear after nightclub row

fields.headline: Collymore in clear after nightclub row
fields.trailText: Stan Collymore has received his club, Bradford City's full backing after a nightclub fracas at the weekend left him with a suspected broken nose.
fields.body:
Stan Collymore has received the full support of Bradford City after a nightclub fracas left the striker with a suspected broken nose.

Collymore was out celebrating Bradford's 2-1 victory over Coventry on Sunday night when, according to his club chairman Geoffrey Richmond, he was attacked without provocation. "We are 100% satisfied that he was not in any way to blame," said Richmond. "He was there in the nightclub having a quiet drink and a group started taunting him about being a 'Villa reject'. The next thing you know he's being headbutted in the nose and there is blood everywhere."

Celtic last night missed Leicester City's deadline to improve their £5m offer for the midfielder Neil Lennon. The Foxes' manager Peter Taylor was seeking £5m for Leicester plus the £700,000 owed to Lennon's former club Crewe as a sell-on clause.

Aston Villa are poised to re-sign the Republic of Ireland defender Steve Staunton, who spent seven seasons with the club from 1991, on a free transfer from Liverpool. But Celtic's unsettled midfielder Eyal Berkovic has refused the offer of a loan deal at Villa Park.

Gary Megson, who has been working as the West Bromwich Albion manager without a contract, has signed a deal which will keep him at the Hawthorns until 2003. "If Albion are stronger than when I took over by the end of my three years then I will be happy," he said.

webTitle: Venables lashes out at FA 'designer people'

fields.headline: Venables lashes out at FA 'designer people'
fields.standfirst: Terry's silence is broken on FA's decision to look overseas
fields.trailText: Terry's silence is broken on FA's decision to look overseas.
fields.body:
Terry Venables has launched a withering attack on the Football Association's mandarins who refused to bow to public pressure and reinstall him as the England coach.

If the end of Venables's diplomatic silence over the FA's decision to install the Swede Sven-Goran Eriksson as the successor to Kevin Keegan was predictable enough, the manner in which the 57-year-old condemned its actions was totally unexpected.

Never afraid to portray himself as a 22-carat patriot, the newly-appointed coach to Middlesbrough derided the "designer people" at the FA who chose to overlook home-grown candidates in favour of Eriksson.

"By choosing to go to a foreign situation we've chosen to say that we are not a power any more but we, the Football Association, will show you the way forwards - show you how clever we are because we are designer people now, we are not old farts any more," Venables told the BBC's Match of the Day magazine.

Venables, who stepped down as England coach after Euro 96 - he claimed to concentrate his efforts on legal matters - even went so far as to suggest that he might find it difficult to lend his support to a national team selected by a foreign coach.

"If [Glenn] Hoddle and Keegan had done well, I'd celebrate like mad," he said. "I have nothing against him [Eriksson]. He looks like a gentleman. Put it this way, I don't think it's a good idea.

"It's like saying, 'we are in the war and we've got no generals. Well, what's Rommel doing [then]? Is he available?' They are saying, we want to cheat; we want to win, and to win we have got to get someone from outside," he added.

The fact that Venables went down under to manage Australia during their unsuccessful 1998 World Cup qualifying campaign might leave him open to accusations of being hypocritical.

"It was slightly different," he claimed. "They said, 'we want you to come to Australia because we are a country that does not get anything on the back page. We think you can do a job for us and we want an Australian manager when you leave'. "

webTitle: Gains and prawn keep United top of the rich list

fields.headline: Gains and prawn keep United top of the rich list
fields.standfirst: Football wealth chart sees ten British clubs among the twenty richest with Man Utd top of the heap
fields.trailText: Football wealth chart sees ten British clubs among the twenty richest with Man Utd top of the heap.
fields.body:
Manchester United have again been named the richest club in the world, although several of their European rivals could overtake the Premiership champions in the near future through lucrative TV deals that dwarf those finalised in Britain.

Ten British clubs are included in the world's top 20 named in the annual Deloitte & Touche/FourFourTwo list yesterday, with United registering a turnover of £110.9m in their treble-winning season of 1998-99, the one on which the rankings are based. The figure represents a 26% increase for the club year-on-year.

The list confirms the popularity and financial well-being of British football, with eight Premiership teams in total, as well as Celtic and Rangers, making up the 20.

Bayern Munich, runners-up to Manchester United in the 1999 European Cup, are second with an £83.5m turnover. The figures include all revenue except that from transfers. No French club made it on to the list, with Paris St-Germain dropping to 25th and Marseille coming in at 22nd.

Among the English clubs Tottenham, Leeds and Arsenal rose in the rankings, while Chelsea were one of the strongest climbers, moving from ninth place to fourth. Despite Tottenham's lack of success on the field the north Londoners registered the most prolific growth in turnover with an increase of 37% to £42.6m. Newcastle finished 12th while Aston Villa and Liverpool slipped, to 19th and 11th respectively.

Gerry Boon of Deloitte & Touche said: "English clubs have a financial advantage over their continental rivals in owning their grounds. This brings other potential revenue streams to the 'kicks-and- mortar' business model.

"However this dominance may be threatened by the flow of TV money. Spanish and Italian clubs recently won the right to negotiate their own TV deals and this should propel them up the rankings.

"[But] The English Premier League TV deal will also produce massive revenues in 2001-02 and it could be all change among the top 20 over the next couple of years."

The combined income of the 20 richest clubs reached £1.05bn. However there are enormous disparities between the clubs with Celtic, in 20th place, registering turnover of £33.8m, less than a third of Manchester United's.

Despite the growing importance of TV revenue, gate receipts are still the most important source of income for British clubs, unlike in Italy where Juventus are the wealthiest club but continue to report poor attendances. Many of the larger Italian clubs rely on TV monies as their most important sources of income though a similar situation may well develop in Britain.

Michael Hann, the editor of FourFourTwo, said: "The average Premiership club earns enough from its executive boxes to pay three players' wages, so the 'prawn sandwich' contingent is essential to English clubs' financial success.

"Match-day income - gate receipts - is still the largest part of Premiership clubs' revenues. The TV deals are likely to challenge this going forward."

webTitle: Bayern spike the Gunners

fields.headline: Bayern spike the Gunners
fields.standfirst: Arsenal 2 - 2 Bayern Munich
fields.trailText: Arsenal 2 - 2 Bayern Munich
fields.body:
Arsenal appeared to forget about the German tradition of comebacks here last night. Having taken a 2-0 lead early in the second half of a Champions League game they urgently needed to win, following a 4-1 defeat by Moscow Spartak, they found themselves being held to a draw after Bayern Munich had scored twice in 10 minutes.

Arsenal went into the game trusting, with justification it soon transpired, that the profligate habits which had left them scoreless in four of their previous six matches had been forgotten. German opponents seldom give second chances and Arsène Wenger's side did not want to find themselves having to chase the game.

The outcome of the encounter was always going to rest on who held the balance in midfield - Patrick Vieira and Gilles Grimandi for Arsenal or Stefan Effenberg and Jens Jeremies for Bayern. While this is true of most games the strength each side enjoyed in the central areas made it especially important in last night's match.

Not that the play had time to develop any kind of pattern before Arsenal went ahead after three minutes. So sweet was the build-up and so clinical the execution that it was hard to see why Arsenal had been finding it hard to score goals.

The move started with Robert Pires on the left. The Frenchman played the ball low into the middle where his compatriot, Thierry Henry, fooled the defence by allowing it to run to Nwankwo Kanu before driving the Nigerian's return pass into the net.

This was exactly the start Arsenal needed to bolster their confidence. For a while the Bayern penalty area was full of bodies as Wenger's team sought a swift second goal but once Bayern had demonstrated the speed of their counterattacks Arsenal needed to guard against leaving themselves exposed.

Nevertheless, Vieira and Grimandi had gained the early grip in midfield the situation demanded and the closeness of their links with Henry and Kanu ensured that Arsenal's movements maintained their early momentum.

With Kanu strolling into likely spaces in the approaches to goal, Arsenal still had the subtlety the Dutchman normally gives them. Effenberg occasionally moved forward to set up the beginnings of a Bayern attack but with his team on the defensive found it hard to maintain any pressure.

After 37 minutes Arsenal came close to increasing their lead. A corner from Pires was nodded on by Henry to Tony Adams whose header was intercepted by Thomas Linke but still hit the near post.

Four minutes later Mehmet Scholl had an opportunity to exploit Bayern's good fortune but missed it. A long pass from Effenberg found Giovane Elber in space behind Martin Keown and the Brazilian laid the ball back to Scholl who should have done better than drag his shot wide.

Not that Arsenal ever considered slowing the tempo in order to sit on their lead. After 49 minutes a shrewd pass from Vieira set up Fredrik Ljungberg for second goal but the Swede snatched at his shot and wafted it over the bar.

No matter it seemed: nine minutes into the second half Arsenal at last scored the goal their continued domination demanded. Again Bayern were deceived by quick thinking and confounded by the pace and precision of the move.

This time Vieira surprised the opposition with a quick free-kick to release Henry on the right. The striker took the ball towards the byline before laying it back into the path of Kanu, who calmly beat Oliver Kahn with an angled left-footed shot off the far post.

That seemed to be that but within a minute Bayern had scored and after another 10 they were level. First Adams and Keown failed to cut out a long free-kick from the right, allowing Scholl to slip the ball back to Michael Tarnat who drove it emphatically past Alex Manninger.

Then Scholl brought the scores level with a twice-taken free-kick. Ljungberg was booked for not retreating the proper distance as Tarnat thumped the ball against the wall, and Scholl took three steps before floating it beyond Manninger's reach into the near corner of the net.

Arsenal (4-4-2): Manninger; Cole, Keown, Adams, Luzhny; Ljungberg, Grimandi, Vieira, Pires; Kanu, Henry.

Bayern Munich (3-4-3): Kahn; Linke, Sforza, Kuffour; Sagnol, Jeremies, Effenberg, Tarnat; Salihamidzic, Elber, Scholl.

Referee: S. Braschi (Italy).

webTitle: Review: Billy Bragg & the Blokes

fields.headline: Billy Bragg still looking back in anger
fields.standfirst:
Billy Bragg & the Blokes
Barbican
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Billy Bragg & the Blokes
Barbican
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Many readers may have noticed that the country has been run by a Labour government for several years, but for Billy Bragg the penny seems to have taken a while to drop. Frequently, this performance was like being beamed back to 1984, as Bragg interspersed his songs with strident rants about the Tories as though the last election never happened and Tony Blair had never existed. There was even a traditional v-sign directed at Margaret Thatcher, who hasn't been in power for 10 years.

True, we are now entering the pantomime season, but this inability to put the past in perspective and move forwards seems to be endemic in British popular culture (why else would the movie Billy Elliott, for all its virtues, use the miners' strike as its emotional launching-pad?). Even when Bragg's rhetoric appears to be progressive and forward-looking - for example, in his lecture about racial diversity and social inclusiveness, which preceded the song England Half English - his band's tepid attempts to mimic reggae or African music mean that his intentions can only end in bathos. I wondered what black or Asian members of the audience thought, but as far as I could see there weren't any.

As Bragg's music has become more consciously wrought and moved away from his original format of raucous guitar with primitive beatbox, it has become harder to blend his polemical side into the equation. If Bragg wants to be considered a "mature" and relatively sophisticated musician, as his collaborations with Wilco or the expertise of his current five-piece band would suggest, do his hectoring tirades about politics and global capitalism still fit, especially when his audience has been hearing them for the last decade and a half?

Still, it's worth going to see Bragg just to hear the keyboard wizardry of former Face and Small Face Ian McLagan, even if it would be more fun to hear him play Had Me A Real Good Time instead of The World Turned Upside Down or The Price I Pay. It's hard to believe that McLagan takes Bragg as seriously as the didactic tunesmith takes himself.

 Billy Bragg & the Blokes play the Empire Music Hall, Belfast (028-9024 9276), tomorrow, then tour.

webTitle: Traveller's cheques

fields.headline: Traveller's cheques
fields.trailText: When buying traveller's cheques, think about the commission charged and the exchange rate used.
fields.body:
When buying traveller's cheques, think about the commission charged and the exchange rate used.

High street banks charge between 1% and 2%, with minimum charges between £3 and £4, but commission can be up to 6%. You can save a bit of money by ordering them online. Nationwide charges no commission on online orders, with a single £3.50 charge for delivery. Thomas Cook also accepts online orders.

You will also be charged commission when you come to cash the cheques, although it is difficult to predict how much as it varies from country to country and outlet to outlet. In the UK, commission can be as high as 6% and the situation may be similar in other countries. Some overseas currency exchange outlets don't charge commission. Instead, they cover the cost of the transaction by exchanging traveller's cheques at a worse rate than that used for currency conversions.

Try and buy your cheques off a retailer that lets you cash leftover ones back at no extra charge. If you bought them from your bank, you may be able to pay them into your account for free.

Where you are headed will dictate what currency your traveller's cheques should be in, but buying them in sterling is often the best option as it will be cheaper for you to cash any leftover cheques back when you return to the UK.

However, euro travellers' cheques can be a good idea in the euro-zone. When you cash them, you will be given whatever the local currency is.

If you are heading to remote areas or developing countries, the currency exchange clerks may shake their heads at sterling travellers' cheques. US dollar cheques are a safer bet, especially in areas like South America.

webTitle: Review: At The Drive-In

fields.headline: Texas rockers with a raw drive
fields.standfirst:
At The Drive-In
Manchester University
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
At The Drive-In
Manchester University
Rating: *****
fields.body:
"You're gonna feel the need to beat the shit out of each other," predicts Cedric Bixler, the wildly afro'd frontman for At The Drive-In. And, certainly, ATDI - a quintet from El Paso, Texas, widely touted as the saviours of rock'n'roll on the back of their debut album, Relationship of Command - play with the sort of elemental, visceral energy that turns mosh-pits into war zones.

Bixler, however, isn't issuing some macho call to arms. Rather, we're told to look after one another. "Don't act like apes," he insists.

ATDI share a producer, Ross Robinson, with nu-metal knuckle-heads such as Slipknot, but their attitude - and sound - is totally different.

Not that they aren't loud enough to please the kids in Korn T-shirts. The opener, Arc Arsenal, is a seismic snap, crackle and squall, balanced atop thunderous, tribal drums. Catacombs, meanwhile, is more violent mid-air turbulence than song.

Like an amphetamine-reared salmon, Bixler bounces, climbs and dives about the stage, occasionally indulging in a little "interpretative" dance, as if living every note. While twirling his mic. Constantly.

It's some spectacle. Particularly as Bixler and guitarist Omar Rodriguez - all cool tattoos, skinny tees and big hair - are as iconic, and as passionate, as their most obvious spiritual antecedents, MC5.

But it's ATDI's subtleties and variety - and Omar's conjuring of spectral, sonic detritus - that make them truly great. There are grungey melodies buried in this barrage that are all the sweeter for being hidden, bold, elegiac rumbles of piano. And during the new single, Rolodex Propaganda (on which Iggy Pop guests), the unwinding organ is more Badly Drawn Boy than bad-ass rock'n'roll.

Bixler's vocals - part intense croon, part sandpaper, evangelical holler - convey deep hurt and anger. Even if you can't make out a word of his oblique, rhetorical lyrics.

Rodriguez, his guitar mingling with various FX and freaky, creaky samples, dispenses obtuse, twisted, broken-fingered lead guitar as angular and alien as Sonic Youth. Like the Pixies' Joey Santiago, his guitar sounds sizzlingly electric, as he bends notes and lends ATDI an edge with his weird, juxtaposed riffs.

Supple and precise, but as raw-sounding as Shellac, ATDI change pace and/or tone at will, songs are arranged oddly, and little, complex details - such as the guitar phrase in Rascuache that lurches softly, then tumbles down - tug at the heart strings.

Be in no doubt, ATDI may sound like two juggernauts colliding, metal shearing and crumpling, but this is soul music, an exorcism that's both sad and mad. Over 12 songs (no encore) it left Manchester stunned.

 At The Drive-In play Leeds Cockpit (0113-244 3446) tonight, then tour.

webTitle: Adult and continuing education

fields.headline: Adult and continuing education
fields.trailText: Having the same job for your entire life is fast becoming a thing of the past, and many people are now considering retraining or going back to college at some point in their career.
fields.body:
Having the same job for your entire life is fast becoming a thing of the past, and many people are now considering retraining or going back to college at some point in their career.

The government has recognised the need for ongoing training and is working on a number of schemes through its Lifelong Learning programme. Depending on what you plan to study and where you intend to study, there may be government funding available. For more information, go to the Department for Education and Employment.

Social welfare benefits are sometimes available to those on low wages who wish to go into higher education. Many colleges provide free or cheap childcare and bursaries are available for certain residential colleges. Career development loans, provided through a partnership between the Department for Education and Employment and four major banks, provide funding for students on vocational courses. The loans are designed for those on two-year courses, but may provide funding for part of longer courses.

At further education colleges or universities, students on their first course can apply for LEA help with tuition fees. Up to the age of 55, they can also apply for a student loan at the Student Loans Company. However, if you have had help from UK or EU public funds for previous study at further education level, you may be excluded.

For post-graduate courses, grants are occasionally available through the relevant research councils, or boards such as the Arts and Humanities Research Board, depending on the subject you intend to study. Some banks offer loans at preferential rates to those entering postgraduate studies, but many are restricted to certain subjects, such as law or business.

Special government assistance is available to those who wish to train for a career in teaching, nursing or medicine.

People with disabilities are also being encouraged to train or study, and a number of bursaries, scholarships and grants are reserved for the disabled. For more information, visit The National Bureau for Students with Disabilities.

To promote Lifelong Learning, the government is currently setting up a structure to manage Individual Learning Accounts. These accounts are to be run by Training and Enterprise Councils and Chambers of Commerce, Training and Enterprise, and will be a way for both employees and employers to contribute to the costs of training. Both parties will be able to pay into the accounts, and will receive good tax breaks as an incentive to do so.

The Individual Learning Accounts are set to replace the Vocational Training Relief, which entitles students on National Vocational Qualification or Scottish Vocational Qualification courses to tax relief.

If all else fails, try applying for a scholarship or sponsorship from a commercial organisation. Often, this requires the student to work for the organisation during holidays or a sandwich year, and competition for such schemes can be tough.

webTitle: University and higher education

fields.headline: University and higher education
fields.trailText: University students have two costs to meet: tuition fees and living expenses. Most students are entitled to some financial help from the local authority with tuition fees, but the living costs will have to be met entirely through student loans and parental contributions.
fields.body:
University students have two costs to meet: tuition fees and living expenses. Most students are entitled to some financial help from the local authority with tuition fees, but the living costs will have to be met entirely through student loans and parental contributions.

The Universities and Colleges Admissions Services says most students will pay around £1,050 in tuition fees for the 2000/2001 academic year. Unfortunately, this figure is likely to increase by about £25 a year. And some Universities charge more - Oxford's current top-up rate is £1,075 a year.

Students apply to their local authority for help with fees and their case is assessed by examining parental income. An estimated third of students whose parental income is taken into account will not have to pay fees.

For living costs, students will be expected to take out a student loan, topped up by parental contributions or part-time and holiday work. For the current financial year, the maximum loans available are £4,590 for those studying in London, £3,725 for those studying outside London and £2,950 for those living at home. Contact the Student Loans Company for details.

The loans do not have to be repaid until the student leaves university and starts earning over a certain amount (currently £10,000 per year). Interest on the loan is linked to inflation, and is therefore much lower than commercial rates.

However, the National Union of Students estimates that living costs are actually much higher than the maximum loans. They estimate it costs £6,636 each year to be a student in London, and £5,268 outside London. And this is before tuition fees are taken into account.

webTitle: Education

fields.headline: Education
fields.standfirst: Education is a huge financial strain for many families. If you don't start saving early, you may find yourself struggling in later years
fields.trailText: Education is a huge financial strain for many families. If you don't start saving early, you may find yourself struggling in later years.
fields.body:
Education is likely to be a huge financial strain for many families, from nursery to university. While many nursery places are free, parents who want their children to go to a special school will have to pay. Three sessions a week at a Montessori school could set you back £30; other nurseries charge around £3 an hour.

And if schools in your area aren't up to scratch you might want to think about sending your children to public school. Even the cheapest public schools are expensive, with day student fees start at around £1,500 a term, rising swiftly for borders. And the more children you have the more you are paying out.

If your children go to university, you can expect to pay several thousand pounds a year in fees and/or maintenance. One estimate put the figure at £6,500 per child per year for a middle income family.

Further qualifications, such as postgraduate degrees or professional training, will cost even more. Your child will almost certainly have to pay the full fees and all maintenance costs, so if you want to contribute to this stage of their education, you'll need to have a nest egg at hand.

Of course, you might be the one wanting to return to school. You're unlikely to get any help for postgraduate or professional qualifications, but the government is keen to promote "lifelong learning" and is offering help with a variety of course fees. It is also paying for people to train for understaffed professions, including nursing and teaching. Contact the Department for Education and Employment for more information.

In short, education costs, and it costs a lot, so start saving early if you do not want to struggle in later years. Assess your current income and financial commitments to determine how much you can save each month and try to estimate how much you will need to accumulate. Think about some of the potential problems - a drop in income, divorce, the child not being accepted by a school or university or choosing not to go - and make sure you choose a strategy that is flexible enough to cope.

webTitle: Income tax

fields.headline: Income tax
fields.trailText: Income tax is payable on all your taxable income. Generally speaking, this will be income from the following:
fields.body:
Income tax is payable on all your taxable income. Generally speaking, this will be income from the following:

1 Earnings from full and part-time work (and note that tips are taxable) 2 Profits from a business or dividends from shares 3 Jobseekers Allowance 4 Rent from letting rooms in a house 5 Interest from bank, national savings or building society accounts

If you have income from any other source, and you are unsure whether it is taxable you can ask the tax office for advice - anonymously by telephone if you like.

The following income sources are not taxable:

1 Student Grants 2 Scholarships 3 Most research awards 4 Housing benefits 5 Allowances from parents or spouse 6 Grant from the University Access Fund

fields.headline: Do I pay tax from holiday jobs?
fields.trailText: Students who only work in vacations (and who have not claimed Jobseekers Allowance in the current year) can complete a P38 and their employer will be able to pay them without deducting tax, provided that their total taxable income for the tax year is not expected to exceed their personal allowance (i.e. £4,385). You won't get a P45 when you leave.
