fields.headline: Technology
fields.trailText: Check that your computer is compatible with the system your bank uses to run its internet operation.
fields.body:
Check that your computer is compatible with the system your bank uses to run its internet operation.

The technology needed to run an internet bank account can vary from bank to bank. Most list the required hardware and software on their websites.

Typical requirements are a relevant operating system, usually Windows 95, 98 or NT, and the right system browser, usually Microsoft Internet Explorer 4 or above or Netscape Navigator 4 or above.

Some of the banks cannot operate on Apple Macintosh Computers.

webTitle: Cash

fields.headline: Cash
fields.trailText: Commission charged for buying currency is usually the same as that for buying travellers cheques, with the minimum charge between £2.50 and £4 on the high street. Like travellers' cheques, currency can also be ordered online from Nationwide and Thomas Cook.
fields.body:

You will probably want to take some local currency with you. Depending on your destination and the type of traveller you are, you might also want to take some US dollars. US currency can be very useful in an emergency or when travelling off the beaten track, as it is always possible to find someone who will take dollars in place of their national currency as payment for food or lodging. In some countries it may be more useful than the local currency - check your guidebook or the travel sites before you go.

webTitle: Saving for pre-school

fields.headline: Saving for pre-school
fields.trailText: In theory, every four-year old has a right to free pre-school education, even though in practice your local authority may not have enough places for your child.
fields.body:
In theory, every four-year old has a right to free pre-school education, even though in practice your local authority may not have enough places for your child.

In these circumstances, try applying to the Early Years Development Plan for a grant of up to £366.67 per term for a private place. For more information, visit the Department for Education and Employment.

The Working Families' Tax Credit allows parents who qualify to claim up to £70 per week for the cost of childcare for one child, or £105 for two children. However, you will not be eligible if you have savings of £8,000 or over or if you work less than 16 hours per week. For more information, visit the Department of Social Security. Application packs are available from the Inland Revenue and social security offices.

webTitle: Internet banking

fields.headline: Internet banking
fields.trailText: Internet banks were established for two basic reasons.
fields.body:
Internet banks were established for two basic reasons.

First, it is dramatically cheaper to run an operation on the internet because overheads and administration costs are kept to a minimum.

In theory, this can help banks maximise their profits and/or pass on savings to customers in the form of better interest rates and low or non-existent charges.

Second, an ever increasing number of internet users are looking for cheap, easy to use online products which they can access from their personal computers, 24 hours a day.

If you are thinking about banking online, our guide to the internet banking sector and its possible benefits and disadvantages should help you decide.

webTitle: Savings accounts

fields.headline: Savings accounts
fields.trailText: Any sensible approach to managing your finances should include keeping £1,000 in an easy access savings account for emergencies or a rainy day.
fields.body:
Any sensible approach to managing your finances should include keeping £1,000 in an easy access savings account for emergencies or a rainy day.

If you have more than £1,000 to save, think about putting it into a stocks and shares investment vehicle, which will probably offer much better returns. Otherwise, look for a savings account with a high rate of interest and the right access conditions.You are highly unlikely to get more than 7% on instant access accounts: rates of between 5% and 6% are the norm, with internet and telephone accounts usually offering the highest. But notice period accounts are not much better. The best deals will offer around 7% or 7.5%, but you may have to agree to a six month notice period to get it. Waiting six months for your cash is no good for an emergency or a rainy day, so only take out one of these accounts if you're sure you won't need the money for a while and don't want to take the risk of investing in the stock market.

And remember the Isa option. If you haven't already used your Isa allowance, think about opening a mini-cash account. You can save up to £3,000 a year and the income will be tax free.

It's also important to check the rate you are offered won't go down after a few months. Finance companies often launch products with high rates and lower them after a few months.

webTitle: Financial exclusion

fields.headline: Financial exclusion
fields.trailText: An estimated 2m to 3m people don't have access to financial services because of their poor credit rating or where they live.
fields.body:
An estimated 2m to 3m people don't have access to financial services because of their poor credit rating or where they live.

The problem has been compounded recently with branch closures leaving some of the most deprived communities high and dry: and the government is getting concerned. It wants to save lots of money by channelling benefit payments directly into bank accounts by 2003. In addition, consumer groups say people without accounts are being penalised by utility companies which often charge less for bills paid by direct debit.

Proposals for a Universal Bank, run by the government, the banks and the post office through the post office's branch network are being considered. But the Treasury helped attack the problem head on recently, when it ordered the high street banks to offer basic accounts to the financially excluded.

This has resulted in a variety of new offers from NatWest, Co-operative, Yorkshire, Lloyds TSB and Barclays amongst others.

Basic bank accounts are fee-free and provide day-to-day banking services but don't allow customers to go into debt - overdrafts are not allowed, although some banks will offer a £10 buffer zone. You can set up direct debits and standing orders, and a card is provided for cash machines. Some go further and offer a debit-type card allowing you to buy goods in shops provided you have the funds.

The accounts can usually be opened regardless of your credit rating, though people who have been declared bankrupt will in many cases still be blacklisted.

Banks will make little, if any, money from basic accounts, as customers won't be paying overdraft charges and many will not be depositing large sums. So they probably won't advertise the accounts, leaving it up to you to ask individual banks if they offer them.

When you go to open a basic account, you will need some form of identification. Passports and driving licenses are the norm, but banks such as Lloyd's TSB will accept pension books, recognised ID cards with a photo and signature and the new orange disabled drivers passes with photos.

webTitle: Current accounts

fields.headline: Current accounts
fields.trailText: A current account is the mainstay of your finances. Most people put their salary into a current account, pay for everyday things from it, transfer money to savings accounts and set up direct debits and standing orders from it. And when they go overdrawn, most current accounts have a facility to tide them over.
fields.body:
A current account is the mainstay of your finances. Most people put their salary into a current account, pay for everyday things from it, transfer money to savings accounts and set up direct debits and standing orders from it. And when they go overdrawn, most current accounts have a facility to tide them over.

Statistically, you're more likely to get divorced than change current account providers, but a number of tantalising new deals have recently hit the market, so you might want to compare them with your account to make sure you're getting the best package.

Generally speaking, look for an account with no or low charges. Many will give you interest free overdrafts or buffer zones. At the very least they should offer low interest overdrafts. Banks should only really levy charges when cheques bounce or when you need to need to do out of the ordinary transactions such as wiring money overseas. Everyday transactions should be free and, with increasing competition from internet banks, many high street banks are thinking of dropping everyday charges. Most banks have abandoned plans to charge you for using cash machines, so if yours still does, find another one.

Also, think about how you want to pay for things. You'll want to be able to get cash from ATM machines, so find out how many your bank has and make sure it doesn't charge you for withdrawing cash. And accounts with switch and cheque book facilities give you more options.

Similarly, how do you want to do your banking: through a branch network, over the phone or through the internet? Some banks offer all three channels. Others only offer one.

Banks have recently started offering headline grabbing interest rates on their current accounts. Most are from the internet banks who save on overheads by not having a branch network and pass these savings on to you, but some high street banks are following suit. The main problem with these offers is that you have to have a huge amount of money in your current account to benefit from the rates. For example: Cahoot will pay you 6.50 pa on balances of £1,000, but to get the more attractive 7.10% pa rate you'd have to have a balance of £10,000. Anyone with this much cash would be better off putting it in a savings account, Isa or investment fund - many of which have the potential to pay dramatically better rates. But if you do tend to keep your current account firmly in the black, these interest-paying current accounts are worth a look.

The so-called "connected accounts" are also worth a mention. Examples include internet bank Intelligent Finance's latest offering and Woolwich's Open Plan Banking. These accounts connect your current account, credit card, any savings accounts you might have and your mortgage to get a figure for your overall rate of borrowing, and charge interest accordingly. So, if you had £5,000 in savings and £2,500 outstanding on a credit card, you would not pay any interest on your credit card because your savings would cancel it out. Savings can also offset your mortgage balance, leading to a reduction in monthly repayments.

webTitle: Review: The Roaring Girl

fields.headline: The Roaring Girl
fields.standfirst:
Finborough
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Finborough
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
The Steam Industry's enterprising London season draws to a close with a revival of the 1611 comedy about sex, money and society by Thomas Dekker and Thomas Middleton. The wonder is that the Jacobean playwrights' portrait of the capital - with its conmen, get-rich-quick merchants, old money and new - isn't very far removed from the images of contemporary London thrown up by some of the other plays in the season.

The architecture may change but human nature remains very much the same, which may explain why, after centuries of neglect, these city comedies are very much back in vogue. Unfortunately for the Steam Industry, although this play - based on the antics of a real-life roaring girl, Mary Frith, or Moll Cutpurse, as she was better known - has patches of quick-witted brilliance, it is not in the same league as Middleton's A Mad World, My Masters and A Chaste Maid in Cheapside, recently revived with considerable success by the Globe.

The first mistake here is to try to recreate the atmosphere of the Globe rather than turn the intimacies of the Finborough space to the production's advantage. Instead of creating authenticity, the mock pillars lend a curiously pantomime air, and some parts of the production follow that cue. It also encourages some members, of what is generally an exceptionally strong cast, to send some of the material up rather than to play it completely straight.

The chief difficulty, though, is in the episodic nature of a piece that is best enjoyed more as a swirling kaleidoscope of city lowlife, with the intriguing figure of the non-conformist Moll laughing and swaggering with gusto at its heart, rather than a traditionally plotted drama. The play looks crude set alongside the contemporary comedies of Ben Jonson.

But providing you go with the flow there is plenty to enjoy in the story of Sebastian Wengrave tricking his father into letting him marry his beloved Mary by pretending he dotes upon the notorious Moll Cutpurse, of Jack Dapper escaping his father's attempts to teach him a lesson by having him arrested for debt, and of a pair of impecunious gallants with their eyes on a couple of shopkeepers' wives and purses getting their much-deserved comeuppance.

As the laughing spider at the heart of the web of lies, deceptions and double-dealings, Joanna van Kampen's Moll is an immensely attractive figure, who, despite dubious methods, always comes out morally on top. Dekker and Middleton may have romanticised Moll and turned her into the first criminal celebrity, but in creating a legend they also created a free-thinking, fearless, feminist role model, and an enduring heroine for our times as much as theirs.

 Until December 9. Box office: 020-7373 3842.

The chief difficulty, though, is in the episodic nature of a piece that is best enjoyed more as a swirling kaleidoscope of city lowlife, with the intriguing figure of the non-conformist Moll laughing and swaggering with gusto at its heart, rather than a traditionally plotted drama. The play looks crude set alongside the contemporary comedies of Ben Jonson. But providing you go with the flow there is plenty to enjoy in the story of Sebastian Wengrave tricking his father into letting him marry his beloved Mary by pretending he dotes upon the notorious Moll Cutpurse, of Jack Dapper escaping his father's attempts to teach him a lesson by having him arrested for debt, and of a pair of impecunious gallants with their eyes on a couple of shopkeepers' wives and purses getting their much-deserved comeuppance. As the laughing spider at the heart of the web of lies, deceptions and double-dealings, Joanna van Kampen's Moll is an immensely attractive figure, who, despite dubious methods, always comes out morally on top. Dekker and Middleton may have romanticised Moll and turned her into the first criminal celebrity, but in creating a legend they also created a free-thinking, fearless, feminist role model, and an enduring heroine for our times as much as theirs.  Until December 9. webTitle: Review: I Just Stopped by to See the Man

fields.headline: Faustian drama in the deep South
fields.standfirst:
I Just Stopped by to See the Man
Royal Court
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
I Just Stopped by to See the Man
Royal Court
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
"If you sing a song about Atlanta, you got to have been to Atlanta," says an old blues folk hero in Stephen Jeffreys's new play; and it is a line that acquires ever greater irony as the evening progresses.

For Jeffreys, a white British writer, here attempts to get to the heart of the black American experience; and the result, while theatrically skilful, often feels like a piece of artful impersonation.

Jeffreys's technique is to apply the Faust myth to the American south. The time is 1975, the setting is an obscure house in the Mississippi Delta. Its occupants are Jesse, a onetime blues legend, who has long been assumed dead, and his fugitive daughter Della.

Their precarious peace is shattered by the arrival of Karl, a Surrey-based rock star whose band has been doing a gig in Memphis, Tennessee. Karl's mission is to woo the septuagenarian Jesse, whom he idolises, back into the limelight for one last stand.

As a practised dramatist, Jeffreys understands the importance of desperation and he shrewdly parcels it out among his three characters.

The pious Jesse, who after the death of his wife forsook the blues as the devil's music, is lured by the adrenaline buzz of live performance. Against that he has to balance Della's need for anonymity after her involvement with the Black Panthers.

Even the Mephistophelian Karl, facing the break-up of his band, is torn between drug-dependence or a new partnership with a renascent Jesse.

Jeffreys draws you into his story, deals his cards cleverly and even, boldly, gives Karl a chance to display his talents as a blues guitarist. But the play also raises disturbing questions about authenticity.

Jesse eloquently argues that, unless you have known what it is to be black, poor and deprived, singing the blues is an adoptive attitude. By the same token, it seems to me difficult for a white writer to inhabit the soul of a blues legend or a black militant of the 1970s. At times, you feel you are watching a skilled pastiche of a play by August Wilson rather than a recreation of lived experience.

What carries the play through is the quality of the performance under the guidance of Richard Wilson - one of the best directors of actors in captivity. Tommy Hollis as the aged Jesse brings out beautifully the man's mixture of reclusive piety and closet vanity: when he dons his old fedora, you see him acquiring a recollected swagger. Ciaran McMenamin as the rock star with a touch of Surrey on top also has exactly the right cool sexiness and implacable selfishness. And, in the trickiest role, Sophie Okonedo makes you believe that Della is bursting with deadly secrets.

It is a cleverly plotted, extremely well-researched play; all it lacks is the hectic, bluesy, volatile veracity that a black writer might have brought to the same theme.

 Until January 6. Box office: 020-7565 5000. This review appeared in later editions yesterday.

webTitle: Review: Five Masters of Imagination

fields.headline: Five Masters of Imagination
fields.standfirst:
Graves Art Gallery
Sheffield
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Graves Art Gallery
Sheffield
Rating: ****
fields.body:
An adorable little collection brings together works on loan from the Tate collection by Marc Chagall, Paul Klee, Amedeo Modigliani, Georges Rouault and Chaim Soutine. For all of them painting was a matter of passionate necessity. All adapted the visual vocabulary of the early 20th century avant-garde to their own romantic vision.

There's pathos and profound melancholy here, but no hint of cultural alienation or creative disillusionment. For all the invigorating traces of struggle, these artists did not have to question what art was. They knew it was a form of gestural self-creation, a subjective reflection of the world embodied in an orchestration of painterly marks that stand for the essential right to self-definition. Each distinctive style can be seen and felt as the sensuous touch of a unique individual.

Imagination for Chagall and Klee meant inventive reverie. They used the brush and paint as tools of dreaming rather than means of recording past dreams. Picasso said of Chagall that "somewhere or other inside his head must be an angel". He painted pictorial love poems, full of bouquets, cat-women, fish that fly and crescent moons that serenade sleeping lovers on gypsy violins. In the all-questioning and all-knowing world of contemporary art, Chagall might be seen as a hopeless sentimentalist, but the best of his images re-embody cliches with the depth of a Lorca ballad.

Klee was more a psychic mischief-maker. Drawing for him was a means of breeding the imps and spider-flowers that live on the other side of the everyday. His work The Protector is an unashamed piece of absurdist whimsy.

Imagination for Modigliani, Rouault and Soutine was a means of defamiliarising the everyday. Modigliani doesn't come across too strongly in this hallowed company. Perhaps he fancied himself too much as an artist in order that he in turn could be fancied by all his stunningly beautiful subjects. In comparison, Rouault is a no-nonsense tragedian, piling up his blunt slabs of colour so they glow with the resonance of gothic stained glass.

Soutine is best represented, with some fine examples of intoxicated landscape painting. In modest-sized pictures such as The Road up the Hill and Cagnes Landscape with Trees, he tears appearance apart and reassembles it in a spirit of wild celebration. Soutine makes free jazz with the features of the landscape, all of nature dancing to a St Vitus rhythm. The prevailing wind is caused by the trees frantically waving their arms. A lanky figure staggers as if on a big dipper treadmill.

Maybe Soutine's impassioned loony-land belongs to a long-gone cultural climate, but it's fun to revisit it.

 Until February 17. Details: 0114-278 2600.

webTitle: G2: Office Christmas parties

fields.headline: The end of the party
fields.standfirst:
Will you go? Should you go? Anita Chaudhuri wonders whether the office bash has had its day

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Will you go? Should you go? Anita Chaudhuri wonders whether the office bash has had its day.
fields.body:
As offices across the land deck photocopiers with mistletoe and buy in emergency rations of Twiglets, you could be forgiven for believing every last desk in Britain has been transformed into a corporate wonderland of festive cheer. But you would be wrong.

According to the latest statistics from the thinktank Labour Research, 30% of companies will this year offer no form of Christmas party or lunch whatsoever. And even at those firms that do offer festive events, there is clear evidence that many workers secretly resent the office do, seeing it as a form of enforced socialising. Research from recruitment consultancy Office Angels indicates that six out of 10 workers feel under pressure to attend out-of-hours events at Christmas, believing their careers could be hit if they stay away.

In an era in which the boundary between work life and home life is growing vaguer by the day, many of us feel obliged to raise a festive glass with colleagues and clients. And we are not talking about just the one: on average, in the run-up to Christmas, we will spend a staggering (literally, in some cases) 45 hours socialising for work. According to this week's survey, most of us would rather spend that time at home.

None of this should come as much of a surprise. There can be few things more irritating than having superiors standing over you monitoring a) what time you sneak off home b) whether you are having a good time and c) that you're not having such a good time that you actually do anything exciting. For something so purportedly laid- back, the office party can be a sublime exercise in workforce control.

A ring around some of Britain's largest companies and government departments backs up this gloomy picture. Debenhams is having a free evening do at London nightclub Heaven, but NatWest is giving its branch managers party budgets, and while the Department of Culture is hosting a party for staff and spouses in the basement of its HQ, everyone will have to pay for the booze kitty. M&S isn't having its do until mid-January, when 3,000 staff will have to shell out £5 each if they want to roll up to London's Metropole Hotel.

"Many companies make assumptions about Christmas parties that do not at all reflect the way we live now," says Judith Doyle, cultural trends analyst for the Industrial Society. "It's outdated and it's also assuming that we all wish to celebrate a Christian festival, which is not the case."

In fact, Doyle argues, the 30% of non-partying companies are heralding the future. "They're just reflecting the fact that Christmas is no longer the focal point of everyone's year. Some hi-tech companies in particular are choosing to skip the festive season, but offer bonuses or trips to Club Med in the summer. It depends what we think the purpose of the Christmas party is. As a reward, I don't think it really does it any more."

One person well-versed in the cultural significance of office life is Matt Beaumont, until last year an account executive at ad agency McCann Erickson, now author of the bestselling novel e. His loathing of office parties is so extreme that it inspired his latest work, The e. Before Christmas, which chronicles the run-up to the annual party and its aftermath in the fictional Miller Shanks advertising agency.

"The last Christmas party I went to at work was so dreadful, I vowed never to go to another. That was years ago," he says. "But whether or not you go, you are aware of the party aftermath and that's compelling. I used to sit there and watch people coming in looking ashamed, or talking about other people's shame. In fact, I used to get a buzz out of not going."

What he misses most about office life, he says, is spending time with people he dislikes. "Getting wound up by unpleasant people, that tension and energy, it's what keeps offices alive. The Christmas party is the culmination of all the crap that's built up all year; it can be very cathartic. Because of that, I think as long as there are offices, there will be office parties."

This will come as bad news to weary veterans of old-style Christmas shindigs. There are some of us who have spent way too many Decembers being frogmarched to the ballrooms of naff city centre hotels to indulge in dubious finger buffets and toe-curling public humiliation of the death by karaoke variety. Some years ago, when I was editor of the trade magazine PR Week, I notched up 20 such functions in a month. The memory still makes me shudder.

"One reason people don't like office parties is that they simply don't know what to talk about," says Paul Jacobs, communications director at Office Angels. "Work is often the only thing you've got in common, but suddenly you're supposed to make small talk. Many people find that a strain. And there's often a sense of anticipation about the event, which makes it more difficult to say no."

There is another big stress factor involved, too. A party is no longer just a chance for workers to get down and boogie: managers are increasingly judging staff on their social skills. "Personality is key nowadays," Doyle says. "It's not about how well you do your job, it's about how well you laugh at the boss's jokes. There's a subtext going on in many offices: 'Promote me, I'm great fun.' Bosses want you to be one of their gang - in certain companies, you may be judged on how you perform at parties, even if you're an accountant."

But could boycotting the office bash really harm your career? "Of course not," says Garry Lace, managing director of ad agency TBWA. "We're not going to be on the door taking a register. People do so much socialising for work now. If by mid- December they've run out of steam, that's perfectly understandable."

It's unlikely any of TBWA's employees will be staying at home, though: no cheesy hotel disco for them. Staff will be taking over the Ministry of Sound for their White Christmas party. Invitations included a laminated William Hill betting slip with £1 wagered on the seven to one odds of there being snow on the 25th. "Even if people don't go, they still might win some money," Lace says. "At the end of the day, a party is no substitute for a cash reward and companies who make that mistake are getting it wrong. It's good fun, but we wouldn't have one if we couldn't afford to pay our staff a bonus, too. That wouldn't be right."

 The e. Before Christmas is available at Millershanks.

webTitle: G2: Richard Reeves on entrepreneurs

fields.headline: Free and uneasy
fields.standfirst:
On feeling part of the family

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Richard Reeves on feeling part of the family
fields.body:
This is supposed to be the Era of the Entrepreneur, a period in history when people strike out, take risks, ride the waves of the new economy. In the US, thousands of column inches have pondered the birth of a new America - the Free Agent Nation. And the UK is said to be following suit, with growing armies of freelancers - sorry, e-lancers - and swathes of start-ups.

There is just one tiny snag: the numbers do not seem to add up. For all the hype, the number of people doing a Branson has not changed: in 1992 there were 3.2m people in Britain working for themselves; today there are ... 3.1m. The number of full-time teleworkers has also dropped slightly over the past decade, while figures just published in the US show the percentage of the labour force in self-employment dropping from 11% in 1994 to 10% last year. So on the face of it, all the claims about portfolio workers and free agents taking over the world look doubtful.

But the figures can be viewed in a different way. Self-employed people fall into two camps: those who have chosen to work for themselves and those who have been forced to because no one else wants them. There's a cartoon in which a senior executive places his hand on an underling's shoulder and says: "Congratulations, Mr Smith - you're about to become a free agent." Plenty of people who find themselves out of work have found consultancy a more socially acceptable activity than redundancy.

By definition, people forced into self-employment are not free agents. And when the economy rebounds, they are likely to try to land a "real" job as soon as possible.

The US economy has just enjoyed nine years of growth, the longest period of expansion in its history; unemployment in many parts has virtually disappeared. So the reluctant consultants have come rushing back into the corporate fold. The ones who are left are the hard core, the true free agents - and there are still plenty of them.

The real story is that one in 10 Americans are choosing to go their own way at a time when employers are fighting for talented staff. Some firms are giving off-road vehicles to employees who recruit new staffers; some give one each to the new recruit and the recruiter. But even with Freelanders on offer, the freelancers are staying out. The wheat has been sorted from the chaff.

At the same time, there are those who have felt the social drawbacks and have opted to return to the community of office life. Karl Welch, who joined an internet service provider after two decades as a self-employed concert promoter, told the New York Times why: "I really wanted to find some stability in my life. I wanted to work for a group of people who were trying to create something."

Many firms have also relaxed the rules so that people can work from home when they want to, or dress casually if they feel like it. Corporations have co-opted some of the benefits of self-employment. One internet worker went back to having a boss, but only in a firm with a flexible approach: "I was going to work for a company, but not one with a corporate sensibility."

The lexicon of email language in the US now includes the use of "WAH" in the subject field. It is the only notice many workers need to give their peers and boss that they are Working At Home. For those who do choose to remain footloose, the ones who can never type WAW - working at work - the risk of alienation remains real.

ut in the absence of a defined work community, they are going ahead and creating their own. The British Library has recently changed its rules to allow laptops in the reading room. This means that the eclectic group of writers who used to research there now write there, too. They have got to know each other and have an informal lunch together on Fridays. Soon it will be time for their "office" Christmas party.

Similarly, lorry drivers and sales reps have established nodes across the country where they can meet "colleagues" and swap gossip over a cup of coffee. Work is a powerful provider of community and identity, and that remains true whether we are free agents or wage slaves.

 Richard Reeves is director of futures at the Industrial Society. You can contact him at rreeves@indsoc.co.uk.

The lexicon of email language in the US now includes the use of "WAH" in the subject field. It is the only notice many workers need to give their peers and boss that they are Working At Home. For those who do choose to remain footloose, the ones who can never type WAW - working at work - the risk of alienation remains real. ut in the absence of a defined work community, they are going ahead and creating their own. The British Library has recently changed its rules to allow laptops in the reading room. This means that the eclectic group of writers who used to research there now write there, too. They have got to know each other and have an informal lunch together on Fridays. Soon it will be time for their "office" Christmas party. Similarly, lorry drivers and sales reps have established nodes across the country where they can meet "colleagues" and swap gossip over a cup of coffee. Work is a powerful provider of community and identity, and that remains true whether we are free agents or wage slaves.  Richard Reeves is director of futures at the Industrial Society. You can contact him at rreeves@indsoc.co.uk.

webTitle: Credit cards

fields.headline: Credit cards
fields.trailText: On a credit or debit card, your bank or building society will usually charge a commission known as a "loading charge". This is typically 2.75 % of the total value for purchases, rising to 4.25 % for cash advances. Nationwide is one of a few that have eliminated loading charges and others may follow suit. If you travel a lot, these loading charges will add up, so you might want to look into cards with low or no charges.
fields.body:

This is typically 2.75 % of the total value for purchases, rising to 4.25 % for cash advances. Nationwide is one of a few that have eliminated loading charges and others may follow suit. If you travel a lot, these loading charges will add up, so you might want to look into cards with low or no charges.

Your bank or building society will then convert the amount of the purchase or the cash withdrawn into sterling using the Mastercard or Visa wholesale exchange rate. This is usually better than the rate charged at exchange booths and the rates for traveller's cheques.

You will be charged interest on your overseas spending, just as if you had spent the money in the UK. If your card issuer only charges interest when you don't settle the balance in full at the end of the month this is not so important. But if you get charged from the moment the item is bought and you don't clear your balance regularly, interest will add up, making your holiday bargains all the more expensive.

At Barclaycard, for example, if you pay off part of the balance, the money will be taken to cover the first purchases made during that month. If that doesn't cover your cash advances, the interest will be calculated back to the day you took out the money.

If you plan on travelling outside big cities or in developing world countries, do not rely on being able to withdraw money from ATM machines or paying bills by credit card. Once you know where you're going, check the location of cash machines using the ATM locators on the Visa and Mastercard websites. And take some traveller's cheques as a precautionary measure.

If you don't have a credit card, a Visa TravelMoney card from Alliance and Leicester might be for you. Before you go on holiday, these smart cards are issued with a set amount of money - between £100 and £5,000 - which you can access through Visa ATMs. They are deemed safer than normal credit cards because you need a PIN number to get at the cash. You can also order extra cards, at a cost of £2 each, to enable other family members to access the same pool of money, or as a back-up if you lose your card. A charge of 1.5 % of the sum purchased is made for the cards, with a handling charge of £3.50.

webTitle: BT enters online energy market

fields.headline: BT enters online energy market
fields.trailText: BT has become the latest in a long line of companies entering the online energy supply market with the announcement today that Scottish and Southern Energy will be selling gas and electricity through BT's internet portal, BT Openworld.
fields.body:
BT has become the latest in a long line of companies entering the online energy supply market with the announcement today that Scottish and Southern Energy will be selling gas and electricity through BT's internet portal, BT Openworld.

Existing energy companies and new entrants, such as BT and internet start-up Servista, see big money in the online energy market. Signing up and managing your account over the internet helps the companies cut costs which, they say, are passed on to you, the consumer.

The idea of managing utilities online appeals to many, but the companies are finding it harder to convince the public of the relative merits of their particular service. All claim to have the cheapest service on the market: and clearly all can't be right.

In addition, actually calculating your energy consumption and costs is a tricky business, leaving you to wade through different peak and off-peak times, different types of boiler and central heating systems, and different special offers. This makes bill comparisons with other energy suppliers very difficult.

On top of this, customers who have switched energy suppliers since the market was deregulated - in 1998 for gas and last year for electricity - say the switch raised lots of problems. Incorrect billing, double billing and slow connections are among the more common complaints. In retrospect, many say they would rather have carried on paying a little more and not having the hassle.

For customers to think changing is worthwhile, companies may have to offer something extra. Here, the internet start-ups such as Servista and Amerada may be able to steal a lead on their 'bricks and mortar' rivals. The two companies both offer a green alternative.

For example, for as little as £1.50 extra a month, customers can get their electricity from wind power. This is proving a popular service with Servista saying nearly one in five of its customers chooses the green option. In addition, some of the internet start-ups, Servista being one of them, are positioning themselves as a general supplier of household services.

At present, the company can supply your phone and internet connection as well as your energy, sending you just one bill a month for all the services. It hopes this will prove popular with people who want to keep both a closer track on their finances and just have one regular bill for all their household needs.

webTitle: Cyberbranches

fields.headline: Cyberbranches
fields.trailText: Cyberbranches are the internet operations of existing high street banks and building societies. These banks offer online access as an additional service to supplement, rather than replace, branch and telephone access. They are designed for customers whose preferred medium is the internet.
fields.body:
Cyberbranches are the internet operations of existing high street banks and building societies. These banks offer online access as an additional service to supplement, rather than replace, branch and telephone access. They are designed for customers whose preferred medium is the internet.

As such, the products, rates and charges mirror those available through the branch or telephone.

If you are an existing customer and your bank has an internet operation, getting online access should be as simple as registering for the internet service and being issued with an ID and password. It takes the banks around one week to process your registration.

The service offered by the high street banks varies significantly.

Some do not have an internet operation while others limit the service to viewing balance information. However, most let you carry out some banking transactions online.

webTitle: What is a P60?

fields.headline: What is a P60?
fields.trailText: A P60 details your earnings and tax deductions for the year. You won't be able to get a duplicate so keep it in a safe place, because the law requires you to keep a record of your taxable income for at least 22 months after the end of the applicable tax year. Self-employed people must keep records for up to six years after the relevant tax year.

webTitle: Travel money

fields.headline: Travel money
fields.trailText: Getting at your money when travelling is now a lot easier than it used to be. In fact, if you've got a credit card, you may not even realise you are in a different country as your card and PIN number will work in most shops, restaurants, hotels and cash machines. Visa has more than 627,000 ATMs in 120 countries, while Mastercard has 541,000, so it's not hard to see why lots of travellers don't bother with traveller's cheques or cash anymore.
fields.body:
Getting at your money when travelling is now a lot easier than it used to be. In fact, if you've got a credit card, you may not even realise you are in a different country as your card and PIN number will work in most shops, restaurants, hotels and cash machines. Visa has more than 627,000 ATMs in 120 countries, while Mastercard has 541,000, so it's not hard to see why lots of travellers don't bother with traveller's cheques or cash anymore.

That being said, even in the big cities hotels and restaurants do not always accept credit cards - and travellers heading to the more remote corners of the world may find ATMs few and far between. Travellers' cheques can be a better option in these circumstances and can probably be replaced more quickly when lost or stolen than a credit card.

If your holiday destination caters for both credit cards and cheques and you can't decide which to take, compare the commission charged and the exchange rate used on both products and go with the cheapest. In many situations, using credit and debit cards is cheaper than buying traveller's cheques, but check the rates before you commit.

Buying some local currency in advance is advisable, in case the ATMs at your destination airport don't work, but avoid carrying more than your insurance policy covers you for.

Arranging travel money is easy when you're staying in five star hotels as most offer round the clock currency exchange services and take any plastic or travellers cheques you have. Travelling on a tight budget means you need to plan ahead and be better prepared. Money facilities vary dramatically from country to country. In Rio de Janeiro, for example, it is much harder to cash Mastercard travellers' cheques than American Express cheques. And in Cuba, shops, hotels and restaurants ask you to pay in US dollars. You are not allowed to pay in the national currency in some places.

The situation will depend very much on where you go, so read the guidebooks or visit the travel sites before you go.

webTitle: How to choose an investment strategy

fields.headline: How to choose an investment strategy
fields.trailText: Saving for university can be very simple. One of the most tax efficient ways to save long term is to open an Individual Savings Account (Isa). These allow you to save or invest up to £7,000 each year without paying tax on the profits. Many financial advisers recommend using Isas because they are flexible. You can invest as little or as much (up to the government-imposed limit) as you like each year and can cash them when you want without incurring any penalties.
fields.body:
Saving for university can be very simple. One of the most tax efficient ways to save long term is to open an Individual Savings Account (Isa). These allow you to save or invest up to £7,000 each year without paying tax on the profits. Many financial advisers recommend using Isas because they are flexible. You can invest as little or as much (up to the government-imposed limit) as you like each year and can cash them when you want without incurring any penalties.

If you are already making the maximum annual investment in an Isa and do not wish to use the money for education, high interest savings accounts with the major banks and building societies are an alternative. These are less tax efficient and the interest earned will probably be lower, but they are safe and flexible.

Just remember that if you're using a stocks and shares Isa, the value of the fund will go up and down with the stock market. Think about what you will do if there's a stock market crash just before your child starts university and the fund falls to half its intended value. To avoid such a scenario, think about putting the money into a more stable savings vehicle as the time for university approaches.

For more information, read Advice Bank: Choosing an Isa.

Unit trusts and investment trusts which invest in the stock market and can produce good returns are an alternative to Isas, although, again, the risk that the investment may fall in value make them a bad idea if you only have a few years to save. Longer term investing should ensure any short term losses are evened out. On the downside, the fees and charges can seem high and the returns are not tax free. For more information, read Advice Bank: Investing in shares.

Endowment policies can be set up to mature and provide a lump sum payout when the child starts university. Some people set up a string of policies to mature in successive years. However, are you confident you can make the regular payments and will not need to cash in the policy before it matures? Surrender a policy early and you might fail to achieve a good rate of return or find your funds have been eaten into by management charges.

It's also worth remembering that endowments are not very flexible and some financial advisers are wary of them for this reason. If you have to cash in the policy before the maturity date, you will pay a hefty surrender penalty and could even lose money on the investment.

Trusts are another option, but, because they are expensive to set up and manage, are only really suitable to people making large investments on behalf of their children

You could also look into the school composition fee schemes offered by some public schools. Just remember that your children will start school long before they go to university, so the sooner you start saving the better.

webTitle: Lloyds TSB offers £20bn for Abbey National in three-way move

fields.headline: Lloyds TSB offers £20bn for Abbey National in three-way move
fields.standfirst:
Bid hits Bank of Scotland merger

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Bid hits Bank of Scotland merger
fields.body:
A three-way tryst in the banking sector emerged yesterday when Abbey National finally admitted it had received a £20bn bid from Lloyds TSB.

The offer to Abbey's top executives threatens to scupper the month-long merger negotiations between Abbey and Bank of Scotland in a complex scenario reminiscent of last year's tussle over NatWest between BoS and the eventual victor, Royal Bank of Scotland.

City sources raised the possibility of the situation being muddied still further by the intervention by institutions such as Barclays or National Australia Bank.

Lloyds TSB, led by out-going chairman Sir Brian Pitman, decided to approach Abbey at Sunday's emergency board meeting. The City believes the offer by Lloyds will top the "nil premium" merger being considered between Abbey and BoS, involve at least £500m of cost savings and include maintaining the Abbey brand and a large part of Abbey's 750-strong branch network. To bolster its attack, Lloyds has brought in investment bankers Merrill Lynch alongside its standing adviser JP Morgan. Merrill Lynch refused to comment yesterday.

Lloyds TSB, with Sir Brian doubling as chief executive and chairman, has grown rapidly through acquisition over the past six years, first through Cheltenham & Gloucester and TSB and, more recently, with Scottish Widows. Under those deals, Lloyds TSB offered roles to the top management of the institutions it took over.

The City expects Lloyds TSB to make a similar offer to Abbey, run by chief executive Ian Harley.

Abbey's shares rose 1lp to 1,156p, Lloyds fell 23p to 642p while BoS dropped 6p to 690p.

webTitle: Standalone banks

fields.headline: Standalone banks
fields.trailText: Standalone banks operate almost exclusively on the internet. Accounts are opened and transactions are conducted online.
fields.body:
Standalone banks operate almost exclusively on the internet. Accounts are opened and transactions are conducted online.

Non-internet communication with the banks is kept to a minimum. Telephone support is provided, but if you ask for information which is available on the internet you are likely to be charged - quite a lot in some cases.

Items such as debit cards, cheque books and paying in slips are ordered online and sent to you by land mail.

Because these banks have dramatically reduced their overheads by operating online, their interest rates are often better than those offered by the high street banks and they boast low or non-existent charges.

The service offered by these banks varies. Some offer a whole range of banking services, from current accounts to savings accounts to loans. Others have a more limited product range.

Egg, Smile, Cahoot, Intelligent Finance and First-E all fall into the standalone category.

fields.trailText: A mortgage currrent account is one of the variations on the "connected account" theme.
fields.body:
A mortgage currrent account is one of the variations on the "connected account" theme.

To date, Virgin is one of the only UK companies to offer these accounts, which work by subtracting your salary from your outstanding mortgage debt. For example: you take out a mortgage for £50,000 to buy a house. Every month your salary is paid into your mortgage current account, reducing the amount you owe and, therefore, the amount of your monthly repayments.

Any savings, windfall shares, inherited money, or Christmas bonuses can also be paid into the account, further reducing the amount owed. All the mortgage lender will ask is that you pay back the money by a pre-agreed date.

As long as you do this, you can pay in and take money out of the account as and when you wish. As such, these accounts are good if you want to take payment holidays, over-pay from time to time, or borrow from your mortgage to cover unforeseen circumstances.

webTitle: How does my employer know how much tax to deduct?

fields.headline: How does my employer know how much tax to deduct?
fields.trailText: Your tax code tells your employer how much you have earned in the current year (if anything) and how much tax (if any) you have paid so far in the current tax year. This information enables them to calculate the correct amount of tax due from your next pay packet. This information only relates to the current tax year that runs from 6th April to 5th April the following year.
fields.body:
Your tax code tells your employer how much you have earned in the current year (if anything) and how much tax (if any) you have paid so far in the current tax year. This information enables them to calculate the correct amount of tax due from your next pay packet. This information only relates to the current tax year that runs from 6th April to 5th April the following year.

If you have already worked, your previous employer should have given you a P45 when you left. If you haven¹t worked before, ask your employer for a P46. In due course you'll receive a form from the tax office asking for details of your income and employment history. Complete this form and return it promptly - if you don¹t, you may end up paying more tax than necessary. It will help the tax office if you ensure your employer¹s tax reference number appears on the form. When they receive your completed form the tax office will issue you with a tax code, a copy of which will be automatically sent to your employer.

webTitle: How much is income tax?

fields.headline: How much is income tax?
fields.trailText: Income tax is a progressive tax - in other words, the rate rises with the level of income. The personal allowance is tax-free. After that three rates of income tax are employed:
fields.body:
Income tax is a progressive tax - in other words, the rate rises with the level of income. The personal allowance is tax-free. After that three rates of income tax are employed:

1 Lower Rate (currently 10%) - payable on the first £1,520 of taxable income over the personal allowance. 2 Basic Rate (currently 22%) - payable on the next £26,880 of taxable income. 3 Higher Rate (currently 40%) - payable on all remaining taxable income

Therefore, a person earning £40,000 per year of taxable income would pay no tax on the first £4,385, 10% on the next £1,520 (= £152), 22% on the next £26,880 (= £5,913.60) and 40% on the remaining £7,215 (= £2,886), making atotal of £8,951.60 in income tax.

webTitle: How can I pay less income tax?

fields.headline: How can I pay less income tax?
fields.trailText: Every year more than £6.8bn is wasted in tax. There are many ways you could be paying the Inland Revenue more than you need to. And with the introduction of Self Assessment, you could be paying even more. Simple planning could cut your tax bill. But how? And where do you start?
fields.body:
Every year more than £6.8bn is wasted in tax. There are many ways you could be paying the Inland Revenue more than you need to. And with the introduction of Self Assessment, you could be paying even more. Simple planning could cut your tax bill. But how? And where do you start?

Begin by checking your tax code. The Inland Revenue has been known to make mistakes and around one in 10 tax codes are incorrect, mostly because the Revenue has been given the wrong information. Take a closer look at your tax coding notice to ensure that it includes your personal allowances and any additional allowances you might be entitled to.

The code is a shortened method of defining your total tax-free pay - usually the total of all your allowances, except that the last figure is omitted. For example, a code of 512H means that you start paying tax after you have earned £5,120 and that you are married or entitled to additional personal allowances. In most cases, the higher your code, the lower your tax bill.

The letter shown after your code defines your status. L, for example, means basic personal allowance entitlement, H means personal allowance plus married couple's allowance or additional personal allowance at basic rate, while D means you are taxed at the higher rate. The letters OT mean that no allowances have been given - probably because you haven't sent in a tax return for a long time or your tax affairs are very complicated. Sometimes your taxable benefits will exceed your allowances, an example being if you are taxed on a company car or owe back tax. In these cases, a K code is used so that your employer can recoup this tax on behalf of the Revenue.

You need to check the figures on your notice of tax code very carefully. If the estimates are excessive, write to your tax office requesting a code change. And if your code is incorrect, it is more than likely that your previous year's code was wrong too.

Make the best use of your tax-free personal allowances. This is particularly relevant if you are married and you and your spouse pay different rates of tax. If, for example one of you is a top-rate taxpayer and the other a basic rate or non-taxpayer, you can cut your tax liability in half by transferring income-yielding assets like building society deposits or shares to the lower earner.

Rental income on property can also be split between you and your spouse in proportions that minimise tax liability, but the Inland Revenue must be informed in a notice of "declaration of beneficial interest in joint property and income" or via form IR17 if you don't fancy getting your tongue around that lot.

There are pitfalls to all this money juggling. If you change the name on a building society account you could forfeit the right to future windfall bonuses from demutualising societies. And of course, if your spouse runs off with the money all the tax efficiency in the world won¹t get it back.

We might enjoy badmouthing Hector the taxman, but to be fair to the guy he does offer taxpayers several other allowances which sometimes get overlooked. For example, if you have kids, are you ensuring that your children's tax-free personal allowances are being used to the full? Are they needlessly paying tax on bank and building society deposits because you've forgotten to fill in tax form R85?

And at work, are there any expenses you could set against tax such as training, fees to professional bodies or travelling costs? Are your donations to charities benefiting from tax relief via the Gift Aid scheme or deeds of covenant?

Make the most of your pension. It's common knowledge that pensions are the most tax efficient investments around, but are you making the most of yours?

If you are in a company scheme you can salt away up to 15% of your earnings from your job into your pension and get tax relief at your highest rate. If your employer's scheme is non-contributory, you can make up the shortfall by making additional voluntary contributions (AVCs) to your company scheme or free-standing additional voluntary contributions (FSAVCs) to a personal free-standing AVC scheme of your choice.

If you have a personal pension instead, the taxman will also limit the amount of pension contributions you can make which will qualify for tax relief. These limits vary according to your age and the type of personal plan you have, but they are set as a percentage of your net relevant earnings. For the self-employed this basically means your profits before tax. If you are under the age of 35, for example, the most you can pay into a personal pension in any one tax year is 17.5% of net relevant earnings.

However, there are a couple of rules which permit you to make contributions which come to more than your particular limit for a particular tax year. Under carry-back provisions, you can make a contribution in one tax year, but have it treated as if it had been paid in the previous year. Of course, you have to have enough unused tax relief from the previous year, but if you had no net relevant earnings in the previous year, you can even carry the contribution back two years.

Carrying back contributions can be particularly useful if you are self-employed, because the delay in making pension contributions for a particular year gives you time to make up your accounts for that year and assess your tax position.

The other way to contribute more into your personal pension than the current year limits allow is to carry forward - the rules allow you to do this if you have any unused tax-relief limit from the last six years. You can carry forward the unused relief and use it now.

webTitle: Review: London Sinfonietta

fields.headline: London Sinfonietta
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Even those who programmed this concert had to admit that an evening of works by John Cage was perhaps out of place in a series devoted to Aaron Copland. The two composers may have shared a nationality and, roughly speaking, a lifetime but, in most ways, there the similarities end. However, they did possess a comparable clarity of vision, even though the results of their work were startlingly different.

Arch-experimentalist Cage is a fascinating figure among the greats of the 20th century, not least because of his contribution to debates surrounding the aesthetics and the ownership of musical composition.

In Ten, written in 1991, the year before Cage's death, each player is guided not by a conductor but by a stopwatch. The notes are written with no fixed duration, but are set within "time brackets", and must all be played once, in order, before that time is out. The volume and length of each note is up to the individual player. To what extent, then, can such a work be said to be Cage's own composition? And, if there is no central force or figure deciding where each note or noise should go, can the performance really be defined as music? It has to be said, unfortunately, that it can be more interesting to ponder the idea behind some of Cage's works than to listen to them.

The First Construction (in Metal) had opened the concert with a bang, employing a whole array of percussion instruments, including five thunder sheets. But even the committed playing of the Sinfonietta (and the sight of the percussionist solemnly using a Nescafé tin as a makeshift instrument) couldn't quite make Ten come alive.

Seated scattered around the stage, the 10 musicians did create atmospheric layers of sound that seemed to unfold and then merge again. But, while a sense of tension was woven in the opening minutes from the idea that nobody in the hall knew exactly what sounds the next few seconds might bring, it proved impossible to sustain that feeling for the work's half-hour duration.

The second half of the programme was devoted to the 16 Dances, written 40 years earlier. Cage's trademark "chance operations" came into play here - he selected his musical phrases from 64 examples written on a chessboard-like chart, moving from one to the next as though playing a game. Yet the way this raw material is put together is all down to Cage's artistry - and, as was proved in this convincing reading under conductor Paul Zukofsky, the work's sense of direction is all the stronger for it.

webTitle: Review: Belonging

fields.headline: Belonging
fields.standfirst:
The Door at Birmingham Rep
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
The Door at Birmingham Rep
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Plays about the Irish experience of emigration and exile have become so common that they are almost a sub-genre in Irish playwriting studies. But Kaite O'Reilly's play is a rarity in that it comes at the question from a different perspective and from the other side of the Irish Sea.

Or more precisely Birmingham. Here, more than 20 years ago, came young Fergal and his bride Maura, part of the great haemorrhage of Irish emigration that built the city and the roads after the war. As one of the characters says: "Spaghetti Junction - that's a great Irish work. Forget fucking Ulysses."

Then came the Birmingham pub bombings, and to be Irish was to be reviled and spat at in the street. Maura kept her head down and spent pounds on elocution lessons to ensure her children Seaneen and Aine grew up sounding as if they came from nowhere.

But now Aine has reinvented herself as a professional Irishwoman, working as an oral historian and colonising the memories of Irish emigrants, Seaneen doesn't give a damn about Ireland and thinks of himself as a European, and Fergal is dying. Maura decides that it is time to go back home to the farm where she was born. But first she wants to walk through the streets of Birmingham with her head held high on the St Patrick's Day parade.

This is a little play, but a really lovely one. It deals in cliches but often makes them seem new-minted. You never mind for a moment that the characters have paint-by-numbers attitudes carefully designed to create maximum dramatic conflict, that the plotting is obvious from a mile off, or even that there is a classic stage Irishman. The pleasure of O'Reilly's play is in the way she revels in these cliches, celebrates them and subverts them. It is also in the easy, generous flow of the writing, with its mixture of wit and singing lyricism.

O'Reilly loves these people and sends them up rotten at the same time, just as she sends up the audience's preconceptions and prejudices about what it means to be Irish and explores whether it is better to travel light or take the past with you wherever you go.

Rachel Blue's design, dominated by a grainy torn photo of the Irish landscape, cleverly unites a play that takes place in the real world and in the mind, in individual experience and the collective unconscious, both now and then. Anthony Clark's nifty production does well to disguise some of the play's construction fault lines. Great performances, too, particularly from Iain McKee as the pragmatic Seaneen, who doesn't understand why you should get more upset about the potato famine than Rwanda or Kosovo, and Eileen Pollock as Maura, whose face turns to scarred granite when she realises that there is no home left to go back to.

 Until December 16. Box office: 012-1236 4455.
